HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Construction Costs;
For Some, a Lucky Time to Be Building

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
IT may sound implausible -- with lenders balking, tenants vanishing, bankruptcies increasing and foreclosures looming -- but the construction climate in New York City hasn't been this good in years.
Building costs have dropped to where they were in the mid-80's, construction executives say. Steel is cheaper. And while labor is not cheaper on the face of it, productivity has improved. Savings might amount to $10 or $20 or $30 a square foot, which has multimillion-dollar implications, given the scale on which New York builds. 
 "The cost for a nominally normal building -- one that isn't so special that it has no competition -- might be as much as 20 percent less than would have been planned three years ago," said John L. Tishman, chairman of the Tishman Construction Corporation of Manhattan. "That's a staggering difference."
Of course, that does not necessarily mean that costs in New York are reasonable, only that they are somewhat less astronomical. "The reductions have come off an artificially high level of costs," Mr. Tishman said, "because, for a period, there was too much work for the competitive process to control pricing as it should."
It also does not mean that general contractors and construction managers are besieged by clients eager to build while the costs are down. "It's like a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow," said Peter M. Lehrer, co-chairman of Lehrer McGovern Bovis, based in Manhattan. With speculative development all but frozen, his organization finds its work in special-purpose structures, such as a new office building for Capital Cities/ ABC at Columbus Avenue and 66th Street.
The cost of new construction for the 10-story ABC building, which will be used chiefly by the network's news division, was justified in contrast to the expense of leasing space. What made the budget attractive was that it factored in some savings that were "presumably due to market conditions," said Julie Hoover, a vice president at Capital Cities/ABC.
The KG A&A Corporation, owner of the Americas Tower office building, which is still under construction, has found that the depressed market has led to "fairly good prices" from subcontractors, said David Leslie, general manager for legal affairs and public relations. Work halted for 14 months at the tower, on the Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets, while the original development partners battled one another in court. Building resumed early this year.
Other savings have been reported.
Four years ago, Morse Diesel International started building a hospital in the Bronx. Now, it is about to embark on another major hospital job, this one in Brooklyn. "What we're finding is that we can build it for the same price or slightly less," said Daniel DeLosa, senior vice president in charge of estimating at Morse Diesel. He did not name the institutions but said that the cost for both was in the low $200-a-square-foot area. "The public sector is actually blessed," said Robert Fee, vice president and general manager of the New York territory for the Turner Construction Company, whose projects include three public schools in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn. He estimated that School Construction Authority projects cost one-third less today than two years ago, when the authority began building.
Meanwhile, Lehrer McGovern Bovis is finishing the Concerto, at Amsterdam Avenue and 60th Street, the fourth apartment tower it has built for the developer Daniel Brodsky, all of which were relatively similar from a construction standpoint, Mr. Lehrer said.
THE Concerto, at less than $100 a square foot, was cheaper than either 45 West 67th Street or 124 West 60th Street (known as South Park Tower), which were built in the mid-80's, Mr. Lehrer said. "And the quality of the building is as good as anything we did in the $125-a-square-foot cost range three or four years ago," he said.
In commercial construction, Mr. Lehrer estimated that the cost of building a core and shell was now in the range of $80 to $130 a square foot, which is at least 10 to 15 percent less than it was three or four years ago.
A critical reason for the decline in office construction costs is that steel is cheaper. Most construction-related steel products have dropped 10 to 20 percent in price from this time last year, said John E. Jacobson, managing director of AUS Consultants of West Conshohocken, Pa., which specializes in steel. He cited the price for wide-flange beams, which are used in commercial construction. They currently run $335 a ton, down from $360 a year ago.
"Steel has dropped at the plant and there are an awful lot of major steel fabricators who are very hungry for work," said Mr. DeLosa. "We're buying steel jobs for less than in the past few years."
Mr. Fee said he believed the biggest decline in the price of steel came in the cost of erecting it. Because there were not many steel erector concerns in New York City, he said, their work had commanded a premium. Now, he said, steel contractors have become more competitive, spurred not only by their efforts to obtain what little work there is from local rivals but also by the arrival on the scene of out-of-town concerns.
All told, it currently costs about $1,500 to $1,600 a ton for steel, erected in place, in a New York City job, Mr. Fee said. That is down from about $1,800 to $1,900 a ton at the height of the 1980's building boom, he said.
An office building might use about 18 pounds of steel per square foot of space. A 30-story tower with 20,000-square-foot floors -- 600,000 square feet in all -- would need 10.8 million pounds, or 5,400 tons, of steel. Therefore, the total cost of steel for this hypothetical tower, which might have been as high as $10 million a few years ago, might now be more in the neighborhood of $8 million.
Among the material-intensive trades, as opposed to those where the major cost is labor itself, steel may be more the exception than the rule.
Mr. Tishman noted that, contrary to the overall rule of decreasing prices were "some of the major trades on major projects where the competition is not sufficient to reflect the savings that should be available." He mentioned subcontractors who install elevators in high-rise buildings and those who specialize in stonework facades. To that list Mr. Lehrer added electrical, heating, air-conditioning and glazing subcontractors.
On the other hand, Mr. Lehrer said, "trades that are highly dependent on labor, such as masonry, foundations, concrete -- these are where we've seen reductions in costs."
"The labor rates themselves seem to have leveled off to a minimal escalation, trade by trade," Mr. Tishman said. "When there's less work, the productivity of labor is enhanced because of the competition among people to keep their jobs. So there is a slackening off of the ultimate labor costs."
"Subcontractors are getting the advantage of picking the best workers," Mr. Lehrer said. "We're seeing better quality and better performance in terms of time because there's a higher percentage of competent mechanics working and a desire on their part to do a good job and stay employed."
Construction executives are unanimous in describing the peril posed by subcontractors who bid too low for their own good.
"Our labor agreements rise 6 percent a year," Mr. Fee said. "Material costs are certainly not creeping up anywhere near that amount. What you're seeing is a squeeze on the margins. People are starting to take jobs for cash flow, saying, 'I won't make any money but maybe I can pay my overhead, keep my business going for a year or so.' That becomes dangerous if they have no room for error. You can eventually drive prices so low that people can go bankrupt on jobs."
"We're watching very carefully where subcontractors are reaching too far," Mr. Tishman said. "The danger is that a downtrend can catch them when it starts going up again" -- that is, if they have overestimated productivity or underestimated material costs.
"I deal with clients who are pressured by contractors, trade contractors, subcontractors to be considered who offer very tempting opportunities which we want to evaluate in the context of their ability to produce," Mr. Tishman said. "The ripple effect of one contractor failing to perform is tremendous."
Mr. Lehrer, too, said that one single subcontractor can disastrously upset the mosaic of a construction project. Lehrer McGovern Bovis has not yet had a major subcontractor go under, he said, although one project was plagued by a marble contractor who was unable to perform.
Taking a wider view of the future, there is less unanimity among the construction executives -- and much less certainty.
Mr. Lehrer foresees special-use projects like the ABC building and the Chase Financial Services Center at the Metrotech complex in downtown Brooklyn.
Mr. Fee sees the traditional general contractors crowding into the field of interiors, as there will always be a demand for new office installations.
Institutional and governmental work clearly has assumed center stage. Tishman, for example, is the construction manager of the Postal Service's 2 million-square-foot General Mail Facility, on Ninth Avenue, between 28th and 29th Streets, and the 1 million-square-foot One Foley Square Federal Office Building on Broadway, between Duane and Reade Streets.
MORSE DIESEL is the construction manager of a 204,000-square-foot research building for the Rockefeller University, over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, at 64th Street, and a 509,000-square-foot office research building for the New York University Medical Center, at First Avenue and 32d Street.
The president of the New York Building Congress, Louis J. Coletti, sees hope for the construction industry in the renovation of existing buildings as well as continued spending on public projects, which can take advantage of the best prices in the past decade.
But Mr. Fee sees a limit to that field. "I'm just afraid that we've all crowded into the public sector, working for the School Construction Authority, Health and Hospitals Corporation, Dormitory Authority," he said. "But if you look to the 70's, they eventually had financial problems and that faucet was shut down."
"I can't conceive that the recession will go further and affect our industry," Mr. Tishman said. "If it goes further down, there will be no construction. So I have to predict that costs have leveled off and will begin to rise again." However, he added, "I don't expect costs to rise nearly as fast as they fell, even with a healthy economy, because there won't be so many projects starting."
In any case, no one is holding a "Prices-Will-Never-Be-This-Low-Again" sale. And until the financing picture grows brighter, it does not seem likely that there would be many buyers anyway. As Mr. Lehrer noted: "We have not yet had someone say, 'It's a great time to build because construction costs are down.' "

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: For First-Time Buyers;
Sonny Mae Workshops

 BODY:
The slump in residential prices throughout the region has given people in the market for housing more leverage than they have had in years. But buying a home can be a daunting experience for newcomers to the scene.
The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which offers low-interest loans to qualified first-time buyers, tries to demystify the home-buying process in the workshops it holds frequently throughout the state. The September schedule includes workshops in Hempstead, L.I., on the 17th; Saugerties, in Ulster County, on the 23d; Yonkers on the 24th and Brooklyn on the 25th. 
 Besides representatives of the agency, known as Sonny Mae, participants will include loan officers from the banks that offer Sonney Mae loans; real estate brokers, lawyers and housing engineers.Prospective home buyers can expect assistance on such matters as figuring out what is affordable and sorting out the various types of mortgages available and the ongoing costs of maintaining a home.
The Brooklyn workshop will begin at 6 P.M. in the Borough Hall Courtroom at 209 Joralemon Street. All workshops are free but registration is advisable. Information on workshops outside New York City is available by calling the agency at (212) 340-4358 or (800) 382-HOME.

HEADLINE: Speeders Beware: New Device Looms

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
IN an intensified effort to discourage speeders, state transportation officials are experimenting with computer-enhanced radar photography that could make conventional radar detectors obsolete.
The new computerized radar system, which is being tested by the New Jersey State Police in several locations, allows the authorities not only to record the speed of a vehicle, but also to make a photograph that could later be used in court. The radar, known as photo-radar, has been hailed by law-enforcement officials as an effective and economical way to curtail speeding. 
 But critics of the new radar system have assailed it as an invasion of motorists' privacy. They have also complained that tickets issued on the basis of photographs made by the machine could end up creating more court cases than the legal system can handle.
"If I'm speeding because my wife is going into labor, or I'm speeding because I'm drunk as a skunk, that distinction can't be made by a machine," said Edward Martone, executive director of the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. Mr. Martone said that ticketing the owner on the basis of a photograph could place the burden of proving guilt or innocence on the vehicle's owner, rather than the authorities.
State highway officials began experimenting with the photo-radar system in an effort to reduce the number of speeding motorists. Under Federal highway guildelines, the Government can strip a state of part of its highway funds if more than 50 percent of the drivers in that state exceed the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit.
Last year, New Jersey came perilously close to losing $30 million in highway funds, when 46 percent of its motorists exceeded the speed limit, said James A. Arena, director of the State Division of Highway Traffic Safety.
"Our objective is simply to gain compliance with the law, have safer roadways and reduce the number of drivers exceeding the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit," Mr. Arena said, adding that the radar system would not be used to monitor drivers 24 hours a day.
The photo-radar unit that the state uses, Mr. Arena said, operates much like a conventional radar, with both the conventional and the photo-radar unit broadcasting a signal that reflects off a vehicle back to a transmitter that computes the vehicle's speed.
The difference, he said, lies in the narrow field of the beam the photo-radar unit uses, as well as the unit's built-in computer, which allows it to make a photograph of a vehicle after the vehicle's speed has been determined. The unit superimposes the vehicle's speed and the date and time of the incident on the photograph.
Because the signal from the photo-radar system is sent out over a narrower field than a conventional radar, Mr. Arena added, it is hard for a driver's radar detector to pick up the unit's signal. In most cases, Mr. Arena said, such detectors do not pick up the radar field until the driver is in it or has passed it. At the same time, he said, the photo-radar unit the state uses can monitor speeds in both directions simultaneously.
"The radar band is four inches wide and an inch high and we can target it right across the road," he said. "By the time your radar detector picks it up, it's already too late."
For now, Mr. Arena said, officials plan to send warning letters and not summonses to people caught speeding by the photo-radar. He declined to say when the state would begin issuing summonses to violators.
Two benefits from the new system, Mr. Arena said, are the amount of time it saves law-enforcement officials and its safety. A typical traffic stop by an officer can take 15 or 20 minutes and can create an unsafe condition for the officer, the speeder and other motorists.
With the photo-radar system, a summons can be issued without the officer's stopping the violator. And the number of summonses that can be issued in a relatively short time is substantial.
During a demonstration by the manufacturer, the Gatso Corporation of the Netherlands, the "device was literally clicking off, clocking, documenting and photographing three speeders per second," Mr. Arena said.
The photo-radar system, which costs $65,000, can clock and photograph vehicles either approaching or going away from the unit and can also photograph vehicles in the dark, using a high-speed, high-intensity flash, Mr. Arena said. The flash would barely be perceptible to motorists, he said.
Mr. Arena said the state would also install electronic message boards that contain radar units to calculate and display the speed of oncoming motorists to alert them that they are either approaching or have just passed through a photo-radar site.
But Steven Carrellas, president of the 2,000-member New Jersey chapter of the National Motorist Association, said that the new technology was a "waste of money" and that using a machine to mass-issue speeding tickets was not going to change the way people drive.
"They wouldn't have the need to use more sophisticated speed-enforcement devices if they just set speed limits at the appropriate levels," Mr. Carrellas said, adding that a 65 m.p.h. speed limit is more realistic because highway traffic often flows 5 to 10 miles above the limit.
"If you're on a road and the speed of the road is 5 to 10 miles per hour higher than the speed limit, then you're a more dangerous driver if you're not keeping up with the traffic," he said.
 
Extenuating Circumstances
 In addition, he said, when speeding tickets are just "fired off" by a computer, extenuating circumstances like emergencies are not taken into consideration.
"If you don't have the cop sitting there, watching what's going on and making judgment calls, then you're not going to be doing your best job for highway safety," he said.
Mr. Martone, of the American Civil Liberties Union, agreed. "If you're not stopping the car at the scene, then there's a real good chance that you're sending the ticket by mail to somebody who wasn't even in the vehicle," he said.
Such a problem, he said, would be exacerbated in the case of rental cars and company cars that are used by many different people. "I can see Mr. Hertz or Mr. Avis spending a lot of time in court denying that it's them behind the wheel," Mr. Martone said.
Officials acknowledge that some tickets might be issued to owners of vehicles who were not driving at the time of the violations. But for those that are issued to the proper people, identification should not be a problem. Officials say that computer enhancement of the photograph -- commonly referred to as computer imaging -- will make it possible to identify the driver accurately.
"Even if you have a blurry photograph," Mr. Arena said, "the imaging equipment will bring out the details clearly."
 
In Use in Other Places
 The overall benefits of photo-radar, he said, have been well documented in other cities that are already using the technology. Paradise Valley, Ariz., for example, has used the photo-radar technology since 1987.
Onno Prinsze, support services division commander of the Paradise Valley Police Department, said the number of traffic accidents there had been cut nearly in half since the town started using photo-radar.
"We like to say we have modified driver behavior," he said. Using photo-radar, he said, the 30-person Police Department issues nearly 10,000 tickets a year in the 12,500-resident municipality, which is between Scottsdale and Phoenix.
"It's not the money we're after," Mr. Prinsze said. "We just want to modify the behavior of the driver."
That sentiment was echoed by New Jersey officials. "No one wants to make enemies," Mr. Arena said. "But there is really a need to have people comply with the law. We intend to send out warnings first. But we don't know if a warning letter will be sufficient. If it is, then everybody's happy."
Critics say, however, that once officials discover they can issue literally thousands of tickets almost automatically, then tickets instead of warnings are sure to follow.
"It would be an absolute windfall," said Thomas A. DeClemente, a Lyndhurst lawyer. "A city could probably repay one machine's cost in two months."
 
Deluge of Complaints Feared
 Pervasive use of photo-radar, Mr. DeClemente said, would raise other legal and logistical problems. "The first thing that comes to mind is that there could be a deluge of complaints that could decimate the municipal court system," he said.
In addition, he said, a court hearing based upon a photo-radar summons is analagous to "trial by machine" where it is virtually impossible to attack the fallibility of a mechanicl device. And photo-radar, he said, is at the very least an invasion of privacy.
"You're getting photographed by a hidden camera without your knowing it," he said. "Big Brother is watching you now for real."
Mr. Arena said the Big Brother metaphor was inappropriate. The use of photo-radar and of the message boards is simply a supplement to traditional police work, he said.
"We don't have to run this thing 24 hours a day and generate 80,000 photographs," he said. "If people know photo-radar is in use -- if they see a flash or their friend gets a warning -- and people slow down because of that, then we've acheived our objective.
"It's almost like playing football," Mr. Arena said. "You have to mix up your plays all the time."

HEADLINE: Now Is the Time to Invest in the Soviets

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Even before the colossal events of recent days -- the Soviet coup, the collapse of Communist rule, the splintering away of the republics -- everything seemed to be going wrong for Dresser Industries' plans to rebuild an aging drill-bit factory in southern Russia.
The central government in Moscow was feuding with the Russian republic over who was empowered to award the huge contract to the Dallas-based producer of oilfield equipment. One of the ministries Dresser was dealing with was almost dissolved. And Dresser's Soviet partners, ministries responsible for chemicals and heavy machinery, were struggling to find the hard currency to finance the project. 
 Although last week's kaleidoscopic twists and turns leave many daunting uncertainties about the Soviet Union's future, Dresser's chairman, John J. Murphy, is confident that August's rush of events will help end the logjam on Dresser's project and the stalled projects of dozens of other Western companies.
"Within the Russian republic I think things will accelerate very quickly, and that should also be true for the Ukraine," said Mr. Murphy. "The people who were blocking reform are gone."
Western capitalists -- those villains the Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev once vowed to bury -- certainly have cause to celebrate their ideological victory. But for companies negotiating Soviet joint ventures, questions remain about how the central government and republics will divvy up power, whether territorial disputes might erupt between republics and what will happen to the near-worthless ruble.
Still, Westerners are reassured by two developments: Not since 1917 have the Soviet Union and its republics been so committed to building a market economy, and not since that time has the country been so interested in attracting foreign capital, technology and management skills to help modernize outmoded factories, fill empty stores and feed the pent-up consumer demand that is palpably evident in Moscow's open markets. So hungry are the Soviets for Western capital, in fact, that they have even offered to sell American investors a stake in their vaunted space program.
"The coup's failure has galvanized a rapidly growing desire to get on with the conversion to a market economy," said Ronald Freeman, first vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the new London-based bank formed to help Eastern Europe. "Everyone, at every level of government, seems to be pointing in that direction."
Many companies have shunned investing in the Soviet Union because they had little enthusiasm for its bureaucratic Socialism. And executives were reluctant to take the plunge, despite the reforms of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, because of talk of a possible hard-line coup that might restore Stalinism.
 
A Question of Timing
 With the coup now defeated, there is less reason to delay. "If you wait until you have an ideal investment environment, with clear laws and rules of the game, you're talking five or 10 years," said Jeffrey Hertzfeld, a Paris-based American lawyer who works with Western investors in the Soviet Union. "But if you wait five years, you might find that a lot of the most attractive partners have already made commitments to other companies."
Western executives making their first visits to Moscow may be shocked by the difficulties of living and doing business there. The telecommunications system is laughable; apartments and office space are hard to get and prohibitively priced. With the nation's political framework changing by the minute, it is harder than ever to know which branch of government owns what and which level one must address to get joint ventures approved.
For instance, the American Trade Consortium, a group that includes RJR Nabisco, Johnson & Johnson and Archer Daniels Midland, has worked closely with the central government on forming joint ventures. But with the Kremlin's power now disintegrating, the consortium may have to negotiate its deals all over again with individual republics.
"It might be difficult today or this week to do things, so you have to let the dust settle a little bit," said James H. Giffen, president of the consortium. "Provided certain things happen, there will be substantial opportunities for Western investors." For Mr. Giffen, those "things" include having at least Russia and a few other republics hang together in a coalition, naming qualified people to replace the ousted Communists, and replacing the "endless debate" about economic reform with "specific action."
What will also give Western investors a bumpy ride is the dire state of the Soviet economy. In addition to the worthless ruble, industrial output is expected to plunge 30 percent this year because of the turmoil and inflation threatens to spiral out of control.
The Soviet Union's new rush toward capitalism, after years of President Gorbachev's waffling, will have huge ramifications for the world's economy. It will open up a consumer market of 280 million people, equal to the United States and Canada combined. That's a lot of teeth, one Colgate-Palmolive executive said, in explaining his company's plans to open a toothpaste factory in Kiev.
Although the Soviet Union is often described as a third-world country, investors may be enticed by its highly educated labor force and skilled engineers, especially in its military industries. "There aren't many third-world countries that produce world chess champions or send rockets into space," said Mr. Hertzfeld.
Despite its people's shabby living standards, the Soviet Union is one of the world's most bountiful nations. It is rich in oil, gas and minerals. Many Soviet officials want Western investors to help tap those natural resources, which will provide vital hard currency needed to modernize factories and import consumer goods.
There should be little surprise then that oil titans like Chevron, Texaco and British Petroleum are seeking to negotiate joint ventures to help the Soviets revive their oil industry. Because of aging equipment and poor management, Soviet daily oil output has dropped 20 percent since 1988, but still remains the largest in the world.
"If you simply look at what needs to be done to increase production from known oil reservoirs, that is probably the greatest single opportunity in the world for our industry," said Dresser's chairman, Mr. Murphy. "If you look at new exploration opportunities, where there are known geologic structures that are promising for drilling, you double or triple that opportunity."
 
Just What Is Europe?
 With Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania breaking away, and Byelorussia, Georgia and the Ukraine declaring their independence, the whole concept or definition of Europe is changing. The notion of a single European market or economic space is also rapidly evolving. For more than a year, there has been talk that Austria and Sweden might soon join the 12-nation European Community, and that Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary might eventually follow. But in recent days discussion has turned to whether the Baltic republics, the Ukraine and Byelorussia might someday become members as well.
"In the year 2,000 and something, the Community may have somewhere between two or three times the present number of members," said Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute of Foreign Relations.
The Soviet situation has also spurred a lively debate within the Group of Seven industrialized nations about whether to provide massive economic aid to revive the Soviet economy. Many European officials argue that aid similar to a Marshall Plan could buoy the Soviet economy, which would in turn spur the world economy. But many American and Japanese officials still maintain that until market reforms are in place, giving massive aid would be like pouring money down a sinkhole.
While Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin has for months sought to adopt market reforms, the central government undermined those plans. With the Kremlin's power evaporating and hard-liners like the coup leaders in jail or out of office, Mr. Yeltsin can now move swiftly.
"The people we have been dealing with in the Russian Federation -- at the city council level and the republic level -- are already in progressive mode and want to do business in a different way," said John A. Norlander, president of the Radisson Hotel Corporation, which runs a 430-room joint-venture Moscow hotel.
 
Market Economies
 Of the 15 Soviet republics, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are expected to adopt market economies first. These Baltic republics, annexed by Moscow in 1940, have fresher memories of capitalism than the rest of the Soviet Union. Though tiny, they are already getting more than their share of Western investment because of their close ties to Scandinavia and long-time disdain for Communism.
Many executives say the best investment opportunities will be in republics with oil, gas and other natural resources, meaning Russia, Kazakhstan and the Ukraine. "As the Soviet Union falls apart, Western investors will look first to those republics that have the best likelihood to generate hard-currency earnings," said Karl von der Heyden, chief financial officer of RJR Nabisco, which is negotiating to produce cigarettes and cookies in Russia and Kazakhstan.
Republics with those resources will have more muscle to set up joint ventures as well as that magical stuff -- hard currency -- that Western companies crave for repatriating profits.
Consumer goods executives say the best place to invest may be the republics with the most people and disposable income. That means the Russian Federation, which has 150 million people, and the Ukraine, with 52 million. Together, they have 70 percent of the nation's population. Reacting to the Ukraine's declaration of independence, Coca-Cola announced plans last Thursday to open an office in Kiev, that republic's capital.
"The Ukraine is the equal of France in population," said Francois Archambault, director of investor relations for L'Oreal, the French cosmetics giant, which has a factory nearMoscow. "It's not a place that you should ignore."
One effect of the republics' struggle to grab power from the center is that businesses setting up shop in the area might have to deal with one less level of bureaucracy. "It should make things easier because you might eliminate a lot of bureaucracy at the central government level," said Nabisco's Mr. von der Heyden.
That should come as a relief for Alcatel, the Paris-based telecommunications giant, which is having problems opening a factory in Leningrad to make digital switching equipment. The huge project would produce about $3.5 billion in equipment over 20 years.
Alcatel officials say a jurisdictional free-for-all among Soviet officials has snagged progress. The Soviet Ministry of Industry, which built the factory; the Soviet Army, which once operated it, and the City of Leningrad, which owns the land, are all claiming ownership. To finalize the joint venture, Alcatel has had to deal with the Soviet ministries of telecommunications and machinery, the Russian republic's ministries of telecommunications and machinery, and several City of Leningrad departments.
"The further you decentralize things, the easier it should be to deal," said John J. Goossens, chairman of Alcatel Bell of Belgium, which is running the project. "If from now on we have to go through just the Russian Federation, with whom we have had very easy dealings, it will definitely make things easier."
Despite the myriad hurdles to set up shop, many companies that have done so, including Polaroid, L'Oreal and Tambrands, say their factories are operating fairly smoothly.
In March 1989, Tambrands, the White Plains-based maker of feminine hygiene supplies, opened a 300-worker factory in Kiev producing 300 million tampons a year. Its partner, the Ukrainian Ministry of Health, contributed the land and building; Tambrands put up $10 million.
 
The Demand Is There
 "In terms of setting up a factory, hiring workers and getting production up to standards, the operation has gone very well," said Paul Konney, a senior vice president with Tambrands. He said Soviet consumers have been eager buyers. "There is huge pent-up demand for consumer goods," he said.
Tambrands has received permission to export Soviet cotton to the West, and the hard currency from those sales can be repatriated to the United States as profits. Several times this year customs agents blocked such exports, but Tambrands officials suspect that hardliners opposed to joint ventures caused these snags. With the hardliners gone, Tambrands expects fewer problems.
George Hamilton, senior managing director of international business development for Polaroid, says Western companies should worry more about developing long-term relationships than rushing to repatriate profits. He said Polaroid, whose three Soviet factories assemble cameras and make printed circuit boards and plastic moldings, hopes to build its position and profits in the Soviet Union by providing what the nation wants: new jobs, new skills and some exports.
"Companies that worry only about taking out short-term profits can feed the nation's distrust of capitalism that started 100 years ago," he said. "We see the Soviet Union as a long-term commitment."
 
 
 
ADVICE PEDDLERS ALL OVER
 Ever since Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev invited in Western investors in 1987, a booming new business has developed: providing advice on investing in the land of Lenin.
Many consultants recommend direct investment in three areas: consumer goods, services and energy.
"If you're interested in energy you can't find a more fertile area for investment," said James H. Giffen, president of the American Trade Consortium, a group of American companies negotiating to set up joint ventures in the Soviet Union. He noted that the Soviet Union has the world's largest reserves of natural gas.
"Services is a really good area because you have a blank slate there," said Michelle Siren, a Soviet expert with Price Waterhouse in London. With Soviet restaurants and hotels so inhospitable, companies like Radisson, Marriott, McDonald's and Pizza Hut are rushing to fill the vacuum.
But some experts say it's important not to assume that choosing a certain sector guarantees success. "I recommend a deal-by-deal, enterprise-by-enterprise approach," said Keith Crane, a senior economist with Planecon, a Washington-based consulting firm specializing in Easten Europe. "It's like in the West. You can lose zillions of dollars in high tech or you can make millions in textiles or vice versa."
There is some disagreement over whether now is the proper time to prospect for opportunities. Some experts recommend waiting a few months, until the nation's murky, unstable situation becomes clearer. But Ms. Siren said: "It is always a good time to look because it takes a long time to find exactly the kind of relationship you're looking for."
 
 
 
IT'LL BE A LONG ROAD TO A MARKET ECONOMY
 DESPITE the Soviet Union's post-coup eagerness to embrace a market economy, the cradle of Communism will likely have a harder time making the conversion to capitalism than have most Eastern European countries, economists say.
The Soviet Union's economy is more primitive, and its output was expected to drop this year even before serious reforms. In addition, many people fear a poor harvest and even famine.
Also unlike many Eastern Europeans, the Soviets have no memories of a market economy. "What is at stake here is not a simple reform," said Aleksander Vacic, chief economist for the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe in Geneva. "It is the alteration of an entire economic system by a completely different system, for which the population doesn't have the preparation and in many cases has animosity toward."
Aggravating matters is political disintegration, which can fray economic ties between republics. A television factory in Russia might have to shut down, for example, if it can't obtain antennas from Byelorussia or tubes from the Ukraine.
As the republics move toward a market economy, many people steeped on Marxism might grow unhappy about soaring prices, growing disparities of wealth and bosses ordering them to work harder.
Jan Stankowski, an economist with the Institute for Comparative Economic Studies in Vienna, said, "The process of establishing an efficient, prosperous market economy in the U.S.S.R. will take not years but decades."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
How Safe Is the Dollar Harbor?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
In the long run, one of the casualties of the demise of Communism in what was the Soviet Union could be the American dollar.
Long the safe harbor at times when the cold war seemed in danger of heating up, the old greenback will no longer have the bogyman of Communism to chase frantic investors its way. Investors will not need a safe harbor as often, and this means one of the props that have helped support the dollar over the long term may be gone. 
 This does not mean the dollar will fall immediately, according to Michael R. Rosenberg, manager of international fixed income research at Merrill Lynch in New York. He is holding to his forecast of 1.80 German marks to the dollar a year from now.
The hope for a recovery in the United States and the expected improvement in American inflation relative to Germany, he said, argue for a stronger dollar, when run though an econometric model. The dollar closed in New York at 1.7470 on Friday.
But he sees the trend changing in a statistical item that has been a relatively good mirror of dollar movements in the past -- the total of United States military spending as a percent of the gross national product. For him, this measure is a proxy for the dollar's attractiveness as a safe harbor.
Since 1970, the dollar has risen as military spending rose as a percent of the gross national product and has fallen when this measure declined. If the changes in the Soviet Union mean elimination of the hard-line threat that the West had faced since World War II, then military spending here could continue to decline. According to the Congressional Budget Office, military spending should fall from 5.5 percent of the gross national product to 4 percent by 1996 under the current budget agreement. This means, Mr. Rosenberg said, that the dollar could move "decisively lower" by the mid-1990's.
The role of the dollar -- and of the United States -- as a safe harbor in time of political or economic turmoil has already declined as the world's financial markets have become more global and more open, and investors, with the help of computers, have been able to move quickly from one currency to another or to gold, stocks or bonds.
Take, for example, the invasion of the Kuwait by Iraq last year. On the day before the invasion, the dollar was at 1.5882 marks to the dollar. The dollar rallied some on the news of the invasion on Aug. 2, but it never moved sharply. And, then, as the Persian Gulf crisis dragged on toward open combat, the dollar fell, reaching its post-World War II low against the mark early this year.
The outlook for the Soviet Union -- or for the republics that were the Soviet Union -- did not get any clearer last week. And the outlook for the free world's markets or economies did not either. It was more of the same: a lot of mixed signals.
In the United States, what was thought to be a small rise in the gross national product in the second quarter was revised by the Commerce Department to a small decline, raising more doubts about the strength of the recovery. But with the hope for a cut in interest rates that this news engendered, the Dow Jones industrial average hit a another record high of 3,055.23.
In Japan the scandals that have wracked the market this year seem still to be holding stock prices back, as trading volume has been pitifully low, languishing at levels that have not been seen since 1982. Hopes for the stock market are being pinned again on another short-term interest-rate cut by the Bank of Japan.
In Europe, the German stock market, which was hit hardest by the coup, reclaimed its lost ground. But the economy still faces rising inflation and the threat of higher interest rates. Britain is still waiting for the recovery and the stock market remains below the highs reached earlier this year.
UBS Phillips & Drew in London is increasing its investment in German stocks, after 15 months of caution, because of the psychological boost expected from the definitive demise of Communism in the Soviet Union.
For a play on the Soviet story, Guy Rigden, the director of strategy at UBS, likes the basics: food, detergents and communications. For him this means stocks like Ferruzzi in Italy, the giant dealer in grains and other commodities, and Henkel in Germany, maker of consumer goods like washing powders. Given the immediate needs in the Soviet Union, these kinds of stocks should get a lift, he said, "if things go well or just moderately well there." He cautioned, though, "If things go badly, no one is going to do well."
Michael Howell, chief strategist in London for Salomon Brothers, does not think there are many good plays to make on the Soviet drama. He believes that domestic issues will continue to dominate stock markets and that the impact of the Soviet Union on stocks will be marginal.
But he has a stock that should move with the domestic rhythms he is watching and still dance with the change in the Soviet Union. It is BSN, the French food and beverage company. That company would benefit from the declining inflation in France while taking advantage of the demand for food in the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: A Battle for Control of the World's Largest Tin Mine

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: BOM FUTURO, Brazil

 BODY:
In 1987, an Amazon woodcutter working on a wilderness ridge here cut down a massive tree. Reaching between the roots, he plucked out a black rock, heavy with tin ore.
Four years later, the ridge has vanished into a 20-square-mile moonscape carved out of the rain forest. It is now the largest tin mine in the world. 
 But, belying its name, "Good Future," the wealth of this tin mountain has been its undoing.
By digging into the open pit mine 1,400 miles from Brazil's Atlantic coast, miners turned Brazil into the world's largest tin producer. But their labor also flooded world markets with tin, helping to depress prices on the London Metals Exchange to about $5,585 a ton now, from $8,600 in 1989.
What is more, Brazil did not realize all the benefits of its own mine, since much of tin was smuggled out and sold for better prices in neighboring Bolivia.
With tin prices at their lowest level in real terms since World War II, the Brazilian Government recently seized a chance to reclaim the mine from the thinning legion of wildcat miners here. Citing violations of environmental laws, 200 federal police swept through on Aug. 3 and closed the mine.
"They operated without paying taxes, without obeying environmental legislation and without providing social benefits," complained Samuel Hanan, chairman of the board of Empresa Brasileira de Estanho S.A., a consortium of seven Brazilian mining companies. Ebesa has been fighting for four years to prove that the wildcat miners jumped its claim to Bom Futuro.
The mining machinery here is locked up until the dispute is resolved. Bom Futuro's impasse is symptomatic of a wider malaise in this vast, mineral-rich nation.
After growing in the 1970's, Brazil's annual mineral production dropped during the 1980's to $4.6 billion in 1990, from $5.2 billion in 1980.
During a recent congress in Brasilia sponsored by the Brazilian Mining Institute, an industry association, mining executives suggested two reasons for the drop.
One is a clause in the country's Constitution, adopted in 1988, which bars foreigners from owning majorities of voting shares in mining companies in Brazil. The other is the chaotic working environment: an estimated 300,000 miners work roughly 1,800 deposits, often with technology little changed from the days of the California gold rush.
Bom Futuro's development shows how damaging that chaos can be to the mineral market and the country.
At a rough board table at Coogari, the miners' cooperative in Bom Futuro, Joel Nunes da Silva recalled the heady days of the tin rush.
"On October 17, 1987, military police expelled the gunslingers hired by Paranapanema," said Mr. da Silva, secretary of the cooperative, referring to the Grupo Paranapanema Mineracoes, which holds 49.67 percent of Ebesa's shares.
"The next morning, it was the most beautiful thing I have ever seen," he continued, speaking of the pell-mell invasion of the mining site. "By the end of the morning, we had washed 2,000 kilos of cassiterite." Cassiterite is the principal ore of tin.
The ground around the deposit was littered with chunks of cassiterite weighing as much as 275 pounds. The deposit averaged 11 pounds of cassiterite per cubic meter of earth. Today, with miners digging deeper, the concentration is lower -- about 4.4 pounds per cubic meter of soil. But the average tin concentration level in cassiterite here is 60 percent -- among the world's highest.
Word spread quickly on the frontier, and overnight Bom Futuro developed into a wild west mining town of 20,000 people -- a motley crew of farm boys, lumberjacks, prostitutes and saloon keepers. Ore trucks frequently left the town carrying bodies of victims of numerous shootings and knifings.
In their fever to dig tin, miners ignored mosquitoes that proliferated when seasonal rains flooded the cratered landscape.
"I gave up mining after 40 bouts of malaria," said Elio Takao Hayashi, a veterinarian by training who is now president of the miners' cooperative.
Disdainful of controls, miners smuggled cassiterite by truck or airplane to Bolivia. There, they were paid directly in dollars -- often 100 percent more than the Brazilian Government paid exporters because of a policy in the late 80's of overvaluing the local currency.
Without opening any new mines, Bolivia's tin production soared in 1989 to 15,000 tons from 6,000 tons. That year, Brazil lost an estimated $300 million in taxes and official export revenues because of the contraband.
Because of wasteful mining practices and plummeting international prices, Brazil suffered other losses.
The technology used here recuperates only 60 percent of the ore, much lower than an 85 percent recovery rate with modern technology, said Mr. Hanan of Ebesa.
In addition, with world tin stocks at 44,000 tons, tin prices have fallen steadily since smuggling started in the second half of 1989. For most Brazilian producers, tin prices were below production costs, which led to a steady decline in official tin production -- from 50,000 tons in 1989, to 33,000 tons in 1990, to an estimated 30,000 tons this year.
"You throw Bom Futuro on the world market, and prices hit the floor," said Mr. Hanan, who is managing director of Paranapanema, which produces 90 percent of Brazil's legal tin.
Miners here charge that if Paranapanema takes over Bom Futuro, it will close the mine to lift prices for a company that has a near monopoly on Brazil's production.
Mr. Hanan denied the charges, saying that the Ebesa consortium has drawn up plans immediately to invest $20 million, including $4 million for pollution controls, in the mine.
The Association of Tin-Producing Countries, has stipulated that Brazil must control production here to join the international cartel. The association's members are Australia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Nigeria, Thailand and Zaire.
One year ago, Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello, announced that his Government intended to join the cartel and promised to end the movement of contraband of tin to Bolivia. Largely for economic reasons, tin smuggling dropped sharply. A new policy of realistic exchange rates has narrowed the difference between the black market cruzeiro rate and the official rate for the dollar from 130 percent two years ago to 10 percent today.
To reopen the mine here, the roughly 30 companies operating here would have to band together to present a plan to end the dumping of as much as 850,000 cubic meters of soil in local rivers. With prices low and rivalry high, such a joint endeavor is deemed unlikely.
"I think it's the end of the adventure," Generidio de Carvalho Schwenk, a 44-year-old trucker, said as he looked at the boarded up bars and pharmacies that line the main street of Bom Futuro, now a mining ghost town.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 25-30

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
 Salomon Gets a Little Help From Its Friends 

 If Warren E. Buffett, the interim chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., has his way, the wolves in Solly's trading room will soon be dressed in wool. Mr. Buffett told them last week he prefers losses to violations of the rules. "If you lose money for the firm by bad decisions, I will be very understanding," he said. "If you lose reputation for the firm, I will be ruthless." That was enough to get Lawrence A. Tisch, the New York investor, to buy a big block of Solly's stock. And Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was also won over. He instructed the State Treasury and Urban Develpment Corporation to add Salomon to the list of firms that can bid on selling securities. Salomon still has a long way to go before it polishes its name. That too was underscored last week, when Moody's Investor Services slightly downgraded $13 billion of Solly's debt. But even with the change, Salomon's paper is superior to New York City's and most of corporate America's. That's not bad.
 
The Shape of Recession '91
 
At the beginning of the year, most economists were saying the recession would be "shallow and short." But this recession is shaping up to be at least as long as the one in 1982. The recession, according to the Commerce Department, continued at least through the second quarter, when the gross national product contracted by 0.1 percent. Though shallower than the 1982 recession, this one still packs a wallop. Profits fell by 1.6 percent in the second quarter. As economists furrowed their brows, investors seemed to celebrate; on Wall Street, sluggishness means interest rates are still falling. According to Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, a further drop "will help the economy enough to give companies better earnings." Such perverse logic helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average to a record 3,055.23 last week before closing at 3,043.60.

Some Cheer on the Horizon
 
For a glimpse of the future, the Commerce Department stands on its tiptoes with the aid of the index of leading economic indicators. On the horizon, it sees a pickup in economic activity. For July, the index jumped by 1.2 percent, the largest increase in three years. The index, which is a patchwork of 11 other statistical gauges, showed big gains in factory orders. Since it is designed to see six months into the future, the sharp rise in July could signal growth before the end of the year. Whether growth will be weak or strong the indicators still cannot predict.

Housing's Still Stalled
 
Housing often leads the economy out of recession. Buy a home and sooner or later you buy the finery to fill it. But if that's true, the economy still has a lot of languishing time. Sales of new homes -- the ones that need new refrigerators and drapes -- fell 8.5 percent in July after rising 4 percent in June, the Commerce Department said. And sales of existing homes -- the ones that already have fixtures -- fell 6.7 percent in July, according to the National Association of Relators. The recession has hurt home sales, but so has price. The association said the median price for a home climbed a full percentage point in June, meaning fewer people can afford to buy than at any time in the last 11 months.

Hot Times at the Factory
 
While most of the economy limps along, the nations' factories have strapped on their running shoes. Orders for manufactured goods rose by 6.2 percent in July, the Commerce Department said last week. That is the largest monthly gain in new orders since December 1970. Big-ticket durable items, like cars and airplanes, make up half the index. They shot up 10.7 percent in July.

Consumers Moody Again
 
Consumers account for two-thirds of all economic activity and when they are confident, they spend. That fuels growth. But last week the Conference Board, which surveys 5,000 homes and compiles a confidence index, reported that the consumer was turning moody. The Index fell to 76.3 in August, from 77.7 in July. That was the fourth decline in the index since the end of the Gulf War. "While many of the economic indicators suggest that a recovery is in progress, the evidence will not be convincing until there is a substantial improvement in consumers' spirits," said Fabien Linden, who directs the survey. What exactly is making the consumer feel blue? They fear their jobs are still in danger.

Pushing the (Silicon) Chip
 
To Washington's expert policy makers, it never mattered much if America exported computer chips or potato chips, as long as it exported. Potato chips are doing fine, thank you, but computer chips are another story. Much of the market has been lost to Japan. Last week a Government advisory committee of 90 (silicon) chip experts proposed a program to improve America's competitiveness in semiconductors. The program, called Micro Tech 2000, would accelerate the nation's design and manufacturing capabilities. It calls for pooling knowhow among producers. Though the report does not say how much Micro Tech 2000 would cost, it did say it would "require the efforts of hundreds of scientists and engineers for a number of years" -- which does not sound cheap. The Bush Administration, which must approve the plan, has a history of snubbing such measures. For the Administration, all chips are the same.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Placing the Blame in Germany
 
He may be an extinct volcano, but last week at his retirement party, Karl Otto Pohl, the former president of Germany's central bank, let out one more puff of smoke. Mr. Pohl told the gathering -- which included his successor at the Bundesbank, Helmut Schlesinger, and 900 other guests -- that Germany's inflation rate was far too high. Last July, it reached all of 4.4 percent, a rate considered enviable these days by even the Japanese. To dampen inflation, said Mr. Pohl, Germans must regain their discipline, especially with respect to wages. But the real culprit for the scary rise in Germany's inflation rate, Mr. Pohl said, was the poorly thought out way eastern Germany's devastated economy was joined to the very vigorous economy of the west. The architect of that plan, Chancellor Helmut Kohl, brushed off the debris from his vest and handed Mr. Pohl a medal of honor for his 11 years of service as head of the Bundesbank.
 
Nissan Thinks Electric
 
Detroit has a long history of unveiling nifty new "concept" cars that could solve big problems if they were ever built. (They almost never are). Last week, Japan's Nissan Motors did the same. Dubbed the FEV, for Future Electric Vehicle, Nissan's new car is all-electric. But what makes the FEV different are its batteries. They can be fully recharged in just 15 minutes instead of overnight. But analysts doubt the FEV will ever make it to the street. The car's nickel cadmium batteries are pricey and much more toxic than lead-acid batteries. They also require special electrical outlets to get recharged. "I don't think it's going to be something that will turn the electric vehicle world upside down," said Roberta Nichols, of the Ford Motor Company. So far, there's not much of a world to upset.

Not Much for Moscow
 
While the heros of the second (or is it third?) Russian revolution stood in front of the tanks at the Parliament building, the rest of the world pinched its pennies. President Bush and British Prime Minister John Major offered a little food while the World Bank approved a $30 million aid package. The bank's less-than-generous package -- about 8 cents for each Soviet citizen -- will not be used to buy goods but to pay for yet another study of what's wrong with the Soviet economy. To most observers, what's wrong is already pretty clear: The Soviets have no goods.

Amnesia in the Tokyo Market
 
First it was a series of embarrassing scandals that spread through Tokyo. Now it is amnesia. Setusya Tabuchi, the former chairman of Nomura Securities, told Parliament he could not remember the gangster who introduced him to Susumu Ishii, the man Nomura is accused of helping manipulate stocks. "I'm embarassed," Mr. Tabuchi said, "but up until yesterday I remembered his name, while today it does not seem to come to mind."
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Completing a Bailout
 
When the Executive Life Insurance Company of California went under earlier this year, most of its 372,000 policy holders figured their policies would be worthless. Then John Garamendi, the California Insurance Commissioner, deftly patched together a $3 billion deal to sell Executive Life and its assets to a group of French investors. But the deal only protected 81 percent of the value of most policies. Last week the insurance industry chipped in with $1 billion more to cover the remaining 19 percent of the losses. The money will be funneled through the National Organization of Life and Health Insurance Guaranty Association, an industry group that protects policy holders against losses. The industry dipped into its pockets, said a spokesman for the organization, to restore the public's confidence.

More Woe for Chip Maker
 
The National Semiconductor Corporation, an old-line manufacturer of semiconductor chips, has too much manufacturing capapcity and too few customers. Last week it said it would take a $149.3 million charge against first quarter earnings for plant closings and reductions in staff. Last year it had to close plants and dismiss some 2,000 workers. Analysts say that they are expecting more layoffs to follow.

McDonnell's Risks
 
When McDonnell Douglas Inc. won the contract to build the C-17, the Air Force's nimble new cargo plane, little did it know it might cost the company its future. The contract calls for as many as 120 planes. If they are all built, it could be worth almost $40 billion. But the program is still in its infancy, and McDonnell must pay any costs over $6.6 billion. McDonnell does not have much cash, the Pentagon estimates its losses on the first phase are as high as $2.6 billion. McDonnell disputes the figures. Analysts think the trouble could weaken the nation's No. 1 weapons maker, perhaps putting it into bankruptcy..

Chrysler Will Buy Chryslers
 
The Chrysler Corporation's best innovations for 1992 may not be in its cars, but in its incentive plans. One plan commits Chrysler to buying a purchaser's car back within four years. But what will Chrysler do with all those used cars? That part of the plan has not been revealed.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
When 'Real' Numbers Are Unreal

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The recession that has now ended -- cross your fingers as you read this -- was worse than either of the past two big recessions.
That statement is absurd by the conventional measure used by economists, that of "real" economic growth. By that standard, this recession was a mild one. The second quarter gross national product level was just 1.1 percent lower than the peak quarter, the third quarter of last year. By contrast, the peak-to-trough falls in the previous two downturns were 4.4 percent in 1974-75 and 3.4 percent in 1981-82. 
 But there is another sense in which this recession was worse, one that in some ways is more real than the "real" figure. That is in terms of the dollars actually spent, before worrying about inflation. By that standard, this economy almost never stops growing, and did not in this recession. The G.N.P. in "nominal" dollars, to use the jargon, rose 1.8 percent over the past three quarters, well under the rises in previous recessions.
Nominal numbers fell into disrepute in the days of high inflation, and indeed they distorted the picture then. But in some ways now it is the real figures that are unreal. As Ray Dalio, an economist at Bridgewater Associates, put it, "businesses live and die by nominal growth." It is nominal dollars that companies collect from customers, and it is nominal dollars that they use to pay bills.
For American business, this is an inconvenient time for nominal G.N.P. growth to be lagging. When businesses added more and more debt in the 1980's, they were placing an implicit bet on inflation continuing, so that they would be taking in more dollars to pay back the debt.
Unfortunately, nominal growth has been slowing for years. Since 1965, the two-year rate of nominal G.N.P. has fallen below 10 percent only once, when it hit 9.6 percent just after the end of the 1981-82 recession. Now it stands at 8.5 percent.
The sustained low growth in nominal G.N.P. helps to explain why this downturn has resulted in so many bank and business failures, and why they may continue even after the recovery comes. Inflation can cover up a lot of mistakes by borrowers, and the lack of it can make those errors seem much larger.
Last week, the bond market rallied as the Government cut its estimates of economic activity in the second quarter and speculation of a new easing by the Federal Reserve grew. That helped share prices rally to records in midweek, on the assumption that the Fed will get business moving and profits rising.
It is possible, as the post-1983 experience shows, for nominal growth to take off, even in a period of falling inflation. In essence, that is the bullish case right now. Count Mr. Dalio as a bear. He argues that growth comes from credit, and that America has too much debt already. He sees a sustained period of low nominal growth and a long period in which bonds perform better than stocks.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Not a Very Good Year, Looking at Volume

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
It was light in August -- all year, in fact, in terms of market volume.
Outside the United States market, trading volume so far this year has been anemic. Hardest hit is Japan, where market scandals have combined with doubts about the pace of economic recovery to drive market volume down more than 38 percent since the first of the year, said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in New York. 
 In Germany, an ebbing of the euphoria over the demolition of the Berlin wall in December 1989 has curbed market activity. Even in the London market, which has been setting new highs, trading volume has increased only modestly. "That suggests that the market's strength has come as a real surprise to people," Mr. Birinyi said.
All told, "the United States has had the largest volume increases of any market in the world, despite brokers' lamentations," he said. That's the good news; the bad news, he added, is that the resulting level of activity is still "not keeping the phones busy."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Indian Gaming Head

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
When the Bush Administration approached him in 1989, Anthony J. Hope did not quite see the virtue of taking a job running one of the newest Federal agencies, the National Indian Gaming Commission. It was an agency, conceived in controversy during the Reagan Administration, that had languished without champion, chief or staff.
"I was trying to turn it down," he said. But the 51-year-old Mr. Hope, a lawyer, was finally intrigued by the chance to build an agency from scratch. Confirmed in May, 1990, he is charged with overseeing the gambling enterprises of American Indian tribes. 
 Until recently, that would most likely have meant small-potatoes gaming. In recent years, however, several tribes have moved into high-stakes casino gambling. The result: an industry worth roughly $1.4 billion annually and howls of pain from the traditional gaming business, which is feeling its own recession.
The gambling industry's opposition to competition from the tribes has softened what might have been a negative response to the new commission from the American Indian community, which is usually wary of Federal agencies.
"We began to work with the Federal Government to protect ourselves," said Leonard L. Prescott, chairman of the National Indian Gaming Association and tribal chairman of the Shakopee Mdewakanton Sioux of Minnesota. "It looked for a while as if the ability of Indians to do gaming was going to be taken away."
Mr. Leonard said the appointment of Mr. Hope, who is not an American Indian and had no experience with gaming or "Indian country," was viewed with concern. But Mr. Hope has won some credibility. "He is making an effort to develop reservation economies," Mr. Prescott said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Julian Lerner's Lessons of the 30's

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
While many managers of mutual funds cut their teeth on the 1980's bull market, Julian A. Lerner says his investment style was shaped by the Great Depression and World War II.
Mr. Lerner, who has run the Houston-based AIM Charter Fund for nearly a quarter-century, manages the fund defensively to avoid big losses. But this has not prevented him from thriving in bull markets. 
 For the five years that ended on June 30, Charter earned an average annual return of 13.5 percent, compared with a rise of 8.7 percent for all growth-and-income funds, which invest mainly in dividend-paying stocks. Over 15 years, Charter's annual return averaged 18.2 percent, compared with 13 percent for its competitors. And the fund rose 8.2 percent in last year's difficult market, making it one of a handful of stock funds to post gains in 1990, according to Morningstar Inc., mutual fund consultants in Chicago.
Morningstar has called Mr. Lerner, who is 66 years old, "the most underappreciated mutual fund manager in America." But investors are catching on. Fund assets have soared to $290 million today from $123 million at the end of 1990. Mr. Lerner and his family, including his three grandchildren, own the largest stake in the fund.
He says the infusion of money this year makes his work less stressful -- "no need to worry about having cash to meet redemptions." He is buying stocks every day and has increased the fund's total holdings from the usual 35 or 40 stocks to 53 today.
Mr. Lerner and his 26-year-old assistant, Lanny Sachnowitz, invest mainly in big, widely known companies with strong growth rates, using rising dividends as a yardstick. Most stocks owned by the fund pay dividends that have grown steadily for at least five years. Bristol-Myers Squibb, for one, has increased its dividend payments more than 15 percent annually for the last 18 years.
As a growth-and-income fund, Charter attempts to offer a steady yield, mainly from dividend-paying stocks, without giving up the chance for handsome appreciation in securities prices. Mr. Lerner's normal goal for the fund is a yield of 2.5 percent. In 1991, however, as share prices have zoomed higher faster than companies have raised their dividends, he expects a yield of only 2 percent.
During the Depression, when Mr. Lerner was a boy, he saw well-dressed people coming to his family's door in Galveston, Tex., for handouts. The experience made him determined to avoid significant losses in the fund and shaped his second yardstick: sell any stock that drops 20 percent or so from its high point. He has not taken a loss of more than 23 percent since 1974, he says.
He admits that this principle led to some mistakes in last year's volatile market, but he also says, "I've never owned a stock that's gone broke." The fund's turnover was 100 percent in 1990, although he prefers a slower-paced 50 percent.
While many fund managers now come to their jobs fresh from business school, Mr. Lerner took a more circuitous route. He dropped out of the University of Texas in 1942, at the age of 18, to enlist in the Army. He served in the infantry in Alsace-Lorraine.
When the war was over, he earned a law degree and opened a small practice handling divorce, custody and criminal cases. Unhappy with the work, he joined the legal department of the Great America Corporation, which managed a small mutual fund. When the company split up in 1966, Mr. Lerner and some backers bought the management company that ran the fund, which was called the Life Insurance Stock Fund. That experience taught him the value of diversified investing.
He set up the Charter Fund in November 1968 with four insurance companies, merged the two funds and ultimately bought out his partners for what he calls "a small amount" in 1979. In 1985, he sold his company to the AIM Group, where he has worked since.
Over the years, he learned that stocks can rise higher than he had dared to dream. "That's why equities are the place to be, even for conservative investors," he said.
What does a man who has seen all manner of economic times think of today's stock market? "I'm not wildly bullish, but I'm not negative either," he said. The reasons: "Usually there's more optimism at the top of a market than we see now, and there could be more cuts in the prime rate."
Right now, the fund's largest industry sectors are pharmaceuticals (13 percent), banks (9.5 percent), foods (8 percent) and chemicals (6 percent).
The fund's largest holding is Pfizer, the New York-based pharmaceutical company, which Mr. Lerner says "has more products in its pipeline than any other company, paricularly for its size."
The second-largest holding is Gillette, which Mr. Lerner says has captured almost the entire razor market, especially overseas. Next is Campbell Soup, whose new chief executive has significantly increased earnings. Then comes Merck, the drug maker, which he calls a "premier growth company."
The fund owns a sizable chunk of J. P. Morgan, which Mr. Lerner calls one of the few remaining "great banks." He predicts a bright future for the banks that survive the current shakeout. The fund also owns BankAmerica, Banc One and Norwest.

HEADLINE: A Hotel Is Not a Home

 BODY:
The revelation that New York City officials are secretly booking homeless families into commercial hotels at up to $100 a night is surely cause for alarm. This desperate tactic suggests that the homeless problem is getting worse, not better, and that government programs at all levels still fall miserably short.
After a dramatic decline in 1989 and 1990, the number of homeless families in the city's shelter system has risen sharply, in part because of the recession. A year ago, some 3,450 families lived in temporary apartments while waiting for a permanent home. The figure is now up to 4,750, 450 short of the 1987 record. 
 The number of families in the city's infamous welfare hotels, intended for short-term stays, has also shot up. Several years ago, 3,700 families lived in squalid hotel rooms, for which the city and the Federal Government paid an appalling $1,800 a month. But when Washington threatened to stop paying its share for any family remaining more than 30 days, the Koch administration adopted a two-year plan to provide alternatives. It built new "Tier II" residences with more space and rehabilitated city-owned apartments.
This program, pressed by Mayor Dinkins, temporarily paid off. The number of families in hotels dropped below 150 by August 1990. Now it's back up to 750. Most live in a dozen hotels devoted largely to the homeless. But with these hotels filled, officials are flipping through the Yellow Pages to find commercial hotel rooms to handle the overflow. Ominously, the overflow may soon become a tidal wave. The city is under court orders to end the use of hotels entirely by Sept. 30. It also faces another threat from Washington to stop paying its share of the bill for temporary shelter.
Despite its genuine concern, the Dinkins administration may have inadvertently aggravated he problem. Roughly 100,000 families are living doubled up with friends and relatives. For some, the quickest route to permanent shelter has been to endure a few months in a hotel, waiting for a place of their own in public housing.
Mr. Dinkins decided to short-circuit this process by setting aside 1,000 rehabilitated apartments for doubled-up families in a program known as Alternative Pathways. But that well-meaning effort to keep people out of the shelter system may also have made it harder for others to leave it.
Government at all levels can help ease the crisis. To stay the Sept. 30 court order and delay the threatened cutoff of Federal funds, the city will need a well-defined timetable for pressing ahead with Tier II shelters and more rehabilitated housing. Albany could help by enlarging housing allowances for welfare families. The allowance for a family of three is now $286 a month, hardly enough to find livable space.
Washington could help by showing patience and continuing to finance temporary shelter while New York continues with its brave effort to build more permanent housing. Of even greater benefit, of course, would be a large new infusion of federally sponsored low-income housing. That probably isn't in the cards. Even so, it should now be clear that combing the Yellow Pages for temporary shelter is no solution.

HEADLINE: Choosing to Live Pleasantly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Paul Leinberger and Bruce Tucker's article on the differences in attitude between members of the present generation and their parents is full of confusions, probably a reflection of the confused minds of the young people they interviewed. 
 Today's employees disdain organizational loyalty; they cynically job-hop from one company to another. They're "ferociously competitive," yet they're "less competitive and more cooperative." Finally, there's confusion over how much work they will do. "It is not that they do not want to work," the authors report. "They want to work differently" -- that is, they want more time for family, personal pursuits and community activities.
Certainly many of us of William H. Whyte's generation longed for a better balance between commitment, competitiveness and work. What is bothersome is that the organizations we worked for held their own against international competition, while American corporations today generally do not.
It seems the present generation is choosing to live pleasantly rather than competitively. I don't argue with their choice, but let them be clear over the consequences: a steadily declining status for their organizations in the world's economic pecking order.
 
HERVIE HAUFLER
Grantham, N.H., Aug. 7
