HEADLINE: Industry Fails as Cure-All for Western China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QIAPUQIA, China, Aug. 30

 BODY:
While the newly prosperous residents of China's coastal towns build lavish brick homes and dream of sending their children to graduate school abroad, the still-poor inhabitants of western China patch their mud huts and sometimes think of an education as merely an optional extra that in any case ends in the fifth or sixth grade.
Life in the hamlets of western China, like this one in Qinghai Province, is clearly getting better, and it is now common to see television antennas sprouting from mud-wall villages. But the pace of development is far slower here than in eastern China. 
 "The gap between east and west is widening," said Wang Xueren, an expert on Gansu Province who joined about 70 officials and development specialists this week at a meeting in this small town to discuss ways of raising living standards in western China.
In one indication of the remoteness of the region, the conference, which attracted about a half dozen Americans, is the first international gathering ever held in Qinghai Province.
As many of the speakers noted, the lag in western China is of special concern because the region is largely inhabited by ethnic minorities. In the northwest are Muslims of Turkic origin, while here and farther south are Tibetans. Next to Tibet is Yunnan Province, with a profusion of other minorities. Though the issue went unstated, it was clearly on everyone's mind that there have been calls for independence in Tibetan and Muslim areas, and that the widening gap between east and west could worsen political unrest.
Chinese experts at the conference, which was sponsored by a branch of the Agriculture Ministry and financed in part by the American-based International Fund for the Development of Tibet, called for a new approach in dealing with the west.
"In the past, we've emphasized growth of economic output as the criterion of development in western China," said Cao Zhenghai, a researcher for the Communist Party in Inner Mongolia. "In fact, this kind of output increase has little relationship to the progress of nationalities."
"The strategy needs to be changed," said He Daofeng, a specialist in rural development from Beijing. Like other speakers, he said more effort must be made to protect the environment and to involve local people in projects that will do more than simply raise the region's industrial output.
The harm caused by misplaced efforts to promote development is reflected in the grasslands around the nearby Longyang hydropower station on the Yellow River. Conceived and financed by the central Government in Beijing, the project has helped alleviate the electricity shortage in western China. But the huge reservoir has also lowered temperatures slightly and led to winds that are now eroding the nearby grasslands. The result is that the desert is eating up the prairies relied upon by local herdsmen.
Many point out that Beijing's policy of setting fixed low prices for natural resources has subsidized eastern Chinese industry and consumers at the expense of the west.
Phunkhang Goranangpa, president of the International Fund for the Development of Tibet, said the Government enterprises set up in minority areas do not always help local people. They sometimes rely on imported workers and harm the environment, leaving residents worse off than before.

HEADLINE: 50 Years After Pearl Harbor, Reconciliation Is Still Elusive

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Aug. 31

 BODY:
When the solemn observances of the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor are over this Dec. 7, the American survivors will hold a final banquet at the Sheraton Waikiki Hotel. The hotel is owned by a Japanese company, Kokusai Kogyo of Tokyo.
This circumstance underscores the powerful cross-currents pulling at Hawaii as it prepares to commemorate that infamous day at a time when the Japanese have achieved with yen what their fathers could not with bombs. 
 High hopes that the observance would begin a new era of cooperation have now turned into fears of an entirely different outcome.
 
'Years of Pain and Hatred'
 Some people are demanding that Japan apologize. Some worry that the ceremonies will intensify anti-Japanese sentiments in this country and anti-America feelings in Japan. Some fear a backlash against Asian-Americans that could drive away the Japanese tourists who are a mainstay of the Hawaiian economy.
Others hope bygones can at last be bygones. "Fifty years of pain and hatred is long enough," said Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, a Japanese-American, said at a dinner held last week by the Japan-America Society of Honolulu. "The time has come for reconciliation."
That Mr. Inouye, a Democrat who lost his right arm as an American soldier fighting in Italy, should have to issue such a plea served only to emphasize the tense state of Japanese-United States relations today.
Neither government appears willing to use the Pearl Harbor ceremonies to grapple with the issues that divide them. In July the Bush Administration, under pressure from veterans groups, said no official foreign guests would be invited to the Pearl Harbor events, thereby avoiding the painful matter of whether to invite the Japanese. The Japanese have been silent, saying the question of how Pearl Harbor is remembered is strictly an internal American issue.
The anniversary comes at a time when the economies of the two countries are more intertwined than ever, but when tensions and resentments are greater than at anytime since the end of the war in 1945, largely because of disputes over trade and investment.
 
Complex Contradictions
 Nowhere are the contradictions between the nations more pointed or complex than here in Hawaii, where the economy is closely tied to Japan. Indeed, as planners sought a site for the final Pearl Harbor observance, they could hardly avoid using one with Japanese ties: Nearly every hotel in Honolulu large enough for the event is owned by Japanese interests.
As the commemoration draws closer, survivors are coming forward with harrowing memories of the attack, the fearsome blasts and the mangled and burned bodies. The early-morning air raid left 2,403 Americans dead, 21 ships sunk or damaged and 188 aircraft destroyed, and drew the United States into the war that ended with the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki three years and eight months later.
Richard I. Fiske, a Marine bugler on the battleship West Virginia, still recalls seeing a Japanese pilot's smiling face as he veered off after delivering a bomb to the nearby battleship Arizona, which was sunk with the loss of 1,177 sailors and marines. "For years I dreamt about it," said Mr. Fiske, who is now 70 years old. "I can still see that smile."
Passions still run high among many of the American survivors. "We did not invite the Japanese 50 years ago and we don't want them now," said Gerald Glaubitz, the national president of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association who is Mayor of Morningside, Md. "This is our own thing. We've been planning for almost five years. I've had widows call me and say, 'You mean they are going to invite the people who killed my husband?' "
Such sentiments have been a source of discomfort to Hawaii's political and business leaders, who hope the events focus not just on a painful past but also on a hopeful future of cooperation.
"Pearl Harbor was very prominent in our history," said Adm. Ron Hays, retired, a former commander in chief of the United States Pacific Command who was appointed by Gov. John Waihee 3d as chairman of a special committee to review the events. "But we are also talking about a strong ally. Our economy and security are interdependent. We both stand for democracy and freedom. So I would hope to see a balanced program to pay tribute to those who lost their lives and also look ahead."
In March, Governor Waihee, a Democrat, led a promotional delegation of Hawaiian business and tourism leaders to Japan. "Pearl Harbor was of great interest to them," said Carolyn Tanaka, his press secretary. "That is a concern to us. Tourism is our No. 1 industry. The Governor reassured them they are always welcome."
 
Request for an Apology
 The debate has been fanned in recent weeks by Honolulu's pugnacious Mayor, Frank F. Fasi. He has suggested the Japanese apologize for Pearl Harbor and then be invited to attend the ceremonies. That brought a testy retort from some Japanese politicians, who said the United States should apologize for the atomic bombings.
In a move rich with symbolism, Takashi Hiraoka, the Mayor of Hiroshima, visited Honolulu this week and laid a wreath at the Arizona Memorial.
For the Japanese, the events present a delicate problem in a state where heavy Japanese investment in real estate has stirred resentment in recent years. At the Japanese consulate just five miles from where Japanese bombers once rained bombs, Consul General Masaji Takahashi chose his English words carefully.
"Who should be invited is a matter to be decided by the American side," said Mr. Takahashi, who was born in 1937 and has no memory of the momentous events of 1941. "The expatriate Japanese here are rather uncomfortable. The feeling is that this may be the start of Japan bashing."
He added, "Fundamentally, the relationship will not be damaged, but there is a certain worry."
 
Four Days of Events
 From 6,000 to 10,000 survivors and their families are expected here for the four days of official events. They are scheduled to begin Dec. 4 and culminate with a solemn ceremony at the Arizona memorial at 7:55 A.M. on Dec. 7, the exact hour the Japanese aerial attack began. President Bush plans to attend the session, on his way home from a trip to Japan. The events are being organized by the Navy and the National Park Service, which maintains the memorial.
Today it is hard to believe that Pearl Harbor, just west of downtown Honolulu, was once the scene of such devastation. About 4,000 visitors a day pass through the museum on shore and then take a Navy barge to the memorial that straddles the sunken remains of the Arizona.
Greeting the visitors are a handful of aging survivors of the attack like Mr. Fiske, the Marine bugler, and Robert Kinzler, who was a 19-year-old Army radio operator from Irvington, N.J., in 1941.
The sharp edges of bitterness have worn off over the years for Mr. Fiske, at least. About a month ago, a Japanese tourist of his own generation put his hand on Mr. Fiske's shoulder, said in halting English "I am so sorry," and broke into tears.
"The war's over now," Mr. Fiske said. "Besides, my daughter married a Japanese boy, so what can I do?"
 
A General Ignorance
 Mr. Kinzler, now 69 and a resident of Hawaii, complained that younger Japanese visitors seemed as ignorant as young Americans about the events. But he says they are very respectful; he surmises many lost relatives in the war.
School children in Hawaii are first introduced to the bombing of Pearl Harbor in the 10th grade as part of their regular study of United States history. The emphasis is no different from that of schools on the mainland. But Hawaiian public schools have recently begun stressing civil rights issues stemming from the internment of Japanese-Americans during the war.
No group is more nervous about the anniversary than Americans of Japanese Ancestry, or A.J.A.'s as they say here, who make up about 23 percent of the Hawaiian population. Unlike German-Americans or Italian-Americans, the A.J.A.'s went to extraordinary lengths after the war to break from their homeland, sometimes even burning photos and family records. Thousands were interned during the war.
"The whole event raises a myriad of issues between the U.S. and Japan," said William M. Kaneko, president of the Japanese American Citizens League, a civil rights group that claims 26,000 members nationwide. "We recognize Japan bombed Pearl Harbor and people died and we should be respectful of that. But we have a serious concern about the possibility of a backlash from people who don't distinguish between Japanese and A.J.A.'s."
For older A.J.A.'s in Hawaii, the memories are just as painful as for the Pearl Harbor veterans. Now 72, Tadao Beppu worked on the waterfront back then and was forced to wear a badge with a black border that restricted him from certain military areas. "I felt like the Jews in Germany," he said.
 
'Strictly American'
 Mr. Beppu later joined the Army and served in the famous all-Japanese 442d Regimental Combat Team that saw combat in Europe. He sat in the clubhouse of the 442d Veterans Club with its executive director, Robert M. Sasaki who was just as adamant as the Pearl Harbor survivors about Japanese participation. "Our country was attacked," he said. "It should be strictly American."
 
Financial Concerns
 If the A.J.A.'s are worried about racism, much of the rest of Hawaii is concerned about money. Japanese tourists constitute one fifth of all visitors to Hawaii and spend nearly five times as much Americans on average. More than 25,000 arrive each week and spend an estimated $825 million a year.
Their importance to the Hawaiian economy became all too clear last winter when the Japanese stayed away during the war in the Middle East, throwing hotels and restaurants into a slump. Hotel and tour operators fear that the Dec. 7 events, coming at the beginning of the high season, could prove damaging if the Japanese feel unwelcome.
The largest Japanese tour operator is the Japan Travel Bureau, which brings 270,000 Japanese a year.
Kenji Ito, the bureau's long-time director here, said: "Every time Dec. 7 comes I feel very bad. It is the same with Hiroshima. The only difference is that Japan attacked Pearl Harbor. We cannot get away from that.
"I understand the feeling of the war veterans, but at the same time many people here depend on the tourist industry for a living."
Jack R. Carreiro, a vice president of the Hawaii Visitors Bureau, the semi-official agency that promotes Hawaiian tourism, echoed these concerns. "No one is talking about what Hitler or Mussolini did. We don't want to relive the war. We must look forward, not backward."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Home of the Little League Struggles to Be Home of a Minor Team, Too

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.

 BODY:
For one week every August, this central Pennsylvania city is transformed into a baseball paradise, where the game's most gifted 12-year-olds gather for an international feast of competition and goodwill.
But Williamsport's connection to the national pastime runs deeper than the Little League World Series. Minor league baseball has been a part of life here for decades, a part of life that is now threatened by the economic realities of the game. 
 On Monday, the Williamsport Bills will play the Harrisburg Senators in what will likely be the last Double-A game held here. The franchise is leaving for Binghamton, N.Y., because its owner, the New York Mets, wants a new stadium, more fans and more money.
At a time when minor league franchises are profit-making ventures, Williamsport is a dinosaur. With a 65-year-old stadium and a population of 31,000, the birthplace of youth baseball has become an expendable outpost in the increasingly lucrative professional landscape.
"We can't generate the revenue the owners want these days," said Mayor Jessie Bloom of Williamsport. "They want brand-new facilities, and we just can't afford that."
Williamsport, where Little League was founded in 1939, has a rich minor league tradition. The city was one of six original members of the Eastern League in 1923, and its stadium, Bowman Field, is the second-oldest minor league park in the country.
 
Stars Played in Williamsport
 Babe Ruth brought an all-star team here, and Roger Maris once ran through Bowman's left-field fence. Nolan Ryan pitched three games for Williamsport as a 17-year-old, striking out 21 in one appearance.
But legacy doesn't erase the numbers. Owners want at least 200,000 in season attendance, and the best the sparsely populated Williamsport area can do is 100,000. Owners want $5 million stadiums built, and the best Williamsport can do is a $1 million renovation.
Nevertheless, Bill Pickelner, Williamsport's most prominent businessman, thinks his city should have Double-A ball. Pickelner, who owns oil and coal businesses and who has long been involved with minor league franchises, is calling out to his numerous friends in major league executive suites, hoping to find a believer.
"We deserve baseball," Pickelner said. "For this town to be out of baseball would be a disaster. It would also be a shame, considering the history of the game here."
Recent history suggests that Williamsport may indeed have to go on without the game. After a steady run from 1923, the city endured a 10-year stretch without baseball before it secured Cleveland's Double-A team in 1987. But Cleveland stayed for only two years. Seattle came in next, and its team, too, remained for just two seasons.
Seattle's defection would have marked the end of Double-A ball in Williamsport, if not for a Mets deal gone sour. New York had decided to move its franchise from Jackson, Miss., to Binghamton for the 1991 season, after Binghamton officials made a promise the Jackson people couldn't make: a new stadium.
 
Providing a Safety Net
 Shortly after announcing its intentions, New York learned that the Binghamton financing had come apart temporarily, leaving the Mets without a home for this season. Williamsport was the safety net.
By all accounts, the Mets told Williamsport officials right away that they would remain only until a new agreement could be reached in Binghamton. And after a state grant of $1.4 million and bank loans of $3.1 million were acquired for the construction of the Binghamton stadium, the Mets announced in June that they wouldn't be back in Williamsport.
Pickelner said Williamsport never had an opportunity to persuade the Mets to stay. He contended that the city could have raised more than $1 million for a stadium if the Mets acted as guarantors of the bank loans for the rest, as they did in Binghamton.
Gerry Hunsicker, the Mets' director of baseball operations, said that a new stadium in Williamsport was never a consideration. "But that was because the Mayor cut me off immediately on that," Hunsicker said. "She said it wasn't a possibility."
Conventional wisdom says that Monday's game will be the last reminder of a Double-A era that began 68 years ago, when the Eastern League was hardly a profitable entity.
So in this baseball paradise for kids, the question now is whether pro ball will be back at any level, or if it will vanish from the Susquehanna hills like the lumber companies, the steel mills and the millionaires.

HEADLINE: In Vermont Schools, Test on How Well Students Think Draws New Interest

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30

 BODY:
As the nation's students return to classes, Vermont is expanding an experimental program in learning and evaluating mathematics and writing skills. Some experts believe the program may revolutionize testing and teaching in the United States.
The state's experience with the method is seen by many educators and lawmakers around the country as a preview of what could be in store for the nation if President Bush gets the national testing program he wants as part of his comprehensive education legislative package, America 2000. 
 Schools in New York City, Pittsburgh, Connecticut and California also are experimenting with the testing method, which involves evaluations of folders of a student's work that are compiled over time, including such components as multi-week investigations of complex math problems and drafts of essays. Interest in the method has been expressed by 35 states.
 
A Deeper Look at Skills
 Whatever form national testing takes, it will undoubtedly contain elements of this "portfolio" method, a complex, multi-faceted assessment that digs much deeper than the simple true-false and multiple-choice testing that most adults remember from their school days.
Advocates of the portfolio approach say it truly tests a student's ability to think and reason. Businesses have long expressed frustration with the level of skills in young people emerging from the American education system and have said that promoting such skills is necessary to keep America from falling behind in international competition.
Determining the applicability of portfolios in national testing has made Vermont the place to watch.
 
The Year's Results
 In June, Vermont completed the first year of its program, with 304 fourth and eighth graders participating at 138 schools. In assessments of portfolios from a sample of 48 schools the students were rated as good to excellent in writing, largely because of almost a decade of emphasis on a writing-process method used by the University of Vermont and others. But the students' performance in mathematics was found to be less than satisfactory.
Nonetheless, the state is committed to extending the experiment to all of its fourth and eighth graders, or 1,500 students, in the 1991-92 school year.
"My reaction about the portfolios is very positive," said Richard Mills, Vermont's Education Commissioner. "Clearly it works. We find that our students write well, some of them very well. In mathematics they have a long way to go. We concentrated on problem solving and mathematical communications and we found that our students are just not skilled problem solvers."
Because it is such a new concept, there still is debate about how to standardize scoring and on which standards to use in evaluating the student's portfolio of work.
"Vermont is the first state in the country to move to authentic assessment for all of its children in key subjects," said Dr. Dan Resnick, director of assessment development of the New Standards Project at the Learning, Research and Development Center in Pittsburgh and an advocate of the method. "Vermont is in a key leadership role." The standards project, which investigates how to set up standards for national testing and which standards to use, is co-sponsored by the National Center on Education and the Economy in Rochester.
The results of Vermont's mathematics assessment showed that the students did not have the sophisticated problem-solving skills that the workers of the 21st century will require.
For example, the mathematics portfolios were assessed using seven criteria, with four levels of performance for each criterion. Four of the seven criteria were related to problem solving and three to the communication of the results. Most of the students were shown to understand the problems. In the fourth grade, 71 percent of the students understood, and in the eighth grade, 88 percent did. But in evaluating the quality of the approaches or procedures used to solve problems, 47 percent of fourth graders and 50 percent of eighth graders were found to use effective strategies.
The proportions decline further when the question is whether the student is making reasoned decisions in solving the problems: 12 percent of fourth graders inferred correctly and with certainty as compared to 21 percent of eighth graders. And students almost completely failed to synthesize, or make generalizations, from their problem solving. Virtually no fourth graders made connections or applications from the problems they solved, and only 4 percent of eighth graders did so.
The mathematics ability of the Vermont students reflected the poor mathematics skills of most American students as reported in state-by-state comparisons made public by the National Assessment of Educational Progress in June. The Federal agency has produced surveys of students' performance for 20 years, but this was the first time it released state-by-state comparisons.
The method is not without critics. The portfolios require teachers to work more intensively with students and, for many, to make drastic changes in teaching style. They also require more interaction among parents, teachers and students because the student work is kept in school. And they require more training of teachers.
Ms. Pierce added that the portfolio system, particularly for mathematics, still left a lot of unanswered questions, especially on how the final scoring at the state level will be accomplished and how it will be reported.
Critics say that determining how to score portfolios uniformly is a major problem, as well as insuring that parents, teachers and principals do not correct student work to such a degree that the portfolio is not an accurate reflection of the student's skill.
Proponents of the tests contend that performance on conventional examinations can be used as checks to insure that the portfolio scoring is valid.
Another advocate of the method, Marc Tucker, says Vermont's experiment has begun to transform the method into a practical approach of refining the skills of American school children. "Vermont has shown that it can be done," said Mr. Tucker, president of the Rochester center. "They've done it not only from a technical standpoint, but have provided information that parents and people in policy positions find very useful."
And Vermont's experience has led to a number of inquiries from states interested in the method. Ramsay Selden, director of the state education assessment center for the Chief State School Officers, said more than 35 states had expressed interest in portfolios.
"It is really important to the public to see how these assessments are changing schools," said Mr. Selden. "What is happening is that quietly techniques are being developed to objectively score and rate these assessments. Portfolios are going to become much more the core of how we evaluate student work."

HEADLINE: Serbia Says It Is Accepting European Peace Proposal

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, announced today that it was accepting a European Community plan to send foreign observers to oversee a cease-fire in Croatia and set up an arbitration commission to resolve the overall Yugoslav crisis.
"The basic elements of this document, which are the result of France's plan and support, are acceptable for Serbia," said Serbia's Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, on Belgrade television tonight. "We consider that it is reasonable, balanced, and does not favor any one side." 
 Mr. Jovanovic rejected the European Community's charge that Serbia was fueling the conflict in separatist Croatia, which has pitted Croatian militias against ethnic Serbs there who oppose secession. The Foreign Minister said European Community officials were not recognizing the "culpability" of Croatia's armed forces.
Serbia for over a month has blocked attempts by the community and Croatia's government to send foreign observers to monitor several failed cease-fires in Croatia. A serious rise in the fighting throughout the separatist republic in the last week has brought sharp criticism from the 12 community nations and the United States.
 
Army Said to Side With Serbs
 This week a community envoy confirmed charges that the Yugoslav Army, which is led by a largely Serbian officer corps, was intervening on the side of the rebel Serbs in Croatia. The army insists it is acting only as a buffer between the Serbs and Croats.
Mr. Jovanovic said tonight that Serbia would accept foreign cease-fire observers so long as they are civilians.
In his attacks on the community's initiatives, Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, has always referred to foreign observers as "foreign troops" and said Serbia would never accept them on Yugoslav soil.
The Yugoslav Army is now the only key player in the Yugoslav crisis not to have announced a decision on the community proposal. Both Croatia and the Yugoslav federal Government approved the plan days ago.
The community gave all sides until Sunday to agree to a cease-fire, allow foreign observers to monitor compliance, and arrange peace talks. They threatened unspecified sanctions against any party that did not agree to the plan.
Before the Serbian announcement tonight, fighting flared again today in Croatia.
In the Danube River town of Osijek, in the ethnically mixed farmlands of eastern Croatia, skirmishes with automatic weapons were reported through much of the day. The long siege of the river city of Vukovar also continued, with pounding from Yugoslav Army artillery, from gunboats on the Danube River and from Serbian rebel units.
In the Serbian stronghold of Knin, on the tip of Croatian land touching the Adriatic, the Serbian-controlled radio reported that rebel Serbs had repelled a Croatian police force controlling the mountainous national park at Plitvice. But the report could not be independently confirmed.
 
Clash at Zagreb Airport
 Zagreb, Croatia's capital, was unusually tense. Croatian officials closed the airport to civilian traffic after army troops fired on Croatian policemen who approached two civilian aircraft that had earlier been forced to land by Yugoslav fighters.
The press agency Tanyug later reported that one of the aircraft -- a civilian Air Uganda jet forced down while en route to another separatist republic, Slovenia -- was found to have 19 tons of rifles, ammunition and anti-tank guns on board. The second plane was allowed to depart after a search.
[A senior Croatian government official quoted by The Associated Press said it appeared that some Croatian police officers died or were hurt when their vehicle was hit by a tank or artillery during the airport clash.]
In Zagreb's old town, the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, met through the day with his government's officials. In a televised interview this evening, Mr. Tudjman gave no indication that Croatia intended to widen hostilities, which he said had already claimed more than 308 lives on the Croatian side.
"I think that a peaceful end to all of this is possible," he said, "and that those who started this aggression against Croatia will be forced to have talks to end the aggression."
 
Return to Barracks Demanded
 Mr. Tudjman warned earlier this month that Croatia would in effect declare war on Yugoslavia if the national army units in his republic were not ordered back to their barracks and if the rebel Serbs who have brought large areas of Croatia under their control were not brought to heel by tonight.
Analysts in Yugoslavia doubt that Mr. Tudjman can risk taking on the larger and better-armed national army.
In the two months since Slovenia, Yugoslavia's wealthiest republic, declared independence, and Croatia, the second most wealthy, said it would initiate steps toward "disassociation" from this multi-ethnic country, more than 300 people have been killed, 140,000 people have fled their homes, federal authority has collapsed and the economy is in a shambles.
Croatia's leaders argue they are fighting simply to maintain control over their territory. Serbia insists it is not seeking to annex Croatian land, but defending what it says are the endangered 600,000 ethnic Serbs residing in Croatia.

The Republic of Serbia later accepted a European Community cease-fire initiative, which has already been accepted by the separatist government of strife-torn Croatia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Study Finds Bias in House Hunting by Minorities

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Black and Hispanic house-hunters encounter discrimination -- from slammed doors to higher prices -- half the time they try to rent or buy a house, a Government-sponsored nationwide survey has found.
"We were very distressed by the high incidence of discrimination," said Margery Turner of the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington. The institute conducted the survey with Syracuse University for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
 Ms. Turner, deputy research director for the project, said the survey found that Hispanic people looking for housing face nearly the same level of discrimination that blacks encounter in the housing market.
The researchers estimated that blacks face discrimination 56 percent of the time they try to rent a house, and 59 percent of the time they try to buy one. The figures for Hispanic house-hunters were 50 percent and 56 percent, respectively.
 
Overt and Subtle Practices
 Types of discrimination range from fairly rare instances of being told that an advertised housing unit is not available to more subtle and widespread practices of being shown fewer homes than whites, being charged more for rentals, being given less information on mortgages or being "steered" to predominantly minority neighborhoods.
The survey consisted of 3,800 audits, or paired tests, in 25 metropolitan areas. Typically, a white tester posed as a customer interested in buying or renting a home. Black or Hispanic testers, characterized as being of the same income or educational levels, inquired about the same housing. Their treatments were then compared.
The survey was conducted in the spring and summer of 1989. Survey officials attributed the delay in making the results public to the difficulty in assembling and analyzing the data and coordinating the findings with the housing department.
These were some of the findings:
*Eight percent of black and Hispanic home buyers were denied a chance to meet with a real estate agent or were told nothing was available, even though units were shown to whites. The figures rose to 15 percent for blacks and 12 percent for Hispanic people trying to rent housing.
*Black renters were shown 18 percent fewer units and were recommended 48 percent fewer units. Hispanic renters were shown 8 percent fewer units than white renters, and 25 percent fewer units were recommended.
*Nearly one-fourth of both black and Hispanic renters faced less favorable terms, like higher rents or higher fees for parking or utilities.
*Twenty-one percent of both black and Hispanic house-hunters encountered agents who tried to steer a potential buyer or renter to an area with a higher minority population or lower per capita income and house values.
John Yinger, professor of economics and public administration at Syracuse who was the research director of the survey, said only minor variations were found among different cities and regions. "I was struck by how few significant differences there were," Mr. Yinger said. "There is discrimination almost everywhere you go."
The practices documented in the study, including denying the availability of housing, quoting less favorable conditions and steering, have been illegal since the late 1960's, when Congress enacted the fair housing law.

HEADLINE: Vast Influence of Procter & Gamble Revives Old Questions in Cincinnati

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Aug. 29

 BODY:
From its twin towers marking the start of downtown to the corporate-subsidized flowerpots that brighten the sidewalks, the imprint of the Procter & Gamble Company on this city is as strong as a Pete Rose slide into second base.
Until this summer, few people here questioned the company's influence in the city where it was founded, in 1837. But the news that the Cincinnati police had conducted an electronic search of all telephone records in the metropolitan area at the behest of Procter & Gamble to help stop news disclosures brought to the surface an old but seldom-discussed complaint. 
 Who but Procter & Gamble, critics said, could get such help from the police? If a sandwich shop made a similar request, would the police search records from 803,000 business and home phones, as they did in this case, to investigate a misdemeanor?
 
Company Influence Widespread
 "It is outrageous that a local corporation can use our police department like it's their own private detective force," said Tyrone Yates, a member of the Cincinnati City Council.
Some business and civic leaders here pointed to the episode as evidence that this prosperous Ohio River city of 385,000 is a company town, an accusation that most of Cincinnati's leading citizens seem to reject. But the company does have extraordinary influence in the city -- in the arts, education, politics and government -- that shows up in dozens of ways.
"In one sense, if you've hurt Procter & Gamble, you've hurt Cincinnati," said Greg Burgess, an analyst with the Greater Cincinnati Center for Economic Education at the University of Cincinnati. The center, like most institutions here, receives some money from Procter & Gamble. "People in Cincinnati take pride in P.&G. in the same way they do with Cincinnati Reds."
Procter & Gamble, which makes toothpaste, diapers, detergent and hundreds of other consumer products, had $27 billion in sales last year. The company went to the police for assistance in stopping unauthorized disclosures to a reporter for The Wall Street Journal because it was trying to protect its shareholders, company officials said.
The police investigation, based on an Ohio law that makes it a crime for a person to divulge certain types of "confidential matter or information" to people outside a company, has proved inconclusive, the authorities say. But a backlash, a civic soul-searching, has developed in its aftermath.
"The use of taxpayer money to invade the privacy of just about every person in the region is, at best, heavy-handed," said an editorial two weeks ago in The Cincinnati Post. "After years of working to improve its reputation as a corporate bully and impenetrable fortress, this incident paints that picture all over again."
This 203-year-old city, with its quiet neighborhoods and fine old stone buildings, finds itself once again at the center of a clash between constitutional liberties and local concerns.
The last such episode brought the city the kind of publicity civic leaders dread. Last year the city's Contemporary Arts Center and its director were charged with obscenity for displaying the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe that depicted sadomasochistic acts between men. Both the director and the gallery were acquitted. Although Procter & Gamble officals said they are no longer pursuing criminal action against whomever spoke to the reporter involved, Cincinnati's police chief, Lawrence Whalen, said the investigation is not yet over. The Hamilton County prosecutor's office, which obtained a subpoena for the police to search the record for all calls made within two area codes to the reporter, now seems to be trying to distance itself from the investigation.
"We assisted them in getting a subpoena and that's as far as we went with it and as far as we intend to go with it," said Terry Gaines, the first assistant prosecutor for Hamilton County, which covers Cincinnati.
Procter & Gamble officials have said the investigation was prompted by two articles in The Wall Street Journal in June. The articles, about a pending resignation of an executive, and the possible sale of a division, were written by Alecia Swasy, who is based in Pittsburgh. She quoted unidentified current and former company employees.
Under a 1974 Ohio law, it is a misdemeanor for an employee of a company to "furnish or disclose confidential matter or information" to "any person not privileged to acquire it."
 
Law Surprises the Experts
 Many legal experts, inside and outside of Ohio, were surprised that such a law was on the books. They said it appears to violate First Amendment protection of free speech. Edward Fletcher, a law professor at the University of Cincinnati who specializes in trade law, said he had never heard of anyone in Ohio being prosecuted under the law. It was intended to stop business secrets from getting into the hands of competitors, he said.
Two subpoenas, one issued on June 17, the other on June 24, ordered the Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company to turn over the numbers of all people in two area codes, 513 in Ohio and 606 in neighboring Kentucky, who may have called Ms. Swasy at her home, office or fax number in Pittsburgh in a three-month period. About 20 names were given to the police, said Chief Whalen.
The police detective who conducted the investigation, Gary Armstrong, also works for Procter & Gamble part time, which added to the criticism that the lines between the public interest and a company's interest had been blurred. Mr. Armstrong did not return phone calls for comment.
Edwin L. Artzt, the P.&G. chairman and chief executive, said in a statement, "There is no impropriety here but I am concerned about the appearance."
He went on, "We have not influenced this investigation in any way."
Procter & Gamble employs about 13,400 people in the Cincinnati area. It is not the biggest employer -- the General Electric Company and the Federal Government have larger payrolls -- but it the biggest company based in Cincinnati.
"We try, in the best sense of the word, to be a responsible, involved corporate citizen," said Robert L. Wehling, the company's vice president for public affairs. "But we also have a self-interest. If we are going to keep good people here, we have to do everything we can to enhance the quality of life."
 
P.&G. Person on Every Board
 About 2,000 of the company's employees are involved in community service, he said, and company executives are active on arts, education and municipal improvement committees.
"You could hardly find a board in town that does not have P.&G. people on it," said Dr. Alfred Tuchfarber, director of the Institute for Policy Research at the University of Cincinnati. The institute receives some money from Procter & Gamble.
"They are active is just just about everything," said Dr. Tuchfarber. "But this is definitely not a company town. Do people just fall down and do what they want? No. Do they listen? Yes. They are the biggest corporate player in town. But they don't control the town."
 
Builds Environmental Image
 The company also sees itself as an environmental leader, but in Cincinnati its record is mixed. The company supports recycling programs, but through board membership on the Chamber of Commerce it fought a strict version of a local air pollution act.
"This had the appearances of being a Chamber of Commerce committee fighting this, but Procter & Gamble had the heavy hand," said Roxanne Qualls, Cincinnati director of Ohio Citizen Action, a consumer and environmental group.
Business groups said the environmental proposal placed too much of a burden on them. A compromise measure was later adopted.
In Ms. Qualls's opinion, the phone subpoenas tell much about Procter & Gamble's power. "I was shocked," she said. "It had all the appearances of this truly being a company town, and shades of a police state as well."
Most Cincinnati political figures do not go that far, but they do scold the company.
"This is not a town run by P.&G.," said Gerald Newfarmer, City Manager of Cincinnati. "But the company made a bad mistake, using a crazy Ohio law. I hope the law is court-tested and thrown out. And I hope P.&G. never makes such a mistake again."

HEADLINE: Boating;
Fall Boat Shows Will Feature Hype

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
A sagging marine market has put new life into the coming boat-show season, which moves into full swing next month. Manufacturers and trade organizers are finding they must look for new ways to sell their wares along waterfront sites.
The fall boat shows are ablaze with hype, much of it directed at the first-time buyer. Free sailing lessons are offered, as well as seminars for fishermen and demonstrations for navigators on a wide array of new marine electronics. 
 Some shows are offering free admission for children under 12. Others are setting up brokerage offices on special boats; reluctant buyers need only step aboard to negotiate a loan.
 
America's Cup on Display
 The Newport International Sailboat Show, Sept. 5-8 in Newport, R.I., plans to display the 140-year-old America's Cup as a kind of nautical roadside attraction. The trophy is returning to Newport for the first time since 1983, when it was lost to Australia in the cup races that year.
"With the way the sailboat economy is going, we felt we had to go beyond what we have ever done," said Karla Holmes-Little, the Newport show's manager. Inside, there will be fashion shows, seminars and a forum on the next America's Cup race series. On display will be Weatherly, the 1962 America's Cup defender, and Amoco Procyon, one of the industry's most technologically advanced sailboats.
The innovation is mostly in presentation, not substance these days with much of the marine industry in a holding pattern, consolidating wherever possible to stay afloat. "It is very, very rough out there," said Greg Proteau of the National Marine Manufacturers Association, a trade group based in Chicago.
 
Not Many Legitimately New Designs>
 "You don't see a great deal of legitimately new products and designs. It makes sense for manufacturers not to make dramatic changes. It would take away the incentive for buyers to look at models already on the market."
Estimates by the manufacturers group, which represents about 80 percent of the marine market in the United States, shows that the number of boats sold has dropped by nearly one-third in the last two years, from 749,000 to 504,100.
The sailboat industry, which has been reeling from poor sales for more than five years, sold 21,000 new boats last year compared with 27,000 in 1989. The powerboat industry, which reached a peak in 1988, sold 339,000 boats last year compared with 445,400 in 1989.
 
Opposition to Tax
 "Over all, my guess is, especially with the hit we've taken with the excise tax, it's going to be down again," Proteau said about 1991 figures. The Federal excise tax adds a 10 percent tax on boats costing more than $100,000. The manufacturers group has lobbied for the tax's repeal, maintaining that it has decreased big-boat sales and created unemployment in the industry.
Jay Silberman, an organizer of the Atlantic City In-Water Power Boat Show, is trying to attract that upper-bracket buyer to his show. "The boats that are soft are between $100,000 and $250,000," he said. "After that, it doesn't matter as much."
One of the newest craft being shown at the Atlantic City show (also Sept. 5-8) this year is a 45-foot speedboat, the Apache Kid. The $750,000 craft is built with three 1,292-horsepower turbocharged engines and travels up to about 40 miles an hour.
The bread and butter of the powerboat industry continues to be the runabout. Sea Ray plans to introduce an affordable boat and trailer package at the Norwalk International In-Water Powerboat Show in Norwalk, Conn., Sept. 12-15: its new 16-foot outboard limited comes with a 50-horsepower outboard engine and specially designed trailer for about $8,000. Bayliner Marine, which introduced the first boat and trailer package in 1984, offers similar packages this year.
Many of the trade shows are stressing accessories, especially in marine electronics, according to Michael Duffy, manager of the Norwalk show.
The Independence Group, a fledgling yachting syndicate based in Cos Cob, Conn., has offered $2 million to organizers for the next America's Cup races in San Diego. The proposed gift comes with the provision that the Independence group be allowed to race as a defense team. The America's Cup Organizing Committee has refused the offer, maintaining that the Connecticut group has not demonstrated that it has legitimate funding or expertise. The organizing committee met in San Diego with Al Constantine, promoter for the Independence Group, last June.
The two official America's Cup defense syndicates, Team Dennis Conner and America 3, plan to announce a new sponsorship agreement Tuesday in New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Tartan 3500, one of the industry's few substantially different designs this year, will be introduced at the Newport, R.I., show.

HEADLINE: 4 of 10 Larger Counties Face Budget Deficits

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Four of every 10 counties in the nation with populations of more than 100,000 are facing deficits, according to a report by the National Association of Counties. In California, Maryland and New York State, more than 70 percent of the counties are in the red.
"There is in fact a major fiscal crisis throughout the nation," Kaye Braaten, president of the organization, said Wednesday, when the report was made public. 
 Nationwide, 443 counties have populations of more than 100,000. The association's survey showed the average budget deficit of those counties was $8.3 million.
The list was headed by Philadelphia County in Pennsylvania, with a $219 million deficit; New York County, or Manhattan, with $100 million and two Maryland suburbs of Washington -- Montgomery County, with an $85 million deficit, and Prince Georges County with $80 million.
 
12 California Counties Listed
 In California, the deficits in 12 counties were in the tens of millions. The four highest were Alameda County, with $66.1 million; Orange County, 65.3 million; Santa Clara County, $49 million, and San Diego County, $40 million.
Sacramento County had a deficit of $30 million; Riverside, $25 million; Santa Barbara, 22.5 million; Los Angeles and Kern counties, $20 million each; Shasta, $17.5 million; Ventura, $13 million, and Stanislaus, $12 million.
In New York State, Suffolk County, at the eastern end of Long Island, reported a $50 million deficit. Multnomah County in Oklahoma was $24 million in the red, and Oklahoma, which includes Oklahoma City, had a $10 million deficit. In Missouri, St. Louis County had a $14 million deficit.
The county executive in Prince Georges County, Parris N. Glendening, criticized Federal and state governments for adding to the counties' burdens by ordering programs to be carried out but providing inadequate money to pay for them.
 
'Passing on Obligations'
 "We ask that Federal and state officials not solve societal problems simply by passing on obligations to local government without the means to pay for them," he said. "And we ask them not to solve their budget problems by cutting funding for local governments."
Mr. Glendening cited special education, clean water, accessibility for the disabled, storm water management, recycling and landfill reclamation as examples of burdens shifted from state and Federal governments to the counties.
"These are all noble efforts," he said. "We are happy to carry out these obligation, but they cost money"
Ms. Braaten, the association's president who is a county commissioner in North Dakota, said the new survey was made after a report earlier in the year that 53 percent of the county governments in the United States with a population of more than 100,000 would be forced to increase taxes in the current fiscal year.
"A very large number of counties are currently in a state of a fiscal crisis," she said. "Those that are not are being pushed to their limits."
The organization's executive director, Larry E. Naake, said nearly 91 percent of the counties plan to cut expenses, many by delaying capital projects or by laying off or furloughing employees.

HEADLINE: EXPERTS QUESTION STAGGERING COSTS OF TOXIC CLEANUPS

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
A decade after Washington declared war on businesses that expose the public to hazardous wastes, environmental experts are questioning the unquestionable: Is it worth spending a staggering $300 billion to $700 billion to restore waste sites to pristine condition?
While acknowledging that no level of exposure to dangerous chemicals is desirable, the experts argue that the risks should be put in perspective. 
 Virtually all of the risk to human health, most analysts agree, could be eliminated for a tiny fraction of these sums. In a typical project, in Holden, Mo., $71,000 would be enough to isolate an abandoned factory containing residues of toxic chemicals, making it extremely unlikely that anyone would ever be harmed by the wastes. Another $3.6 million would clean up virtually all residues and bury remaining traces under a blanket of clay.
 
What Is Justified?
 But state and Federal laws requirea cleanup that would cost $13.6 million to $41.5 million. "The last couple turns of the screw cannot be justified on economic criteria," said Tom Grumbly, an environmentalist who is president of Clean Sites, a nonprofit organization in Virginia that advises communities on hazardous waste cleanups.
To be sure, the problem of weighing cleanup benefits against the costs is complicated by a lack of information about how dangerous individual chemicals are, and in what concentrations. Nonetheless, experts insist that what began as a crusade against polluters has become a diversion, siphoning money and technical expertise from more pressing environmental concerns.
 
Tougher Criteria Suggested
 More stringent scientific criteria should be used to identify waste sites needing immediate attention, they say. And once identified, the cleanup should be carefully aimed at saving lives rather than restoring land to preindustrial condition.
Analysts acknowledge that redirecting Government policy will be nearly impossible without a radical change in the way Americans think about the risks from hazardous waste. Some would try to temper the zeal for large-scale cleanups by asking the communities that benefit to share in the costs. "Everybody wants a Cadillac as long as someone else is paying," said Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington.
 
Little Confidence in Washington

But there is little confidence in Washington that cost-sharing would make a big difference in public attitudes. And no enthusiasm can be detected for asking voters to pay to protect themselves against hazards they did not create.
A first priority, argues Frank Blake, a former general counsel to the Environmental Protection Agency who now works for the General Electric Company, is more credible information that lifts the "fog of fear" from public perceptions. Specifically, he says, people need ways to compare the risks of exposure with the dozens of other risks that are accepted as part of daily life.
 
$11 Billion Is Spent
 The best-known Federal waste initiative is Superfund, which has spent $11 billion in a decade on emergency measures at 400 abandoned sites and full-scale cleanups at 60 others. But the cleanup mandated by the Superfund legislation has barely begun.
Some 1,200 other sites are already on the Environmental Protection Agency's national priority list, and the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment expects thousands to be added. What is more, a slew of Federal laws require the eventual cleanup of tens of thousands of other sites polluted by government and business. Mr. Grumbly of Clean Sites says the bill for waste containment could reach $20 billion a year by the end of the decade.
 
What the Country Can Afford
 The country could afford such sums, everyone agrees, if the problem demanded it. Businesses and taxpayers have managed to cope with other anti-pollution regulations that now cost $115 billion annually, by the E.P.A.'s reckoning. But little hard evidence exists to support a crash effort.
People living or working near identified toxic waste sites naturally worry that the chemicals will find their way into air, food and water. But many analysts believe the immediate dangers have been exaggerated.
"When you look for deaths from hazardous wastes, you just don't find them," said Bill Ralston, an analyst at SRI International, a consulting company in California.
The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that roughly 1,000 cancer cases annually can be linked to public exposure to hazardous waste. That hardly makes abadoned waste sites a non-problem in anyone's book. But the environmental agency does rank hazardous waste far behind cancer risks like exposure to chemicals in the workplace and depletion of the atmosheric ozone layer. Moreover, many of these greater risks could be reduced at a tiny fraction of the cost of the hazardous waste fix mandated by law.
 
The Example of Radon Gas
 The E.P.A. estimates, for example, that 5,000 to 20,000 lung cancer deaths are caused each year by indoor exposure to radon gas leaking from underground rock formations. Most of these deaths could be prevented by performing inexpensive tests on buildings in radon-prone areas and ventilating basements where concentrations of the radioactive gas are high.
What explains this apparent distortion in environmental priorities? Political economists have long noted that the focused convictions of the few almost always dominate the weakly held views of the many. And Christopher Daggett, the former head of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, argues that nothing focuses convictions like a nearby waste site. "Try telling people that the leaking drums across the street aren't a hazard," he said.
 
Legal and Moral Responsibility
 There are the questions of legal and moral responsibility. Some environmental hazards, like auto emissions, are everyone's fault -- and therefore no one's. Some, like cigarette smoking, are no one's fault but one's own. But Mr. Gough notes that the public blames "greedy and thoughtless" corporations for the waste peril and is thus little inclined to weigh the benefits of cleanups against the costs.
It is not surprising, then, that communities with waste sites in their midst want them restored to how they were before industrial use. Nor is it surprising that the elected officials and administrators who write the rules for cleanups take their cues from an angry and anxious public.
Consider the 11-acre Rose Chemicals Company site in Holden, Mo. Until 1986 the site was used to store and process PCB's, toxic liquid chemicals prized by makers of electrical transmission equipment for their insulating properties and their stability at high temperatures. The barrels of PCB's were removed long ago, but residues remain in the buildings, the soil and the bed of a small stream.
 
A Range of Options
 An E.P.A. analysis says that for $71,000, the site could be permanently isolated from the community. The town's drinking water would be safe because there is no groundwater to tap near the site. But under Superfund regulations, this cheap fix would be unacceptable because there is one chance in 10,000 that someone would develop cancer from eating the cattle that grazed near the property's perimeter -- and roughly the same risk that a determined trespasser could get cancer from repeated contact with building surfaces.
Other possible fixes range from cleaning the stream bed and capping the site with 10 inches of clay ($3.7 million) to removing 14,000 tons of contaminated soil and building materials and incinerating it elsewhere ($41.5 million). The E.P.A.'s preferred $13.6 million option: remove all of the suspect soil and materials, then incinerate the most contaminated debris and bury the rest in a specially designed landfill.
 
A Cheaper Alternative
 Mr. Grumbly of Clean Sites notes that the E.P.A.'s compromise would allow virtually any future use of the site. And he points out that it would cost just a third as much as the maximum effort.
But others may wonder whether the more flexible use of the land is worth the extra $900,000 an acre beyond the cost of scrubbing the stream and capping the property. And still others may ask whether a bare-bones fix -- one that reduces neighborhood cancer risks to, say, one-thousandth the chance of getting cancer from a lifetime of normal exposure to the sun -- would not be adequate.
Mr. Hahn of the American Enterprise Institute and others inclined toward less ambitious goals suggest using financial incentives to discipline the decision-making process. If those at risk from hazardous waste sites wanted more than a basic cleanup, they could be asked to share in the cost.
Dan Dudek, an economist at the Environmental Defense Fund, a mainstream environmental group, offers a variation based on the carrot rather than the stick. Instead of taxing communities to cover the extra cleanup effort, he would give them part of the savings associated with a less-than- total repair. The town of Holden, for example, might be offered 20 percent of the $9.9 million difference as an incentive to save lives in other ways -- say, by purchasing more efficient firefighting equipment, or by testing every home for radon and lead contamination.
That idea appeals to Francis Brillhart, the mayor of Holden, who said he fears that the "E.P.A. is going a bit overboard," slowing the cleanup by choosing a method that requires incineration. If Holden could keep some of the savings generated by a faster cleanup, he says, so much the better.
But few experts think many communities would be likely to take the financial bait. The approach presumes that people would compromise on safety in return for lower taxes or improved public services. Everyone trades safety for money or convenience or simply pleasure in daily life -- new tires are safer than worn ones, turkey breast is safer to eat than a cheeseburger. But people rarely acknowledge they are making choices, even to themselves.
 
Need to Educate the Public
 That is why most analysts worried about the open-ended commitment to scrubbing the country pin their hopes on educating the public about relative risks. "We need more and better information about health risks," said Katherine Probst, an analyst at Resources for the Future, a nonprofit environmental research group.
The way in which the information is presented may also matter: knowing hazardous waste can kill is less useful than knowing it kills one-twentieth as many Americans as radon.
Mr. Grumbly of Clean Sites argues that the credibility of government turns on the transparency of its decision-making. One key to a rational public debate, he insists, is to "let the public in on the game."
But Mr. Grumbly is an optimist. "People understand," he says, "when they are wasting other people's money."

HEADLINE: Northwest Loggers Challenge Rules on Spotted Owl

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
West Coast logging and community groups have challenged Federal rules intended to protect the Northern spotted owl, saying the regulations have harmed the economy in timber-dependent areas of the Pacific Northwest.
In a lawsuit filed Friday in Federal District Court here, the plaintiffs contended that the Fish and Wildlife Service overstepped its legal mandate when it issued the regulations in July 1990. 
 The suit said that the rules had been set without regard to economic impact and that Washington State, Oregon and California had relied on them in adopting local regulations."As a result," it said, "large areas of land are improperly off-limits to timber harvesting."
The plaintiffs include groups in Sweet Home and Mill City, Ore., trustees for timberland holdings and several logging companies.
The lawsuit said the Fish and Wildlife rules had been adopted without proper public notice and comment periods.
It also said the Government had improperly stretched the Endangered Species Act's definition of actions that constitute harming a threatened species. The law intended that land-use actions like timber harvesting would not be considered harming a threatened animal unless it would cause the species to become extinct, the suit said.
 
A Question of Habitat
 Destruction of habitat is at the center of the debate over protection of the spotted owl, which was declared a threatened species by the Fish and Wildlife Service in June 1990. At the time, the agency cited excessive logging of the Northwest's old-growth forests as a major cause of the population decline by the owl.
Craig Rieben, spokesman for the agency, said Friday that it could not comment on the lawsuit because its lawyers had not yet had a chance to review it.
The lawsuit said the Federal regulations barred timber harvesting in areas as large as 3,960 acres surrounding each owl nest site or activity area.
One plaintiff, Pat McCollum of Sweet Home, Ore., owns a family logging company. The lawsuit said that because the owl has been found throughout the area, Mr. McCollum has no timber to harvest and has had to lay off most of his employees.
McCollum also owns a stand of timber that he planned to harvest to pay for his retirement, but because an owl nest was found nearby he has not been allowed to, the suit said.
"His current livelihood and provisions for retirement are thus both undermined by the unlawful guidelines," it said.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
How to Push Through A State Income Tax

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
"Make no mistake," said Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in his television and print ads in last year's campaign to be Connecticut's governor. "I'm not 'for' an income tax."
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican running as an independent, won a three-way race for governor without getting a single member of his tiny party into the legislature. Today, he stands triumphant over the nation's newest state income tax. He proposed it a month after taking office, and then insisted upon its passage through a summer-long deadlock with the legislature, during which he vetoed three state budgets and let the government partially shut down for lack of funds. 
 Economists and politicians around the country say that as the Federal government shifts more burdens to the states, others will probably be tempted to try Mr. Weicker's road. Nine states now have no income tax: New Hampshire, Texas, Tennessee, South Dakota, Washington, Florida, Alaska, Wyoming and Nevada. And five have no sales tax: New Hampshire, Alaska, Delaware, Montana, Delaware and Oregon. Of these, Texas, New Hampshire, Oregon and Montana are expected to become battlegrounds soon.
So, herewith, a few tips from Mr. Weicker's book of legislative confrontation and conquest:
* Diffuse the issue. Even as he vetoed budgets, Mr. Weicker insisted that he disliked the income tax and that he was really not "for" it at all. The budgets he killed, he said in speech after speech, were dishonest, gimmick-laden schemes that would hurt the economy. "It's not about an income tax," he said, ignoring the chorus to the contrary from residents and lawmakers.
* Divide and conquer. From his first proposal of the tax in February, Mr. Weicker began courting allies that could be played off against blocs within the Democrat-controlled legislature. The business community was won over by promises of balanced budgets and cuts in business taxes. The state's labor unions, long supporters of Mr. Weicker, threatened to cancel the package of wage and benefits deferrals they had agreed to in order to close the deficit.
* Take the heat yourself. Lawmakers said Mr. Weicker's willingness to make tax overhaul a personal crusade convinced some hesitant politicians that it would be he, not they, who would feel any wrath from voters. Mr. Weicker has made it almost a point of pride that he may be a one-term governor.
* Never underestimate size of the problem you say you're solving. Mr. Weicker, who had said during the campaign that imposing an income tax during a recession would be like "pouring gasoline on a fire," argued after his election that the state's budget deficit and the recession were so great that only a sweeping tax overhaul could revive the economy. He warned of billions of dollars in deficits, when the only definitive deficit number available, which was for the year that ended on June 30, was well under $1 billion.
The governor's allies admitted that bad news made a good political climate. The bigger the looming deficit, they said, the greater need for a tax on wages.
"I wish it were $3 billion," Jerome P. Brown, president of District 1199 of the New England Health Care Employees Union said earlier this year.
But politicians around the country said the personal and political chemistry that combined here were unique to Connecticut. In New Hampshire, for example, which is preparing for a tax fight next year, the dynamic is exactly the opposite. There the legislature is moving toward adopting the tax and Gov. Judd Gregg has vowed to block it.
And other states do not have Mr. Weicker, whose lack of party support in the General Assembly almost seemed an advantage as coalitions formed and split over the dozens of tax plans floated during the summer.
"The Governor's no marshmallow," said state Senator Fred H. Lovegrove Jr., a Republican from Fairfield who opposed the tax and never believed it would pass. "He's proven to be a much more formidable opponent than I thought he would be."
But governors thinking of taking Mr. Weicker's tips should tread carefully. During the Depression, when many states imposed income or sales taxes for the first time to compensate for plummeting property taxes, governors who ran again afterwards were kicked out of office 24 percent of the time.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Teachers Flunk Democrats (And Vice Versa) in Jersey

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
With costs soaring and performance declining, New Jersey schools reopen this month amid a political free-for-all that began in earnest last month. The warring sides appear less concerned about why schoolchildren can't learn than about who is to blame.
Scholastic Aptitude Test scores released last week showed New Jersey students lagging behind an already declining national average. 
 The state government has taken over another large school district, Paterson, for what officials described as incompetence and lack of leadership. Education Commissioner John Ellis said he hopes to avoid a takeover in Newark, where the schools are also in trouble. Two years ago, in the first such seizure, state officials took control of the Jersey City schools, citing a pattern of corruption and educational failure.
All this turmoil occurs amid a new cash infusion this school year from legislation that Gov. Jim Florio optimistically called the Quality Education Act. And the aid package itself has caused a feud between New Jersey's Democratic legislative leadership and the education establishment to erupt into open political warfare.
The 136,000-member New Jersey Education Association that less than two years ago exulted in the election of Mr. Florio and a Democratic Legislature last month endorsed a slate almost exclusively Republican for the November elections, in which all 120 seats in the Legislature are at stake.
Behind the rupture in large part is the Democratically controlled Legislature's $360 million cutback this year in the education act it approved just last year. More important, in the view of Senate President John A. Lynch, is the teachers union's opposition to the strict, new spending caps on local school boards that he wrote into the legislation.
The teachers union president Betty Kraemer accuses the Democrats of "putting their election ahead of the children," while Mr. Lynch, who engineered the aid cutbacks earlier this year, accuses the teachers of "hiding behind" those same children to justify continued 8 to 10 percent annual salary increases in the face of declines in the economy, to say nothing of declines in student test scores. Last week, Democratic state chairman Philip Keegan, stung by the Republican endorsements, joined Mr. Lynch in attacking the union.
In announcing two weeks ago that the education association's political action committee had endorsed 46 Republicans and only three Democrats for the November legislative elections, a sharp reversal of its normal leanings, Ms. Kraemer said that "the Democrats turned their backs on educators, our schools and our students when they slashed $360 million from the original Quality Education Act."
That act, passed by the Legislature at the urging of the Governor last year, in part as a result of a court order that the state provide more aid to distressed districts, originally provided a record $1.1 billion in new aid to poorer and middle-income districts. The program quickly became political when Mr. Lynch led a fight to withhold $360 million on the grounds that if the entire amount went to the schools, none would be left to provide property tax relief to taxpayers, who are critical to the Governor and Democratic legislators' political survival amid a massive protest against a $2.8 billion tax increase.
While Mr. Lynch maintained that the teachers still had an $800 million windfall, the education association contended that schools were being forced to cut staff, supplies and programs. Mr. Lynch stops short of saying teachers are paid enough, but he often notes that close to $8 billion of the $10 billion spent annually on education in New Jersey goes to the salaries of teachers, administrators and staff.
Certainly, salaries have increased significantly since 1985, when Gov. Thomas H. Kean imposed an $18,500 starting minimum for teachers, creating a ripple effect that pushed all salaries up. Beginning teachers now average $22,000; those with advanced degrees and seniority in some districts earn more than $60,000. The average is about $39,000.
In announcing its pro-Republican slate, the teachers union specifically targeted Mr. Lynch for defeat, asking its 130,000 members to contribute "Ten for Tiller" -- $10 each to the campaign of Mr. Lynch's opponent, Edward Tiller.
Mr. Lynch says he is being singled out because he supports legislation limiting school spending increases to 7.5 to 9 percent in most districts, which makes raises difficult. Union leaders, he said, "despise the spending caps because they will help stop the double-digit teachers' salary hikes" that have been the norm for the last decade.
The political infighting intensified Thursday with a broadside from Mr. Keegan, the state democratic chairman, who wrote, "Betty Kraemer, and her ruling clique at the N. J. E. A., has brought shame and disgrace upon dedicated teachers throughout the state by selling out our kids, teachers and taxpayers." In an earlier open letter to Ms. Kraemer, he admonished, "Say it ain't so, Betty."
In an interview Thursday, Ms. Kraemer said the statements were designed to "split the members from the leadership through a personal attack." She also criticized Mr. Keegan's grammar, saying, "I hope he didn't attend a New Jersey public school."

HEADLINE: Jet Noise And the Economy

 BODY:
In a recent letter to the New Jersey editor responding to the article "Jet Noise: A New Battle Looms," James Muldoon, general manager of the aviation technical services division of the Port Authority, said that "we are hopeful that the Port Authority will adopt regulations that the states will view as appropriate and effective."
Considering the past performance of the New Jersey Assembly, this may be of little comfort to North Jerseyans, whom the extended East Coast Plan has blessed with constant jet noise and fuel residues. 
 When I recently urged Speaker Joseph V. Doria to finally bring A.4386 (which deals with Stage 2 phase-out) to the floor, he emphasized the need to gather more information on the possible economic impact: "Obviously, at the present time, given the economy of the nation and the state, we cannot afford to allow any type of commerce to be decreased as a result of government regulations."
I wrote once more to inquire what impact on the New Jersey economy was expected if airlines were asked to fly quieter planes out of Newark. Did Mr. Doria believe they would take their "commerce" to hopelessly oversaturated Kennedy or La Guardia Airports? Besides, flight paths could be shifted eastward, if the Federal Aviation Administration really tried.
His response was that any shifting might just move the problem elsewhere. (How many dolphins sit in the Assembly?) Only a reduction in total traffic from Newark would help, and that would certainly deprive New Jersey of revenue.
In one public hearing I attended, the F.A.A. said that shifting flight paths over the Atlantic would interfere with routes from the Caribbean to New England, and with military needs. In reality, shifting such a flight path 50 miles will increase flight time by 1 percent, boosting airlines' costs only slightly. The military has already admitted that in times of peace its claims on East Coast air space are excessive.
What it all boils down to is that both the state and the F.A.A. are more beholden to commerce than to the people. Many of us invested our life savings in a peaceful living space. Let aircraft users pay an extra dollar to keep it that way.
 
MAX J. SCHINDLER
Boonton

HEADLINE: Hard Work in Soviet Union Lies Ahead

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The jubilation over the dissolution of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the declaration of independence by a number of republics should not overshadow the tremendous economic, social and political problems facing the Russians and the many other nationalities of the Soviet Union. An entire superstructure of a state with 11 time zones and some 60 languages has collapsed.
Food and housing shortages, the tremendous rise of crime and the black market, the total worthlessness of the currency, the sudden unemployment of millions of unproductive bureaucrats, as well as the question of nuclear stockpiles throughout the territory -- all of these have to be addressed immediately.
Border, ethnic and religious disputes and differences, in addition to centuries of mistrust and hatred, may create a far more explosive situation than in Yugoslavia or anything else seen in this century.
The United States, Japan, the United Nations and the European Parliament and the European Community should all act together and without delay. Recognition of independence and congratulatory messages will not be enough. They should offer immediate financial and technical assistance, and be prepared to resolve border disputes, along with a rush of immigration and future population transfers.
 
GEORGE BOURNOUTIAN
Professor of Russian and Soviet
History, Iona College
