HEADLINE: Combine Higher Taxes and Savings Incentives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Pinch-Hitting for the Democrats: Invest in the Future? Yes, but How?" (editorial, Aug. 11) never proposes a solution to the pitiful United States personal savings rate. 
 Rather than increasing taxes -- hardest on the portion of the populace that votes the most, the elderly -- why not try something new?
Taxes generally cause people to do less of whatever is taxed, so that they can keep more of their money. Thus, with interest earned on most savings taxed at an average effective rate of more than 20 percent, Americans spend on goods and services, where they are taxed at 10 percent, tops.
But if Americans were given a tax credit on earned income -- say, $2,000 of credit on 5 percent or more saved -- an average middle-class household earning $40,000 would pinch pennies to save the 5 percent, or $2,000. That family would double its savings with such a tax credit.
This idea was originally whispered by our President about a year ago and then evaporated when Mr. Bush fled to some foreign land.
With nearly twice as much savings in American banks, interest rates would fall, and companies would again be able to borrow the cash they need for factories and fax machines. Any tax shortfall caused by the middle-income tax credit would be offset by increased tax revenue from a business sector rejuvenated by much lower interest rates, which would employ more people paying income taxes.
An additional benefit to national infrastructure would be a similar tax credit for those investing that 5 percent in United States savings bonds.
I don't care whether the Democrats use these ideas or George Bush picks them up, just as long as somebody leads us with a campaign that does not propose higher taxes without increased savings as the answer to our problems.
 
MICHAEL D. FRANK
Washington, Aug. 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Combine Higher Taxes and Savings Incentives;
We Need Stable Prices

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jeff Madrick gives insufficient attention to the risks of rising prices in "Recovery? The Economy Is a Mess" (Op-Ed, Aug. 14). The real achievement of the United States economy has been to contain inflation amid global inflation while suffering from a huge budget deficit, a weak dollar and increased local taxes. Any of these could have pushed the economy back to the double-digit inflation of the 1970's and early 80's. 
 Mr. Madrick calls the Federal Reserve Bank stubborn for keeping interest rates high just as the Federal funds rate is cut to its lowest since 1977. He suffers from the illusion that growth and inflation are alternatives, when the best foundation for growth is stable prices, a point made at our expense by Germany and Japan.
Mr. Madrick implies that the country would do better with some pump priming -- higher taxes, higher long-term interest rates, even bigger government. And this, just as tight monetary policy has at last reduced the cost of capital in the United States to the level paid in Japan. One trusts that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, does not heed the siren voices of easy growth.
 
DANIEL JEFFREYS
New York, Aug. 14, 1991

HEADLINE: Combine Higher Taxes and Savings Incentives;
Toll of Reaganomics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "On Reaganomics' 10th Birthday, Not All Celebrate" (The Week in Review, Aug. 11), you stress that although total taxes by all United States governments declined in the early Reagan years, as a result of the dramatic 1981 tax cut for high-income recipients, they "gradually climbed back to the level where they were when Mr. Reagan took office: slightly more than 27 percent of G.N.P." You note that the composition of the tax mix changed -- more revenue from Social Security taxes and "local taxes" -- yet your conclusion veils the inequity of that change. 
 "There have been some clear winners and losers," you state truly. But then you identify among the losers only "people who had invested heavily in tax shelters." And the winners, you state, "included wage earners with few deductions, credits or exclusions under the old tax law."
How those wage earners gained from changes in the law that merely reduced the tax evasions available to the rich isn't outstandingly obvious. The typical wage earner with few deductions became increasingly burdened by growing state and local taxes, largely increases in regressive sales and excise taxes, and user fees.
And what could be more regressive than the 8.6 percent increase since 1984 in the Social Security tax rate, which applies to 100 percent of the income of those earning less than approximately $54,000 and to only a diminishing proportion of the income of those earning more than $54,000?
Between 1981 and 1988, the 20 percent of Americans with incomes above $56,000 gained an almost 5 percent increase in their share of total income, while the lowest 20 percent suffered a loss of 10 percent. Meanwhile, unearned income gained stunningly over wages and salaries as a share of total income.
A more honest conclusion would include among the winners the very wealthy who make a major part of their living collecting rents and pushing financial instruments around, and among the major losers those who have tried to raise children and live on wages and salaries of $54,000 and less.
 
RICHARD M. ABRAMS
Prof. of History, U. of California
Berkeley, Calif., Aug. 11, 1991

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1142 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Lighter Bags, Shorter Trips

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
WHEN the travel industry bites a lemon, luggage makers pucker; since fewer people are taking vacations, luggage sales are expected to be down 5 percent for 1991. But as the luggage market adapts to tough times, it is producing changes that will interest people who are preparing to pack for school or others who, like me, have decided their current bags are too battered to continue.
The strong trend in consumer choices is away from hard suitcases and toward duffel bags, mainly big, some of which can be carried either by shoulder strap or handles, or enlarged versions of gym bags, soft satchels, big pouches, boat bags and the like. This shift is a direct outgrowth of the virtual halt in foreign travel during the Persian Gulf war and the continuing impact of the recession. 
 "People aren't taking big trips," Stan Schwarz, president of the Innovation luggage chain, said recently standing on the sidewalk in front of his store on Broadway and 56th Street. "They are just going over the bridge to visit an aunt." He circled his cigar toward the north, in the general direction of the George Washington Bridge. "So they want casual bags, not a traditional suitcase to hold 55 changes of clothes." He pointed to a window full of soft-sided bags in bright colors. "These things flatten to store, a good thing in New York," he said, this time waving south.
"The soft category is up 28 percent at Innovation since January," Mr. Schwarz said. Since overall sales will be flat or down, he said this growth was mainly at the expense of the traditional suitcase.
Robert K. Ermatinger, executive vice president of the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, confirmed the trends noted at Innovation, not surprising since Mr. Schwarz said he is the largest luggage dealer in North America. Mr. Ermatinger said that sales of big duffels rose 26 percent last year, and that other gainers were also soft-sided: garment bags and small totes. Bags that fold inside others, allowing for expansion on the return trip or for segregating dirty laundry, are increasingly popular. Chiao is offering one called a pancake, flat and round, as the name implies, which unzips around the edge to form a cylinder-shaped bag. It is $35.
With the trend, the quality of casual bags is improving: stronger fabrics, better waterproofing and stouter zippers.
In dollar volume, Innovation says its biggest seller is the Samsonite Silhouette 4 Ultra Valet fabric garment bag, model 617633, which sells for $220. The second seller is also a garment bag, the Boyt Mach II 42-inch long Walk-In Closet, model 34609, which sells for $370. The best-seller on the basis of unit sales represents the new trend. It is the black Lucas expandable carry-on, a duffel-style bag that expands, with zippers, from 21 inches to 25 inches in length. This one, model 872108, costs $70.
 
Testing Hard vs. Soft
 If you watch the flow at the airports, you see instantly that foreign travelers coming to the United States are still carrying "traditional" molded suitcases, and very big ones at that. Luggage handlers and luggage makers say that if a year's worth of belongings is going to travel as baggage, the hard case is the only sure way to get them there unshredded. At the Innovation store, customers from overseas were kneeling down to study the insides of big, hard cases. "Can't sell soft sides to them," Mr. Schwarz said. "For security, nothing matches the hard Pullman."
But Consumer Reports did not concur when it evaluated luggage in the June 1990 issue. Eggs were wrapped in padding and placed in both types of bags. Then the bags were tumbled in a rotating drum intended to replicate the sort of bouncing around that bags get from airlines. The eggs in the soft-sided bags survived better than those in the hard bags, which transmitted the impact of the falls. However, when the bags were laid on the floor and a 200-person stepped on them, the hard bags protected the eggs better.
On a hard bag, the quality of the latch and lock is of great importance; on a fabric bag, it is the zipper that should be strong.
The hard cases are themselves heavier than canvas ones, and bigger -- 29 to even 32 inches wide -- and trying to move these things fully laden is difficult. If you must carry all your bags yourself, as when you pass Customs, the big cases almost invariably require attached wheels and a pull strap at one corner. But anyone who has used a strap to drag a full suitcase has discovered that they are top-heavy and fall sideways as you turn a corner. Also, when the bags pop out on the luggage carousel, the little metal casters with sharp metal bases seem to cause many tears in other fabric suitcases. Often enough a wheel is gone, probably a victim of a similar mischance.
Some suitcases have larger plastic or hard rubber wheels, set into the corners, and these balance better, although they do not swivel for steering. The models that have the wheels on the shorter dimension of an oblong case, like those Asian students seem to favor, are rolled along rather than dragged, but one per person is about the limit here.
 
Mishandled Bags
 Most air travelers believe that the amount of carry-on luggage has increased, apparently because flight attendants are loath to challenge travelers in a time when planes are flying nowhere near their load limits. Salespeople in luggage departments around New York say that customers are still worried about losing their bags and generally want to buy items they can carry aboard.
However, according to Department of Transportation figures, travelers' complaints to the airlines about "mishandled" luggage -- lost, damaged, delayed or pilfered -- were down in June this year, compared with June last year. The figures for 1991 showed a total of 182,902 customer complaints to the separate airlines, a rate of 5.04 for each 1,000 domestic passengers, as against the total of 230,693 complaints in 1990, a rate of 6.56 for each 1,000 domestic passengers.
The number of complaints addressed to the department itself about mishandled baggage was 109 in June 1991, as against 91 in June 1990. Hoyte B. Decker Jr., the assistant director for consumer affairs in the department, said there was no way to judge why the total of complaints to airlines -- necessary for any restitution -- and of complaints to the department went in opposite directions.
There is one factor favoring bigger bags: on domestic trips, airlines charge by the bag, not by the pound, for surplus luggage. The amount can be pretty big, but varies by airline and even by city, according to Bill Jackman of the Air Transport Association. As a sample, American and United generally accept three bags free and charge $45 each for bags number 4 to 7 and $65 each for bags 8, 9 and 10. Continental's surcharge begins at $35 a bag.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5182 words

HEADLINE: Off Course

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle reports on economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:
FROM USAIR'S GLASS-ENCLOSED TOWER, Greater Pittsburgh International Airport seems asleep. Nearly 40 airliners nuzzle quietly along wharflike terminals, like giant, docile porpoises. The planes are taking on passengers, but the tower crew can't see the activity. What is visible through the tower's panoramic windows at 4:30 P.M. on a busy weekday is a vast, empty airfield.
But then the porpoises, twin-engined DC-9's and Boeing 737's, come alive. At 4:35, the first backs away from the terminal. "Gate One is pushing," says Kim Hunter, the young tower chief. In minutes, more than 30 planes are under way. Swarming and mingling, they seem almost to greet each other before falling gradually into line and taxiing to the runways. A USAir fleet is departing, and for the fifth time since early morning a deserted airport becomes a congested one. 
 Nothing so stands out as the hallmark of airline deregulation -- the removal of Government controls over routes and fares -- than these surges of activity that all but overwhelm even the largest airports at certain times, only to fade to eerie quiet at others. Since deregulation became law in 1978, the airlines have put together their own version of a mass transit system that moves more planes to more places more frequently than anyone ever imagined. From 29 "hub" airports across the nation, the airlines send out fleets of aircraft, draw them back and quickly send them out again to "spoke" towns and cities, generating more than 14,000 domestic flights a day.
But not without considerable pain for consumers, and for many of the airlines themselves. Witness the near death this summer of that pioneer of commercial aviation, Pan American World Airways, which lacked the foresight and resources to develop the hub operations essential to profitability in today's airline industry. The hub-and-spoke system that has dominated air travel since the mid-80's was never envisioned by the authors of deregulation; it evolved only after a handful of major airlines discovered that by controlling the flow of traffic in and out of large, strategically placed airports, they would gain much of the same power over routes and fares that the Government once exercised.
Spewing out flights in every direction, the hub-based mass transit system is not, by nature, user-friendly. The graceful rhythms of a fleet departure, so arresting a sight from USAir's traffic control tower, are lost on passengers squeezed into narrow seats inside an airliner that's been stuck for more than a quarter of an hour on the Tarmac.
Such irritations have undoubtedly contributed to the erosion of public support for deregulation that the Roper Organization, in its national opinion polls, has found over the years. A decade ago, only 17 percent of Americans polled expressed dissatisfaction with deregulation and supported more Government controls. That figure rose to 36 percent last October. Most of the increase came in the mid-80's, just as the hub airports were coming into their own.
"The biggest complaint is delays, and two-thirds of these are weather-related," says Cornish Hitchcock, legal director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project in Washington. With the hub-and-spoke system, a local rainstorm can have a ripple effect. "You can be sitting in Chicago, waiting for a flight to Boston," he says, "and you are told that the aircraft you are supposed to take hasn't reached Dallas, much less Chicago, because it is raining in Phoenix."
Even on this cloudless June afternoon in Pittsburgh, an ideal flying day, the USAir fleet is experiencing the kind of nettlesome delays that Department of Transportation data show to be endemic to the world of hub and spoke. One late arrival from Los Angeles, Flight 82, is disrupting operations, threatening to make not only its own pasengers late, but also hundreds of others.
Flight 82 is 28 minutes behind schedule, and nearly half of its 102 passengers have paid for seats on more than 20 connecting flights, six of which are now forced to delay their departures. Through the radio chatter in the tower, Hunter keeps abreast of Flight 82's passengers hurrying through the terminal and of baggage handlers rushing to transfer suitcases to waiting planes.
A DC-9 bound for Norfolk is the first of the laggards to cast off, having picked up two of the Los Angeles passengers. Three other travelers now board a plane to Buffalo, three more take a connecting flight to Newport News, Va., and two more to Syracuse. A flight to Erie, Pa., which waits for 10 passengers from the Los Angeles flight, is still boarding them and their luggage 15 minutes past its departure time. Hunter considers releasing the plane, which would leave some ticket holders, or their bags, stranded. "You tend to be more liberal late in the day, because you don't want people stuck here overnight," she says, deciding to stretch the deadline. The Erie flight finally rolls off at 5 o'clock -- 20 minutes behind schedule for a 38-minute flight.
THE GREAT PROMISE OF AIRLINE deregulation -- vigorous competition among numerous carriers that would keep fares low -- is fading. The system was supposed to provide travelers with a buyer's market of choices in airlines, flights and fares, and, in fact, there are more flights now than before deregulation. But a much lower percentage of them are nonstop, adding hours and stress to many trips. Even a short 316-mile flight from Birmingham, Ala., to New Orleans normally requires an almost absurd detour to a hub -- a plane change in Atlanta, Memphis or Nashville that turns a trip of less than one hour's flying time into a four-hour odyssey. The trade-off for these inconveniences was supposed to be lower fares, but they, too, are beginning to disappear.
Passengers are not the only ones who have suffered under deregulation. Continental, T.W.A., Midway and America West, all once prosperous carriers, are either operating in bankruptcy or very close to it. A fifth, Eastern, died in January, and Pan Am has greatly shrunk, having sold off most of its remaining routes to Delta. More than ever, the danger exists that the airline industry could "collapse into a tight little oligopoly, controlled by a handful of firms," Kenneth M. Mead, director of transportation issues for the General Accounting Office, told a House committee recently. But the oligopoly is already here. Today, five airlines -- American, United, Delta, Northwest and USAir -- dominate air travel in the United States, handling 71 percent of all the traffic and, like ward bosses, controlling 21 of the nation's 29 hub airports.
Twice before in the 70-year history of commercial aviation, the airlines have undergone consolidation. The first round was in the 1920's, when the United States Post Office awarded rich mail-carrying contracts to a few airlines, choosing from among the numerous tiny companies that were competing for a foothold. A second contraction was set in motion after a political scandal ended the Post Office's power to subsidize airlines. But the Roosevelt Administration soon created the Civil Aeronautics Authority, later renamed the Civil Aeronautics Board, to divvy up routes and set uniform fares.
The act of deregulation was a new wrinkle. With high inflation plaguing Americans in the 1970's, the airlines and the bureaucratic C.A.B. had become lightning rods for public wrath. In another era, the solution might have been Federal subsidies to lower fares. But laissez-faire economics was all the rage, and the answer that emerged, pushed by President Carter himself, was a wide-open marketplace. The theory was that this would produce many new airlines and much fare cutting, which would provide Americans not only with cheaper air travel but also lower inflation.
The cheap travel and numerous new airlines did, for a while, materialize. But in time, the major airlines, groping for ways to eliminate the new competition, came up with the hugely expensive hub system, which effectively shut out the young, underfunded challengers. Virtually all the small airlines born in the early years of deregulation, including People Express, New York Air and Capitol, soon died off -- a graveyard of nearly 200 in 13 years.
ONCE AIRLINE ROUTES WERE STRAIGHT LINES between cities drawn by the Government, but today they are designed by the airlines themselves, radiating like the ribs of an umbrella from hub airports. And whatever changes deregulation brings next, the hub-and-spoke system seems certain to be with us for a very long time. Despite the congestion and the passenger inconveniences, no one is pressing to do away with what is, from the airlines' viewpoint, a wonderfully efficient setup. The endless flights from outlying cities to a hub and then out again help fill seats and keep planes constantly in use -- increasing revenues.
"When you have 20 people from some small city going to 20 different destinations, you can put them all on one plane, fly them to a hub like Pittsburgh and then scatter them," says David A. Swierenga, an assistant vice president of the Air Transport Association of America, the airlines' trade group.
The hubs are also labor saving. One shift of USAir employees -- including Hunter's tower crew, ticket agents, baggage handlers, mechanics and supervisors -- handles not only the late afternoon fleet and its horde of passengers, but four other incoming and outgoing fleets: a total of nearly 200 flights.
Then there is the leverage that an airline, monopolizing a hub, exercises over local passengers. More than 30 percent of the travelers passing through Pittsburgh International, for example, begin or end their journeys in that city. Since USAir handles 85 percent of the traffic into and out of the airport, these passengers find themselves forced to pay ticket prices well above average. The same is true of most of the other hubs, where local customers end up paying premium fares -- roughly 10 to 15 percent above the norm.
"The real payoff in operating a hub airport," says Severin Borenstein, an economist specializing in the airline industry at the University of California at Davis, "comes from the travelers who either begin or end their journeys at the hub."
The nonlocals, those merely changing planes at a hub, can bargain better. If USAir seems to charge too much to go from, say, Akron, Ohio, to New York's LaGuardia Airport via Pittsburgh, there are other routes, via other hubs. You can take a Delta commuter plane into that airline's Cincinnati hub, then fly to New York in a Delta jet; or grab a Northwest flight to Northwest's Detroit hub and from there make a direct connection to LaGuardia. Luring travelers through their hubs is the main thrust of competition among the airlines.
Tellingly, that competition never reaches the point of trying to take over a rival's hub. When American sought one in North Carolina several years ago, rather than going through the expense and energy of trying to dislodge USAir from that airline's Charlotte hub, it went the easier route by centering its operations in nearby Raleigh-Durham. (The few cases in which airlines share a hub -- American and United at Chicago's O'Hare Airport, United and Continental at Denver's Stapleton Airport, Delta and Northwest at Boston's Logan Airport and American and Delta at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport -- are largely holdovers from pre-deregulation days.) "The airlines compete between their hubs, not at them," says Patrick V. Murphy Jr., Deputy Assistant Secretary at the Department of Transportation.
YET DESPITE THE NUMEROUS flights through the different hubs, it is not always easy to get an affordable seat. Those passengers who pay full price in coach or first class, spending more than in the days before deregulation, have quick and unlimited use of the system. But the great majority of passengers purchase discount tickets, which restricts their access to flights. It would be the same if subway riders could buy half-price tokens that would be valid only for every fourth or fifth train that enters the station. "You are paying a premium for the right to travel anytime you want," says Barbara R. Amster, vice president for ticket pricing at American Airlines.
But discount tickets aren't the bargain they once were, either. Gone is the wild fare-cutting, when a People Express offered a $99 one-way, coast-to-coast ticket and others matched the rock-bottom price. Today, the New York-Los Angeles fare rarely drops below $200. And while airline tickets -- full fare and discount combined -- cost substantially less now, on average, than in 1978, the low point came in 1987. Since then, fares have been inching up.
Newspaper ads still herald eye-popping bargains, of course, but they usually don't last long, and the restrictions can be daunting. Passengers are often obliged to purchase tickets at least seven days in advance, to buy round trip (with no refund for cancellation), to travel in the early morning or late afternoon, to stay over Saturday night, to use their tickets by a certain date and, most important, to change planes -- sometimes doubling or even tripling the length of a journey.
This proliferation of rules limits the number of tickets sold and the pressure on competing airlines to match the bargains. "Fares may not rise," says Julius Maldutis, an airline industry analyst at Salomon Brothers, "but the availability of discounts will shrink, and the size of the discounts will also shrink."
THE AIRLINES ARE, IN FACT, DILIGENTLY working toward this goal. Their method is called yield management, a formidable computerized system of frequently repricing seats on every upcoming flight until the day the plane departs. Barbara Amster, vice president for ticketing at American Airlines, is a master of the game.
Amster, 44, was born and raised in New York City. Starting as a reservations clerk 24 years ago, she moved up American's ranks, always selling tickets, and in 1977 was transferred south to its corporate headquarters at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport. Now she is seated at her office desk, examining my airline ticket. Her nasal voice and frequent staccato laugh are pleasantly scornful.
"This is my kind of guy, all right," she says, noting that I had paid $530 -- full coach fare -- to fly from New York to Dallas on American. "We'll definitely bring you a cup of coffee."
Her secretary does, also in good humor. I had purchased my round-trip ticket eight days in advance. At the time, the computers had shown $530 to be the least expensive fare available on such short notice for a nonstop flight. But a day or two later, having not sold enough seats, Amster's staff opened up some places at $466, requiring only three days' advance purchase. I was out $64.
"What you should have done," Amster advises, "was purchase your ticket and get wait-listed for the three-day advance fare." Only then, she explains, would American have notified me that a cheaper seat had become available.
She continues the lesson. American has 2,450 jet departures a day. Each flight averages more than 12 different published fares, whose availability is juggled constantly. A businessman traveling from Austin to the Dallas-Fort Worth hub might be told that no seats are available on his chosen flight, even at full coach fare. But a vacationer on the same flight to Dallas who is then going on to New York -- or, better yet, London -- has no problem getting a seat. Even with an excursion fare, the vacationer is paying far more for his long journey than the business traveler making the one-hour hop to Dallas.
"I have to see how many people I can get to give me the most money," Amster says. Then, leaning across her desk, she draws a diagram, dividing the 190 seats on a Dallas-to-New York flight into various groups. Fifteen are assigned a "yield," or value, of $600 apiece, 15 more of $400 and so on down the scale to about $100. The traveler from Austin-to-Dallas-to-New York is paying enough to be assigned a $400 value on the Dallas-New York leg.
There are other tricks in Amster's bag. Sixty days before the flight, the greatest demand is for the lowest excursion fares, but few are put up for sale. "You don't want to sell too many of these and lose the higher-paying traveler who books late," she says.
Forty days before a flight, a traveler might be told that a $268 round-trip excursion fare, requiring 30 days' advance purchase, is sold out. He then buys a higher-priced discount ticket, paying, say, $318. But five days later, the anticipated demand for more expensive seats has not surfaced, and the $268 fare goes back on sale. Early planning results in a $50 loss.
"If we are too optimistic about selling the expensive seats, we lose sales at the $400 level," Amster says. "But I'd rather lose those than the $600 seats."
MARCHING TO THIS strategy, the airlines change fares 80,000 times every day, and slowly their revenues seem to be rising. Five years ago, average revenue paid by each passenger on the nation's airlines had fallen to 11.08 cents a mile from 12.74 cents in 1981. These were the go-go years when People Express, New York Air and other newcomers were selling all their seats at bargain prices. The explosion of cheap air travel made folk heroes of entrepreneurs like Donald C. Burr, founder of People Express. Frank A. Lorenzo, whose New York Air slashed shuttle fares in the Northeast, was also acclaimed, until his bitter struggles with the unions at Eastern cast him in the role of villain.
After initially attempting to match the challengers, the established airlines stumbled on yield management. They found that by offering a relatively small number of low-priced seats, they were able to lure away enough passengers to put the upstarts out of business, which they did in the mid-80's. Since 1986, revenue per passenger mile has steadily risen to an average of more than 13 cents, despite the problems that beset the industry during the recession and the Persian Gulf crisis.
But the new stability in revenues came too late for some airlines. The problems of Eastern, Pan Am, T.W.A., America West and Midway -- high debt, lack of capital, inadequate equipment or bad management -- have crippled their chances to play the hub-and-spoke game against the big airlines.
"It is unfortunate that people are being hurt," says Clifford Winston, an airline expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington and a passionate advocate of deregulation. "But this happens in free markets. The least efficient drop out."
IN THIS LATEST chapter in commercial aviation history, American, United and Delta have become the most powerful, their fleets blanketing the country. More and more, their planes are also coming and going from abroad. The big three are rapidly adding flights to Europe, the Far East and Latin America, purchasing overseas routes from T.W.A. and Pan Am, taking over their roles as the nation's principal overseas carriers. Above all, the expansion abroad helps fill flights within the United States. A resident of Wichita, Kan., or Oklahoma City, traveling to London, is likely today to fly American into its Dallas-Fort Worth hub and then cross the Atlantic on that airline's nightly flight from Dallas.
The frequent-flyer programs offered by American, United and Delta -- the most comprehensive in the industry -- are another weapon that assures their domination. Once a customer accumulates enough miles, the big three offer a much greater variety of trips in this country and abroad than other airlines. "We can't offer the world and that hurts us," says Edward R. Beauvais, chairman and founder of America West, an eight-year-old airline whose operations are concentrated in the West. It filed for bankruptcy in June to avoid paying creditors.
Another big advantage for American and United is that they own or control the two computer reservation systems most used by travel agents to book flights. (Eighty-five percent of all reservations are made through travel agents.) While every airline's flights and fares are listed in each giant system (called Sabre and Apollo), control gives American and United an edge in getting agents to steer customers their way. Among other things, the two airlines give free use of Sabre and Apollo to agents who book a minimum number of flights. Just using the computer terminals to make reservations on airlines other than American and United is harder, requiring more key strokes.
But of all the muscles the big three can flex, perhaps the biggest -- and most worrisome to smaller competitors -- is overseas expansion. It is of particular concern to Edwin I. Colodny, chairman of USAir, which has only a handful of overseas flights. Under Colodny, now 65, USAir grew from a regional carrier in the Northeast, called Allegheny, to a national one, renamed USAir, that expanded and prospered by acquiring faltering airlines.
But Colodny concedes that USAir might not be strong enough to make the next big leap necessary to survival in the age of deregulation -- the acquisition of overseas routes. While the big three battled until mid-August over what was left of Pan Am's global network, USAir, despite flourishing hubs in Pittsburgh and three other cities, lacked the huge capital to get into the bidding. "Ultimately," Colodny says, "USAir might have to ally with a foreign airline, or be acquired by one of the big American carriers."
AT THIS JUNCTURE IN the deregulation sweepstakes, American Airlines looks like the biggest winner, enjoying greater prosperity than even United or Delta (in spite of the latter's expansion with the purchase last month of many Pan Am routes). So it is no surprise that one of the country's most tireless boosters of airline deregulation is American's 55-year-old chairman, Robert L. Crandall. With his strong hands, rugged face and slightly off-center nose, Crandall could easily be mistaken for a mechanic from his own airline. But his bluntness and zeal have made him the industry's most visible spokesman.
"There is a great debate brewing that is solidly rooted in misunderstanding and misinformation," Crandall says, sitting in his office at the company's Dallas-Fort Worth headquarters. "It has to do with the supposition of a good many people that in order to have competiton you have to have 15 domestic airlines. In fact, 15 domestic airlines would create less competition than three domestic airlines."
Superairlines are necessary, Crandall asserts, to reduce overcapacity (four out of every 10 seats go unfilled) and to go head-to-head with well-heeled, often Government-subsidized foreign carriers in international competition. The corollary to this argument is that the United States Government, in assigning overseas routes, should give preference to American, United, Delta and Northwest.
There is an arrogance to Crandall's line of thinking, but also a logic. The major airlines operate on very small profit margins, even in good times, and so far this year they have lost billions of dollars to war-related fuel increases and travel declines. To assure profits, Crandall says, fares must rise about 6 percent above present levels. And to make possible these higher fares, the industry inevitably will have to shrink.
"Fares have to go up," says Crandall, voicing a sentiment that few airline executives would disagree with. "If the public wants to have an airline industry at all, and if the public wants new airplanes and safe airplanes and adequate terminals, they have to be paid for."
The Crandall philosophy is loaded with irony. His prescription for the industry -- fewer airlines and higher fares -- was precisely what airline deregulation was intended to eliminate. Moreover, opponents of deregulation, like Paul S. Dempsey, a transportation expert at the University of Denver, see nothing but rising fares on the horizon. "We know the survivors will be rational wealth maximizers inclined to raise fares to super levels," he says.
In pursuit of more passengers and higher fares, Crandall has violated a taboo within his industry that is decades old: selling safety. In the July issue of American Way, the airline's magazine, Crandall insinuated that the big airlines were safer than the smaller ones because they could afford the required maintenance.
But Anthony J. Broderick, the F.A.A.'s associate administrator for regulation and certification, contends that American and the other large carriers have accident records that are virtually indistinguishable from those of the smaller airlines. For the industry as a whole, fatalities have dropped to all-time low levels over the last 15 years, in part because new computer monitoring technology has made aircraft more reliable.
The safety issue is complicated, however. The hubs themselves push acceptable safety limits when fleets converge on airports, increasing the stress on pilots and air traffic controllers. With planes coming in only 30 seconds apart, controllers sometimes find themselves rapidly issuing instructions to five or six approaching aircraft, never knowing for sure if their messages have been received.
Kit Darby, a co-pilot for United, has experienced these bursts of instructions many times. "It would be nice if they would give you time to repeat the information back to them," he says. "In my plane, there are three of us listening to check what we thought we heard with each other."
HISTORY HAS inscribed Alfred E. Kahn as the father of airline deregulation. As chairman of the C.A.B. under President Carter, he was the man who led the dismantling of the Government's power to award routes and set fares. But Kahn, now 73 and living near Ithaca, N.Y., acknowledges that the system he wrought is idiosyncratic and perhaps drifting dangerously off course.
Kahn likes to tell the following story: Three years ago, he received an invitation from his old boss. "President Carter invited the people who had worked with him down to lunch in Atlanta on a Monday," he recalls, "and I wanted to go and come back on the same day. It was $560 round trip. So my travel agent got me two discount round-trip tickets, each requiring a weekend's stayover, and I threw away the two extremes and the trip cost me only $355." (Half of one round-trip ticket permitted him to fly to Atlanta on the chosen Monday morning; the other ticket's return leg allowed him to fly home that afternoon.)
Would Kahn go back to regulating fares? No, he replies. He still favors allowing the marketplace to set ticket prices, although he acknowledges that the process breeds confusion, inequities and annoyances among consumers. "I cannot deny the increased resentment of passengers," he says, "not only at the stopovers, but at the proliferation of fares and how much harder it is to be a good shopper today. And the crowding."
But, says Kahn, that's the way the system is supposed to work. The theory is, you get what you pay for. It's the old tradeoff of uncomfortable travel for low fares. What bothers Kahn is that this old tradeoff, which seemed to thrive in the early years of deregulation, is now skewed. Discounts are less abundant, but discomforts aren't.
Kahn, in part, blames the Reagan and Bush Administrations. "A Government sensitive to predatory pricing might have helped retain more competition in the form of more airlines," he says. Antitrust laws, Kahn argues, should have been invoked. "If I were in charge of the antitrust division," he says, "I would damn well see if I could build a case that yield management is predatory pricing."
So why didn't he raise the antitrust objections when he was in charge? Kahn says that in the fall of 1978, just before airline deregulation officially started, he became concerned about the potential for damaging mergers. While vacationing with his wife in Venice, he drafted a memo outlining his fears. But after Kahn returned to Washington, President Carter pulled him out of the C.A.B., which would be slowly dismantled over the next few years, and put him in charge of fighting inflation as chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability.
"I never was able to follow up," Kahn says, a little wistfully. "It is hard for anyone who was not there at the time to appreciate the way in which the forces began to take on a momentum of their own."
FOR ALL OF deregulation's problems, no one in official Washington has yet called for a return to full-scale Government regulation. But some would at least take the rough edges off deregulation. Under a bill now before the House, life would become easier for the faltering airlines. They would have more access to landing slots at the airports of their competitors and more leverage over the computer reservation systems controlled by American and United. In addition, the reassignment of overseas routes, now dominated by the big three, would be supervised by the Government to insure that the smaller airlines got a bigger share. Finally, the legislation would permit foreign carriers to own up to 49 percent of a United States airline's voting stock, if that airline was in danger of failing for lack of capital. The current limit is 25 percent.
The Bush Administration, recognizing that a few foreign airlines already have major investments in American carriers (among them, KLM in Northwest, S.A.S. in Continental), strongly supports an increase in foreign ownership up to 49 percent. But the Administration shows signs of going a step further, allowing foreign carriers to operate routes within the United States itself. It is not far-fetched to envision British Airways someday flying direct from New York or Chicago to St. Louis, even taking over T.W.A.'s big hub there if that airline goes under.
Some Administration officials foresee American carriers making similar inroads abroad, particularly as deregulation takes hold in Europe and the Far East. "I believe that the airlines of the future will be multinational companies," Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner says. "They will operate in each other's countries, like many manufacturing corporations do today."
Skinner draws an analogy with the auto industry. Just as General Motors and Ford have big manufacturing operations in Europe, and as Nissan, Honda and Toyota have factories in the United States, so airlines would set up shop around the globe.
But airlines aren't auto manufacturers. Building and selling cars in the United States is a penny-ante proposition compared with the gigantic costs of establishing a hub here, when the best hub cities are already taken. Acquiring American carriers, like T.W.A. or USAir, might be the least troublesome and least costly means of a foreign airline's gaining entry.
But what if Congress doesn't buy the idea? Without the intervention of foreign airlines -- or some Government regulation to protect the weaker carriers -- airline industry contraction seems destined to continue. "Eventually," says the University of California's Severn Borenstein, "the number of major airlines might be reduced to just a few, or possibly even one."

PUB-DATE: September 1, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 14; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1711 words

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Farewell, Red Menace: U.S. Starts Altering Its Perspective on the World

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 31

 BODY:
Just when the United States had adjusted to the idea that the Kremlin had turned from implacable enemy to benign adversary, the breathtaking events in the Soviet Union have forced the country to confront the possibility that soon there may be no adversary there at all.
 The sudden prospect that the Soviet Union will cease to exist in its current form has implications that go far beyond Soviet-American relations, and the Soviet upheaval has already forced the Bush Administration to begin re-examining its fundamental policy goals. 
So far, Bush Administration officials, as stunned as everyone by the events in Moscow, are focusing on short-term problems and making only modest changes in policy.
 
Direct Aid to Republics
 The White House made clear this week, for example, that it was prepared to send humanitarian aid directly to the republics, bypassing the collapsing central Government in Moscow. It also was encouraging the Soviet Union to maintain at least an economic union, and taking advantage of the upheaval to press Moscow to reduce military spending.
 For 45 years, the Soviet Union has been the lens through which American foreign policy around the world and American military thinking, especially nuclear strategy, have been focused.
 The threat of Communism has been at the heart of virtually every crisis the United States has faced since World War II, crystallizing national resolve in such seminal events as the Berlin airlift of 1948 and the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, or convulsing American society in darker passages, like the Vietnam War.
 
Pervaded American Life
 Fear of Communism and the Kremlin has touched almost every aspect of American life -- literature, theater, the movies, television, the universities, main street.
 Always painted in menacing shadows, the Kremlin has been a powerful and at times distorting influence on domestic politics since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, from the anti-Communist raids led by Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer in 1919 to the witch hunts and blacklists of the McCarthy period in the 1950's to the Reagan Administration's politically divisive efforts to roll back Soviet influence in Nicaragua in the 1980's.
 The effort to repel Communism was the binding force of the modern conservative coalition, helping to keep Republicans in the White House, and the specter of the Soviet enemy has helped define the nation's image of itself as the defender of threatened freedoms. The Soviet Union was the yardstick by which Americans measured their successes and their place in the world: the fear of losing the space race and falling behind in science when Sputnik soared into orbit in 1957, for example, or the national jubilation when sledgehammers tore into the Berlin Wall in 1989, and now for many a sense that the American-led stand against Communism and the Soviet Union has succeeded beyond anyone's expectations.
 
The 'New World Order' Ages
 When President Bush offered his "new world order" a year ago to explain why the nation had to face war with Iraq during another tumultuous August, he grounded his vision on the assumption that there would continue to be a Soviet Union -- much like the one that had existed since 1917, just friendlier and less of a military threat.
 Last week, the President seemed to acknowledge the passing of that epoch. "Out of this change in the Soviet Union, if we handle it properly and if things keep going forward instead of slipping back, there's an opportunity for a vastly restructured national security posture," he said.
 Cautious as ever, he added, "It's way too early -- way too early -- to get into that."
 But even as he spoke, his Government was in the early stages of what eventually may be a fundamental rewriting of American policy, and a new debate was quickly developing in Washington about whether to make deeper cuts in the Pentagon budget.
 The short-term questions the Administration is studying are perplexing enough: Who are the new people taking over the Soviet Union? Will Mikhail S. Gorbachev or Boris N. Yeltsin emerge the nation's leader? Who is in control of the Soviet nuclear arsenal? How much food will the Soviet Union need this winter?
 "All we can do now is to try to do everything we can think of to position ourselves to be able to move rapidly when the situation clarifies," a senior official said.
 
More Fundamental Questions
 But beyond these questions are more fundamental ones, each of which may require sweeping changes in American policy. Will the central Soviet Government survive, and if not, what will emerge? How will the United States do business with four or five or more Governments where there is now one? What are the responsibilities of the United States as the only superpower in what used to be a two-superpower world? Against whom is the United States now arming itself militarily and ideologically?
 "We've got to begin to lay an intellectual base for U.S. involvement in the world, a rationale that people understand and support and around which you can build a consensus, as was done with containment," said Representative Lee Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana. Mr. Hamilton was referring to the goal of "containing" the Soviet bloc, which was set soon after World War II and has been the driving force behind American policy on the Soviet Union since then.
 Already, the upheaval in Moscow has complicated a central aim of American foreign policy over the last two years: maintaining influence in Western Europe.
 
Justification for NATO
 "We've been talking for some time now about how to manage the breakdown of the cold war institutions, like NATO, without boxing us out of Europe," an Administration official said. "That was hard enough with the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and it's much harder now."
 The United States will be "looking to the European Community to pick up a major share of the financial burden" as Soviet republics emerge as countries, an American official said.
 The Bush Administration was confident before the coup that it had forestalled the demise of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but that debate is now rejoined. What will justify NATO's existence if there is no Soviet military from which to protect Western Europe?
 Caspar W. Weinberger, the former Secretary of Defense, argued that the military threat was not gone as long as whatever form of country emerged retained an enormous nuclear arsenal and a large conventional military.
 But Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said the United States should consider a security system that might include Poland, Hungary and even some former Soviet republics, like the Baltics, after they are free. "We ought to take a careful look at people who share our same ethos for democracy and market economics and right now are in a netherworld with regard to security," Mr. Lugar said.
 
Questions About Asia
 The Bush Administration also faces important questions about its dealings with Asia, where the Soviet Union is less important and Japan is increasingly powerful.
 Domestically, the Administration will argue that there is a need for a strong American military, citing the threat posed by Iraq last summer as a clear example. That may buy some time. But it is increasingly apparent that with the potential breakup of the Soviet Union, the current basis for American nuclear policy may not be enough to hold a consensus for military spending.
 Despite all the changes of the last two years, that policy is still based on the principle of "strategic deterrence" -- the amassing of nuclear weapons, initially to deter a Soviet attack on Western Europe and more recently to deter a Soviet nuclear attack.
 The American intelligence community, as well, is being challenged to change from an organization devoted to spying on the Soviet Union and thwarting its foreign policy to one that deals with a more diverse world.
 As perceptions and attitudes change, longstanding principles are already colliding with pragmatic goals. In the Soviet Union, the United States is torn between its support for self-determination and the Administration's belief that central control over the military, trade and foreign aid and some aspects of foreign policy is desirable to maintain stability.
 
Political Considerations
 Politically, Republicans have held on to the White House in large measure because of the perception that their party has been better equipped to safeguard the national security, even if opinion polls say that they do not handle the economy as well as Democrats.
 But the disappearance of a Soviet enemy stands that notion on its head. It may no longer be enough simply to argue, as Mr. Bush does, that the United States has a responsibility to keep the peace and, in fact, is the only country that can do so.
 "People are very proud of the fact that the United States is the superpower and the leader in the world," Mr. Hamilton said. "At the same time, they think we can better solve our problems at home if we scale down our efforts overseas. They've got a real doubt in their minds about whether they want to pay the taxes and send the young men and women abroad in support of that role."
 As the Soviet Union undergoes its metamorphosis, even vocabularies will haveto change. American officials now grope for a word to describe the Soviet Union. Certainly, the word "Kremlin" is losing its symbolism as the monolith of Soviet power. Hard-line, conservative, liberal, Communist, all have new meanings -- or no meaning at all.
 There is little in the modern American experience to prepare Washington for this upheaval.
 "The challenge now is the transformation of a vast empire and that was never part of our agenda," said Richard Perle, former Assistant Secretary of Defense.
 Mr. Perle added: "Our international agenda for 40 years was much more modest, to cope with the Soviet Union, which we saw as a military threat, not to transform the Soviet Union itself. Even the rollback policy, which was considered adventurist in the cold war, never contemplated involving the United States in the transformation of Soviet society or the Soviet republics."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1166 words

HEADLINE: Focus: The Southeast;
Home Builders Are Hungering for Credit

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: ANDERSON, S.C.

 BODY:
SAM HAMMOND usually builds 10 houses a year in this northwestern South Carolina city and its vicinity. But so far this year, he has built just one. And he had to use his own money to do it.
Several hundred miles south of here in Fort Myers, Fla., a golf course and surrounding middle-income housing development probably will not be built at all. Larry Swank, a builder and developer in Nappanee, Ind., and four others cannot borrow the money to buy the land. 
 And east of here, in Columbia, S.C., Bill Johnston may lose Federal tax credits because he has not found a permanent loan for a low-income apartment complex, despite eight months of searching.
The National Association of Home Builders estimates that 15 percent of the nation's 390,000 builders have ceased building houses, due in large measure to the problems they've had borrowing money.
Here in the Southeast, the so-called "credit crunch" has driven some builders into bankruptcy, while others have sought work in other fields. Some are taking odd jobs, renovations and the like, to get them through the lean times.
"Most of them are just devastated," said Ken Mitchell, the executive director of the North Carolina Home Builders Association. "Through no fault of their own," he said, builders of all sizes and experience have been hurt.
"It's as if you've been branded," said Mr. Swank, the president of the Sterling Group in Nappanee, Ind., a suburb of Elkhart. "You walk into a bank and you feel like the word developer or real estate is printed on your forehead. The window goes down before you even ask the first question."
But banking spokesmen say that in a recession, they would be deemed imprudent if they continued to make borrowing money easy.
"I like to use the analogy that the economic road is still bumpy," said Tara Little, a spokeswoman for the American Banking Association in Washington. "The lending organizations are trying to drive carefully and cautiously. The regulators are saying slow down. The developers are honking and beeping."
Builders say they first felt a credit pinch in August 1989, when Congress passed the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act. The act, adopted in the wake of the savings and loan crisis, sharply reduced the amount of money savings and loans could lend to any one developer. The institutions had long been a primary financing source for home builders, some of whom already owed the maximum allowed under the new standards. S. & L.'s called loans due or reduced limits.
Money became scarcer still with the Federal takeover of failed savings and loans and banks. Builders counted on banks to fill the void, but six months later, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal regulatory agency for banks, issued a letter warning against real-estate lending.
"It's almost as though somebody wrote the script and said, 'This is the way it is no matter who walks through your doors,' " said Mr. Swank. "The bank examiners are choreographing this."
Examiners from the Federal Reserve or the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation generally review financial institutions' books annually, and those relying heavily on real-estate loans receive more scrutiny.
But Mark Burneko, a spokesman for the American Banking Association, said that was expected because of the rapid devaluation of property in many sections of the country, especially in New England, Washington and south Florida.
"For better or worse there is a stigma attached to real estate, especially because of the precipitous drop in the value of real estate," said Mr. Burneko. "It's a matter of banks still having to be prudent in evaluating a loan and knowing that an examiner is going to be particularly scrupulous in looking at that loan."
He said money had also been scarce because the 1988 Basel Accord, an international agreement to standardize banking capital requirements, called for banks in all industrial nations to place more of their own money at risk for any sort of loan, and because the Federal Deposit Insurance premiums have increased 300 percent since 1989.
BUILDERS say they were heartened by the July 30 injunction by the Comptroller's office to member banks to make sound loans to sound builders. But so far, builders say, they have yet to see an improvement.
Mr. Swank said that over the last 18 months he had been turned down and his credit limits reduced, despite his 30 years in the business and a flawless record of building 30 apartment complexes. His company owns and manages 54 complexes in three states.
His bank also has imposed a host of new restrictions before he can build a single house in a subdivision.
"It really is overkill," he said. In addition, he said builders face higher origination fees, or up-front fees on loans, and higher interest rates.
He said he believes that banks are refusing real-estate loans in an effort to make their balance sheets look "lily white" to attract a buyer or to take part in the high- stakes merger fever sweeping the banking industry today.
And, he added, regional banks are less likely than community banks to lend money to developers. "My banks are 225 miles away in Detroit or 275 miles away in Cleveland," he said. "I don't know these loan officers and they don't know me or my business."
Mrs. Little countered: "Isn't it good business for anyone to have a good balance sheet? They look at that on a daily basis. It's not as if they haven't done this for 10 years."
MR. JOHNSTON, meanwhile, says his South Carolina project is one of two he is unable to borrow money to build. He experienced problems getting a permanent loan for a Lithonia, Ga., project after his original lender went into bankruptcy.
He sought a $3.9 million loan on a 132-unit low-income apartment complex valued at $5.5 million, but could get only $3.2 million.
"We had a perfect record and it was a cash flowing project," said Mr. Johnston, president of the Norsouth Corporation in Savannah, Ga., which builds and manages low-income housing in four Southeastern states.
Mr. Johnston and Mr. Swank, who also builds apartment complexes, say low-income families will be hardest hit by the new credit restrictions.
"We have a homeless problem now, but by 1995, it will be much worse," said Mr. Swank. Fewer than 200,000 apartments for low-income families will be built this year, but 75,000 to 100,000 more are needed.
Mr. Hammond said that tight credit had also hurt his subcontractors and suppliers. At the house he is building here, which is under contract, he said, he persuaded the subcontractors to wait for payment until the house was sold.
"I did it just to get something going," he said. "The pressures of building are just getting worse and worse."
At 36, he has been building houses for 15 years, but is thinking of calling it quits. He said he owns a small building here that might do nicely as a video rental store.
"I could sell hot dogs, drinks, anything to make a few hundred," he said.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Southeast's Builders Hungering for Credit

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 21; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1180 words

HEADLINE: Companies Juggle to Adapt to New Limits on Student Hours

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
COUNTY businesses with many young employees are preparing to meet new state regulations that take effect today sharply limiting the number of hours youths can work while school is in session.
The laws, which were supported by parent-teacher organizations countywide to allow 16- and 17-year-olds more time to study, include provisions that make the state's Child Labor Law one of the strictest in the United States. 
 Under the law, 16- and 17-year-olds who had been allowed to work up to 48 hours a week and as late as midnight when school was in session are now permitted only 28 hours of work a week and none later than 10 P.M. on school days.
The regulations will cause some disruptions in businesses like fast-food restaurants, which traditionally employ young people, said Janann Williams, personnel manager of McDonald's restaurants in the New York region, which includes Westchester.
 
New Work Schedules
 "We're preparing to juggle work schedules and make changes, especially in the late-night shifts," Ms. Williams said. "But the state is giving us three months to make the changes."
And there also is a provision in the law that allows students who keep up their grades to work past 10 P.M. "Students who bring in an academic certificate from school saying their grades are good, plus a written note of permission from their parents, will be able to work past 10," Ms. Williams said.
Had the law gone into effect several years ago, Ms. Williams added, it would have posed more serious problems.
"Ten years ago, most of our restaurants were staffed by teen-agers," she said. "Now we have more of a mix of ages, and we're hiring a lot of mature workers that include retirees and people who are working two jobs."
Rita D'Agostino, the manager of a McDonald's on Yonkers Avenue in Yonkers, said only 10 teen-age workers at her store would be affected. "Although we're open until 2 A.M. every day, I don't see any big problems," Ms. D'Agostino said. "We have 90 people on various shifts here, and I hope we'll be able to move some of them around. Because of the recession, we've had a lot of job applicants. A few years ago, when jobs were hard to fill, it would have been harder for us."
Ms. D'Agostino, who started working part time in the Yonkers restaurant eight years ago and rose through the ranks to become manager, predicted that her teen-age workers, who were used to earning $150 for 36 hours a week, might have to make some adjustments.
"I hope they'll be able to bring in the consent forms that allow them to work longer," she said, "because a lot of them are saving their money for college."
Since she began working at the Yonkers McDonald's last year, 17-year-old Carmen Pluas, has been saving her wages for college. But Carmen, who will be a senior at Saunders High School in Yonkers this fall, said the new law would not affect her.
"Because my parents don't like me to work at night, I have been working on weekends only, from 7 A.M. to 3 o'clock in the afternoon on Saturdays and Sundays," she said, "I make $55 a weekend, and it is adding up."
Ms. Pluas, who said she plans to study business administration in college, added that she found working at McDonald's valuable because "you can watch and see how a business is run."
The regulations limiting student working hours were proposed by a panel appointed by Commissioner Thomas F. Hartnett of the State Department of Labor. The panel spent three years studying the situation, said Assemblywoman Cecile D. Singer. The Republican of the 84th district, which includes parts of Yonkers, Tuckahoe, East Chester, Scarsdale and White Plains, voted for the bill.
 
Sleeping in Class>
 "They found that high school students, avid to earn as much money as they could, were actually falling asleep in the classrooms and neglecting their schoolwork because they were working so many hours," Ms. Singer said. "It got to the point that every school district in Westchester and every P.T.A. has been pushing for this bill for several years now."
When asked about the possible adverse effects of the bill on single-parent households that may need the wages of teen-agers, Assemblywoman Singer said: "We agonized over that. But the bill was passed for the good of the majority of high school students, after it was discovered that almost all of them who were working were working to buy things like cars or for more spending money."
Ms. Singer emphasized that the bill was not intended to be punitive. "We believe we've given students and businesses plenty of time to adapt. Students who keep their grades up should have no problems with it."
 
40-Hour Weeks Elsewhere
 In Connecticut and New Jersey, 16- and 17-year-olds can work up to 40 hours a week and until 11 P.M. on school days. But Peter Samaha, the co-owner of seven McDonald's restaurants in Westchester, some close to the Connecticut border, said he has no plans to staff those restaurants with Connecticut youths.
"I'm in favor of the bill," Mr. Samaha said. "McDonald's corporate policy gives the highest priority to education for young people. I'm not anticipating any disruptions.
"We might have had difficulties a few years back when the economy was booming and fast-food restaurants found it hard to fill positions, but with the recession now we have people of all ages working at our McDonald's. I think we'll have enough older employees to fill the late-night slump."
Louis Patin, the manager of Dunkin' Donuts in Mamaroneck, agreed, saying he had been able to hire enough full-time older workers to fill almost all his staffing needs.
"We are open around the clock, 24 hours a day," he said. "While we had a couple of teen-agers working for six-hour shifts in the summer and on the weekends, they are in the minority now."
 
Many People Became Available
 Mr. Patin added, "When the economy took a dive, a lot of people became available to work. We have people here who have lost their jobs, who are working two jobs, some who are retired and need additional income."
Kathleen Ali, a college graduate with a degree in marketing, is a single parent who lives in the Wakefield section of the Bronx and works in Westchester. Ms. Ali said she approved of the new law because she thought it would make it easier for parents who don't want their children to work at night to say no.
Ms. Ali, who is from Trinidad and who said her four children, aged 14 to 25, have always done well in school, said she felt that the new law backs up parents who believe that getting an education should be the first concern of young people.
"When my oldest children -- my daughter is now at Lehman College and my son is studying to become a priest -- begged me to let them work at night, I refused," she said. "I told them they had to be home when the street lights were turned on."
As a result, she said: "My daughter found a job in a bookstore and my son found several good part-time daytime jobs. In the evening they knew they had to concentrate on their schoolwork. I am very strict about that."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carmen Pluas, left, a 17-year-old senior at Saunders High School working at MacDonald's in Yonkers. Even before the new law, her parents did not want her to work at night. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 23; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 947 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Charitable Overlay For 90's Networking

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
On a breezy August evening, a crowd of businesspeople gathered at a penthouse above Central Park to sip gin and tonics, watch the sun set over the Manhattan skyline and gossip about the scandal at Salomon Brothers, the botched Soviet coup and the bankruptcy of real estate developer Peter Kalikow. Then a tall brunette dressed in black called for attention.
"We're here tonight to do something great for civilization," said Carol Treadwell. "We're going to participate in the event of a lifetime, and help save the earth in the process." 
 A tall order, perhaps. But Ms. Treadwell is director of the Millennium Society, a charitable group with a clear agenda: Throw the biggest party in history, on Dec. 31, 1999. Some 2,000 members are expected to travel to Egypt aboard the Queen Elizabeth II to ring in the year 2000 at the Great Pyramid of Cheops. Those who can't afford the trip needn't fret; the Millennium Society plans celebrations in each of the globe's 24 time zones, at sites including Stonehenge, Red Square and the Taj Mahal.
The Millennium Society has another mission as well, and it was apparent at the party. It's networking in the politically correct manner of the 1990's. The tactics are subtler and more sophisticated than in the 80's; the rubric is social activism, rather than overt economic gain. The "new" networking is about looking after others' interests, instead of one's own. But the impetus remains the same -- forging personal connections that foster professional advancement.
"Over the past few years, it's become an incredible network," said Edward Mcnally, chairman of the Millennium Society, who is the District Attorney in Anchorage, Alaska. "There's a strong corporate aspect to our membership, so it's a great way to meet people in the business world."
Networking has changed, said James Cabrera, president of Drake Beam Morin Inc., a New York-based outplacement firm. Instead of tossing business cards into fishbowls at singles' bars, executives are seeking out people with similar interests and backgrounds. "People are more specific about who they network with now," he said.
A glance around the society's fundraiser revealed plenty of phone numbers being scratched on cocktail napkins. One woman in a navy blue suit, who identified herself as a corporate lawyer, said she came to meet people -- not necessarily in a professional capacity. "I thought maybe I could find a date for the 1999 party," she said.
Nearby stood Tex McCrary, the group's president, who runs his own New York public relations company. He carried a crystal ball, and invited guests to predict what the Dow Jones average -- or Japan's Nikkei -- would be in 1999. "Normally, people start wallowing in nostalgia toward the end of a century," Mr. McCrary said. "We're doing just the opposite."
The Millennium Society also has a secondary goal: to endow a $100 million scholarship program designed to promote cultural exchange. "We wanted to leave a legacy," said Ms. Treadwell, former director of investor communications at Prudential-Bache Inc. "We didn't want to wake up the day after the biggest party in history with nothing left."
Founded in 1979 by a couple of college students, the Millennium Society has grown to 6,000 members worldwide. Today it's a nonprofit Section 501 (c)(3) charity with a dozen chapters -- composed mostly of young executives -- in New York, Washington, Chicago, London, Tokyo and other cities.
Capitalizing on its attractive demographics -- the average age of members is about 35, and most earn more than $50,000 -- the group has already signed up Tiffany & Co. and Absolut Vodka as sponsors of its 1999 celebration. That's not all. "We're looking to choose the official film, the official soft drink, the official airline, the official automobile for the year 2000," Ms. Treadwell said.
Oddly enough, this ploy may pay off. According to Paul Saffo, an analyst at the Institute for Future Studies in Menlo Park, Calif., businesses will soon be afflicted by millennial fever. "Marketers are in for a decade-long silly season that will intensify as we approach the year 2000," he said. "The millennium is a powerful undercurrent that will seep through consumers' consciousness. It'll be harder to target different groups and sell to them."
Millennial fever may not be limited just to businesses. Academics already show signs of the affliction. To wit: "The millennium has intense symbolic meaning for the baby-boom generation," said Douglas Labier, a psychoanalyst and director of the Project on Adult Lives in Washington. "They're filled with anxiety about the future, and yearning for meaningful transition in their lives. The year 2000 is fraught with signficance for them."
Not all of them. Alden M. Richards, chief executive of Space Machine Advisors Inc., a New York-based econometrics firm, didn't fork over $19.99 to join the Millennium Society because of an apocalyptic vision. "When I think about the year 2000, I think mostly about being able to address letters to my clients the following year with the date 2001," he said.
Recognizing their generation's shifting Zeitgeist, the society's leaders are focusing less on partying and more on charity. This year, the group sponsored four students -- called "Millennium Scholars" -- at H.R.H. the Prince of Wales' United World Colleges.
And should the millennium generation's Zeitgeist swerve again -- back toward hedonism and away from charity -- there will be a chance for another round of partying. As Mr. Saffo likes to point out: "The millennium really occurs at the end of 2000, not 1999. They're throwing their big bash on the wrong date."

HEADLINE: Aliens Law Shouldn't Lead to Fear of Hiring

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Aug. 7 article on recent increased enforcement of sanctions against employers of illegal aliens points out contradictions and challenges of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which aimed to welcome illegal immigrants with histories of residence and employment in the United States through "amnesty" and to discourage employment of new arrivals through fines for employers of illegal aliens. 
 You mention that a General Accounting Office report showed widespread employment discrimination against legal immigrants as a result of the sanctions [some editions].
Employer sanctions were opposed by Hispanic, immigrant and other civil rights groups including the Hermandad Mexicana Nacional during the debate preceding passage of the 1986 legislation. Those groups have described the law as the only piece of legislation in United States history that institutionalizes employment discrimination against a minority. Much of immigration-related discrimination would disappear with the repeal of sanctions.
As long as employer sanctions are with us, however, our best chance of assuring equal employment opportunity in this country is to support and heed the Justice Department's campaign of public education regarding the antidiscrimination provisions of the 1986 legislation. The department's Office of Special Counsel, through a national competition begun last year, awards grants to community agencies to inform workers and employers on their rights and responsibilities with regard to the hiring of work-authorized immigrants, refugees and those granted asylum.
Thanks to these public education efforts, immigrants in communities where grants have been made are learning to identify discrimination, and employers in violation of the anti
discrimination provisions are being investigated and prosecuted. Employers who ask for work-authorization documents at the time of application, rather than waiting until the time of hiring, or who are "playing it safe" and hiring only native-born applicants, are among those subject to penalties for discrimination.
Since discriminatory practices are the result of lack of understanding of the 1986 law and fear of sanctions on the part of employers, the public information campaign aims to provide the business community with accurate and up-to-date information, so that employers can offer foreign-born job applicants the same opportunities as natives.
The Office of Special Counsel's public education program is thus of mutual benefit to immigrants and employers. It will allow immigrants to continue to make the contribution to the United States economy they have made historically, and it will enable the business community to make informed and optimal decisions in the hiring of new employees.
The program, with little more than $1 million available this year, is working well in communities where public education grants have been awarded, but it needs and deserves more resources. To educate all those who look foreign or who speak English with an accent, as well as every employer with four or more employees in this country, is an enormous challenge.
The Justice Department has taken on that challenge, but with modest funds. Upon the success of its public education campaign depends not only the economic advancement of America's newest residents and their employers, but also our society's well-being.
 
MARGO CORONA DE LEY
President, Hermandad Mexicana
Nacional Legal Center
Chicago, Aug. 12, 1991
