HEADLINE: Folks Back Home Do Give a Hoot How '80 Election Was Won

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Responding to the coming Congressional investigation of whether or not the 1980 Reagan campaign improperly interfered with the attempt to secure the return of American hostages in Iran, House Minority Leader Bob Michel said that he didn't think the people back home gave two hoots about what happened 10 years ago (news article, Aug. 6). 
 I am 78 years old. I was a construction worker and now run a small business. I have lived through one major depression, two world wars and other national crises and traumas. I am an ordinary American. My wife and I have struggled to raise a family, provide for their education, insure their health care and prepare them for a better future.
Now, largely as the result of Federal policies during the last decade, I believe my grandchildren face dimmer prospects than their parents did because of what happened 10 years ago. They have been robbed of at least some of their future, in part because of the kind of arrogance in Washington that has led politicians to believe they can get away with anything because "the people back home don't care two hoots."
The people back home do care two hoots about what happened 10 years ago. We all know Jimmy Carter lost the election, but we do give two hoots about how he lost and about how Ronald Reagan won.
We give lots of hoots about the Iran-contra affair and why Mr. Reagan did not know what was happening in his own Rose Garden; about the scandal at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the savings and loan scandal and the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal and how they have all picked the ordinary taxpayer's pocket.
And we give a few hoots too that American families can no longer afford to send their children to college, can no longer afford to pay for medical care and must increasingly have two wage earners to make ends meet.
We care about what happened 10 years ago and how we came to have a multi-hundred-billion-dollar deficit, and how that deficit has begun to erode our Social Security and Medicare systems, as well as other essential services.
We care about our declining school systems, the growing economic disasters in our cities and the loss of hope. We care about the rising numbers of homeless in our streets -- not even in the Great Depression did I see that -- and we wonder how long we will be paying for the economic plundering that began 10 years ago. Those of us who came to adulthood during a world war that was fought to resist a brutal dictator wonder why we continue to support and supply murderous regimes in places like El Salvador and Peru.
Back home, we do care. And we are furious that Mr. Michel and so many of his colleagues in Washington apparently do not.
 
SIDNEY GLASSER
New York, Aug. 12, 1991

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;
An Ailing, Murky Industry Looks for Signs of Change

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen

 BODY:
AT the National Book Award ceremony last year, Catharine Stimpson, the chairman of the fiction jury, declared that American writing was marked by an astonishing vitality and vigor. She was swiftly followed on the podium by the author Saul Bellow, who said he had never known the country's literature to be in such a lamentably lifeless state.
It is the third rule of publishing that no two people will agree on anything, even where to have lunch. (The first rule is that there is only one thing worse than losing an auction for a book -- and that is winning it. The second is that it is nearly always more profitable to leave your money in the bank than to venture into trade-book publishing, where a profit margin of even 5 percent is elusive.) 
 The third rule is central to the business because it underscores one central fact: nothing in publishing is demonstrably true. Optimism and pessimism, fact and rumor, statistics and guesswork mingle so completely that objective certitude and this industry bear as much relation to each other as an Argentine steak and a vegetarian dinner.
Even the most basic question of when a book is sold remains nebulous. Publishers like to think that when they have shipped a book to a store, it is "sold." But in fact, stores can always return unsold books to publishers. So many of the "sales" publishers talk about amount to no more than what Steve Wasserman, the editorial director of Times Books, calls "wishful thinking." As a result, everything from authors' royalty statements to industry sales figures remains hopelessly vague.
Despairing of this state of things, and of the sometimes-nasty rumors that are the lifeblood of a $17 billion industry, Richard E. Snyder, the chief executive of Simon & Schuster, said recently: "People in this business can be so mean. That is why I have two dogs that I love!"
The pressure on publishers to look to their dogs for consolation has been particularly strong of late. Sales are very weak. Even the most die-hard optimists concede that the notion of publishing being recession-proof has been shown to be nonsense. Thinking more carefully about what to buy, consumers feel they can do without buying hardcover books.
So a profound change, it seems, is taking place. After a decade of rapid sales growth, which fueled a rapid rise in the money that authors were able to command for their books, a period of retrenchment has begun.
"In the 90's, there is going to be a lot of pressure on us to be lean and to be mean," said Alberto Vitale, the chief executive of Random House.
Lean and mean almost certainly means fewer people and fewer books. Layoffs at companies from Simon & Schuster to Farrar, Straus & Giroux have been proceeding quietly. The lists of published books have not shrunk as fast as work forces because, as most publishers see it, the fewer books you publish the less chance you have of a best seller.
But Viking Penguin, for example, intends to cut its list by about 25 percent. And Morgan Entrekin, the new president and publisher of the Atlantic Monthly Press, is cutting the house's list by more than 30 percent.
"There are too many books and too much staff in publishing today," he said. "Margins have shrunk and something has to give. Whether it is a day away or a month or a year, I do not know. But there will be a day of reckoning."
Before that day, some of the vast media conglomerates that bought into the industry over the last decade may tire of it and sell off houses.
Advances to authors are likely to come down gradually. Publishers love to lament that they are paying too much for books, but when their blood is up, their capacity for self-delusion remains as vigorous as ever.
"We are paying millions for books for which we should be paying $750,000, and $500,000 for books worth $100,000 and $50,000 for those worth $20,000," said Joseph Fox, a Random House senior editor. "It's crazy."
Even in this summer's doldrums, Random House paid a reported $375,000 to Nathan McCall of The Washington Post for a book about growing up as a black male in America, and Alfred A. Knopf has paid more than $400,000 for a novel by Donna Tartt. Neither of these writers has ever had a book published before.
But optimism is the opium of the publisher. Hope sustains him even as book after book disappears without a trace, dead as commercial propositions after two-week lives and five-year pregnancies. "Against the odds, you have to believe in every book," said John Sterling, the editor in chief of Houghton Mifflin.
Romanticism still runs strong. Amid all the rubbish published -- and most people agree that it is more abundant than ever -- many publishers still dream of finding the undiscovered Joyce or Hemingway of the 1990's and believe that what they do contributes in some way to culture and learning.
Some say these publishers are naive, hapless participants in a losing battle, dinosaurs in an age of space shuttles. Videos and cable television, Nintendo and falling literacy rates have all been identified as spelling death for the book industry.
But you can't take a video to bed or the beach; reading remains the cheapest form of sustained entertainment, and millions of Americans still like it. The fact is that bookstores have mushroomed in the 1980s and, with the help of new computer technology, they are becoming larger and better than ever. More space means more room for backlist titles -- the older books on which publishers really profit because their costs have already been defrayed.
Whatever happens, one thing is sure: nobody will really know what is going on, so the margin for muddling through is likely to be very large.

HEADLINE: Recovery In Housing Is Erratic

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
After five months of robust sales gains during the spring and early summer, the nation's housing markets have lapsed into a sluggish, uneven recovery. Still, prices are increasing gradually in most areas, while new construction is rising steadily.
"This is a very weak and spotty recovery," said David Shulman, a real estate analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. He said he did not expect home sales and housing construction to rebound swiftly, in contrast to what happened after previous recessions and housing slumps. 
 Real estate experts said the erratic nature of the upturn was underscored last week by reports that new-home sales in July had fallen 8.5 percent and that sales of existing homes were down 6.7 percent, compared with June. That followed sharp rises in each month since February.
 
Little Comfort for Builders
 July is normally the peak of the summer buying season for families with school-age children, and the weak sales offered little comfort to frustrated builders and home sellers in some regions, particuarly the expensive areas of the California coast and the Northeast, where prices have plummeted by more than 20 percent during the last two years.
But despite the July drop, analysts said the housing markets were stronger than a year ago and far more robust than during the second half of 1990, when Iraq's invasion of Kuwait led to a steep decline in consumer confidence that was most apparent in home sales.
It may be sloppy, these people said, but it is still a recovery.
"It would be a mistake to jump to the conclusion that the recovery is now over," said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. He said mortgage interest rates, down a full percentage point from a year ago, should continue to decline, attracting more home buyers.
 
'The Economy Is Still Weak'
 The downturn in July might have been expected after the sharp increase in sales earlier in the year, he said, adding, "People were euphoric at the resolution of the Persian Gulf war, but it didn't take long to wake up and realize the unemployment is still high and the economy still weak."
The robust sales earlier in the year were reflected in the second quarter, when sales of existing homes rose 3.5 percent, compared with the 1990 quarter. The pace of housing construction, which rose each month since March, continued to quicken in July, climbing 3.7 percent, to an annual rate of 1.07 million housing starts.
Median selling prices have also risen steadily, but at a far slower rate than during the booming 1980's. The National Association of Realtors said the median for July was $103,000, up 1 percent from June and 12 percent from the depth of the slump in December, when it was $91,700.
Compared with the mid-1980's, the housing market remains slack. The National Association of Home Builders predicted that new construction, despite recent gains, would be lower for 1991 than in any year since 1945.
Conditions in the beleaguered Northeast have improved, but remain weak. The region has been in a housing slump for more than three years, and real estate executives say some sellers are being forced to accept prices more than 30 percent below what they might have received in 1988.
Sales volume in the Northeast increased 6.3 percent in the second quarter, and 5.5 percent in July, compared with a year earlier. The gains were the biggest of any region, the realtors group said. But a separate analysis of median sales prices during the second quarter, compared with a year earlier, found them decreasing. The median was down 1.9 percent in New York City, northern New Jersey and Long Island, to $172,000.
Experts say a decline in the median selling price does not always mean values are decreasing; it can mean simply that more people are buying lower-priced homes. Indeed, increased sales of lower-priced properties could form the basis for a continued increase in demand, as sellers move on to more expensive houses.
 
Some Pessimists Remain
 A small minority of real estate industry executives and experts insist the nation is in for a far more protracted housing slump.
"The trend toward diminishing prices remains intact," said Michael Aronstein, president of Comstock Partners, a Wall Street money-management concern. He predicts a long, deep nationwide decline in house prices that will not end until at least the year 2000, correcting a long and exaggerated upward cycle that began in 1933.
That view gained some currency when the housing slump, which took hold in the Northeast in 1989, spread throughout the nation last year. Another stark prospect was outlined in a 1989 Harvard University study that analyzed demographic changes -- principally the so-called baby bust -- and projected a 3 percent annual decline in housing prices every year until 2007.
But most experts dismiss such theories, saying that lower interest rates and the slow pace of new construction are leading to greater demand and a reduced supply of housing.
 
'Best Investment You Can Make'
 "There have always been doomsayers, but a home is still proving to be the best investment you can make," said H. Lynn Horak, chairman of Norwest Bank Iowa, the largest bank in Des Moines. According to the National Association of Realtors survey, median house prices in his city during the second quarter increased 16.5 percent from the year earlier, to $67,700. It was the biggest gain of any city.
In Southern California, "the recovery is not dramatic, but it is certainly happening," said Jon Douglas, owner of Jon Douglas Real Estate, the largest residential brokerage in Los Angeles.
One constraint, he said, is the conservative appraisal policies that have been adopted by lenders, who have been turning down many more mortgage applications than they did in the 1980's. Mr. Douglas said second-quarter sales brokered by his firm were up 28 percent from year-earlier levels and had doubled from the fall and winter months.
In New Jersey, Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., a large builder that specializes in inexpensive homes, earned a reputation in the 1980's for selling out its new subdivisions within days or even hours. Now, after three years of depressed sales, it is experiencing an upturn.
 
Home Buyers Camp Out
 Hovnanian conducted a sales events on July 27 offering 180 attached, two-story town houses with garages, priced from $128,000 to $145,000, in Bridgewater Township, a community in central New Jersey. Three people camped out overnight to be the first in line, and 81 sales contracts were signed the first day.
"We absolutely see signs of improvement," said Ara Hovnanian, the company's president. He said sales at Bridgewater Township and at other New Jersey projects had been far stronger since March than during the prior two years.
In its second-quarter survey of median selling prices, the National Association of Realtors found an average increase of 4.7 percent, to a nationwide median price of $101,100. In the Northeast, the increase was only five-tenths of 1 percent, to $144,200. Median prices rose 7.5 percent in the West, to $140,800; 4.4 percent in the Midwest, to $77,900, and 2.8 percent in the South, to $89,200.
In a more current measure of housing demand, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a trade group that represents mortgage brokers, savings institutiions and commercial banks, said applications for mortgage loans plummeted in December and January, soared in March, April and May, fell back slightly in June, and rebounded to high levels in July.
 
Problem of Tighter Credit
 The group said the data reflected applications by people intending to buy homes, rather than refinance their mortgages. But the study provided no measure of what proportion of the applications were accepted.
Analysts say that with a recovery under way, the policies of lenders will be critical.
Barbara Allen, a housing analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said tight credit, while a nuisance to many house hunters, had proved a far greater problem for developers unable to obtain construction financing.
The result, she said, is that housing construction is running far below the levels necessary to keep pace with population growth, which would require more than 1.3 million housing starts a year.
"We are setting ourselves up for a serious shortage of new construction," she said, "and that may very well lead to strong price increases."

HEADLINE: Health on a Budget/A special report.;
In a Stronghold for H.M.O.'s, One Possible Future Emerges

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
When Michael Boucher was hired this year as one of 300 new teachers in the public schools here, he was offered a choice of two health plans. Both were administered by health maintenance organizations, popularly known as H.M.O.'s.
The limited choice did not seem to bother Mr. Boucher, a social studies teacher at the Folwell Middle School, who said that over the years he had enrolled in three H.M.O.'s, the members of which agree to accept limits on their medical choices in return for low-cost care that emphasizes preventive medicine. Mr. Boucher said he would rejoin the H.M.O. he "belonged to as a kid."
 
Widely Used in Minneapolis
 Minneapolis is a stronghold of the prepaid medical plans, which many experts across the country say are likely to have an essential role in the struggle to slow medical spending. With one of the country's highest rates of H.M.O. membership, 44 percent, this city may provide a glimpse of the future in health care. 
 Nearly everyone in Minneapolis and neighboring St. Paul seems to have an opinion about health maintenance organizations, which have been available here for 20 years. Criticism is plentiful, but in interviews with H.M.O. members, residents, physicians, employers and union officials, the prepaid plans seemed to be widely accepted as an institution that provides good care.
Members of health maintenance organizations have to bring any problems first to an H.M.O. doctor, who takes charge of their case. H.M.O. doctors and nurses are encouraged to practice preventive medicine, which is supposed to help members to stay healthy and out of expensive hospitals. The plans, for example, provide annual checkups, which are not covered by most traditional insurance.
And in an approach experts say has the greatest potential of all to slow the rise in medical bills, physicians are under pressure to avoid ordering diagnostic tests or treatments of questionable value.
The prepaid plans say they maintain high standards because their doctors share information and because the quality of care is always being reviewed. Critics, however, tell stories of some doctors who scrimped by having hospital patients discharged prematurely or by not referring patients to specialists.
But independent doctors in Minnesota and a number of studies say the best prepaid health plans do provide excellent care. A report just published in the Annals of Internal Medicine, a professional journal put out by the American College of Physicians, found the care given to Massachusetts H.M.O. patients was equal to or better than care for those not in H.M.O.'s.
Employers typically negotiate with a health maintenance organization for discounts on premiums or fees, in return for supplying large groups of members. National surveys say H.M.O.'s cost somewhat less than traditional fee-for-service medicine. But business executives still complain that H.M.O. costs keep rising too fast, albeit at a slower pace than those of other insurance plans.
In Minneapolis and St. Paul, employers pay about 72 percent of the H.M.O. cost for their employees, and a family of four would pay about $82 a month for its H.M.O. benefits, said David Beech, a principal in Minneapolis with A. Foster Higgins, a benefits-consulting firm. In addition, many H.M.O. members pay $5 to $10 for each visit to a doctor's office and the same amount for each prescription, but prenatal screenings and well-baby care are typically free.
For traditional health insurance, a family of four in an employee group would pay an average of $60 a month, as well as the first $150 to $250 of its medical bills each year, and then 20 percent of costs until the bills total $2,000. In addition, the family often has to pay for its own prescriptions.
Most businesses hesitate to require every employee to join a health maintenance organization, which might mean forcing them to cut ties to their family doctor. Yet, as businesses are increasingly squeezed by rising medical costs, a growing number of them offer to pay more of the costs for an employee who chooses an H.M.O.
Nationally, H.M.O.'s enrolled 1.7 million new members last year. The Group Health Association of America, an H.M.O. trade group, said membership quadrupled in 10 years, to 36.5 million in 1990, from 9.1 million in 1980.
"Everybody I know is in an H.M.O. of one type or another," said Peggy Steif Abram, a 33-year-old Minneapolis lawyer who recently had her first baby. She said that both the medical care and payment arrangements for her medical bills by the H.M.O. were excellent. H.M.O.'s are popular with women of child-bearing age: at least nine million are members, often attracted by the free checkups and child care.
 
Many Experts Disappointed
 But even as H.M.O.'s spread around the nation, many experts say they have not lived up to their potential at holding down costs. Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, a Minnesota physician and health policy analyst who was a father of the H.M.O. movement in the 1970's, said, "If H.M.O.'s can't do better, they aren't the answer."
But he said health maintenance organizations might yet provide the structure for achieving major savings, if they can learn to measure quality of care more effectively and weed out inefficient services.
Government economists estimate that Americans will spend $738.2 billion on health care this year, a 10 percent increase from $670.9 billion in 1990. After adjusting for inflation in medical and overall living costs, the increase was 4.6 percent,
Dr. Ellwood contends that unless health-care spending is tamed, tighter Government controls are inevitable. Then, he said, "we'll have to prioritize and ration" care by setting ceilings on spending, as most industrial countries do.
Some experts argue that H.M.O.'s have already squeezed much of the waste out of doctoring, especially by reducing hospital stays. Given the flood of expensive new technologies and other cost pressures, they contend, some form of rationing may be inevitable in any case.
 
How H.M.O.'s Work
No Fee Incentive For Extra Visits

In the early years, Dr. Ellwood and other experts promoted health maintenance organizations as a way of bringing market forces to an industry that had been relatively free of competition. Costs had typically not been much of a consideration, and medical bills were rarely questioned.
H.M.O. advocates borrowed ideas from group medical practices like Kaiser Permanente in California and cooperatives like the Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound, near Seattle. H.M.O. doctors would work in teams to keep standards high and costs down. With doctors on salary, there would be no incentive to order extra visits or procedures, an inherent problem in fee-for-service medicine.
Other health insurers and doctors, in theory, would have to compete for patients by matching the health maintenance organizations. Employers were required by Federal law to offer an H.M.O. option in their health plans.
But many employees resisted a choice that could require a drive across town to an unfamiliar clinic and doctor. So H.M.O. advocates came up with a new approach: Dozens of self-employed doctors banded together in loosely structured independent-practice associations that offered discounted fees for medical services to employer groups.
In Minneapolis and St. Paul almost every doctor, 4,000 in all, agreed to accept patients from the Physicians Health Plan, an independent-practice association started by members of the county medical society.
So, while some doctors work on H.M.O. staffs, many more serve some of their patients through H.M.O.'s and others in the traditional manner. The American Medical Association says almost half of urban and suburban doctors have at least one H.M.O. contract; many have several.
 
Where Members Are
More in California Than in New York

Almost half the 36.5 million H.M.O. members live in eight large population centers: Los Angeles, San Francisco, the three-state New York City area, Washington-Baltimore, Chicago, Philadelphia-Wilmington, Boston and Minneapolis-St. Paul.
But the prepaid plans are strongest in California, where Kaiser, the nation's largest H.M.O., set the pattern and millions of new residents did not have ties to a family doctor. The Kaiser Foundation Health Plans have 6.5 million members.
The concentration is highest, 46 percent, in the area of San Francisco, Oakland, San Jose and Sacramento, and in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, 44 percent.
In New York, by contrast, most middle-class people resist any limits on their ability to choose freely among the region's many doctors. The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, which was organized by city employees during the Depression, has one million members. But only 11 percent of the 18 million residents in the New York metropolitan area are in H.M.O.'s.
Other H.M.O.'s with at least one million enrolled include units of the Cigna Corporation, based in Philadelphia; the United Healthcare Corporation, based in Minneapolis; the Aetna Life and Casualty Insurance Company, based in Hartford, and U.S. Healthcare Inc., based in Blue Bell, Pa.
About one-fourth of H.M.O. members work for governments. And a growing number are in H.M.O.'s that contract with the Medicare program for the elderly and disabled or Medicaid programs for the poor.
 
Trade-Offs and Savings
Premiums Rising 10% to 15% in '91

Doctors and employers say the growing strength of health maintenance organizations in cities like Minneapolis, where competition for patients is intense, can bring broader economic benefits, making it harder for hospitals and all doctors to raise their fees.
As a result, while H.M.O. costs were 13 percent lower than those of traditional health insurance in the Minneapolis area, all other medical costs, too, were 10 percent to 14 percent below national averages in 1990, according to A. Foster Higgins, the benefits consulting firm.
But even in Minnesota, health care is one of the fastest-growing expenses for businesses. And nationally, large employers, which are typically self-insured, faced increases of 20 percent to 30 percent in health spending in 1991. H.M.O. premiums are rising by 10 percent to 15 percent.
 
Passing Costs to Employees
 The increases are often passed through to employees, who have to pay a growing portion of their medical bills or forgo wage increases.
"We are outraged at the escalation of costs that we keep eating," said Louise Sundin, president of the Minnesota Federation of Teachers union. But employees in some companies still pay little heed to differences among health plans because the companies pay more than 70 percent of the cost.
Employers said the lowest prices in Minneapolis were offered by Group Health Inc., which has a staff of 330 salaried physicians. Doctors on salary do not file claims for each patient seen, cutting down on time-consuming paperwork that is a growing cost for most American doctors.
Group Health had 285,000 members last year. The Physicians Health Plan, an independent-practice association which offers a wider choice of doctors and offices, had 330,000 members.
 
Two Plans Compared in Study
 The Citizens League, a nonprofit Minneapolis research group, recently compared the 1990 costs of the H.M.O. plans. It said that Group Health members who were under 65 spent less time in hospitals than members of the other H.M.O.'s, and far less than the national averages for H.M.O.'s and other types of health plans.
But Group Health members saw their doctors more often than the other health-plan members, taking advantage of free services like prenatal care.
Patients in Physicians Health Plan, the independent-practice group, saw their doctors less frequently but spent more time in hospitals. Health-care experts say that such groups, which base their fees on services rendered, often find it difficult to persuade their doctors to consider costs when they order care.
The league added that Group Health spent 9.4 percent of its budget on administrative expenses and Physicians Health Plan spent 17.4 percent.
 
Doctors' Worries
Deep Discounts Affecting Salaries
 Experts say that H.M.O.'s are playing an important part in making health care more efficient. "They have changed the whole concept, making it acceptable to patients to have a restricted list of doctors, and acceptable to doctors to be subject to restraints," said Dr. A. Stuart Hanson, chairman of the Park Nicollet Medical Foundation in Minneapolis.
But Minnesota doctors say that the deep H.M.O. discounts have depressed their incomes. Dr. Kent Wilson, an ear, nose and throat specialist in a St. Paul clinic, said some employers were demanding 40 percent to 50 percent reductions.
Dr. Christopher M. Foley, president-elect of the Minnesota Society of Internal Medicine, a professional group, said, "Primary-care physicians are grossly underpaid." He added that Twin Cities internists earn $90,000 to $100,000 a year, on average, after paying expenses, well under the national average of $146,500 in 1989, the latest year reported by the American Medical Association.
The doctors say they worry about attracting the best medical graduates to Minnesota. Dr. Hanson said that some doctors were leaving the state and that recruiting was becoming difficult.
 
Quality Concerns
Few Complaints In Minneapolis
 Physicians and spokesmen for Minneapolis employers said the quality of care was high. Indeed, Ms. Sundin, the teachers union president, said many families "grow up with and develop a relationship with the H.M.O." For their part, many members say that a major concern is being forced to change doctors when, as frequently happens, their employer selects a different H.M.O.
Asked to cite examples of improper behavior, a number of employers, unions and nonprofit agencies came up with only a handful of problems. "People think it's poor quality if they can't go to the doctor that they want to go to," said Sue Kvendru, health and issues director with the Minnesota Senior Federation, an advocacy group for the elderly. "They think they have to wait too long for an appointment, especially for preventive and routine care."
Rochelle Brandt, a psychologist with the Early Childhood Center at the Minnesota Children's Medical Center, said H.M.O.'s had raised objections to treatment recommended for "disturbed pre-schoolers."
 
Reviews Mainly Favorable
 Harry Hendrickson, a 66-year-old metals salesman, said his regular doctor at a clinic affiliated with Group Health did not visit him in the hospital when he had a stroke last year. He said other Group Health doctors came by, but "I got nothing explained to me." He added, "The doctor-patient relationship is gone."
He also said that the H.M.O. had been reluctant to approve physical therapy recommended by hospital therapists. Pamela G. Effertz, a Group Health spokeswoman, said Mr. Hendrickson's doctor had been on vacation.
But the reviews were overwhelmingly favorable when the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company based in Minneapolis, recently asked 4,300 employees to evaluate two H.M.O.'s. In unsigned replies, majorities of 80 percent and 93 percent said they were "always" or "usually" satisfied.
And Mr. Hendrickson said his $20,000 medical bill had been paid promptly. "Thank God, I had Group Health," he said. "They did take care of everything. They were beautiful about that."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Everybody I know is in an H.M.O. of one type or another," said Peggy Steif Abram, a lawyer in Minneapolis, who recently gave birth to a daughter, Ellen.  BODY:

Shaping the New Order
A WARNING ABOUT THE CONGRESS: Pro-reform politicians warned that an emergency national congress that is supposed to seek a new formula for reviving the exhausted Soviet political system could provide an opportunity for Communist reactionaries to seek a constitutional coup to depose President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Page 1. 
 NEW SCHOOL IN THE OLD STYLE: A Leningrad poet told a knot of grinning students that their schoolhouse would "forever be a monument to the new life, the new future that awaits your generation." The school is an experiment in restoring pre-revolutionary classical education. Page 4.
AN APPEAL FOR FOREIGN AID: President Gorbachev appealed to Prime Minister John Major of Britain, representing the Group of Seven leading industrial democracies, for economic help. Page 5.
 
Anxiety for Russians in the Republics
 DEMONSTRATION IN MOLDAVIA: Women from Moldavia's Russian and Ukrainian ethnic minorities demonstrated against the republic's proclamation of independence by blocking trains in the region they call the Dniester republic. Page 6.
RUSSIANS IN THE BALTICS WORRY: With Lithuania racing toward independence, many Russians fear that the good life they have enjoyed there for years may be threatened. Russians in Latvia and Estonia share their concern. Page 6.
 
The View From Overseas
 NO MORE SPY VS. SPY?: The imminent dissolution of the Soviet Union and the purge of the K.G.B. have injected new urgency into the debate over the role of the American intelligence services in a world where the Communist competition has left the playing field. Page 1.
U.S. AMBIVALENT ABOUT YELTSIN: Bush Administration officials have grown increasingly ambivalent about Boris N. Yeltsin in the two weeks since the failed Kremlin coup, questioning some of his actions and intentions and starting to criticize him in private as a "demagogue." Page 7.
VIEWING HOMELAND'S CHANGES FROM AFAR: Soviet students in the United States can only watch in suspense as their country transforms itself. Some say they may be in the right place at the right time. Page 10.
MEMORIES OF BALTIC EMIGRES: Baltic-Americans liken the standard of living in their native countries between the World Wars to that of Scandinavia. Page 6.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2608 words

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Gorbachev Interview: 'People Expect an Answer From Us About the Future'

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's interview today in St. George's Hall in the Kremlin with Steve Hurst, CNN's Moscow bureau chief, and Yegor Yakovlev, the director of Soviet television, as translated by CNN: 
 YAKOVLEV: Mikhail Sergeyevich, for two weeks the world has been in a state of tension watching the events in the Soviet Union, and so once you'd agreed to be interviewed by the Soviet television, I decided to invite our colleagues from CNN, first of all, because this American television company beams the interview to the entire world, and secondly, because my colleague Steve Hurst for three days was broadcasting from the White House -- from the Soviet White House -- to the world, and so the two of us will be interviewing you.
My first question, the putsch did not last even three days, but the syndrome in our society has been very substantial after this putsch. People are now asking who was where and who was doing what during those three days, and very soon we are going to have once again the lists of those who are reds and those who are whites, and so on. How can we cure ourselves from that syndrome?
GORBACHEV: First of all, I think that we should say the putsch was doomed from the very beginning, because our society is different: it does not accept this kind of thing, No. 1. No. 2, let me say that the punitive measures, the legal punitive measures, as a consequence of the putsch should apply to the organizers and to those who were directly involved, to the conspirators. And that does not apply to the people, to those in the army units who were in the streets, because generally the army was on the side of the people. This does not apply to certain organizations who received certain instructions, who were working in order for the country to continue working. This does not apply to the Communists and to members of the party who were not involved in any way -- millions of Communists rejected the coup from the very beginning.
So we should be very firm. And the democrats should do their best -- those who defeated the conspirators should do their best to make sure that there will be no attempt to ascribe guilt and to engage in a witch hunt, and to expand the group of those who are responsible.
Only those who are directly involved should be punished. And those are my instructions to the Attorney General and to all the others. And this should be known to all our people.
This is my view and the view of all the republics.
HURST: We spoke with Vitaly Ignatenko [the new director of Tass, the Government news agency, and a former spokesman for Mr. Gorbachev] not long ago about the Party Congress coming up, and he -- the Congress of People's Deputies. He said that you were going to make the speech of your political life. I would like to know what for you politically and personally is riding on this speech that you'll be giving to the Congress tomorrow?
GORBACHEV: Well, I think that the situation is of a kind which requires us to draw all the lessons from what has happened, the difficult lessons. We should be really very clear in our analysis. People expect not so much debate. The situation is clear, the causes of the coup are also clear. What the people want is the specifics, the specific steps to solve our problems. We have many problems and people expect us to find solutions to those problems.
I spent the first part of today working with the leaders of 11 republics, who gathered together with the President of the Soviet Union in order to develop a joint position, to develop our position. And I will continue talking to them a little later today. What the Congress will hear is not the report of the President, but the collective view of the republics about the measures which have to be taken. People expect an answer from us about the future of the Soviet Union and the position of those 11 republics about this.
We should maintain, we should preserve our union, but it should be based on the principles that will make it possible to implement the new points, to implement certain new points that have evolved over these days. But people expect the Congress to support this position for the union.
 
Seeking Economic Agreement

We also favor an immediate economic agreement between the 15 republics in order to create necessary conditions for economic growth and to remove all the obstacles in order to take advantage of this victory over the conspirators, over the putsch, in order to expand cooperation but in a common economic space, and also to develop cooperation with our Western partners in a more active way. This is a position, a clear position of all the republics who are ready to participate in such an economic agreement.
And finally, we should over this transitional interim period which we will have to go through as we are putting together a new union treaty and a new economic agreement, a new economic union, a new constitution, and a new election, we should have transitional Government bodies that should have credibility in the country. And that means that we should -- we must prepare certain proposals for the Congress. We are now preparing and formulating those proposals, and the Congress will hear those proposals tomorrow.
So on all questions, on the entire package of issues that our society is concerned about today, the Congress will have proposals in order to address those proposals, and we hope that the Congress will take a responsible and clear attitude and that within just a couple of days, two or three days, it will address and discuss those questions and give answers to the country.
YAKOVLEV: Mikhail Sergeyevich, the preservation of the Soviet Union is probably the most important thing today for you.
GORBACHEV: I think it's the most important thing for the whole society. I feel what is happening and that the people are concerned about this. I think you understand that, too. Steve, I have to say to you that we feel the concern also of the international community, of the people of the United States, and our people are aware of that.
So it is clear to us that we must have a new union, we must develop a formula of the union of sovereign states who are free in very important ways. At the same time, they will cooperate. All the subjects of the new union will cooperate for the benefit of the people, and of course, there will also be other kinds of associations, maybe confederate type associations, and in multiple ways.
So it depends on how the people and the republics will decide -- yes, yes, indeed, and that's a very important stage.
HURST: Well, you've said since the coup, you're a changed man and you're wanting to take decisions that before you put off. The Baltic republics: at the Congress, will you address that issue and will you say that the Baltic republics, if they wish to leave the Soviet Union, are free to do so without the cumbersome waiting period that you've spoken of before?
GORBACHEV: First of all, what I have already said opens up possibilities for every republic to take an independent attitude and to decide. Some will want to conclude the union treaty, others will want to have associate status and associate cooperation with the union, and other republics will want complete independence, although I see that as regards economic cooperation, here there is a substantial degree of agreement between all the 15 republics. So all of these possibilities, I think, open up the way to solve the problems that we have for every republic, for every nation.
And the problem of the Baltic republics, as a special problem, will be addressed by the Congress.
YAKOVLEV: Mikhail Sergeyevich, I will not be a prophet if I say that at the Congress the question of your possible resignation may turn up. What will be your response, what will be your reaction in this situation? I would like to emphasize that the Congress of People's Deputies can, of course, release the President, but the Congress of People's Deputies cannot elect a new President, so if you resign today it will mean that the country will be without its President, pending the nationwide election. So what will be your response?
GORBACHEV: I have said that I will not now resign. This would be an immoral act. Without mentioning some other aspects, I think that at this very difficult stage, when we are approaching very important decisions that will define the future of the country in the course that we began in '85, I will not permit myself -- as a citizen, I cannot permit myself to just leave. So I will not resign.
YAKOVLEV: Well, but you have said many times in the past that you may resign.
GORBACHEV: There is one condition -- the union; the union should be retained. But as for the Congress, the Congress may discuss -- I will be able to say a few things to the Congress. I have quite a lot to say to the Congress. I have mentioned my responsibility, that I am to blame to a certain extent. I have given my analysis of the reasons, of the causes of the coup, but at the same time the fact that the coup was defeated internally and internationally, that would not have happened without the profound changes and reforms that have already happened in the country and internationally. And I think that I have taken some part in that.
YAKOVLEV: Well, some people say that Gorbachev is to blame for the putsch, and he also was involved in defeating the putsch.
GORBACHEV: Without a democracy, Gorbachev's democracy, the putsch wouldn't have been defeated, people say. Well, I think that what happened deserves very serious analysis, but I would like certainly to reject any kind of speculation about the President's position during those days. My position was a position of principle, and that I think was one factor that defeated the coup, through our joint efforts.
HURST: One quick follow-up question, and then another, if I may, please. But am I understanding you correctly -- and I don't mean to press this issue, but I want to make sure that we're clear on the issue of the Baltics if they do continue on this path. Lithuania, for example, has declared that it is independent, has been recognized by a number of Western European governments, and probably will be on Monday by President Bush. Then that is a fait accompli, as far as you're concerned?
GORBACHEV: Well, my attitude is that this is consistent with my approach about the development of the situation as we are reforming the Soviet Union, because every nation, every republic can take advantage of its constitutional right to self-determination, and therefore, if this is the final will, definitive will and intention of the people of those republics, then I am sure we must take that into account and agree with that.
YAKOVLEV: Mikhail Sergeyevich, sometimes leaders of the country can speak with a somewhat different voice compared to the past. When you returned from your isolation, you have taken many decisive steps. And some of the people who acted very decisively during the putsch, like Yeltsin, Sobchak, Yakovlev, are now close to you. But I don't see a man close to you, a man who first warned us about that danger, who spoke loud and clear about that danger -- Eduard Shevardnadze. I'm very concerned about his future.
GORBACHEV: I think that Eduard Shevardnadze, both at that time and now, has been taking a very clear attitude, an attitude of principle for continuing the policy that we began in 1985, and from that standpoint what we have been able to do together with him is something that I value very highly. And I also value very highly the relationship that I have -- that I still have personally with him.
I think that as a result of a major regrouping of political forces and of personnel in our country, we should certainly take advantage of his ability and capability as a politician. He is a major factor, and I think we'll take advantage of that.
YAKOVLEV: How will you do it?
GORBACHEV: I think that his experience -- and he has enormous experience in foreign policy and in domestic policy -- makes it possible for him to act within the new structures to oversee. For example, foreign policy and foreign trade, too.
HURST: A quick question. We're all concerned about Mrs. Gorbachev's health, and we're wondering if you could tell us, is she recovering?
And secondly, Mr. Yeltsin -- your relationship with him has seemed an emotional relationship for several years now. You've come back from this failed coup, and you've been put in a position where it looks to the outside world and perhaps to some people in the Soviet Union as if you're somehow sharing power with him or sharing decision-making.
Can you explain to us, after we hear about Mrs. Gorbachev, what your position is now with Boris Nikolayevich?
GORBACHEV: Well, first of all, to respond to your question about Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev, I would like to tell you and to others who have expressed sympathy and support, I would like to thank you. Of course, I and my family have had to go through a great deal. She was behaving very courageously in that situation, and our entire family gave me support in my decision and they said to me that they were ready to share my destiny, whatever might happen; and we understood what could have happened. And I am very proud of my family.
Secondly, when the BBC first communicated that the group of conspirators was on the way to the Crimea in order to perhaps show Gorbachev to the Soviet people and to the international public, we were worried about their intentions; maybe they had something very treacherous on their minds. And as a result, she had a very bad attack, she had a very bad heart attack and with some very bad consequences. We had a doctor who saved her. But now she is recuperating and it's O.K., but it will take some more time. She is already active. She is talking to people, and I think yesterday or today she was even interviewed over the telephone.
So, your second question. When I say that all of us have to reassess many things after what has happened, I am of course referring also to a reassessment, a necessary reassessment among the democrats. The democrats have, let us say, different shades and different trends. I think that one of the reasons why the conspirators undertook that putsch, undertook that risk, and one of the reasons that we had not been able to rule out such situations totally and completely is a lack of organization and certain infighting among the democratic forces. And that's an important lesson for me and I think also for Boris Nikolayevich Yeltsin and for all the others.
But I have to say that in winter and in early spring, we already acted on that important lesson when we began that process of nine plus one. And that already was a reassessment, and that put us very close to the signing of the union treaty, and that scared the conspirators. And that's why they saw that their time was almost up.
I think that now if anyone expects that he will be able to drive a wedge between Gorbachev and Yeltsin, to provoke a confrontation between Gorbachev and Yeltsin, I think that we should know that we have learned our bitter lessons and we will not allow ourselves to be provoked. That is out of the question. We are cooperating. We are cooperating, aware of the enormous responsibility, of our enormous responsibility with the other presidents in the Soviet Union at this very crucial time.
YAKOVLEV: Mikhail Sergeyevich, let me and Steve thank you for finding time for us. And we wish you to have some rest before tomorrow.
GORBACHEV: Well, I will go on working with the republics today. Thank you.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
The Baltics' Free Past: Lively Era, Brutal End

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
According to memories and memoirs, the three Baltic republics that emerged from the collapse of empires in World War I developed rather smoothly as small but cohesive economic and political entities during their brief life in independence.
Baltic-Americans who grew up in the region likened the standard of living to that of Scandinavia. Asked about the quality of life then, Hans Kobin of Hackensack, N.J., an Estonian from Tartu who is 69 years old, said, "It was comparable to life in Denmark." 
 "We had American films, a theater in every town, an opera, nightclubs," said Berta Roze, 88, a Latvian now living in suburban Washington who comes from Riga, the Latvian capital. "It was so very lively. The country was young. We think we were very tolerant."
Her recollection of the period before the Baltics lost their independence to Moscow in 1940, under a secret protocol between Hitler and Stalin, conforms with that of George F. Kennan, the American diplomat, who lived in Riga as a young Foreign Service officer. In his memoir, "From That Place and Time," he recalled "a variegated and highly cosmopolitan cultural life: newspapers and theaters in the Lettish, German, Russian and Yiddish tongues" and "vigorous" religious communities. The presence of minorities, which were allowed considerable autonomy, provided a cosmopolitan air, especially in Riga, known as "the Paris of the Baltic."
 
Farm and Timber Exports
 Because they are situated at the eastern end of the Baltic Sea and because of previous connections to Germany and Russia, all three republics maintained lively commerce with those countries as well as with Britain. They mainly exported agricultural products and timber.
Largely Lutheran Latvia and Estonia and largely Catholic Lithuania had authoritarian governments through most of the 1930's. Lithuania had a homegrown Fascist organization called Iron Wolf and Latvia had one called Thundercross. Both were suppressed.
In Lithuania, an army-backed coup installed Antanas Smetona, a nationalist, as leader in 1926. In 1934, Konstantin Patsa, a nationalist in Estonia, seized power there and banned political parties. A parallel dictatorship was created in Latvia that year under Karlis Ulmanis.
Survivors of the period regard the dictators as having been relatively benign, particularly when compared with the region's later successive experiences of totalitarian rule under Soviet Communists and German Nazis. "There was censorship, but the way of life was democratic," recalled Valdemars Kreicbergs, counselor of the Latvian legation here.
The Baltic-Americans, who were very young at the time, said that as they remembered the 20 years of independence between the world wars, there was little or no fear of fresh encroachment in the region by Russians or Germans until Hitler attacked Poland in 1939. Relations between the Baltic peoples and minorities, including Russians, Germans and Jews, were generally good, those who lived in the region during the interwar years said in interviews.
"We had a cow, chickens and freedom," said Elvyra Vodopalas of her grandmother's home near the Lithuanian town of Vilkaviskis.
There was an orchard, too, "with pears, apples, cherries and gooseberry bushes," she recalled. "When I went back in 1982, the orchard was gone and the house burned down."
Mrs. Vodopalas, a retired physical education teacher who lives in Fairfax Station, Va., also remembered the joy of Lithuanians when their country's basketball team won the European championship in 1937.
"I remember that, too," said Mr. Kreicbergs. "The Lithuanians imported several players from America that year. The score, I think, was 22 to 21." Latvia, he noted, had won the European championship in 1935.
 
Comfortable Neighbors
 The Baltic-Americans said that despite the fact that czarist Russia had dominated their lands for centuries and the Soviet Union first menaced and later extinguished the freedom of the Baltic republics, members of the Russian minority made comfortable neighbors in the independence period.
Indeed, the influence of Russian culture remained strong. Baltic people spoke of "zakuski" instead of hors d'oeuvres and they relished various kinds of homemade vodka, which the Latvians called "degvins."
Mr. Kreicbergs, 79, who studied law at Riga University, recalled that his professors included a Russian, a German and a Jew. "The Russian newspaper, Sevodnya, had European prestige," he said.
Peggie Benton, an Englishwoman who lived in Lithuania and Latvia during the late 1930's, said in a memoir entitled "Baltic Countdown" that one of her countrymen spoke of the region as "solid, stolid and squalid," and that she found Riga "was run with doll's house neatness."
She found Kaunas, the makeshift capital of Lithuania after the traditional capital of Vilnius was taken over by Poland, "patchily modernized."
 
'Greatest City in World'
 In contrast, Antanas Dundzila, who was born in Kaunas 59 years ago, remembers it as "the greatest city in the world as far as I am concerned," although he, like all Lithuanians of the time, missed Vilnius "very strongly." The Virginia computer scientist remarked that in his youth Kaunas was "a fairly blooming commercial center,"
Although the German minorities in all three countries organized clandestine Hitler Youth groups and other Nazi organizations, and although Communists were also active, the threat to independence that might have implied was not perceived at the time by those who were interviewed.
"My generation in general was not aware of the dangers," said Mr. Kreicbergs, the Latvian. "We assumed independence would continue forever."
"All of a sudden the ax fell," Mr. Dundzila said, referring to Oct. 10, 1939, when the first Soviet Army forces moved into Lithuania to establish garrisons and air bases.
 
Many Killed or Deported
 Between June 15 and June 17, 1940, the Soviet Army blanketed the three Baltic countries and installed Communist puppet governments. They were sent under Stalin's interpretation of his secret 1939 pact with Hitler. About 60,000 Estonians were killed or deported to Siberia, along with 45,000 Lithuanians and 35,000 Latvians.
A little over a year later, Hitler's Wehrmacht swept in, followed by SS units that rounded up some 221,000 Jews in the region. They were systematically killed, partly with the help of special Baltic units under the SS.
In September 1944, Soviet forces surged back toward the region and those who could fled westward by land and sea -- 63,000 Estonians, 80,000 Lithuanians and 65,000 Latvians. The newly installed Soviet authorities resumed deporting Baltic people to Siberia or the Russian interior -- a total of 400,000 from 1944 to 1949.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Fidelity Is Bullish on Weekly Papers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Fidelity Investments, the huge Boston-based financial conglomerate known for its mutual funds, has entered the unlikely field of weekly journalism in the Boston suburbs. In the last year, it has become the region's most aggressive buyer of weekly newspapers.
Fidelity Capital has been joined in its acquisitions by members of the Harte family, which has owned newspapers for three generations. They began acquiring weeklies in 1986, and together they control 34 weekly papers and free shoppers in the Boston area, with a combined distribution of nearly 400,000 homes. 
 Indeed, Fidelity is too aggressive for Neil P. Collins, the co-owner of a half-dozen weeklies north of Boston, who is trying -- so far unsuccessfully -- to embarrass what he considers to be the Fidelity juggernaut into leaving him alone.
Specifically, Mr. Collins wants Fidelity, which managed $119 billion in assets in 1990, to abandon its plans to start a newspaper in Medford, a community just north of Boston, where Mr. Collins and his partner started a weekly paper last year.
Mr. Collins has publicly accused Edward C. Johnson 3d, the chairman and principal owner of Fidelity of "bully-boy tactics." William R. Elfers, who oversees Fidelity's newspaper operation, counters that Mr. Collins "would like to have a license on a monopoly in Medford."
 
Commodity Worth a Battle
 As the looming fight for Medford illustrates, the small hometown weekly has become a commodity well worth a battle, especially if it is in an affluent community near a big city.
"The weekly business is going to be the fastest-growing segment on the print side of the advertising business, because of the ability to target readers and because there's a big market for small advertisers who can't afford to buy a big daily," said W. Dean Singleton, chief executive of Media News Group Inc., which owns a group of weeklies in northern New Jersey.
The Boston Globe, which dominates the region's daily press, has started five weekly sections in response to the threat from groups of weeklies.
And now that the fabled mom-and-pop stand-alone weekly is nearly extinct, small chains of weeklies are feeling pressure from larger and larger chains that acquire them or compete with them.
These ever-larger chains of weeklies can spread their overhead among many papers and offer advertisers multiple markets. Their profit potential is sufficient to attract a venture-capital company like Fidelity Capital.
In addition to Fidelity, Capital Cities/ABC, the Chronicle Publishing Company of San Francisco and Harte-Hanks Communications have large groups of weeklies, with each company's papers concentrated in a particular area.
And laced through these large groups are a smattering of smaller groups, like that of Mr. Collins.
At a time when an advertising drought and squeezed earnings have all but stopped acquisitions by large media companies, Fidelity has shown its bullishness on the weekly newspaper business by going on a spending spree in the Boston area.
Within the last year, Fidelity and its partners acquired three papers on Cape Cod and a handful of weeklies elsewhere in Massachusetts, as well as the Dole Publishing Company, which included papers in Cambridge and Somerville, which borders Medford. Fidelity, a privately held company, would not disclose how much it paid for its acquisitions.
"They are on a kind of feeding frenzy," said K. Prescott Low, the publisher and owner of The Patriot Ledger, a daily in Quincy, just south of Boston.
Mr. Low said that the Fidelity group's maneuvers were becoming something of an obsession with the region's publishers and that rumors abounded regarding what the next acquisition might be.
Mr. Elfers, who is one of five managing directors of Fidelity Capital, declined to comment on possible future acquisitions. But he said the partners were interested in considering any deal that accommodates what he termed the "two plus two equals five" criteria -- meaning that a large chain of weeklies in a specific geographic area was worth more than the sum of its parts.
 
Is Fidelity Looking to Sell?
 Mr. Collins and some other newspaper publishers say that they believe that Fidelity's interest is purely financial, not journalistic, and that the company wants to assemble a mega-chain that will sell for a premium price in a few years.
But Mr. Elfers, who is 42 years old, said Fidelity had no plans to sell the weeklies. Indeed, he said he had a personal affection for the newspaper business from his days at The Princetonian, his college paper, and hoped to indulge that affection for the next 20 years.
Christopher M. Harte, who is 43 years old and a partner in the venture along with his two sisters, said he hoped that his family would acquire Fidelity's interest if the company wanted to sell. Mr. Harte said he and his sisters had no equity in Harte-Hanks Communications, a company co-founded by his grandfather. His father, however, owns about 25 percent of Harte-Hanks.
 
Far Smaller Scale
 In a sense, Mr. Collins and his partner, Mary L. N. McGrew, are entrepreneurs similar to those at Fidelity, but on a far smaller scale.
Mr. Collins, who is 45 years old, worked at the Gannett Company for 13 years, where he was publisher of The Palladium-Item in Richmond, Ind., and then worked for Beacon Communications, which is Chronicle Publishing's group of weeklies outside of Boston.
In the mid-1980's, Mr. Collins decided to try to realize the dream of many journalists and buy his own weekly. He and Ms. McGrew, who also worked at Beacon, bought The Revere Journal, a weekly just north of Boston, in 1987. The next year they bought a small group that included a weekly in Saugus.
But in 1989, the New England economy went sour and the newspaper business became very tough. To raise money, Mr. Collins and Ms. McGrew sold The Saugus Advertiser, which was profitable, to North Shore Weeklies Inc., one of the units of the Fidelity group, which had a free paper in Saugus that was unprofitable.
Fidelity closed its free paper after the purchase.
 
A New Weekly in Medford
 In 1990, Mr. Collins and Ms. McGrew used part of the approximately $300,000 from the sale of The Advertiser to start a weekly, The Medford Transcript. But among the papers that circulate in Medford is a free shopper that Fidelity acquired in the Dole buyout in May.
In July, Charles F. Goodrich, publisher of North Shore Weeklies, said he told Ms. McGrew that the company planned to start a new paper in Medford. "I did mention that she and her partner should let me know if they were interested in doing in Medford as we had in Saugus," he said.
Mr. Collins interpreted the exchange as a threat to sell or else, and he wrote a blistering letter to Mr. Johnson, Fidelity's chairman, which he published in The Transcript and circulated widely in the Boston area.
 
Tactics Seen as 'Reprehensible'
 "When the aggressor is part of a multibillion-dollar company like yours, able to lose money while starving out the competition, and the prey is a small, independent local company, such tactics may not be illegal, but they are certainly reprehensible," Mr. Collins wrote.
A Fidelity spokesman said Mr. Johnson was not available for an interview. He has not responded to Mr. Collins's letter.
Mr. Elfers said it was only logical for Fidelity to start a paper in Medford, since it already had a presence there through its shopper. Its plans call for the new Fidelity weekly to begin publishing in the fall.

HEADLINE: B.C.C.I. Forgave Consultant Loan

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The Bank of Credit and Commerce International last year forgave a $150,000 loan to Andrew Young's dormant consulting firm, freeing him from a personal obligation to make $32,000 in annual payments on interest and principal, Mr. Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta, Congressman and United Nations Ambassador, said in an interview.
The gesture was typical of the style of the bank, which spent millions around the world in efforts to influence public officials. B.C.C.I. was seized last month by financial regulators in seven countries after the Bank of England uncovered evidence of widespread fraud, drug trafficking and money laundering.
Mr. Young said he regarded the debt forgiveness as belated payment of $50,000 in annual retainer fees that the bank had promised his consulting firm while he was Atlanta's Mayor. Mr. Young was Mayor from 1982 to 1990 and remains one of Georgia's most influential public figures. Currently, for example, he is head of the Olympic Organizing Committee for Atlanta, which will be the host city for the 1996 Summer Games. 
 Mr. Young said the oral agreement for the consulting fees was made by the founder of B.C.C.I., Aga Hassan Abedi, a Pakistani financier who is now gravely ill in Karachi. Generally, to be legally binding, such a promise must be made in writing.
 
U.S. Investigating
 Federal investigators confirmed that the circumstances of the debt-forgiveness agreement are under investigation as part of the Government inquiry into B.C.C.I.'s Georgia connections. The investigators say they have no evidence that Mr. Young did anything illegal, like using his position as Mayor to help the bank.
Joe Whitley, the United States Attorney in Atlanta, said that no law -- Federal, state or local -- bars public officials from conducting businesses or receiving gifts while in office.
Mr. Young said that neither he nor his firm, in fact, performed any services for the promised fees other than to be on call as a consultant. He said they were never called upon and had never received the retainer fees.
The forgiveness of the loan was compensation for B.C.C.I.'s having had "the right to call on us if they wanted to or needed to," Mr. Young said. "They didn't.
"When people retain a lawyer or a consultant," Mr. Young added, "they retain them whether or not they actually call on them."
 Mr. Young said Mr. Abedi suggested in 1986 that the firm receive a retainer.' "Then he had his heart attack, so we never got it," Mr. Young said.
Mr. Abedi remained in command of B.C.C.I. in 1987. It was not until early 1988 that he had the heart attack, followed by a heart transplant. He has been in poor health since and has not had an active role in B.C.C.I.
The loan to Andrew Young Associates initially came from a $175,000 line of credit obtained from the National Bank of Georgia in 1982, the year Mr. Young became Mayor. He said it was secured by liens on his house and the house of Stoney Cooks, his longtime business and political associate.
The Georgia bank was acquired in 1987 by First American Bankshares of Washington, which regulators contend was secretly owned by B.C.C.I.
The debt forgiveness took place after Mr. Young left the mayor's office in 1990, but while he was running for governor of Georgia.
Mr. Young said Mr. Cooks initiated the negotiations with B.C.C.I. that led to forgiving the debt, because Mr. Cooks wanted to refinance his house and needed to remove the lien that had secured the debt. Mr. Young also said that B.C.C.I. officials had suggested canceling the debt.
"It was their idea," Mr. Young said. "I signed off on it."
A Differing Recollection
 Mr. Cooks's recollection of the matter differs.
Mr. Cooks said in an interview that the amount of the debt was $165,000, not $150,000. He said that the negotiations were not prompted by a desire to refinance his house but by a wish to be compensated for services that he said were in fact performed by the firm. He went to B.C.C.I. in late 1989, he said, and dealt with a Mr. Jamil, whose first name he said he could not recall.
"There was a period of work with no compensation," Mr. Cooks said. "When I inquired, I was told that I should recapitulate all the hours and involvement and travel. I was asked whether or not it was O.K. for it to be applied to the outstanding debt.
"It certainly worked out well," he added."
 
Suspended Operations
 Mr. Young said the money from the loan had been used to help pay the rent of the consulting company, salaries and other costs incurred in 1986 or before. He suspended the firm's operations in 1986 because "we realized that we weren't making enough money to pay expenses."
He said he had personally paid about $32,000 annually on the interest and principal on the loan from 1984 to 1989. Mr. Cooks paid nothing.
Both men said they did not know how much had been paid on the principal. The figure of $150,000 cited by Mr. Young was the amount he thought was still owed in 1990 at the time the loan was forgiven. Mr. Young said the interest rate had been based on a typical formula: one percentage point above the prime rate.
 
'Vigorous' Inquiry in Georgia
 Mr. Whitley, the United States Attorney, said his office was conducting a "vigorous, aggressive" investigation of B.C.C.I.'s Georgia connections.
Although Mr. Whitley declined to be specific, the investigation is believed to include the bank's relationships with Mr. Young and with former President Jimmy Carter, who created charitable organizations that received $8.8 million in contributions from B.C.C.I.; with Bert Lance, Mr. Carter's former budget director who once owned the National Bank of Georgia, and with Ghaith Pharaon, a major B.C.C.I. stockholder who bought the Georgia bank from Mr. Lance.
Federal investigators say they do not believe there was anything unlawful about Mr. Carter's relationship with B.C.C.I., but they want to examine the circumstances of the bank's contributions to Mr. Carter's charities.
Similarly, there are no allegations of unlawful conduct on the part of Mr. Lance, who introduced Mr. Abedi to Mr. Carter and others, but Federal investigators say they want to investigate the full extent of B.C.C.I.'s relationship with Mr. Lance. They are also investigating allegations that Mr. Pharaon was a front for B.C.C.I.
Federal investigators, moreover, are looking into the lobbying effort that helped persuade the Georgia Legislature to change state law to allow First American to buy the National Bank of Georgia.
"We'll go wherever the facts take us," Mr. Whitley said.
 
Tampa Problems Seen as Isolated
 B.C.C.I. and several of its officials were indicted in 1988 in Tampa on charges of drug running and money laundering, and were convicted in 1990. Tax returns provided by the Carter Center show that Mr. Carter's charitable organizations received $5 million from B.C.C.I. after the Tampa indictments.
Carie Harmon, a spokeswoman for the Carter Center, said the money had been accepted because Justice Department officials said publicly that the Tampa indictment was no reflection on the overall character of B.C.C.I.
Did Mr. Young have any reservations about the propriety of accepting the B.C.C.I. debt forgiveness?
"We were told by the Justice Department that these were just a few bad apples in a basicaly good pie," Mr. Young said. "I saw this as a Florida scandal, not a B.C.C.I. scandal."
Mr. Young said that Mr. Carter had played no role in the debt forgiveness, and that Mr. Young had received no other money from B.C.C.I. Mr. Young also said his association with B.C.C.I. ended last year.
 
Forgiving Loans 'Highly Unusual'
 Banking industry executives say banks rarely forgive loans.
"It is highly unusual for a bank to do that," said Mark Burneko, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association, a trade group of the nation's biggest banks.
Mr. Young said that before Mr. Abedi's oral promise to pay a $50,000 retainer, Mr. Young in 1985 and 1986 had helped B.C.C.I. in its efforts to assist in the development of several African nations, including Angola, Mozambique and Namibia, that were "trying to get established in the world economy." He said he also helped set up a conference of 14 African nations that met in Tunisia. The transportation expenses of Mr. Young and other participants were paid by B.C.C.I.'s Third World Foundation.
Mr. Young said that in his view he was assisting those develping nations, and not B.C.C.I., and he had not charged for his services. "I thought I was working pro bono, for the African governments," Mr. Young said. "If B.C.C.I. said that 'it was helpful to us, and we'll cancel out the loan,' that was O.K. with me."
Last month, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, asked the General Accounting Office to investigate "the relationship between B.C.C.I. officials or B.C.C.I.-controlled entities with any current or former U.S. public officials, including but not limited to, gifts, political contributions and personal loans."
Mr. Young said he had been upset by the B.C.C.I. scandal. "I have agonized over this," Mr. Young said. "I've been trying to understand Mr. Abedi." He said that Mr. Abedi demonstrated "a very strong desire to serve the less fortunate."
"That's what I was attracted to," Mr. Young said, "and I'm sure that's what Carter was attracted to."
Mr. Young said that Mr. Abedi, in discussing the $50,000 annual retainer in 1986, had asked for Mr. Young's assistance in establishing business relationships in Africa. "I went to Angola after that," Mr. Young said. "I maintained my connections with Angola, Mozambique and Namibia. Any time they were ready to move in, we could have helped," he said of B.C.C.I.
But the call never came, he said.
Mr. Young is now president of the Law International division of Law Companies International, an engineering and consulting organization.
