HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
SOVIETS' DISORDER IS FELT BY CUBANS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Last Thursday, when Cuba's Marxist-Leninist Government broke a 10-day silence over the political upheaval in the Soviet Union, it was to announce to the world that it would never veer from its "revolutionary and scientific" path, even after what it called the failure of Communist experiments elsewhere.
The same day, the Communist Party's official newspaper, Granmna, said in a front-page editorial: "Whatever happens in the Soviet Union, we will not move away from the path we have chosen. We will continue with our independent, Cuban, socialist line." 
 Despite this defiant tone, however, experts on the island's affairs say that the turmoil in the Soviet Union, Cuba's principal benefactor, will give the Government of President Fidel Castro new challenges that it may not be able to surmount without dramatic economic and political reforms of its own.
As the clouds of change over the Soviet Union grew more ominous in recent months, Mr. Castro had begun to speak of a "zero option," in which he envisioned Cuba's survival cut off from its traditional supporters and living almost alone in the world.
 
Oil Bartering
 For three decades, through generous economic aid packages and elaborate barter arrangements, Moscow has provided Cuba with almost all its oil and three-quarters of its other goods -- from much food and medicine to machinery and raw materials. Suddenly, as the Soviet republics sort out their non-Communist future, the reliability of receiving these supplies has been thrown into doubt.
"If it turns out that they are forced to swim without the Soviet life preserver, there is little doubt but that they will drown," a United States official who monitors Cuban affairs said. "It would only be a question of time."
In the last year, partly in response to growing Soviet economic disorder, Cuba has introduced a battery of unpopular austerity measures that have included a major expansion of the country's Spartan rationing system, cuts in public transportation, factory closings, shortened working hours and the use of bicycles as the principal means of mass transportation.
While Cuban office workers are now rotated through rural cooperatives in an effort to achieve agricultural self-sufficiency, housewives in Havana and other cities spend long, hot hours waiting in line for meager rations of milk, bread and eggs. For most, meat and fresh fish disappeared long ago.
 
Dissidents Emboldened
 Mr. Castro's bleak "zero option" talk has emboldened human rights groups and political dissidents to make more direct challenges to a system that many Cubans see as failing.
And the lack of hope for any improvement in living conditions has pushed Cubans -- from the pampered elites of the sports and arts worlds to ordinary workers -- to seek exile in the United States and elsewhere. On the streets of Havana, criticism of Mr. Castro and his Government is uttered with a new-found abandon.
Sensing the possibility of an internal challenge to its authority, Havana has begun to create "rapid deployment brigades" in neighborhoods and workplaces, which human rights advocates say are intended to suppress any protests quickly, before they can spread through a discontented population.
"The most important part of the equation all along has been the availablity of Soviet supplies, and it is a fair assumption that they are going to decline even more dramatically," said Carmelo Mesa-Lago, a specialist on the Cuban economy at the University of Pittsburgh.
 
Tourists and Capitalists
 "If there has been a marked deterioration in the internal situation between last July and this July, the next six months will be much worse," Mr. Mesa-Lago said. "Popular discontent is going to expand much faster. And if they don't change -- and tactical changes are not going to make the necessary difference -- there is no way now that they can survive."
In recent months, small but potentially significant changes have crept into the Cuban system, like an increased role for foreign capital in tourism. But Mr. Castro has unconditionally rejected fundamental changes.
The Cuban leader was quoted today as acknowledging that "we're living in difficult times," but insisting that "we will continue to push ahead with our projects, our ideas and our dreams."
 
Erosion of Castro's Power
 Mr. Castro's prestige as the leader of the revolution and his accumulation of power since 1959 have enabled him to stifle the debate over change up to now.
Yet the Soviet upheaval, coming only two months before the Cuban Communist Party's much-delayed fourth congress, are expected to rekindle the argument for greater reforms.
Gillian Gunn, a Cuban analyst at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said:
"My guess is that there is an intense debate as we speak in the party, and that those who have only succeeded in getting their ideas partly accepted, like privatization of large sectors of the economy and free farmers markets, will see their hands strengthened. The prospects for survival are much smaller now, but if Fidel turns out to be more of a survivor than a Marxist, he may yet be able to pull it off."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Some Advice For Entering Advertising

BYLINE: By Jacques Steinberg

 BODY:
THE prospects are daunting for recent college graduates hoping to enter the advertising industry. The recession, belt-tightening by advertisers and layoffs at several major agencies have narrowed the opportunities.
Through those clouds, however, advertising professors and agency executives say they see a glimmer of hope. And they cite what has traditionally been an axiom of the industry: Sooner or later, every agency requires the vitality and enthusiasm of a young person. 
 "Downsizing doesn't change the need to bring new people into the business," said Anne Melanson, executive vice president and director of human resources and administration at Backer Spielvogel Bates in New York. "You still need new blood."
But given the current economic climate, applicants for entry-level jobs at advertising agencies must be exceptionally patient. And with stiff competition for the few positions that are available, young applicants should be extraordinarily imaginative in presenting themselves, said Gene Kummel, the chairman emeritus of McCann-Erickson Worldwide.
While Mr. Kummel preaches persistence and "wearing out shoe leather," he also urges young people to demonstrate something more.
"I just don't think you sit still and rap on doors," said Mr. Kummel, who is also the chairman and chief executive of the Advertising Educational Foundation. "The advertising industry has always responded to people with ingenuity."
An applicant seeking an account management job at an agency that has a car account, for example, might first get a short-term job at a dealership that sells that car, Mr. Kummel said. Someone interested in a media-planning position, Mr. Kummel said, should research how an agency places its advertising for a particular product and then critique that strategy, perhaps making suggestions for improvement.
Such tactics might not have been required in the early 1980's, when the advertising business was booming, but they have become necessary as the industry begins to shrink.
"An applicant needs to be able to tell an agency how he can make money for them right now," said Robert Lauterborn, a professor of advertising at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. "That didn't used to be the case."
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the total number of jobs at advertising agencies nationwide fell to 163,800 in June from 170,100 in June 1990, a drop of 3.7 percent. The 1991 figure represents a decrease of 5.5 percent from June 1989, when the bureau estimates there were 173,400 advertising jobs.
In addition, six major agencies across the country have disclosed layoffs in the last three months. Among them were Backer, which has no entry-level jobs available, and Ayer Inc., which is "not in a hiring frame of mind," said Joseph M. Harte, the agency's senior vice president for human resources.
The layoffs at Backer, however, could result in several entry-level openings at the agency in the next six months, as younger employees are promoted to fill the spots of those who were let go, said Ms. Melanson, the agency's human resources director.
And though he is "not aggressively recruiting from the outside," Mr. Harte said he pores over 20 resumes "on a light day" and is planning for the future.
Jim Patterson, the chairman of J. Walter Thompson N.A., offered encouragement to those seeking positions on the creative side of an agency.
"Please come and see us," said Mr. Patterson, who cautioned that his standards are high. "I'm looking for writers and art directors and producers."
Professor Lauterborn said such opportunities are available to the top candidates but provide little consolation to those "in the mass middle."
"It's almost like the Broadway theater," he said. "You doggedly go to all the auditions and someone eventually hires you. In the interim, maybe you clerk, maybe you work as a waiter, maybe you wash dishes."
Jeff Gaylord, who graduated from the University of Maryland last spring with a degree in journalism, estimated that he had sent his resume to more than 30 New York agencies this year.
With no offer in hand, he took two part-time summer jobs waiting tables in Westhampton, L.I. He continues to send out cover letters, however, and even presents his customers with copies of his resume if he hears them refer to an agency.
"You always have to keep your eyes and ears open," said Mr. Gaylord, who is 21. "I'm constantly asking people if they've heard anything."

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Excerpts From Bush's Conference: 'Strong Support' for Baltic Independence

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Kennebunkport, Me., today, as recorded through the facilities of CNN:
 
 
OPENING STATEMENT

Well, nearly two weeks ago, the world watched with fascination the courage of the Soviet people in foiling a cynical coup, a coup that, thank God, failed. We've marveled since in their efforts to build a new and democratic future. Major changes are now taking place in the Soviet Union, not the least of which is the establishment of new arrangements between the republics and the central government. 
 While we await the final outcome, I welcome President Gorbachev's support for the concept that the republics will be free to determine their own future. This new 10-plus-1 agreement speaks eloquently to that.
This is a watershed in Soviet political thinking, equal to the dramatic movements toward democracy and market economies that we are witnessing in the republics themselves. The United States strongly supports these efforts.
The Baltic peoples of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, and their democratically elected governments, have declared their independence and are moving now to control their own national territories and their own destinies.
The United States has always supported the independence of the Baltic states, and is now prepared immediately to establish diplomatic relations with their governments.
 
American Assistance
 The United States is also prepared to do whatever it can to assist in the completion of the current process of making Baltic independence a factual reality. To facilitate this, I'll be sending the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, Mr. Kamen, to the Baltics.
We also understand the enormous challenges that lie ahead for the Soviet people in meeting their own food and energy needs particularly, and beginning true economic reform.
And therefore I'm sending Undersecretary of Agriculture Crowder with an experts' mission to survey with Soviet and republic officials their critical food requirements for the coming winter, particularly in those republics that are likely to be in the great need. And, a month, a presidential mission led by Secretary of Agriculture Madigan -- Ed Mdigan -- will bring a delegation of senior private sector and government officials to the U.S.S.R. to seek solutions to a winter food problem, if we determine that one exists, and to continue our long term efforts to help the Soviet Union and the Soviet people resolve problems in food distribution.
I've also asked Secretary of State Jim Baker, and our AID administrator, Mr. Roskins, to work with Project Hope to augment and extend my Presidential initiative on medical assistance to the U.S.S.R. through the end of 1992.
We intend to work closely with Soviet and republic officials in both of these efforts. This morning I talked with the president of Estonia and of Latvia, as I did to Mr. Landsbergis of Lithuania a couple of days ago, to tell him of this official position now being taken by the United States of America.
Now, I'll be glad to take just a few questions.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Independence Moves
 Q. What does today's action signify to the independence movements of the other republics? Does it offer the guarantee that when they declare their independence that the United States will also recognize them?
A. Well, what we'll do is look at each case on a case-by-case basis, but I think more important than what we might do down the road is what apparently is happening there in agreement between the center and the republics, and that is that each shall determine its own future. The Baltics, of course, are quite different. We never, as you know, recognized their incorporation in the first place. So there are some technical difficulties as we go along.
But I think this is very good news that they're willing to sort it out, and we'll look at it obviously on a case-by-case basis. We got to know first what kind of relationship these republics want to have with the center before we can jump way ahead and say what we're going to do in each case.
 
Recognizing Baltics
 Q. Mr. President, you delayed recognizing the Baltic countries, we are given to understand, because of the role of the United States as a superpower and because of your desire not to undercut Mikhail Gorbachev. What are the criteria now that you have decided this is the time to do this? Have you talked with someone in the Soviet Union? Are you satisfied with what the Russian Parliament is doing?
A. Well, I think it's all moving in the right direction. I thought that Gorbachev's statement yesterday, for example, which was heralded around the world as recognizing the right of the Baltics to be free, whether that's a proper interpretation or not -- that was a good statement. And we have been quietly asserting to him for a long time that the best thing he could do in terms of relationships with the United States is to free the Baltic states. And we've been working hard on that.
And so it's taking a final decision three or four more days than somebody else. But in the sweep of history I think we will be proved correct in taking just a few days to see if we can't effect change within the Soviet Union. And I'm very pleased at the two developments I talked to you today about.
Q. Have you had any contact with senior Soviet officials about this? Has this been coordinated with them at all?
A. I've been in touch with Mr. Gorbachev two or three times since my telephone conversation with him.
 
A Central Union
 Q. Mr. President, I wonder if you'd amplify a bit on your reactions to this 10-plus-1 deal that Mr. Gorbachev seems to be working out, especially in light of some of your comments last week and those of your advisers, and the interest that the United States has in there being a Soviet Union, in there being a central government?
A. Well, I can't help you at all on it until I know a little more about it, until I know what will work out between them. You may also remember that last week I talked about the need for them to work these problems out without dictation or decree every day from the United States. . . .
Q. Well, I wonder if at some point, sir, you saw events spinning out of control, that at some point it appeared Mr. Gorbachev may have been out of it, that the Soviet Union was going away.
A. Well, I don't feel that. I think things are moving. It's very difficult for them, but you -- when you see their Congress meeting, as it is, I think that's an extraordinarily good sign. When you see declarations at the center and the head of the president of the biggest republic want to work together, that's a good sign.
When you see an orderly process being worked out for determining just exactly that, the relations between the republics and the center, that's a good sign. So these things are moving. Again, I don't want to underestimate the problems the leaders face over there, but I really think it's too early for us to definitively comment on each republic, what the relations with the United States are going to be.
It is very clear that the Baltics are different. It's been clear all along that we were for their independence, and I think that this step that I've taken today will have wide support around the world. Clearly, in the United States it'll have very strong support. And it's the right thing to do.
And I'm pleased that at least there seems to be some recognition coming out of the center now that this is a proper move.
Q. Will it not be simpler for the United States, sir, to be conducting foreign policy still with the central Government? Are you not hoping that there's some sort of central government for foreign policy and arms control?
A. Well, I think there's got to be some Government with which the United States works on many questions. I mentioned the other day contractual questions. You've raised the question here of further arms control agreements. We've got to work with the Soviet Union in terms of their very important role in the peace process in the Middle East.
And so we will continue to deal with the Foreign Ministry, for example, in Moscow. But as these other republics get on to -- come front and center, we then must determine what their role will be and how they can help with peace, or what they're going to do about distancing themselves from the last remaining Communist dictator in this hemisphere -- I'm talking about Fidel Castro.
And we've heard Boris N. Yeltsin, I think, properly say, look, there's not going to be any aid from Russia, from the Russian republic to Castro. That's good. We're for that position. We'd like to hear the center say the same time.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Is Gorbachev Best?
 Q. Do you see, Mr. President, Gorbachev as the best person positioned to weld the republics together into some form of economic union?
A. Well, I see him as the President of the Soviet Union, and therefore he will be dealt with with respect. People know how I feel about him, and he is in an extraordinarily difficult position now, and he has had our support, he will continue to have our support. This isn't -- policy isn't based on personality. It's based on who you're dealing with.
The fact that I happen to think that he's done an awful lot for the world is out there for all to see. I think everybody in the G-7 and E.C. and all these groupings share my respect for what has been done. Take a look at Eastern Europe as a good place to start. And take a look at this hemisphere, where we've had cooperation, or Angola, or many other things. That's there. That's on the record.
Now, how we move forward? I'll deal with him -- and with respect and with a certain degree of recognition that we look at some of these problems, foreign policy problems, eye to eye.
How it evolves inside the Soviet Union, I once again say: that's their business.
 
Time for Recognition
 Q. Has he sent any communications at all to you requesting that you delay your announcement on the Baltic states?
A. I think -- put it this way, without going into the confidentiality of any communications -- I think the fact that we have waited till now is not only understood but very much appreciated by him and hopefully by others in the Soviet Union.
I like to think that some of these positive statements might, perhaps indirectly, but might be a result of a policy of taking a day or two more, not being stampeded into something the whole world knew we were going to do in the first place. And I've made sure that President Landsbergis and the others understand this, because I wouldn't want to send a signal to them that we were weakening in our desire to have them free.
But when history is written, nobody is going to remember that we took 48 hours more than Iceland or whoever else it is. But what's going to be remembered is what happens, how does it work out. And that's what we're interested in, is seeing the Baltic states quickly get their independence and the freedom that they've long aspired to. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Negotiations in Order
 Q. You called for the Baltics to become independent as soon as possible. Gorbachev in his public statements seemed very vague about how cumbersome this constitutional process will be, how long it will take. Has he given you any assurances in private about some of the practical and legal dynamics and complications at work here?
A. Not in the last couple of weeks. But I've been into that with him in great detail in terms of what he says as the constitutional constraints, if you will. In spite of all that, my urging is to anybody with authority in the Soviet Union, is turn the Baltics loose now, free, clear -- and, yes, there's going to have to be some negotiation between the center and between the states, because there's an overlapping of resource responsibility, where does the energy come from, how do the steel imports go from one of the Baltics into the center. There's a lot of -- and there's, you know, control of one's own territory.
One of the things that we have felt was necessary before full recognition has been control of the territory. And yet, as you see these Soviet troops leaving and you hear statements out of the Soviet Union that give you encouragement, then we feel that they are in a much better position to control their own territory totally. There are still, as you point out, some details to be worked out, however.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush at a meeting with reporters yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me. He announced that the United States had given full diplomatic recognition to the Baltics. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Lithuania Disappointed by U.S. Timing

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Lithuanian officials reacted ambivalently today to the announcement that the United States was granting diplmatic recognition to their Government.
They were pleased to have the political protection that it implies but irritated that it did not come sooner. 
 No one expressed the ambivalence more clearly than President Vytautas Landsbergis, who left Lithuania this morning for a one-day trip to Budapest and was unavailable for comment.
A spokesman said Mr. Landsbergis had not known that the announcement of American recognition was to be made today, though President Bush called him on Friday and said that he would have a significant announcement on Monday. Lithuanian journalists speculated that Mr. Landsbergis's absence was a signal of displeasure with American policy.
 
A Gesture to Gorbachev
 More than 30 nations recognized Lithuania during the second half of August. Several have already named their ambassadors, and one, Sweden, has opened an embassy.
United States policy, like that of some other Western powers, was to postpone recognition briefly, apparently as a gesture to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. But officials here consider Mr. Gorbachev one of their principal enemies and disapprove of any policy designed to strengthen or help him.
Lithuanian politicians said they believed they would probably receive some aid from the United States but not as much as they are expecting from European countries, particularly Germany, Denmark and Sweden.
All three Baltic republics, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, are likely soon to become affiliated with the European Community but will probably not become full members for some years.
 
Estonia and Latvia Are Favored
 American recognition of the Baltic republics may encourage private investment in the region, but experts believe that for at least the next few years, investors will prefer to risk their money in Estonia and Latvia rather than in Lithuania.
"I can tell you from conversations I have had in recent days that some important foreign investors are skeptical about Lithuania," said Kazimiera Prunskiene, who was Lithuania's Prime Minister until January. She was dismissed after Mr. Landsbergis concluded that her anti-Sovietism was not militant enough, and she now heads the parliamentary opposition.
"We should recognize that for the time being, we need to maintain ties with Russia and other Soviet republics," Mrs. Prunskiene said. "There is a view here that it is better to have nothing to eat and to ride horses and bicycles than to have anything to do with the former Soviet Union. Within the Government, that is the majority view.
"For many people here," she continued, "it is psychologically very important that Lithuania break all of its ties with the Soviet Union as soon as possible. But economically, that policy will create great problems for us."
The most vital product Lithuania receives from the Soviet Union is oil, which it pays for not with hard currency but with locally produced goods. Lithuania's economy does not generate nearly enough hard currency to buy the oil it needs on the world market.
In the weeks since it became clear that Lithuania was heading toward full independence, officials had been waiting for an announcement like the one President Bush made today. Many view it as a virtual guarantee that no unforeseen problems will emerge to block Lithuania's final departure from the Soviet Union.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Reaction by Latvia, Estonia
 RIGA, Latvia, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Latvia's President, Anatolijs Gorbunovs, said today that President Bush had told him of Washington's decision on diplomatic recognition in a telephone call.
"This makes our independence irreversible," Mr. Gorbunovs said at a news conference in the Parliament, which has been heavily guarded by militia since last month's failed Soviet coup. "I ask President Mikhail Gorbachev to follow the example" of Mr. Bush.
In Moscow, an Estonian official, Endel Lipmaa, said the way was now open for universal recognition after a two-year independence struggle. "I'd say this clinches the matter," he said.
Asked if he thought Mr. Gorbachev would now recognize Baltic independence, he replied: "The Soviet Union is changing so much, the presidency is now questionable. But it would be a nice gesture."
Latvian officials said today that they would offer tax breaks to attract foreign investment in tourism and other important industries. "The first target area for foreign investment is tourism," said Arijs Ziverts, deputy director of Latvia's foreign trade department.
The republic's goal is to manage a smooth transition to a market economy and recreate Latvia as a separate economic unit, the Economics Minister, Janis Aboltins, said.
New foreign investment rules are laid out in a bill Latvia's Parliament is expected to pass this year. New businesses in Latvia are exempt from a profits tax for the first two years and those started with foreign capital will escape tax for two more years. Some additional exemptions are available, and there will be no restrictions on the repatriation of hard-currency profits.
In addition to tourism, industries targeted for foreign investment include forestry and pulp, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, electronics, farming and assembly operations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Latvia's President, Anatolijs Gorbunovs, after being told by President Bush of Latvian recognition. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
The Day's Highlights

 BODY:
Shaping the New Order
Gorbachev Proposes Interim Government: Declaring that the Soviet Union was "on the brink of catastrophe," President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leaders of 10 republics asked the Congress of People's Deputies to transfer all central authority to them and an appointed legislative council until a new union could be formed. The move stunned and dismayed many deputies, who were effectively being asked to dissolve the only national assembly elected by the entire Soviet Union. Page A1. 
 Critical Unknowns In New Plan: The latest crisis plan has at least as many open questions as its predecessors of the last six years. Critical unknowns include when there will be fresh elections and a new constitution, whether the republics will find a better way to generate economic recovery, and the precise long-term role of President Gorbachev, for the moment the needed agent of national resolve. News analysis, page A1.
Closeout Sale On Sputniks: Officials of the Soviet space program have put the enterprise up for sale. Virtually everything is on the block, including the space station Mir, now in orbit. Science Times, page C1.
 
For the Baltics, Recognition, Joy and Ambivalence
Baltics Gain Full U.S. Recognition: President Bush, rather than continue to wait for Moscow to act, gave full diplomatic recognition to Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, the Baltic nations conquered by Stalin and now on the verge of independence from a crumbling Soviet Union. Page A1.
An Estonian Is Celebrating: Lennart Meri's appointment as Foreign Minister of Estonia seemed to be a mere act of defiance. Now he has been clinking glasses of champagne with foreign representatives to celebrate the reopening of diplomatic relations. Page A10.
Ambivalence In Lithuania: Lithuanian officials reacted ambivalently to the announcement that the United States was granting diplmatic recognition to their Government. They were pleased to have the political protection that it implies but irritated that it did not come sooner. Page A9.
 
Ripples Around the World
Can Cuba Maintain Its Path?: Cuba's Marxist-Leninist Government vowed that it would never veer from its "revolutionary and scientific" path. But experts in the United States say the turmoil in the Soviet Union presents President Fidel Castro with immense new challenges. Page A10.
All Quiet On The Western Front: The changes in the Soviet Union are having little effect on the time-honored routines of military life among the 270,000 Soviet soldiers still stationed in Germany. Page A10.

HEADLINE: Reluctant Regulator: A special report.;
Free-Wheeling Treasuries Market Is at Turning Point With Congress

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
When a Congressional committee convenes tomorrow to examine the Salomon Brothers scandal and its implications, it will set the stage for a battle over the regulation of one of the world's largest and most important financial arenas: the market for United States Treasury securities.
That market -- where $117 billion in bills, notes and bonds changes hands daily -- is the mechanism on which the Government relies to finance the nation's $3.61 trillion public debt. The unfolding scandal at Salomon Brothers is forcing a fresh examination of how the market operates, what rules govern it and how those rules are enforced. The recent query by the Securities and Exchange Commission to all big Treasury dealers is an effort to find out more about what really goes on in this important corner of Wall Street. 
 But even as the S.E.C. awaits its answers, the picture that is emerging shows a trading community governed under a poorly defined set of rules by a reluctant regulator: the Treasury itself, an agency that has grown increasingly dependent on the financial companies it oversees to channel the Government's flood of debt securities into investors' hands.
 In the face of the Treasury's apparent reluctance to be a tougher policman, market participants say, some dealers have grown increasingly arrogant about their power and casual about overstepping bounds, putting the market's reputation at risk in the global finance community.
"People in this market have long had a belligerent attitude toward the regulators," said a top executive at a New York firm, stating a view expressed by many in the market. "They think, 'Hey, we're doing you a favor, so get out of our way.' "
 
A Lot of Anger in Congress
 The very nature of the misbehavior at Salomon -- the use of phony bids to buy more than the legal limit of Treasury securities, and the failure of top executives to take action when they found out -- has generated a lot of anger in Congress. One person there said the firm's activity "communicates a very high level of contempt for one's regulators."
At the same time, the common response to critics, heard even in the wake of the Salomon disclosures, is that the market is highly effective. Market professionals are warning Washington that clumsy attempts to regulate this market more tightly could impair its ability to function efficiently and could burden the taxpayer with higher interest costs.
"The rules in this market are certainly unclear," said Thomas A. Russo, a partner at the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft in New York. "They are not of the 20th century, and they should certainly be clarified. But Washington should not add two and two and get six. The Treasury market generally has worked very well, and regulators must resist the temptation to overreact."
The critical issue facing policy makers is to find a way to preserve the strengths of this vast debt-financing network while correcting a regulatory culture that one senior Wall Street executive said had turned the market into "an accident waiting to happen."
While the scope of Salomon's missteps took some by surprise, critics of the system say such problems are encouraged by the Treasury's light regulatory touch, combined with an equal reticence on the part of the Treasury's agent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Treasury and Federal Reserve officials, for example, are said to have done little more than admonish firms when they have overstepped boundaries in the past.
"What you had was an honor system," said one senior Government official who insisted on anonymity. "It was not rationally designed. Authority and responsibility were not assigned in a clear-cut way. We have to sit down and design something that everyone is confident about to assure anyone looking at this market that this cannot happen again."
 
The First Skirmish
The Regulators Are Divided

Four Congressional committees have announced plans to examine the Salomon problems and the subsequent questions about the market's regulation. The first skirmish will be the hearing tomorrow of the Telecommunications and Finance Subcommittee of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, led by Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts.
The key regulatory players will all be represented: Nicholas F. Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, which maintains that its oversight has been sound; E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which conducts the Treasury's weekly auction but has shrunk from assuming regulatory oversight, and Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is showing signs of wanting to take a more active role, even as the other financial agencies hang back. Warren E. Buffett, the new chairman of Salomon Brothers, will also testify.
The S.E.C. is the watchdog for most securities markets, and its primary job is to protect investors. But it has almost no mandate in the Treasury markets except for cases that clearly constitute fraud. With its all-encompassing query to leading Treasury dealers and big investors, the S.E.C. has shown its eagerness to get involved.
 
Differences Are Already Evident
 While none of the agencies are saying much publicly about their views, differences are already evident.
Treasury Secretary Brady, in a recent telephone interview, defended the department's actions so far, saying they had sent "word to the world that we intend to conduct an honest market." At the same time, he said, the Salomon case has made it "worthwhile to review the process itself."
Mr. Breeden, on the other hand, seems to express more doubts about the adequacy of the current system. "Questions about the regulatory structure are not just questions of turf; they go to whether we can design a system that is likely to achieve our objectives," he said. "And our objectives here must be to finance Government at the lowest cost, but also to maintain a respect for law and integrity in the market."
In an interview last week, he gave no indication of what he thought might be needed to improve regulatory oversight of the market. "We are in the midst of a very active and very widespread investigation, and I would prefer to learn the outcome before I comment specifically," he said.
As the S.E.C.'s investigation proceeds, and as more is learned about the Salomon episodes, there is sure to be extensive debate on how to fix what went wrong. But even now, there are widespread predictions that the result will be more power for the S.E.C.
"You will never see the Treasury and the Fed totally supplanted," said Harvey Pitt, a partner at the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. "They will set the tone and policy. But in terms of enforcement, it is simply logical that people will conclude that there was a vacuum, and that the S.E.C. is the most competent agency to fill it."
 
A Bit of Dickens
A Large, Simple Trading Machine

The Government bond market was born in 1791 as a byproduct of the original debt-financing activities of Alexander Hamilton, the first Secretary of the Treasury. For years, it existed as an unexciting backwater of the financial markets, the province of a handful of firms. In the late 1800's, the Treasury used only a single investment banker, Jay Cooke, as its agent in selling its debt.
Today, in a world increasingly linked by trade, the vast and still-growing market is a linchpin of the United States economy, as well as of the world economy. As it helps finance the Government, it also sets the benchmark interest rates that affect the cost of everything from home mortgages in New York and California to rates in London and Tokyo to the cost of the Brazilian debt.
For all its importance, the market is a fairly simple machine, a network of dealers who transact business over telephone lines and computer screens, rather than on some central trading floor. The core of the system is the primary market, the auctions where giant dealers like Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch and Citibank bid against each other for a share of billions of dollars worth of Treasury securities, ranging in maturities from three months to three decades.
The method by which the auctions are conducted is "right out of Dickens," as Joseph A. Grundfest, a former S.E.C. commissioner, put it. Written bids are due at the offices of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Liberty Street in lower Manhattan by 1 P.M. on the day of an auction. Some firms send runners to deliver their hand-scribbled bids to the Fed. Others install employees at a small bank of telephones in the Fed's lobby and relay their bids by telephone minutes before the deadline.
Back at the firms' trading desks, high-powered executives are talking feverishly to their counterparts at other firms and to their biggest clients, trying to get an idea of how strong the buying interest is. It is this judgment, combined with how rates are behaving in other securities markets, that helps the traders figure out where to peg their bids.
 
Taking the Lowest-Rate Bid
 A typical bidder might offer to buy "$2 billion at 8.25," which means the bidder wants to buy $2 billion in bonds paying an interest rate of 8.25 percent. The lower the quoted rate, the better the deal for the Government, so in this auction, the low bidder wins.
When all the firms have submitted their sealed bids, Fed officials take the best bids and announce them about an hour later.
In theory, anyone can buy the securities directly. In practice, however, the bidding is dominated by the giant firms, like Salomon Brothers, that have been designated by the Fed as primary dealers. They typically buy more than 80 percent of the securities at most Treasury auctions, for their own accounts and for customers.
These firms, which now number 39, agree to bid in all auctions and to continue to make a market in Treasury securities afterward. In return, they are the only bidders other than commercial banks that are allowed to submit bids on behalf of other buyers. They are also the firms the Fed uses to conduct routine purchases and sales of Treasuries to modulate the nation's money supply.
Orbiting around the small primary-market nucleus is the vast secondary market, where successful bidders resell the newly issued securities to other dealers and investors, who add them to the mountain of seasoned securities that change hands each day.
 
A Free Market
A Rule Born In August 1962

The 1929 market crash led Congress to enact the set of laws that created the S.E.C. and empowered it to monitor securities markets in order to protect investors. But the Treasury market was largely exempted from that framework on the grounds that the Treasury was a uniquely solid credit risk and would not mislead investors.
As it moved to using more dealers, the main rules, which evolved over time, mainly focused on the conduct of the auction, including limits on how much any bidder could buy and who could bid. Dealers whose only business was selling Government securities in the secondary market were subject to virtually no rules at all until 1986.
A review of recent history shows that clearly codified rules and stern enforcement have never been a prominent characteristic of this marketplace. Several Wall Street executives and Government officials said behavior by a primary dealer that displeased the Treasury was most likely to result in a private frown -- and a brief public announcement of some small rule change that addressed the issue at hand.
For example, on Aug. 28, 1962, the Treasury tersely disclosed an "unusual occurrence" in the auction of three-month Treasury bills on the day before. A single bidder, unnamed, bid for an exceptionally high proportion of the total volume of three-month bills offered for sale.
 
Rules Not in Any Codified Form
 At the time, no rules prohibited such an aggressive strategy, although anyone who controlled a very large portion of a single issue might be able to extract near-monopoly profits later. The Treasury simply rejected the bid and announced that no single bidder would be awarded more than 25 percent of the total supply of three- or six-month Treasury bills in the future. The limits were gradually modified and extended to cover purchases of Treasury notes and bonds as well. Most rule changes were set out only in news releases, mailed to firms and not pulled together in any codified form.
Although dealers consistently seemed to find ways around each new rule, the Treasury continued its pattern of meeting each thrust by quietly tinkering with the rules. This continued through the 1980's -- a period during which the once-sedate government securities market went into overdrive.
The Federal deficit began to skyrocket, requiring the Government to begin borrowing on a scale that dwarfed anything the market had seen in its 190 years. The Government's debt has nearly doubled from 1980 to 1990 as a percent of gross national product, and the government securities market, ready or not, had to grow along with it.
Through this period, the primary market appeared relatively placid, but problems emerged in the secondary market, where Treasury securities are traded after they are issued. Some small, unregulated firms selling these issues were defrauding investors in various ways, including overcharging and borrowing against securities they did not own. These problems prompted Congress to propose legislation that would bring the secondary Treasury market under closer supervision. The hearings on those proposals now seem almost like a dress rehearsal for the current debate.
As administrative and industry witnesses came forward, legislators asked: Should the S.E.C. assume greater supervision and authority over the market? Should the rule-making authority for the market be shifted to the Federal Reserve? Did the Treasury's role as a huge issuer of debt conflict with its role as a market regulator?
In each case, the Treasury answered, "No." Paul A. Volcker, who was chairman of the Federal Reserve at the time, and John S. R. Shad, who was chairman of the S.E.C., supported the Treasury's position.
In the Government Securities Act of 1986, Congress left regulatory responsibility with the Treasury and omitted any rules over sales practices. But it gave the S.E.C. some power over the previously unsupervised dealers in the secondary market.
 
The Bombshell
Salomon Admits It Cheated

After 1986, other problems on Wall Street held Washington's attention until the bombshell fell on Aug. 9. That was when Salomon Brothers, one of the most powerful and respected brokerage houses on Wall Street, announced that it had cheated in several recent Treasury auctions.
It is still hard to measure who was harmed by Salomon's actions, and how much. Investors are already suing Salomon, contending that its actions artificially pushed up the prices of securities they bought. Shareholders in the firm are also suing it.
Perhaps the biggest concern is that the audacity of the misdeeds, and the Government's apparent slowness in reacting, could damage the credibility of the market, causing investors to stay away and forcing the Government to pay higher interest rates.
Recent auctions do not seem to have lacked for buyers. Nonetheless, the Salomon episode has generated uneasiness about the current regulatory structure -- especially Treasury's role in policing its own underwriters. Government policy experts say such an arrangement does not foster strong enforcement.
"It is very difficult to mix the regulatory function and other kinds of functions," said Michael Danielson, professor of politics and public affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School of Princeton University. "If my primary function is to sell something, and in the end I'm going to be judged on how effectively I sell it, then I am likely to have problems carrying out regulatory functions that get in the way."
 
Relationship With Group Questioned
 Some critics also question the Treasury's close relationship with an influential industry organization once known as the Primary Dealers Association, now the Public Securities Association. Its members, which include all the big bond-trading houses, consult with the Treasury on the structure and scheduling of new issues. Critics of the current framework point out that there is no separate unit at the Treasury charged with checking for rule violations by auction bidders.
Frances Bermanzohn, general counsel for the association, said there was nothing inappropriate in the group's relationship with the department. "There has never been any undue influence on the Treasury in its regulatory capacity," she continued. "Regulators invite and solicit industry feedback for information. Anything that has been done in this market has been in that spirit."
But not everyone is satisfied by that response. Even during the 1985 testimony, Aulana Peters, an S.E.C. commissioner, declared, "I do think that the Treasury Department would have a conflict of interest." She said she was "a little more comfortable" with moving the regulatory baton to the Federal Reserve. "But if I had my druthers," she added, the regulator "would be the S.E.C."
Others, too, have suggested that other agencies would be preferable to the Treasury, and the Fed is a frequent choice because, as the Treasury's fiscal agent, it is most familiar with the auction process.
 
Need Seen for Clearer Division of Labor
 If nothing else, the Congressional hearings are expected to call for a clearer division of labor among regulators in this market.
"One of the things that should come out of this is a more careful consideration of the rules that govern the entire market, and whether these rules are the best for the taxpayer," said Mr. Grundfest, the former S.E.C. member, who now teaches law at Stanford University.
For example, he said, the Government could change its auction methods entirely -- automating the process, encouraging more bidders or selling a broader variety of issues. These regulatory revisions, in Mr. Grundfest's view, might produce less risk of abuse and lower borrowing costs.
One common bet in Washington is that at the very least, the S.E.C. will be given power to gather more information about the Government securities market. "It is inevitable that one of the recommendations you'll have to see come out of this," said Mr. Pitt, the lawyer, "is that the Government will start now to collect data in a more rigid way."
The immediate focus for the debate will be the reauthorization of the Government Securities Act of 1986, which will expire in October unless renewed. Although the act was meant to deal with problems in the secondary market, similar concerns have emerged following the disclosures about Salomon's behavior in the primary market.
 
'Broader Issues' Said to Be at Stake
 The big question now, Represenative Markey said, "is the broader issues surrounding the need for reform of the Government securities market." His committee and others, he added, need to explore "where we, in the Congress, need to go from here."
Treasury officials seem hopeful that they will be able to keep their pre-eminence as the regulator for their market, although they will not rule out the adoption of new procedures within the department. "We feel our authority is sufficient," one official said, "and we have begun reviewing the rules governing Treasury auctions to see what, if any, changes would be appropriate."
However the Washington power struggle turns out, it is likely that the fate of Salomon Brothers itself will be more instructive to Wall Street than anything either Congress or the Treasury could cook up. As Victor Chang, a former bond market executive and now the head of his own investment advisory firm, said after the resignation of John H. Gutfreund, Salomon's former chairman, and his two top executives: "This problem, and the way it was resolved, with three top people losing their jobs, will do more to prevent future abuses than any piece of legislation which could be introduced."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Uneven Economic Recovery Shakes Faith in Fed's Power

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The economy's uneven response to the Federal Reserve Board's deliberate reduction in short-term interest rates over the last year has led to a debate among credit market analysts about whether the Fed is capable of engineering a sustainable recovery.
"The Fed seems to have less ability to stimulate the economy today than it had in the past," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "It will be hard to get the kind of recovery we have had in the past with just monetary policy." 
 The Fed's job was clearly easier in the past, when the interest-sensitive industrial sector accounted for a larger share of overall production.
Moreover, the central bank has usually not had to act as the sole pump primer. This time, huge budget deficits at the Federal, state and local levels have effectively removed government fiscal policy as an ally.
 
New Capital Requirements
 Currently, the Fed's job is further hampered by the new capital requirements that it placed on commercial banks. Meeting those new standards is a reason that banks have been unwilling to step up lending over the last 12 months or so.
Even if new credit were readily available, it is questionable whether loan demand would be strong, given the exceptional increase in debt taken on by consumers and businesses during the 1980's, analysts said.
Because of the new capital adequacy requirements, "continually lowering rates and putting reserves into the banking system is not having the impact it formerly did and normally would," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
And Jay N. Woodworth, senior domestic economist at the Bankers Trust Company, said, "The slow death of the savings and loan industry and changes in the banking system make it more difficult for the Fed's usual policy levers to bring about changes in the growth rate of money, credit and of the economy."
 
Lower Federal Funds Rate
 Since August 1990, the Fed has reduced the overnight Federal funds rate, which it closely controls, by 2.5 percentage points, to 5.5 percent. And in recent weeks, the economy has been showing some sputtering signs of life, particularly in manufacturing industries.
Since April, a month in which many analysts think the recession bottomed, industrial production has risen by 7.5 percent at an annual rate.
But with personal income growth remaining weak, analysts question whether the rise in industrial activity during the last three months is sustainable. Car sales, they note, remain mired at close to recession lows. A failure by Detroit to move its new models in September and early October could lead to production cutbacks later in the fall.
The view is not universal that the Fed's powers have been diminished by time and special circumstances. Indeed, some analysts say the sputtering recovery may be just what the Fed wants.
 
The Fed's Intention
 "I still think the Fed has plenty of ability to affect the economy," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. Seeking to curb a resurgence in inflation, "the Fed has intentionally tried to promote a gradual recovery," Mr. Johnson said, adding, "That intention is apparent in the relatively modest cuts in the funds rate that we have seen."
Compared with the way the Fed has responded during previous recessions, the reduction of 2.5 percentage points in the Federal funds rate thus far is mild, Mr. Johnson said.
"Typically, the Fed has pushed very hard and driven the funds rate through the rate of inflation," Mr. Johnson said.
Based on recent inflation readings, the Federal funds rate would need to drop by roughly 1.5 percentage points from its current level if the Fed were to revert to previous pattern.
Few analysts are willing to say the Federal funds rate will actually decline by that much before a sustained recovery is in place. But most economists acknowledge that lower rates are needed.
 
Value of a Quarter-Point
 "Four percent funds is a long ways from where we are now," Mr. Wood at Bank of America said. "I would be surprised that the Fed would have to move that far to get the economy going again. But I don't think the next quarter-point cut in the funds rate, when it comes, will accomplish very much. The last quarter-point cut didn't get us anything."
Debate about when the Fed will move to reduce rates again will probably come to a boil this week, because employment statistics, the key monthly reading on the economy, are scheduled to be released on Friday.
In advance of the August figures, most analysts are forecasting that nonfarm payroll employment rose by about 50,000 last month, but that the unemployment rate inched higher from its 6.8 percent reading in July.
"The market is setting itself up for how the Fed is going to respond," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
In Mr. Slifer's view, a report that showed payroll growth close to the consensus forecast would provide the Fed with enough incentive to ease monetary policy further.
"Everybody will be on pins and needles on Sept. 6," Mr. Fine said. "That bothers me, but it also makes a lot of sense."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
When a Congressional committee convenes tomorrow to examine the Salomon Brothers scandal, it will set the stage for a battle over regulation of the Treasury securities market. The scandal is forcing a new examination of how the market operates, what rules govern it and how those rules are enforced. The emerging picture is of a trading community governed under poorly defined rules by a reluctant regulator: the Treasury itself, an agency that has grown dependent on the firms it oversees. [Page A1.] 
 Economists are pointing cheerfully to a recovery that they say has moved firmly into gear. But for those left behind, the recession gets darker with each passing day of no work. [A1.]
Back-to-school sales have been disappointing at many stores, executives say, and retailers have been forced to cut prices to generate sales. Experts say the weak spending bodes ill for the rest of the important fall and Christmas shopping season. [D1.]
The financial troubles of the insurance industry are making corporate-benefit consultants and other experts increasingly anxious about the safety of 401(k) retirement savings plans. [D1.]
 
Companies
Near the center of the tangled financial story of First American Bankshares is the mentor and protege relationship of Clark M. Clifford and Robert A. Altman. [D1.] Clifford and Altman resigned from their executive posts with their reputations tarnished, their pockets full and questions unanswered, investigators say. [D1.]
 
International
The Government of Panama began a legal effort in London to try to recover $23 million that it contends was stolen by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and routed through B.C.C.I. [D4.]
Soviet space officials have told the White House that their cash-hungry civilian space program may collapse unless it makes large sales to the West. They say almost everything is on the table. [C1.]
A Japanese Finance Ministry official said brokerages compensated cients even though they did not have stock-market losses, raising suspicions that profits might have been guaranteed. [D2.]
 
Markets
The dollar drifted lower overseas in trading subdued by the Labor Day holiday in the U.S. Gold was little changed. [D9.]
The uneven response to lower short-term interest rates has led to a debate about whether the Fed is capable of engineering a sustainable recovery. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D9.]

SOVIET TURMOIL A6-10
The national Congress was stunned when President Gorbachev and the leaders of 10 republics proposed to transfer all central authority to themselves and a legislative council until a new union can be formed. A1

PUB-DATE: September 3, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 3342 words

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Excerpts From Soviet Congress: Time for Drastic Changes

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a session of the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow yesterday. All speeches were translated by CNN, except for that of Aleksandr M. Obolensky, which was translated by The New York Times.
 
NURSULTAN A. NAZARBAYEV: President of Kazakhstan
 As a result of a coup d'etat committed on Aug. 19-21, the process of forming new union relationships between the sovereign republics was disrupted. These developments brought this country to the brink of catastrophe. The situation that evolved in this country after the putsch, should it get out of control, could bring about unpredictable consequences both inside this country and in our relations with foreign countries. 
 We hereby state that the frustration of the coup and the victory of the democratic forces dealt a crucial blow to the reactionary forces and to everything that had been obstructing the process of democratic change. In this way, a historic chance was created for accelerating the drastic changes and the renovation of this country.
In this situation, the lawfully elected leader of this country in the person of the U.S.S.R. President and the presidents and chairmen of the Supreme Soviets of the union republics hereby agree on the following, with a view to preventing the further disintegration of power and the creation of a new system of interrepublican relationships and the forming of interrepublican and union power structures for the transitional period until a new constitution is effected and new elections take place:
To draft and sign a treaty on the union of sovereign states between all the republics that choose to do so, with every state being able to define the format of its participation in the union;
To ask all the republics, no matter what status they have declared for themselves, to immediately enter an economic union with a view to creating a single economic sphere, and to insuring the normal functioning of the economy and accelerated conducting of economic reform.
Third, during this transitional period, efforts will be made to create a Council of Representatives of People's Deputies on the principle of equal representation from the union republics, with 20 deputies from each union republic delegated by their Supreme Soviets to perform legislative functions and prepare a new constitution of the union of sovereign republics.
Efforts will be made to set up a State Council to be led by the U.S.S.R. President and the leaders of the union republics to address major international issues.
To coordinate the economic effort and the implementation of radical reform, an interrepublican economic committee shall be set up with all the republics being represented on an equal basis.
A draft of a Constitution, after it is prepared, shall be examined and approved by the Parliaments of the union republics, and then finally endorsed at a congress of representatives of all the union republics.
The status of people's deputies shall be confirmed for the people's deputies who were elected in due manner. We hreby ask that the relevant articles of the U.S.S.R. constitution to be suspended.
Fourth, to conclude an agreement on the principles of collective security in the area of defense, to preserve a united armed forces and a united military-strategic sphere and carry out radical reform in the armed forces, the K.G.B. of the U.S.S.R. and the prosecutor's office of the U.S.S.R., taking into account the republics' sovereignty.
Fifth, to confirm strict observance of all international commitments made by the U.S.S.R., including those in the arms reduction area and foreign economic commitments.
Sixth, a declaration shall be endorsed to guarantee the rights and freedoms of citizens irrespective of their party affiliation, ethnic backgrounds and place of residence, and the rights of ethnic minorities.
Seventh, to ask the Congress of the U.S.S.R.'s People's Deputies to support the request by the union republics to join the United Nations, concerning the request for U.N. recognition of them as subjects of international law and on the question of their membership in the United Nations.
The above measures being vital, we have asked them to be examined thoroughly and approved. The document has been signed by the President of the U.S.S.R., the president of the Russian Federation, the Presidents of the Byelorussian Republic, Azerbaijan, Kirghizia, Tadzhikistan, the Ukraine, Armenia and Turkmenia.
Georgia participated in the work of this meeting. There were observations submitted by several republics. These observations and objections were ironed out last night and this morning during additional meetings.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV: President of the Soviet Union
 I will continue the work of our congress and I hope that we will be able to move forward working and listening to one another and formulating an agreed position.
I am not going to tolerate any demonstrations or demonstrative claims or shouts or whatever. If anybody wants to try to undermine our work and tries to do that, if anybody wants to cooperate, the Presidium will cooperate in a constructive way in order that we should resolve all issues.
Now, the first thing I want to do is to call upon the president of the Constitutional Committee, Sergei Alekseyev, and then I'm going to call upon the representatives of the republics.
 
SERGEI S. ALEKSEYEV: Constitutional Committee President
 Distinguished people's deputies, distinguished President, comrades. First of all, let me express my regret that the rules of procedure were violated earlier before the break. This made it possible to give an arbitrary interpretation of the process that is ongoing at the present time, which is important for the country. . . .
Now, on the substance of what we have before us, the Committee on Constitutional Supervision totally supports the statement, and let us be straightforward with one another. Our union was not only on the verge of collapse, but was in fact already in a state of collapse. We were in a state similar to that of Yugoslavia. And I am sure that this decision . . . if we consider what has happened, there was no other way of proceeding. We have to move forward, and the representatives of Armenia and the Ukraine are sitting at the table here, and that is a great achievement already.
In the second place, we have to realize that after the putsch, the country has become a different one, a genuine revolution has already started, a real perestroika. We're trying to clean up the ground to make this possible and we have every possibility of doing it.
I would like to go back to the statement I made at the Supreme Soviet. I did not resign. What I said was that we have to clean up the ground and I'm well ready to do that now. So let us proceed along that path. . . .
Many of those proposals made to us have not been properly worked through legally -- the way in which the constitution is to be changed, and the rest. Therefore, I propose that the Committee on Constitution now be entrusted to work on this. We're willing to entertain such proposals so that by tomorrow such a finished document would be in a position to be circulated.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
ANATOLY A. SOBCHAK: Mayor of Leningrad
 . . . At the session of the people's deputies of the Russian Republic deputies, the final decision was accepted to support the statement of the President of the U.S.S.R. and of the leaders of the republics on the situation, and on the necessity of creating new governmental structures for a transitional period, to accept the measures proposed in the statement as a basis for discussion, and to continue our work on creating structures for the transitional period which would stop the uncontrolled collapse of the country and which would make it possible to create a unified economic area and immediately conclude an economic union and a unified military and strategic area by creating the necessary agreements on measures of collective security, to reform the army, and a unified political area by creating a declaration on the rights of the citizen and of the individual regardless of his nationality, place of residence, party affiliation, or political persuasion, et cetera.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
YURI N. SHCHERBAK: Deputy From the Ukraine
 Comrade Deputies. In speaking at the request of the People's Deputies of the U.S.S.R. from the Ukraine, I feel it necessary to state the following. The overwhelming majority of votes from the Ukrainian delegation were in support of the agenda and the procedure as proposed by the president of the U.S.S.R. and the leaders of the republics. . . .
In the discussions, some extreme positions were in fact expressed. But on the whole we supported the comments formulated by the president of the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine, Kravchuk [Leonid M. Kravchuk], which we feel were not sufficiently taken into consideration in Comrade Nazarbayev's statement.
We think that questions of the political formulation of interrepublican associations which may arise should not be discussed at the president congress. We feel that we should not become slaves of any far-fetched schemes. We have, rather, to think about how to make sure that the population can be fed, and how the economy can function in this transitional period. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	For this transitional period we propose that we develop a rules of procedure for intergovernmental relations as accepted by the European Community. . . .
We agreed that very important questions have to be discussed immediately, and it was stressed that full unity is possible only on matters of military strategy. The Ukraine wants to become a nuclear free zone. . . .
As far as the question of the economic area was concerned, it was stated that in view of the collapse of the financial system of the U.S.S.R. the only genuine way to defend the interests of the Ukraine is to create its own finances, and financial system. And we are starting to have discussions on our gold reserves and our debts.
In conclusion, I'd like to say the following. We supported President Gorbachev and it was stated that he's got to be prevented from being attacked and in no way permit him from being relieved of his responsibilities here at this congress.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
STANISLAV SHUSHKEVICH: Deputy Speaker of Byelorussia
 Mr. Chairman, deputies. Yes, the proposals of Byelorussia are very similar to the comments just made by the representative of the Ukraine. Therefore, I have to go into them in detail.
We feel that it's necessary to take as a basis the proposal that's been made, to examine at this Congress.
We're very sensitive to the question of supporting the statement that this congress should support the statements of declaration of the republics. Byelorussia has just adopted such a statement. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
VLADIMIR T. ADYLOV: Deputy From Uzbekistan
 Distinguished chairman, deputies. We have also closely discussed the question and the proposal submitted this morning at the congress. And we support it. We're not going to repeat what has been said by those who have already spoken. We support the adoption of this proposal as a basis for discussion. Of course, we will discuss all aspects of these questions which are of interest to the union republics, and we urge all of you to start constructive work as rapidly as possible, and not to repeat the discussion. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
TENGIZ P. BUACHIDZE: Art professor From Georgia
 The Supreme Soviet of the Georgian Republic hopes that the Congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies will take into account the will of the nations of Georgia and that of the Supreme Soviet of the Georgian Republic, and will recognize a renovated Georgia with its new statehood.
Our deputies, the Georgian deputies, support the statement and note the following. While supporting the process of radical democratization taking place in the states, the process of complete abolition of the totalitarian regime, with the principle of orderliness taking the place of violence, the deputies of the Georgian Republic note the remarkable role played by the Russian parliament in the victory gained over the plotters.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
SABIT K. NEGMATULLOYEV: Head of Tadzhik Academy of Sciences
 Dear Comrades, on behalf of the people's deputies from Tadzhikistan and on behalf of the delegation of the Tadzhik Supreme Soviet, I have been instructed to express our principled support of the statement by the U.S.S.R. president and the leaders of the union republics.
We believe that this is the only way of stabilizing the current situation.
From our perspective, it is necessary to set a deadline for the economic agreement to be signed. This deadline, we believe, should be September of this year. We also believe that provisions should be made for the preservation of all the existing economic ties, including the mutual commitments in terms of interrepublican supplies for the transitional period.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
LEVON TER-PETROSYAN: President of Armenia
 I should say that what this statement does in the first place is remove the concern which I expressed in my remarks at the session of the Supreme Soviet last week where I said I feared that the previous union or structures of authorities could be resuscitated while they had long since proven impotent and bankrupt.
The President of the U.S.S.R., the union of the republics, have learned their lesson well from the coup d'etat, have come across the new realities, and instead of trying and restoring the old discredited structures, have set about setting up new interrepublican bodies of power.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The second point I would like to call your attention to is point No. 7 of the statement, which guarantees the rights of the republics to become full-fledged members of the international community and of the United Nations. In this way the republics fall under the reliable protection of international law. I am sure that the appropriate request by the Congress of People's Deputies will be positively met by the Western circles who are interested in seeing political tension reduced in the Soviet Union. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
ION KHADYRKE: Deputy Chairman, Moldavian Parliament
 The deputies of Moldavia have discussed the statement and are prepared to consider it a basis for discussion at this Congress.
At the same time, I have the honor and the privilege to bring to your knowledge the following: Considering the irreversibility of the process of democratization, freedom, independence and statehood, and establishment of a law-based societies, confirming the rights of all nations and their right of self-determination in accordance with the U.N. Charter and the Helsinki standards, the parliament of Moldovia, elected on a democratic basis, declared the Republic of Moldova a sovereign, free and independent state on Aug. 27, 1991.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
PATRIARCH ALEKSY II: Russian Orthodox Church
 Esteemed chairman, esteemed president, esteemed people's deputies, a heavy responsibility has befallen us: to witness and to participate in the recent dramatic events in the history of our motherland. We are turning a new page, a new leaf in the great chronicles and the 74 years are receding into the past. An artificial model of a welfare society based on separation with a thousand years of human experience is crumbling.
I recall these words from the Bible: "Except the Lord build the house, they labor in vain that build it." [Psalm 127:1] They were building their house on the basis of [unintelligible] and the practical rejection of the meaning and the dignity of a human life. Before our very eyes, we see a system crumbling which leaves behind us a grave legacy of spiritual emptiness and environmental catastrophes.
We have no hesitation in determining the position of the church in relation to the tragic events that befell our country in August of this year. I will not describe those events again. We were concerned by the fate of democracy, and it is understandable from the experience of the church, which existed under the burden of the totalitarian regime, which extinguished millions of dissenters and persecuted all groups of our compatriots.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
ALEKSANDR M. OBOLENSKY: A Leningrad engineer
 A group of the top leaders of the union republics, with all respect to them, having shamelessly taken all the constructive part of their resolution from the corresponding resolution of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, did not even mention the Supreme Soviet in its statement. Instead of this they made a destructive contribution, by proposing to form two unconstitutional organs of power -- the state council and council of representatives.
I think that the chairmen of the chambers of the Supreme Soviet simply betrayed the organs headed by them. . . . To put it figuratively, a week's work of the supreme organ of legislative power together with efforts of the preparatory comissions has been thrown onto a garbage heap.

 	 	 		. . .	 	As a result of the frustration of the coup the wind of democratization reached the highest level of executive power of the country, which has so far served as a stronghold of the reactionary forces. A real opportunity is emerging for a breakthrough in the sphere of the economic reforms on the basis of formation of a coalition government of public confidence.
And in this situation the leadership of the republics which on Aug. 18 were ready to sign the union treaty, began on Aug. 26 to take steps toward final dismantling of union power. This means that the dictatorship of the plotters would suit them better than retention of the constitutional system.
I would not want to believe it. Maybe it's high time to treat the Constitution like a whore, adjusting it each time to the whims of a new ruler. By experimenting with the Constitution we managed to bring the country to the verge of death.
There must be something in a society to serve as a basis of stability and law. . . . It was with outrages against legal power that all civil wars began, including ours, which began not with the October revolution, which the society took as replacement of one provisional power by another, but with dissolution of the constituent assembly.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Yes, central power has weakened. It can be easily taken by someone by just kicking us out of this hall, not to speak about physical destruction. But we do not have a right to give it up with our own hands.
On Aug. 19-21 the Supreme Soviet could not withstand the plotters, and it was ordinary people who withstood them by standing hand in hand in the squares. Today our time has come and we must stand up to defend the Constitution. If we do not manage to retain power in our hands we must, by our fate, demonstrate to the whole world the fact of its usurpation to provide for a right to resistance to the self-appointed saviors of fatherland.
And in conclusion. I am going to make some specific proposals. Taking into account that our President issued statement that were considered by the constitutional committee as contradicting to the constitution, could not perform his duty of a guarantor of rights and freedoms of citizens, allowed a plot against the constitution to ripen in his close surrounding, including his personal responsibility for nomination and persistent promotion of a candidate to vice presidency who became the head of the coup. also, taking into account the statement of support to introduction of unconstitutional organs of power, I think we can include into the agenda a question of relieving the U.S.S.R President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, from his duties.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lenin's portrait hung in its traditional place at the Congress of People's Deputies in the Kremlin last December, above. When the Congress reconvened yesterday, Lenin's image was replaced by lettering that read, "Extraordinary Congress of People's Deputies." (Photographs by Associated Press)
