HEADLINE: Israel Request Raises Issue of Settlements

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Israeli officials said today that they planned to request $10 billion in housing loan guarantees from the Bush Administration later this week, a move that could force the Administration to choose between its desire to get the Israelis to attend peace talks and President Bush's longstanding desire to tie any extra aid to a freeze on Israeli settlements in the occupied territories.
President Bush is said by aides to feel very strongly about the fact that, although the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, signed a letter last Oct. 1 promising Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that previous housing guarantees of $400 million would not be used to build new settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza strip, Israeli settlement activity there increased, financed by Israeli money instead. 
 The President, aides say, is convinced that Israel simply does not take him seriously on this issue and insists that Washington get firm commitments from Israel to freeze settlement activity in exchange for the $10 billion housing guarantee -- which would be in addition to the $3 billion in economic and military aid extended to Israel already this year. The new guarantees would be used to build housing, roads, hospitals, schools and services to help Israel absorb up to a million Soviet emigres, roughly 345,000 of whom have already arrived.
 
Obstacles to Peace Talks
 State Department and other officials, while identifying with the President's feelings on settlements, do not want him to get embroiled in a nasty political fight on this issue with the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, when Israel's cooperation is needed for the proposed Middle East peace conference.
These officials argue that the best way to freeze settlements would be in the context of a peace conference, and that to fight over the issue now would only give Israeli hardliners an excuse to back out of the conference on the grounds that the United States was taking sides on an issue that should be worked out at the bargaining table.
Senior officials said Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker discussed the issue in the Oval Office today. Israel's Ambassador to Washington, Zalman Shoval, is expected to present his formal request to Mr. Baker on Thursday or Friday. For now, the Administration has apparently decided to try to persuade Israel, and its Congressional backers, to defer the request until the peace conference, which would begin in October. The Israelis are not inclined to do that, but it is not clear where their Congressional backers stand.
 
Nationwide Lobby
 The American-Israel Public Affairs Committee, the so-called Israel lobby, has spent the last few months lining up support for the housing guarantees. It wants to see them included in this year's foreign aid bill, which is being drawn up at the end of September, so they are not delayed another year.
Jewish groups are mobilizing mass backing for the loan guarantees, including a plan to distribute information on how and why the guarantees should be supported, in synagogues around the country during the Jewish New Year holiday.
 The United States will not actually be lending the money to Israel, only guaranteeing that Israel will repay the money. This will allow Israel to go to Wall Street and borrow from commercial banks. With the guarantees, Israel will be able to get 30-year loans instead of the seven-year loans that it would be able to obtain on its own credit rating.
The cost to the United States depends on what percentage of the loan amounts the Administration has to set aside -- by law -- as a reserve. This one-time charge, set by the Office of Management and Budget in negotiation with the State Department, could be as low as $50 million or as high as $1.9 billion.
With the presidential election campaign about to begin, the guarantees could become a political issue as some Democrats press to increase spending on domestic problems.
Mr. Baker is widely expected to make a trip to the Soviet Union and the Middle East in mid-September to try to finalize the peace conference, which still is by no means a certainty. The Administration is still waiting for the Palestinians and Jordanians to come up with a list of Palestinian negotiators who would be acceptable to Israel.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
R. R. Donnelley Picks New Division Officers

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, the Chicago-based printing concern, announced top management changes yesterday for its magazine and telecommunications divisions.
John S. Oberhill, 49 years old, president of the magazine group, will become president of the telecommunications group on Oct. 1. He will succeed Ronald K. Vickrey, 55, who is retiring. 
 Edward E. Lane, 39, will succeed Mr. Oberhill as director of the magazine group. Mr. Lane was formerly vice president and director of the magazine division in Danville, Ky.
Mr. Oberhill, known as Jack, had previously worked five years in the telecommunications group, which accounted for 17 percent of the company's revenues last year. Its main services include printing telephone books and computer manuals. He said it was too early to predict whether he would make strategic changes to the group, which has reported steady sales growth in recent years.
R. R. Donnelley, the world's largest printing company, with 31,000 employees worldwide, reported a 1990 net income of $225.8 million from sales of $3.5 billion, which was 12 percent over 1989. For that year, it reported a net income of $222 million on sales of $3.1 billion.
The magazine group, which represents about 18 percent of the company's overall business, has reported steady sales increases in recent years, Mr. Oberhill said. Among the magazines it prints are TV Guide, Modern Maturity and Family Circle.
"We've suffered with the magazine industry as a whole, but our market share has grown," he said.
Mr. Oberhill joined R. R. Donnelley in 1966 as an engineer in its Chicago division. He was promoted to president of the magazine group in 1988 from senior vice president and director of manufacturing for the magazine group.
He attended the United States Military Academy and received a bachelor's degree in economics and mathematics from New York University. He and his wife, Pat, have five children.
After joining R. R. Donnelley in 1976 as a sales representative, Mr. Lane became a vice president and regional sales manager in 1984, a senior vice president and sales division director in 1988 and division director in Danville in 1990.
He has received a bachelor's degree in English from Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., and a master's degree in business administration from Cornell University. He and his wife, Jeanne, have two children.

Yeltsin, togeter urged a national congress to adopt a new governing structure ceding greater powers to the republics. A vote is expected today. Page A1.

 Views of an Apparatchik: Nikolai S. Portugalov, a member of the Soviet Communist Party for 40 of his 63 years, says: "I never thought I'd be out on the street and accused of being a member of a criminal organization. But I'm not shedding any tears for the party." Page A13.
 
Changes Across a Vast Land
 Baltics Move to Join the U.N.: Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia applied to join the United Nations, and diplomats said they might be admitted this month. Lithuania's new 31-year-old Defense Minister, a psychotherapist in his former life, is pondering how to insure security. Page A12.
 Bartering for Survival: Leningrad may be a harbinger of improvisational economic relationships within the Soviet Union. City officials have been roaming the country making barter deals for food and raw materials. But the city's residents are worried. "Anything is possible," said one woman. "We could go hungry this winter." Page A16.
 Changing Stripes in Azerbaijan: Azerbaijan's formerly Communist political machine has declared the republic independent, and even the cynics, who are plentiful, are admiring the audacious showmanship of a leadership performing for its political life. Page A16.
 
As the West Watches
 Motives Behind TV Appearances: As ABC and CNN aggressively woo Gorbachev and Yeltsin, the two leaders evidently find American television useful in helping them stabilize their leadership. Page A17.

HEADLINE: Japanese Cars Stronger In Weak U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Japan's auto companies are emerging from the recession in the United States with a far bigger slice of that market than they had two years ago, but the political problems from their success in the United States have persisted.
In the first six months of this year, Japanese companies supplied just less than 30 percent of all the passenger cars sold in the United States -- an increase of more than four percentage points in market share since 1989. 
 In recent interviews, top executives of Japanese auto makers attributed their gains to their quick success in marketing new lines of luxury cars like the Acura by Honda and the Lexus by Toyota. They also said their willingness to invest in new factories and research and development, even as their profits were badly hurt during the recession, had led to continual improvements in many of their cars. Many analysts agree.
American auto executives, meanwhile, point more to what they say are new and more subtle forms of unfair trade practices by the Japanese.
To be sure, the Japanese auto makers have not been immune to the downturn in the United States, but they have suffered far less, in terms of declining profits and sales, than their American competitors.
The contrast between the conditions of the American and Japanese auto industries is striking. While Detroit, reeling from billions of dollars in losses, sheds thousands of workers and closes plants, some Japanese auto companies complain of a shortage of workers. Just the other day, for example, Toyota said it would begin to rehire its Japanese retirees.
But for the Japanese, crossing the 30 percent barrier in the United States brings a host of political problems. Among them: increased pressure to assure that American auto makers fare better in Japan and that the Japanese sharply raise their use of American auto parts.
To their surprise, the Japanese companies are discovering that few of those problems have eased because Japan now produces a significant percentage of its cars in the United States, with American workers.
"We still have to become far more Americanized," Shoichiro Irimajiri, a top executive at the Honda Motor Company, said in a recent interview. "It took 80 years for Ford and G.M. to be considered domestic producers in Europe. And it might take us that long." Mr. Irimajiri was the architect of Honda's manufacturing strategy in the United States.
Nearly all of the Japanese manufacturers' market-share gain in the United States came from Japanese-owned factories in North America.
These so-called transplant factories of Toyota, Honda, Nissan and others are not subject to the "voluntary" export restraints on which Detroit has relied in the last decade to suppress Japanese competition.
 
Similar Plans for Europe
 As a result, actual exports of Japanese cars to the United States have fallen precipitously in recent months. In fact, this strategy of basing plants where the sales are is seen as so successful that Japan is planning to add capacity for at least a million cars a year in Europe, its next big target.
The success of the transplants has not dispelled new American complaints about the huge contribution that autos and auto parts make to the American trade deficit with Japan -- upward of 70 percent of the deficit. Partnerships between Japanese concerns and each of the Big Three auto companies did not prevent Detroit from filing charges several months ago that their Japanese competitors were "dumping" vehicles, especially mini-vans. Dumping is selling goods at below fair-market value to drive out competitors.
And for the last three months, American officials, led by Vice President Dan Quayle during a recent visit to Tokyo, have hammered at a long-standing sore point: the continuing failure of American car makers to do more than dent Japan's own auto market, the world's second-largest national market after the United States.
American auto makers have long contended that the Japanese market is rigged against them because of the expense and difficulties of establishing dealerships. But it is a complaint for which Japanese executives have no patience; they say the success of Mercedes-Benz, Volkswagen and BMW in Japan is evidence that American car makers are simply not trying hard enough.
"No one else is going to help them while they are sitting on their hands," Yutaka Kume, the president of the Nissan Motor Company, said in an interview recently.
Mr. Quayle, he added, "is wrong about the market being closed." No American auto manufacturer has designed a car specifically for the Japanese market, he said, and none builds vehicles here.
 
Recession Strategies Differ
 In interviews over the last several weeks, the top executives of several of Japan's auto companies have expressed little surprise that their competitive position has improved so much in the United States. Detroit auto makers, they said, were unprepared to deal with the recession.
"There is still a basic, fundamental difference between Japanese and U.S. manufacturers in a time of downturn," said Mr. Irimajiri, who spent most of the 1980's at Honda's assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio. "The Japanese bring out new models and try to revitalize their lines. They use a recession to rebuild their capacity. The Big Three tend to delay introductions or cut the budget to develop new models. They tend to wait."
The Japanese say they are not yet certain they will be able to maintain their 30 percent share of the market -- a level they briefly reached during the fuel crisis of the mid-70's -- when the economic recovery picks up steam. With gasoline prices low, Americans may turn again to bigger cars, meaning that Detroit should benefit more than Tokyo.
In fact, Honda's strategy for the next year -- offering a new, redesigned engine in the Civic, its low-end compact -- may improve fuel efficiency more than profitability. The car gets more than 50 miles a gallon on the highway.
 
Beachhead in Luxury Market
 But what has helped the Japanese the most, analysts said, is that they have finally won an important share of the market for large and luxurious cars, and they did so at a pace that few anticipated in the late 1980's. Those cars are still all made in Japan -- one reason that the deficit in automobile trade seems to stay high even though the number of cars shipped from Japan has declined.
The earliest of these luxury brands, Honda's Acura, remains extraordinarily successful. Sales of the Toyota Motor Corporation's Lexus have also remained strong.
Even Nissan's Infiniti -- a car that got off to a halting start in the United States with its Zen-inspired commercials that featured rocks rather than cars, leaving customers befuddled -- is starting to pick up.
Other Japanese car makers are jumping in: the Mazda Motor Corporation just announced a new luxury car division, and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation recently introduced a luxury model, the Diamante.
Nissan is perhaps the best example of how quickly the Japanese car makers are bouncing back from their recession lows. In July, it posted a 24 percent increase in sales in the United States, compared with July 1990. Nissan has overhauled its product line on both continents, and it has enjoyed particular success in Japan with a series of specialty cars, many in a style that harkens back to the 1950's.
Still, each of the Japanese car makers is facing growing pains. Production is stagnant this year in Japan, though Toyota has seen its passenger car production drop 5 percent.
Honda, always more popular in America than in its home country, is losing market share in Japan, prompting an organizational shake-up that the company said was long overdue. "We became too big," Mr. Irimajiri said. "We had success for 10 or 15 years straight, but we expanded too rapidly. We need to regain our old speed." The company has recently introduced a tiny convertible, called the Beat, that has begun to revitalize its sales in Japan.
The unknown for all of the Japanese makers is Europe. No sooner had Japan and the European Community reached an agreement a few weeks ago on limiting Japan's presence there -- much like the "voluntary restraint" agreement in the United States -- than they began to bicker openly about what the agreement meant. The big issue is whether, as Japan says, the agreement puts no limit on the number of cars it can make in Europe, cars that would be considered "European" in origin.
Japan produces a little more than 200,000 cars a year in Europe -- mostly in Britain -- and it plans to increase that number to a million or more.
One reason the Japanese are so vociferous on the issue is that they fear any limit on transplants could inspire the United States to do the same. Already, there has been some movement in the United States to begin treating "transplant" cars as Japanese, not American. The Bush Administration has opposed those moves, saying they would chill investment in the United States.

HEADLINE: Dow Plummets 25.93 to Finish at 3,017.67

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday amid persistent concerns about the pace of the nation's economic recovery and the impact of computerized trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 25.93 points, to 3,017.67, the lowest reading since news of the failure of the coup in the Soviet Union sent stocks soaring two weeks ago. 
 The Nasdaq composite index was down 4.77 points, to 520.91, a drop of nearly 1 percent. The American Stock Exchange's composite index was off 0.61, to 371.52. The Standard & Poor's 500 index declined 3.28, to 392.15. And the New York Stock Exchange's index was down 1.56, to 215.13.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said computer-driven selling accounted for 15.22 points of the Dow's decline.
Declining issues outpaced advancing stocks by a margin of about 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 955 issues declining and 613 gaining. Trading increased to 153.7 million shares, from 143.4 million on Friday -- the last trading session before Labor Day.
The Dow climbed in the first hour, after a report by the nation's purchasing managers indicated that the manufacturing economy expanded in August. But a sell program after 11 A.M. took the Dow down sharply. After holding steady for much of the afternoon, a series of three more computerized sell programs sent the Dow plunging another 25 points after 2:45.
"The decline cannot be attributed to any one thing in particular," said Alan Titunick, president of Davis, Dinsmore Associates. "The bond market has been keeping the stock market up, and a lot of people have had high expectations."
Mr. Titunick added that expectations that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates had helped push stock prices upward. "But perhaps people anticipate that that won't happen any time soon," he said.
Walt Disney was a big loser on the Big Board, with the largest drop among the Dow issues. The stock, which fell 2, to 116 3/4, has been hurt in recent weeks by analysts' estimates of lower earnings. Eastman Kodak closed at 41 1/2, down 1 5/8. It has been hurt because of job cuts and its plans to take a charge in the third quarter. International Paper was down 1 3/8, to 68 1/4, and DuPont was off 1, to 47 1/4. Those four stocks contributed about 40 percent of the Dow's decline.
I.B.M. was among the big gainers in a day of declining issues, climbing 1 1/8, to 98. The company announced on Monday that it and the Westland Group had won an order from the British Navy to produce equipment for the next generation of anti-sumbarine helicopters.
On the New York Stock Exchange, the most active issue was Browning Ferris, a waste-management company. It stunned investors by announcing that it expected lower fourth-quarter and full-year profits. The stock was down 4, to 21 3/4, with 3.37 million shares changing hands.
The most active issue on the American Stock Exchange was Continental Airlines Holdings, which was up 3/8, to 2 1/8, with 925,200 shares changing hands. The company confirmed that it was holding talks with H. Ross Perot Jr. about a possible venture.
In over-the-counter trading, the most active issue was Xoma, a biotechnology company. The stock was down 2 1/2, to 20 1/2, with 4.5 million shares changing hands. The company's stock was affected by anticipation about the results of the Food and Drug Administration's tests of drugs for treating a deadly bacterial infection. The results were expected today.

HEADLINE: Forstmann Little in Deal For a Share of Whittle

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Forstmann Little & Company has signed an initial agreement to invest $350 million for a one-third interest in Whittle Communications, the media company that was founded by Christopher Whittle.
The investment would reduce the stakes in Whittle now held by Time Warner Inc., Associated Newspapers of London, Mr. Whittle and 60 Whittle executives. 
 Forstmann Little, an investment firm that has historically specialized in leveraged buyouts while avoiding the junk bonds that characterized many of those deals in the 1980's, is expected to put up the $350 million in subordinated financing, convertible at a future date into a one-third equity stake.
One executive with knowledge of the talks said the conversion would be in three to five years. Theodore Forstmann, general partner in the firm, would not confirm that timetable.
 
Sharp Jump in Value
 The conversion would value Whittle Communications, based in Knoxville, Tenn., at $1.05 billion, a significant increase over the value that the former Time Inc. had put on Whittle in 1988, when it bought 50 percent of the company for $185 million.
Until the conversion takes place, valuing the company is tricky. Reginald K. Brack, chairman of Time Warner Publishing, said his company's initial investment had more than doubled. Analysts generally agreed that it appeared to be a very good deal for Time Warner.
The investment would give Whittle Communications financing at a relatively low cost; the interest is 6 percent. In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Whittle said that $220 million of the money would be used for existing projects and new businesses. He said the balance would go to existing partners. Time Warner would receive $65 million.
The current ownership of the company would be diluted, with Time Warner's stake dropping to 33.3 percent from 50 percent; Associated Newspapers' stake falling to 22 percent from 33 percent; Mr. Whittle's to 7.3 percent from 11 percent, and the 60 executives' stake falling to 4 percent from 6 percent.
Because Time Warner has been extremely optisimistic about Whittle's growth, some analysts attributed its willingness to take a reduced stake to its heavy debt load. Mr. Brack, however, rejected that idea, saying that a new investor would benefit both Whittle and Time Warner.
"We speed up growth, and we don't have to invest anything more in the interim," he said.
Mr. Whittle said he was willing to take a reduced stake in the company because he believed he would own a smaller piece of a larger pie.
Dennis Leibowitz, who follows the company for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said it appeared to be a very good deal for Time Warner. The company has already recouped $65 million of its $185 million investment and would still own a third of a company with a current value of about $800 million and a potential value of more than $1 billion.
 
Broadcasting Interests
 Since 1988 Whittle has cut back its special-interest magazines and added an advertiser-supported school television network and a television channel for doctors' offices and other medical centers. Mr. Whittle said that revenues for the year ended June 30, were $207 million, and they are expected to reach $300 million this year.

HEADLINE: Saudis Increasing Oil Storage

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 3

 BODY:
With Soviet oil production falling precipitously, Saudi Arabia has significantly increased its stocks of oil in storage to around 60 million barrels and is signaling its determination to keep worldwide supplies plentiful and prices down.
A senior official in the Persian Gulf oil industry, in a telephone interview today, confirmed a published report that the Saudis have been storing oil at the impressive rate of 400,000 to 500,000 barrels a day since July. The report appeared in Petrostrategies, an oil newsletter published in Paris. The publication, which is close to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, noted that Saudi Arabia would be going to the Geneva meeting of OPEC oil ministers this month "with some 50 to 60 million barrels of onshore and offshore oil stocks."
 
On Land and at Sea
 Because Saudi Arabia has the oil stored both on land and in tankers at sea, the country is in an ideal position to replace immediately any supply shortfalls, particularly from the Soviet Union. Most other oil-producing nations are operating at capacity and do not have ample stored supplies. 
 The increased storage also underlines Saudi Arabia's often-stated intention of keeping world oil prices at their present low levels -- about $18.70 a barrel for OPEC oil -- to encourage consumption and discourage consumers from switching to other fuels. The Saudis are sending their message largely to the price hawks in OPEC -- Algeria, Iran and Libya. Those nations are expected to press for higher oil prices at the Geneva meeting scheduled for Sept. 24.
Oil industry officials said that another consideration behind the Saudi move was the widely shared expectation among oil experts that worldwide demand for oil would rise sharply in the fall and winter.
"The Saudis are quite happy with current prices and want to make sure that OPEC will be in a position to supply the market with all the oil that is needed in the fourth quarter this year and the first quarter next year," said Gary Ross, an executive of Petroleum Industry Research Associates in New York.
Oil experts expect the demand for OPEC oil in the next few months to rise to a level between 24.5 million barrels a day and 25 million. OPEC, of which Saudi Arabia is the largest producer, is now pumping about 23.6 million barrels a day. For most oil producers, including other OPEC members, it would be difficult to raise output without spending substantially on their infrastructures.
In the immediate future, Saudi Arabia wishes to preserve its dominance within OPEC, both by showing it can respond to additional demand and by keeping prices down.
The Saudi view, officials said, is that any increase in oil exports from Iraq and Kuwait would be offset this year, at least, by a fall in Soviet exports, leaving Saudi Arabia as the ultimate world supplier.
 
Slow Comeback for Kuwait
 Kuwaiti oil exports, which have resumed recently at the low rate of about 140,000 barrels a day, are expected by experts to rise slowly to 200,000 barrels a day over the next few months. Iraq is still subject to a ban on its oil exports imposed by the United Nations during the gulf crisis, but a relaxation of the ban is possible. The amount of exports allowed would, however, probably be kept low until Iraq adhered to all resolutions of the United Nations Security Council.
Soviet oil production, which exceeded 12 million barrels a day four years ago, has fallen to 10.5 million barrels a day this year and is expected by oil industry executives to tumble further, given the nation's deteriorating economic condition.
More important, Soviet exports of oil and refined products to both Western and Eastern Europe have fallen to an average of 2.60 million barrels a day this year from an estimated 4.11 million barrels a day in 1988, according to Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a Boston-based oil consulting firm.
 
The Soviet 'Wild Card'
 An Arab involved in the gulf oil industry, who asked not to be identified, said: "In the next four or five years, the wild card in the world oil industry is going to be the Soviet Union. If, in addition to that, you have another accident like the gulf crisis, prices could shoot up, which is just what Saudi Arabia wants to guard against."
At the September OPEC meeting, Iran and Algeria are expected to push for keeping OPEC output low so that prices could rise closer to an average of $21 a barrel, a target price that OPEC adopted some years ago but has not been able to maintain, partly because of expanding Saudi production. Now, it seems that Saudi Arabia wants to keep the price at current levels by using its stored oil as a backup supply.
The advantage of storing oil on tankers at sea is that it can be offered for sale instantly and be placed close to strategic markets.
Since the beginning of the gulf crisis in August of last year, Saudi Arabia has substantially increased its exports of oil, from five million barrels a day to more than eight million, and has repeatedly indicated its unwillingness to cut back.

HEADLINE: Spending on Construction Rose 1.6% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Residential and Government spending helped raise the value of new construction 1.6 percent in July, the Commerce Department said in a report released today. Analysts said the findings showed that the building industry was continuing to make a spotty recovery from the recession.
"But the real strength continues to be outside the commercial and non-residential sectors in general," said Daryl Delano, an analyst at Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. 
 Over all, residential, nonresidential and Government spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $404.9 billion, up from $398.7 billion in June, the report said. But the total value of new construction in July was 10.6 percent below that of July 1990.
Spending in June actually fell one-tenth of 1 percent rather than the three-tenths of 1 percent gain that was initially estimated a month ago. That adjustment made the July increase the first since a 1.0 percent advance in April. In May, spending declined 1.7 percent, to $399 billion.
Residential spending rose 2.2 percent, to $161.9 billion, its third consecutive monthly rise. But the gain was entirely in single-family housing, which jumped 5.1 percent, to $96.7 billion, also the third straight increase.
Spending on apartment projects continued to slide, for the seventh straight month. This sector, which has been slowed by overbuilding and the stricter lending standards, was down 6.8 percent, to $13.8 billion.
Nonresidential spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $95.2 billion, after falling for two months. But the rise was largely centered in industrial projects, which rose 4.7 percent, their second consecutive gain.
Mr. Delano said hotel spending was off 51 percent from July 1990. Spending on other commercial projects, like shopping centers, fell 32 percent.
Despite budget constraints, Government spending rose 1.9 percent, to $109.9 billion, after a two-tenths of 1 percent loss in June. Educational construction rose 2.2 percent, to $23.2 billion; spending on roads slipped 3.5 percent, to $27.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
When Children Have Children

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows that teen-age pregnancy is the curse of the underclass -- that children who have children doom themselves to a life of poverty and dependence. But everyone, it seems, could be wrong.
A National Bureau of Economic Research working paper published this summer by Arline Geronimus, a researcher at the University of Michigan, and Sanders Korenman, a Princeton economist, offers striking evidence that early motherhood does not much affect women's future earnings or increase the probability they will end up on welfare. 
 No reasonable interpretation of the results, however, will provide comfort to the more-the-merrier, birth-control-is-genocide crowd. The fact that poor women lose little by giving birth as teen-agers, Mr. Korenman argues, says only that poor women have little to lose.
Study after study has shown that girls who have babies end up poorer and less educated than other women. And the experience of the women in the broad sample used by Ms. Geronimus and Mr. Korenman is no different. Among women followed for two decades by the Center for Human Resource Research at Ohio State University, those who became mothers as teen-agers were four times as likely to end up on welfare and three times as likely to become dropouts as those who waited to have babies.
But correlation is not causation: The fact that people with heart disease average more sleep than healthy adults does not mean that sleep damages the heart. And as one might expect, studies that have been controlled for family background -- parents' income, race, education and occupational status -- suggest that early pregnancy is just one of several factors determining the economic future of young women.
Ms. Geronimus and Mr. Korenman suspected, however, that these standard background variables did not capture all the relevant differences between families. So they limited their own statistical analysis to a sub-sample of 51 families in which at least one sister had a baby before age 20 and at least one did not.
They discovered that teen-age motherhood lost most of its dismal predictive value: Early parenthood in itself apparently did not make it more likely that the women would end their schooling before high school graduation or become dependent on welfare.
What is one to make of this remarkable finding? The casual interpretation is that teen-age pregnancy is no big deal -- and thus that denying teen-agers easy access to birth control information and abortion would have no great social or economic consequence.
And apparently inadvertently, Ms. Geronimus has given her critics reason to believe this is her own reading of the evidence. In earlier scholarly articles she argued that contrary to the conventional wisdom poor women were more apt to deliver healthy babies when they were teen-agers -- before their capacity for successful reproduction was damaged by drugs and hard living. She has also speculated that poor teen-age mothers, in contrast to older impoverished mothers, are better able to draw on extended families for support of the young.
But a simpler and more defensible interpretation of this study's result is that 1990's-style poverty is apt to ruin the lives of young women, whether or not they give birth as teen-agers. The fact that so many poor girls choose to have the babies may follow from their sense that they have nothing better to look forward to. Or as Ms. Geronomus put it, "Teen-age fertility among the poor may well be an adaptive response to social reality."
This does not imply that teen-age motherhood is any less of a catastrophe: Something is deeply wrong, it is safe to assume, when 15-year-old girls would rather change diapers than get on with the adventure of growing up. Nor does it get politicians and school administrators off the hook on abortion and contraception. Girls who are motivated to break out of poverty may still lack the means to make it without help in remaining childless.
What the findings may do, however, is make it less respectable to dismiss poverty as the consequence of sin. The very idea of an underclass is an embarrassment to a nation that takes great pride in social mobility. Thus for many Americans, the only plausible explanation for chronic poverty in a land of opportunity is moral deficiency.
Few of the liberal social scientists who have been sounding the alarm about teen-age parenthood in the last decade would classify themselves as moralists. But the idea that poverty is a consequence of casual, early sex does mesh neatly with the view that bad things mostly happen to bad people. And while the Geronimus-Korenman research is not likely to cause a sea change in attitudes, it might slow the gradual but unmistakable erosion of public sympathy for the victims of poverty.

HEADLINE: Lumber Tax To Be Ended By Canada

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Canada told the United States today that it would cancel a tax on lumber exports, a move that could reignite a longstanding political battle over lumber trade and complicate negotiations for a continental free-trade area that would also include Mexico.
The tax had been imposed in 1986 in response to American complaints that Canada was subsidizing its lumber industry. The decision to remove it brought an immediate protest from the United States. 
 The Office of the United States Trade Representative said in a statement that it regretted Canada's action and would be "considering all options, including imposition of a U.S. import tax, if appropriate, to offset any existing subsidies."
 
Imposed Since 1986
 Canada signed a memorandum of understanding with the United States on Dec. 31, 1986, to impose a 15 percent tax on southbound exports of softwood lumber. If it had not done so, a permanent tax would have been imposed on these shipments the next day by the United States.
The Reagan administration had sought the tax, even though it raised prices for the American construction industry, because it said Government subsidies were allowing Canadian lumber companies to undercut American rivals.
The Administration and American producers contended that fees charged by Canadian provincial governments for timber harvests on public lands were so low that they amounted to production subsidies. The memorandum provided for the tax to be lifted if the fees were raised.
Michael H. Wilson, Canada's Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and its Minister for International Trade, said in a statement today that provinces accounting for 92 percent of Canadian exports had raised their fees.
Canadian lumber producers had also lobbied aggressively for an end to the export fees, contending that since the memorandum was signed they were burdened with falling lumber prices, a stronger Canadian dollar and a slumping housing construction market in North America.
Canada's leading lumber-exporting province, British Columbia, has been exempt from the export tax since 1987 under an amendment to the memorandum that links timber harvesting fees there to lumber prices. Lumber has risen in price this year, and Gus Kuehne, the president of the Northwest Independent Forest Manufacturers, a trade group in Tacoma, Wash., said that the Canadian move today was an effort to avoid raising the harvest fees in British Columbia.
A Canadian official who insisted on anonymity said Canada acted now because it had just finished a large-scale study showing that the provinces' management of their forests was profitable, and that no subsidies were involved.
Either country may cancel the 1986 memorandum by giving 30 days' notice. Canada served notice today, so that the pact will expire on Oct. 4.
Lawmakers from Western lumber-producing states were quick to criticize the announcement today by the Canadian Government and to link it to the talks now under way for a North American Free Trade Agreement.
"You certainly can't feel very confident blasting forward on a set of expanded market-opening measures when they can't even honor a smaller agreement," said Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who voted in May to give the Administration authority to negotiate the free-trade pact.

HEADLINE: Industry Survey Shows Solid Growth in August

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Helped by a surge in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded solidly in August, according to a monthly survey by the nation's purchasing managers. It was the third consecutive monthly expansion and economists saw it as another sign that the nation's economic recovery was under way at a steady, albeit gradual pace.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its monthly index of business activity edged up to 54.8 percent, from 51.8 percent in July. The index, compiled from interviews with purchasing officers at more than 300 industrial companies across the country, was at 50.9 percent in June. Before that, the survey had indicated a decline in the manufacturing economy for more than a year. 
 A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is declining, while a reading above 50 percent indicates an expansion.
 
Pace Seen Accelerating
 "The index demonstrates that economic activity is still rising and, measured by this index, it appears that the pace of expansion has accelerated recently," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former governor of the Federal Reserve and president of Brimmer & Associates, an economic consulting firm in Washington. "The reduction in inventories suggests that production in the future will most likely pick up somewhat as demand continues to expand."
The purchasing managers' report came out as the Government released data stating that construction spending rose 1.6 percent in July. The two reports, which followed conflicting economic reports last year, sent stock prices higher briefly yesterday morning, before the market sagged again.
Mr. Brimmer said that a gradual increase in prices in the economy indicated "there is little pressure on capacity at the moment." He added, "This suggests that the industrial sector is sharing and is supporting the economic recovery."
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers from a wide range of industrial companies. Also, it is the first important indicator each month of how the nation's economy performed in the previous month.
The survey indicated that production rose moderately in August, while employment declined. Also, new orders for export expanded in August at a higher pace than in the previous month.
The August figures represented the highest level in the purchasing managers' survey since December 1988, when the index stood at 56 percent.
"The economic recovery galvanized in August," said Robert J. Bretz, director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. and chairman of the association's survey committee. "The continued growth in the manufacturing economy was apparently achieved without any growth in inventory."
 
Gain Termed Significant
 Mr. Bretz and several economists suggested that the gain in new orders was particularly significant because it served as a harbinger of the pace of industrial production in the months to come. The survey's index of new orders climbed to 63.1 percent, up sharply from 56.3 percent in July. That was the highest level in more than three years; the index stood at 63.3 percent in June 1988.
The association's index of new orders for export climbed to 55 percent, from 52.5 percent in July. Production continued to grow in August, the third consecutive monthly increase and the highest reading since June 1988, when the index stood at 61.7 percent. The production index rose to 61.4 percent, from 59.5 percent in July. Economists said production should increase sharply in coming months because of the increase in new orders.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Undaunted by Doubters, Wilder Ponders '92

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
A call for budget cuts and fiscal responsibility is probably not the most compelling message for the more liberal voters of the Democratic Presidential primaries.
And a first-term Governor only 20 months into his term is probably not the strongest contender for his party's Presidential nomination, some analysts would argue. 
 But Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia is comfortable contradicting conventional wisdom. When he ran for lieutenant governor in 1985, he tells his audiences, "People said I was crazy." And when he ran for governor in 1989, he says, "People said I was certifiably insane."
 
'My Future Is Now'
 Now Mr. Wilder, the first black to be elected Governor of a state in the nation's history, is considering a run for the Presidency. Barred by Virginia law from seeking two consecutive terms and facing a wide-open field for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Governor Wilder says with a smile: "Some people say my future is now. I don't see any downside at all."
The 60-year-old Governor would bring to the race a compelling life story, a clear star appeal and a set of sharp political elbows. He wants to run as a chief executive who can "put necessities before niceties," put the nation's fiscal house in order and ease the tax burden on the middle class. He positions himself as an outsider, taking aim at the clubby Washington elites and what he calls their annual "fiscal follies."
 
Battle in the South
 Mr. Wilder's entry could set the stage for a hard-fought campaign in the South against a fellow Governor, Bill Clinton of Arkansas, another potential candidate. This could be all the more competitive if the Rev. Jesse Jackson chooses not to run, a move that would give Mr. Wilder and others a much clearer shot for the support of black voters, who made up 24 percent of the Democratic vote in the 1988 "Super Tuesday" Southern primaries.
It is an intriguing script for a Presidential campaign, but Mr. Wilder has often veered from it. After announcing an exploratory committee last spring, he spent much of the summer in the limelight -- not over his Presidential ambitions, but over a bitter, almost incomprehensible feud with Senator Charles S. Robb, a fellow Democrat and Virginian.
In his recent Presidential forays Mr. Wilder has found himself still explaining and apologizing for a remark he made in midsummer about Judge Clarence Thomas: Mr. Wilder suggested to reporters that the Supreme Court nominee should be closely questioned about his views on abortion because of his Roman Catholic background.
Like many of the other potential candidates for the Democratic nomi nation, Mr. Wilder has few credentials on foreign policy. He drew attention to that vulnerability last week when he seemed to discuss, in a television interview, the possibility of assassinating Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President, as a means of bringing stability to the Middle East.
For all of that, Mr. Wilder seemed unshaken, blithely ready for new battles as he drove through New Hampshire last week. He brushed aside the talk of gaffes and stumbles, and dismissed the notion of an invincible President Bush.
"It bothers me, it really bothers me, when people say Bush can't be beaten," Mr. Wilder said in an interview. "Why? Who says so? Margaret Thatcher couldn't be beaten. Winston Churchill couldn't be. Gorbachev couldn't be.
"All were considered experts on foreign policy, but hoist on the petard of domestic inactivity," the Governor said.
 
Emphasis on Domestic Needs
 Mr. Wilder sticks implacably to the nation's domestic needs, even as the Soviet Union implodes in ever more dramatic ways. Amid rising calls for aid to the Soviet Union, Mr. Wilder said, "Before there is any significant aid in any massive amount, the American people ought to be considered our first priority."
His latest slogan is "Put America First," an echo of past isolationist movements in the United States that campaign aides said was inadvertent.
Like other Democratic contenders, Mr. Wilder focuses on the troubled economy -- "We're in for hard times, lean times, even mean times," he says -- but his emphasis and his remedies are not the normal Democratic fare.
Mr. Wilder argues that "the restoration of the nation's fiscal health" should become "the highest priority." He assails the "fiscal follies in Washington, which see more and more of our national resources going not to educate our kids, not to reform our health care system, not to build new industries, but merely to service the mushrooming debt that has been growing in order to pay for the high living of the past."
 
$35 Billion in Tax Relief
 He calls for $50 billion in cuts in the Federal budget, redirecting $35 billion to middle-class tax relief and $15 billion to state and local governments for new approaches to social problems like drug abuse. He does not specify where those cuts are to be made, but cites his record in Virginia as evidence he could make them, and points to his ability to handle the state's fiscal problems by cutting spending rather than raising taxes to balance the budget.
Robert D. Holsworth, chairman of the political science department at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, said Mr. Wilder "can certainly point to an unwavering commitment to fiscal discipline in the state since he came into office." But Mr. Holsworth added that Mr. Wilder has been largely a "status quo, caretaker Governor," with little he can point to in the way of experimentation in social programs.
Joe Elton, executive director of the Virginia Republican Party, asserted, "It's sort of like Dukakis; the story he sells is not exactly the story we're living in Virginia."
Governor Wilder also argues that the Democratic Party needs to address, head on, the issue of civil rights in the face of Republican efforts to cast the Democrats as advocates of racial quotas.
"It's something that Democrats cannot and should not be afraid to debate and put on the table," he said in an interview. "Mr. Bush, are you going to make this a gentler, kinder nation? Then quit this nonsense about the civil rights act being a quota bill. Quit it. You know darn well that it's not a quota bill."
The Governor added: "If they want to know what real quotas are I could tell them -- sitting in the back of the bus, being herded into neighborhood theaters, not being able to get a book out of the neighborhood library. Denied the opportunity to vote -- by law. Denied the opportunity to hold elective office - by law. Talk about quotas -- come on, let's get real now. And not be afraid to discuss it, anywhere."
On the stump Mr. Wilder was often vague on bread-and-butter Democratic issues like health care. "He'll need to get more specific as the campaign progresses," said Robert Craig, a former state Democratic chairman and professor of political science at the University of New Hampshire, after listening to the Virginia Governor speak there.
But Mr. Wilder has a gracious style with voters that was very much in evidence in New Hampshire, where he ended nearly every encounter with a "God bless." He chatted companionably about the economy in a barber shop in Nashua. He headed into a restaurant in Portsmouth, press entourage sprawling behind him, and was greeted by the proprieter, Emilio Maddaloni, like a long-lost friend -- "You gotta cream soda here, here you go."
When a passer-by in Nashua told Mr. Wilder that the Democrats would "never, never, never" beat Mr. Bush, the Governor replied with a smile, "Never say never." And when he was asked about his background at a Democratic reception in Nashua, Mr. Wilder began, "I went to Haaaaa-vard." Then he proceeded to give his actual educational resume: Virginia Union University and Howard University School of Law.
Mr. Wilder says he will announce his decision on whether to run for the Presidency on or around Sept. 15.
 
Ready to Compare Records
 Paul Goldman, the chairman of the Virginia Democratic Party and a top adviser to the Governor, said he looks forward to putting Mr. Wilder's record up against those of potential competitors. As for the argument that Mr. Wilder has a comparatively short tenure as Governor for a Presidential contender, Mr. Goldman said: "Doug Wilder has been in government a long time. And unlike Bill Clinton, Doug Wilder couldn't have been elected Governor of Virginia in 1978."
Mr. Wilder seemed delighted to be back on the campaign trail last week. He was more reflective, in an interview, when asked if he burned to be President.
"That's what I've got to find out," he said. "If I burned, there wouldn't be any qustion about what I'd be doing."
Moments later, however, as he prepared for his next campaign event, he said, "I'll tell you, it's warming up."

With him were Eileen Foley, left, the Mayor of Portsmouth, and Anita Freedman, chairman of the city's Democratic Party. (pg. A21) (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Families Seek Out Shelters As Route to Better Homes

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
New York City's shelter system for homeless families has become so livable that hundreds, if not thousands, of families who could stay elsewhere are flocking to shelters so they can move to the top of the list for permanent subsidized housing, city officials say.
Dorian and Renita Steeley and their three children, for example, were crowded into a two-bedroom apartment with relatives. But they wanted their own place. So they went to the city and said they were homeless. They now have a functional two-bedroom apartment in a Bronx shelter, at a cost to the city of $2,730 a month. 
 Mr. Steeley is certified to work with the mentally ill, and Mrs. Steeley has been employed as a dental assistant. But they are now receiving public assistance, and neither plans to work until they get a permanent place to live.
"I consider this a little vacation, " she said recently.
 
Distorting System's Purpose
 City officials say families like the Steeleys are distorting the shelter system's original purpose -- to help families who have no place to live or who live in dangerous conditions -- and raising questions about the city's strategy for aiding homeless families.
Critics say that the city's policy on homelessness, which is by far the most generous and extensive in the nation, illustrates the difficulty of balancing society's responsibility to help the poor against the poor's responsibility to help themselves.
The city, which was long criticized for dumping homeless families into crumbling, drug-infested welfare hotels, has in recent years built a system that is more humane. But at the same time, officials in the administration of former Mayor Edward I. Koch warned that making it too easy for families in shelters to get permanent housing could lure more families into the system.
Some experts argue that the system now perversely rewards such "homeless" families by giving them priority for subsidized housing -- and in effect penalizes those who continue to struggle without help in overcrowded, often substandard apartments.
 
'They're Not Stupid'
 It is only natural that some families will use the rules of the system to their advantage, said Randall Filer, a professor of economics at Hunter College. "The clients may be poor, but they're not stupid," he said.
The Steeleys could have stayed on with relatives, Renita Steeley said, but they saw the shelter system as an opportunity to improve their lot.
They are now waiting for a permanent apartment in a city-run public housing project. The waiting list for such housing is 189,000 names long. But the city is setting aside 2,000 of an anticipated 8,000 apartment vacancies this year for homeless families in the shelter system, so the Steeleys have a much better chance of getting a unit than a family on the waiting list that is not officially "homeless."
Mr. Steeley said it would have made a lot more sense for the city to place them directly in permanent housing. "We have skills," he said. "We're not bums. We just need a place to live."
Unlike the Steeleys, Shirley H. and Jamel H. work full time, as Wells Fargo guards at a city homeless shelter, earning $6.90 an hour each. But these homeless shelter workers, who have a 5-month-old baby, are now "homeless" themselves.
The couple -- who would not allow their last name to be used -- understood the system. They were living with Jamel's mother in Harlem -- nine people jammed into a two-bedroom apartment -- when they decided to enter the shelter system in the hope of being placed in permanent housing.
Jamel knew he did not want to live in a barracks-type shelter where many families share a single, large room -- the so-called Tier I shelters. He and Shirley work in a Tier I, after all.
"I would have stayed at my mother's house or gone to my brother's," rather than go to a Tier I, Jamel said. And many other families make the same choice. About 25 percent of the families assigned to Tier I shelters are no-shows, according to city records.
But the city assigned Shirley and Jamel to a Tier II shelter, where they have a private two-bedroom apartment. They got priority for a Tier II placement because they have a baby.
In the last five years, the city has tripled the number of Tier II apartments for homeless families, to 3,200. As the family shelter system has improved, the cost of running it has skyrocketed from $28 million in 1983 to an anticipated $210 million this year.
Now, while Jamel and Shirley wait to qualify for subsidized housing, they are taking advantage of the months with no rent to pay. Jamel, 37 years old, asked, "Where else you going to go where you don't have to pay bills and have time to save something?"
In the last few years, the shelter system has improved so much that thousands of families live in decent, rent-free apartments while they wait a few months to a year for permanent, subsidized housing.
 
A Right to Shelter
 The driving engine of city policy is a 1986 state court order, obtained by legal advocates for the homeless, that gives families a right to shelter on demand. But the city has no system or staff to find out whether families truly have no other options for housing.
Larry Schatt, director of city shelters for homeless families in the Human Resources Administration, said: "You could have credit cards and money in the bank, and if you say you can't house yourself, I still have to house you. I have no real ability to verify anything."
Mayor David N. Dinkins came into office in 1990 with plans to reduce the number of homeless families in welfare hotels and shelters. His administration mobilized to move them quickly into permanent housing, cutting the wait from nine months to three months or less.
The administration acted despite an explicit warning from William J. Grinker, head of the Human Resources Administration under Mayor Koch, that speeding up the placement of families in permanent housing could encourage more families to enter the system.
At the time, Nancy G. Wackstein, director of Mayor Dinkins's office on homelessness, dismissed the idea that people used shelters as a route to permanent housing. Only cynics would argue that, she thought.
"I was a little more naive then," she now says ruefully. "It was a Kochian philosophy that I had rejected."
 
More Enter the System
 But Ms. Wackstein -- who resigned yesterday, citing frustration with the city's inability to solve the problems of homelessness -- said it quickly became evident that the faster families got out of the shelters, the faster new families came in.
About 11,290 families entered the shelter system last year, compared with 10,370 the year before and 9,640 in fiscal year 1989. Of the 11,290 families last year, city records show that about three-quarters were living doubled up with friends or relatives just before entering the system.
It is impossible to say how many of those families were forced out of their previous homes and really have nowhere else to go, but city officials say that a substantial portion of them entered the shelter system voluntarily.
The city's Housing Authority estimates that 100,000 people are living doubled up in public housing alone.
Advocates for the homeless, however, dispute the contention that large numbers of families are coming into the shelter system by choice. "The overwhelming majority of families seeking shelter have no other options," said Steve Banks, coordinating attorney of the Homeless Family Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society.
 
Shortage of Housing
 City officials and advocates for the homeless agree that the central problem is a shortage of low-income housing. The Federal Government pays half the costs of sheltering homeless families, but has slashed spending to create permanent homes that poor people can afford. The city has spent $600 million since 1984 to create 27,000 permanent apartments for homeless families and single adults, but the demand is unquenched.
City officials have considered a number of changes to try to insure that the shelter system is used only as a last resort for the desperate.
In November, the Dinkins administration tried to discourage doubled-up families from moving into shelters by once again making them wait 9 to 12 months in the system to get most apartments. The city also set aside about 1,000 subsidized apartments for doubled-up families who had not entered the shelter system.
The city has also considered narrowing the definition of homelessness to families who really have no place -- or no safe place -- to live. But that would require a costly bureaucracy to investigate everyone who applied for shelter.
What's an Emergency?
"Who determines what's a real emergency?" Ms. Wackstein asked. "If you're living with a brother who's a drug dealer and carries an Uzi, is that dangerous?"
For some teen-age mothers on welfare, the shelter system is a rite of passage to independence.
"I figured the best way to get a place of my own was to go through the system," said 19-year-old Deborah Brown, jouncing her 18-month-old son on her knee. "I told them I wasn't homeless. But my mother raised me already. Why should I have to live with her?"
For others, the shelter is better than living with demanding relatives. Judy Green, 29, has been in and out of welfare hotels and shelters at least 10 times. Her life has been disrupted by men who went to jail and by her own crack habit, which she said she has kicked.
Most recently, she was living with her grandmother. "Sometimes, I didn't feel like getting up and cleaning up," Ms. Green said. "And my grandmother keeps a very clean place."
So she returned to the shelter system. "Only thing this place is good for," she said, "is getting you a place to stay."

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Says New Art Museum Must Help Pay Costs

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
Unless substantial private money is found to replace state funds, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, the dream museum that would showcase large-scale collections of 20th-century art in North Adams, Mass., will not get off the drawing board.
That's the word from the office of Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican whose administration inherited the state-backed project from the Democratic regime of former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. 
 In a memorandum to Governor Weld, Daniel S. Gregory, secretary for economic affairs in the Weld administration, wrote, "The administration must support the project to some degree for economic development reasons, but must also leverage the project into an example of the administration's privatization campaign."
The $87.5 million museum, known by the acronym Mass Moca, was conceived six years ago by Thomas Krens, at the time director of the Williams College Art Museum in nearby Williamstown and now director of the Guggenheim Museum in New York City.
 
Abandoned Factory Site
 The museum would occupy the buildings of the abandoned Sprague Electric factory site in North Adams, a town in the northwest corner of the state in which 17 percent of the population lives below the poverty line. The Weld administration's stand is a blow to the town, which has been looking to the museum as a tourist attraction that would provide jobs and generate dollars for the hard-pressed local economy.
The museum's focus on large-scale contemporary art would be implemented by loans from several internationally known collectors, and also from the collection of the Guggenheim Museum in New York, which has expressed interest in becoming the museum's operator.
Governor Weld has directed Mr. Gregory to meet with members of the Mass Moca Commission -- a body set up to oversee the construction and operation of the museum -- so that agreement can be reached on a "specific financial restructuring plan" before the state releases further funds, a spokesman for the Governor said.
The Weld team has frozen $688,000 approved for release by the Dukakis administration. The money was meant to cover the costs of soliciting a private operator for the museum, to start a fund-raising campaign and to undertake environmental impact studies. The plan was for the $688,000 to be drawn, like earlier money given for a feasibility study, against a $35 million bond issue passed by the legislature during Mr. Dukakis's tenure. But for now, at least, the state will not float the bond issue.
 
'Dollars as Well as Words'
 In his memorandum to the Governor, Mr. Gregory wrote: "In approving this project, the previous administration obligated the state to bear the financial burden. Considering the administration's stance on privatization, I disagree with this premise. The private sector and partner institutions such as the Guggenheim Museum must demonstrate their support with substantial dollars as well as words. As it currently stands, Mass Moca is a monument to state-subsidized projects."
Under terms of the agreement between the Mass Moca Commission and the state, 30 percent of the projected $35 million bond issue must be raised in local matching funds to effect the full release of the bond money, in increments over three years. The $688,000 was to be the next increment. To produce the matching funds required, a volunteer committee has undertaken the first phase of a three-year fund-raising campaign that would bring in $12.8 million, more than the required 30 percent. So far it has raised more than $1 million from private local and regional supporters.
In reporting to Governor Weld, Mr. Gregory mentioned several "flaws" he saw in the Mass Moca project as it stands, among them a projected attendance of more than 150,000 people a year, which Mr. Gregory said was too high. The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in nearby Williamstown, world renowned for its collection of Impressionist art, only draws 116,000 visitors a year, Mr. Gregory pointed out.
He also said that while the Guggenheim had tentatively agreed to operate the museum and provide "a majority of the art presented," it was unclear whether the Guggenheim would simply be using the site to get some of its art out of storage.
 
The Guggenheim's Role
 Michael Govan, deputy director of the Guggenheim, said that the museum, if chosen as Mass Moca's operator, would be responsible for the art installations, would assemble long-term loans from artists and collectors and would present works from its own collection. But he added,
"In no way would this activity compromise the quality of our New York activities."
Mr. Krens, the Guggenheim's director, was formerly chairman of the Mass Moca Commission, but has no formal connection with the museum at this point. When the feasibility study for the project was approved by the commission, Mr. Krens resigned from Mass Moca to avoid the perception of a conflict of interest.
In a recent letter to Joseph Thompson, director of Mass Moca, Mr. Gregory referred to the project as "fiscally unsound." But he said he would work with Mr. Thompson to try to create a "feasible scenario" that would allow Mass Moca to move ahead soon.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
McMullen Giving Up Best Seat in the House

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

 BODY:
When all is said and done, owners of baseball's two expansion teams are each expected to pay out at least $120 million each for expenses, including a $95 million sign-up fee, before one pitch is thrown.
In Baltimore, owners of the Orioles are trying to sell their team for a reported $200 million. 
 Which brings to mind two questions. Who, in their right mind, would buy a baseball team at such prices? Second, if franchises are now being valued in the hundreds of millions, who, in their right mind, would sell?
Well, John McMullen has been in both positions. He bought the Houston Astros about a decade ago. And now, in 1991, he wants to sell. McMullen doesn't believe sanity or lack thereof is a factor at either end of the equation.
"If a person just has $100 million to their name, then they shouldn't buy a baseball team," McMullen said with a laugh. "If he has $200 million, though, why not? What's he going to do with that money, anyway? And where else are you going to have this kind of fun?"
As for his reasons for selling, he cites a multiplicity of reasons. First, none of his three adult children have shown an interest in taking over the team. And, said the 73-year-old McMullen, "I've reached that stage of life when one thinks about the inevitable."
Therefore, baseball, a labor of love that McMullen insists it still is, just doesn't provide enough fun to keep him indefinitely hankering for more.
There are other reasons, some of them having to do with current economic trends. But McMullen says: "I don't believe in the doomsday prognostications. I believe the value of franchises will continue to go up."
Now, some might say, McMullen has a vested interest in assuring anyone of that. But McMullen remains outspoken on enough issues, including expansion (he's against it), and $5 million salaries (he's against them) to show that he still has financial doubts. His prognostications also include continued adversarial relationships between management and the players union and difficult financial times in smaller markets.
"But this is a game that survives itself," he said.
So it is this middle of the road, far away from predictions of unrelenting ruin, where you will find McMullen trying to sell his team. Although he will not deal in specifics, the $95 million fee for expansion teams reportedly appeals to him. Whether he could get that in Houston or be allowed to look to other markets remain significant questions.
What types buy in this day and age?
Corporations, for one, he says, powerful in their own rights, looking to be made even larger in the public eye. Consortiums interested in preventing franchises from relocating also buy. Then there are the private individual investors, "people who have the commitment, the love of the game," McMullen said.
These are the types who had better have the money, too. Some do, like Wayne Huizenga, who is about to absorb the costs connected with the start-up of the Florida Marlins. Others, notably Jeff Smulyan in Seattle, ultimately may not have had enough to survive in the game.
Even if all the money is there, it may not ultimately be able to buy a tough-enough hide, an important consideration.
McMullen admits the fun isn't what it once was. Being not only from out of town but from up north, McMullen, a New York City businessman, never enjoyed warm relations with Houston or its news media. An absolute chill after he decided against re-signing Nolan Ryan or other players who were seeking to make their fortunes via free agency.
McMullen, who also owns hockey's New Jersey Devils, does not back away from his beliefs no matter how unpopular. He boasts of the fact that his 1991 Astros are the only team in the majors without a player's contract extending past the current season. "Who do the fans appreciate more, what they saw a Ryan Bowen do yesterday, a pitcher we pay $100,000, or what Frank Viola does, a pitcher who makes, what, $3 million?" McMullen asked, referring to the Astros rookie who outdueled Viola in a 3-0 Houston victory at Shea Stadium Monday afternoon.
The Astros, with 11 rookies on the active roster, are also in last place in the National League West. But McMullen, who has his own formula for figuring standings based on salaries, defiantly states that, "based on dollars, we're winning by a wide margin." But, admits McMullen, "How do you explain that to the media?"
Or to the fans. For all the excitement about the youth movement and players like Jeff Bagwell and Al Osuna, the Astros are averaging just 16,000 fans a game.
If that is a proper gauge on how he is doing or at least how fans are voting, McMullen will not say. And he won't deny that the Ryan Bowens eventually grow up and, if good enough, perform at levels that command the salaries like Frank Viola's. That going rate is one of the things that John McMullen chooses to no longer deal with.
McMullen won't be around to see which of his prognostications prove out. The game now must find yet another to take that gamble.
Anyone with $100 million, $200 million to spare?

HEADLINE: Washington Journal;
Neighborhood Builds on Its Rubble

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Two years ago, Ana Ventura and her family lived in squalor in a run-down apartment building in this city's Shaw neighborhood, trying to avoid the drug trafficking that occurred on every floor.
Today, Ms. Ventura, along with the other tenants, is about to take ownership of the building, which has been cleaned up with the help of a city program and a local church. 
 The Spirit of W Street, as the co-operative building is now called, is a visible example of the changes taking place in Shaw, a Northwest Washington neighborhood about a mile from the White House that once was the focal point of black life here.
A quarter-century after the riots that left the area a grid of burned-out and abandoned buildings, Shaw is struggling to come back. With help from the city, community organizations and private developers, housing is being built and renovated, theaters are to be restored and a memorial is planned to the black soldiers of the Civil War.
"It'll never come back to what it was," said John Snipes, who runs a store in the area. "But if we let this area go without first saying, 'Hey, these are some of the achievements blacks made,' young people won't know that at one time great things happened in this neighborhood."
When segregation laws divided the nation's capital into racial blocks, Shaw was the center of Washington's black community. It was a place where black stores and churches thrived and where the well-dressed turned out for the restaurants and theaters and nightclubs that hummed with the sounds of performers from Nat (King) Cole to James Brown.
"You could go from one block of U Street to the next and along the way find some of the most popular black entertainers in the world," Mr. Snipes said. "Sarah Vaughan, Ray Charles, every famous musician played U Street."
Beyond its status as an entertainment mecca, the neighborhood had a thriving business district, and in its heyday was known for its spirit of community. "It was a really happy community," said Lozzie York, an older woman who has lived in the neighborhood most of her life. "Really, really happy."
The community began to unravel in the mid-1950's as desegregation opened up new sections of the city and its suburbs to blacks. Then, the 1968 riots that followed the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ripped the neighborhood open, scaring away residents and leaving poverty and crime. "The riots were what killed off the life of the community," said Stanley Mayes, a neighborhood commissioner.
A visitor today can walk for blocks in some parts of the neighborhood and find little commercial activity. "We don't have any supermarkets, we don't have any hardware stores, we don't have the local conveniences people think of when they think of a community," Mr. Mayes said. "So the money goes elsewhere."
He said he feared that without proper planning to attract stores handsome enough to keep residents in the neighborhood the sense of community would not return. He has called for a conference with developers and city officials to expand on the planning the city has already undertaken.
Attention has recently focused on the Lincoln Theater, a 69-year-old movie house the city is planning to take over and renovate. The developer who was restoring the theater has declared bankruptcy.
"Maybe we can get some entrepreneurs to come in and get some night spots put in, maybe some jazz," said Dominic Moulden, director of community outreach for St. Augustine Catholic Church.
The church has worked with a neighborhood coalition that has built housing units and has also worked with tenants, including Ms. Ventura, in forming co-operative housing boards, Mr. Moulden said.
Residents say that for all its problems Shaw's property values rose through the 1980's as the city's professional class began moving in, to be near Washington's downtown.
Mr. Moulden said he worries about the pitfalls of gentrification, which slowed greatly with the current recession. "I would say the neighborhood is heading in a good direction, but I worry about the low-income people and the senior citizens," he said. "A lot of the people who have been here a long time have been displaced."
The 1980's saw the neighborhood facing yet another difficulty with the construction of a subway line. Finally completed this spring, construction of the Green Line tore up the streets and chased away shoppers, bankrupting many businesses that had managed to survive everything else, local residents say.
"The Green Line knocked everything out of whack," Mr. Snipes said. "Those people that tried to hang on got nailed."
The hope now is that the finished Green Line will bring businesses and people back.

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk
