HEADLINE: About New York

BYLINE: By Joseph Berger

 BODY:
The year was 1888, a time when Brooklyn was its own city crowing over a shimmering new bridge to Manhattan. It was a time when young men with few resources, with scarcely a morsel of English, could make an honest living with a shoeshine brush and a box of polishes.
One of these was an orphan from Italy, Frank Caramanica. Buffing his way through the law and government offices that honeycomb Court Street downtown, he was able within a few years to establish a stand -- three chairs shaded by an awning -- right outside Borough Hall. 
 One hundred and three years later, that business is still going strong, kept alive by a grizzled Caramanica grandson and an aged family friend. It has been upgraded to a green metal shack sheltering three chairs and three pairs of brass footrests. A homemade sign boasts, "Shoe Shine The Best In Town."
At a time when people insist upon meaning and prestige as the price for a day's work, Frank Caramanica and Tony Juliano, in their undershirts and grimy blue aprons, are proving that a respectable living can still be made with a brush and a box full of polishes. They expect to shine shoes until the day they die, just like "the old man," who put down his brush at 94.
"Young people in their minds, they downgrade it," Mr. Caramanica said. "The shoeshine is nothing. Some people think, If you shine shoes, what kind of education can you have? But you get an education. You become streetwise. You learn human nature. I can look a person in the eye and see if they've got meanness in their eye."
The shoes that have been polished at the Caramanica stand reflect the brassy history of Brooklyn's politics and culture. Meade Esposito, Stanley Steingut, Abe Stark, Eugene Gold, Howard Golden, Charles Hynes and Thaddeus Owens all had their shoes shined there.
"Tony done Cuomo when Cuomo was a young lawyer at 26 Court Street," Mr. Caramanica said of the Governor.
Many a Brooklyn Dodger had his leisure shoes shined there when the team's owner, Walter O'Malley, had offices nearby. Marilyn Monroe had hers shined there, too, when she visited her ex-husband, the playwright Arthur Miller. Photographs of these celebrities are scattered on the walls among modest pinups that would offend few of the occasional female customers.
With the discretion of priests or psychologists, Mr. Caramanica and Mr. Juliano will not disclose the secrets confided to them by the powerful at whose feet they have bent.
"In this kind of business you've got to mind your own business," Mr. Caramanica said. "They talk. You don't pay attention. You can't ask questions. Who are you to ask questions? You shine shoes. You understand what I mean?"
Mr. Juliano added: "You ask questions, they tell you, 'Go into politics. Don't shine shoes.' "
Mr. Caramanica is a stocky man of 68 with doleful eyes and missing front teeth, and Mr. Juliano is a more wiry 79 with merry eyes that peek out through horn-rimmed glasses. From 7 A.M. to 2 P.M., they pump their brushes and flutter their cloths over wingtips, brogues and loafers at $2 a shine. It is, for the most part, a quiet business, since a shoeshine is a private indulgence, a grasp at solitude and reflection in a fast-paced day.
Yet burnishing a luminous shine into a shoe is no trifling skill.
"It's concentration," Mr. Caramanica said. "It's a lot of wrist action. You've got to know the colors, the tones. It ain't all that easy. If a guy comes in with green shoes, what do you do with green shoes?"
He answers his own question by pulling out a brush as plush and green as a sod of grass.
There are myths of fortunes built on a shoeshine and a smile, but the Caramanica stand does not subscribe. "We had no option," Mr. Caramanica said. "Our families were poor. There was no such thing as welfare." Still, Mr. Caramanica has managed to raise three daughters and Mr. Juliano one in modest apartments in working-class neighborhoods.
"You're free," Mr. Caramanica said. "You have no bosses telling you what to do. You feel like you're your own man, even though you're shining shoes."
The two men even shine each other's shoes.
Sadly, their business is endangered by a ragged economy -- "a shine is a luxury," Mr. Caramanica explained stoically -- and by more systemic ills.
"See those four men," he tells a visitor, pointing to a cluster of schmoozers on Joralemon Street. "Three of them are wearing sneakers. That's why I got time to sit here and talk with you. Even the lawyers wear sneakers."
Still, there is hope in customers like Carlos Russell, a retired professor, who derive from a shoeshine something more mystical than mere grooming; who believe, in words Fred Astaire once sang, that "when there's a shine on your shoes, there's a melody in your heart."
"One of the small pleasures one can get in life is having someone shine your shoes," Mr. Russell said. "My sense is that people believe shining shoes demeans them. It doesn't. It's an honest employment and a lost art."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Caramanica, left, and Tony Juliano at their shoeshine stand next to Borough Hall in Brooklyn. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Queens District, Visions of Future Races

SERIES: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council -- An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
While five candidates in District 21 in Queens try to woo voters in the City Council race, another political campaign is under way in the district. In Jackson Heights, Corona, Elmhurst and East Elmhurst, Hispanic leaders have begun courting people like Luis Santos, who cannot vote in this election because they are not American citizens.
"I want to be from here and from there," Mr. Santos, a 61-year-old janitor who came to the United States from the Dominican Republic 30 years ago, said recently.
For those who tried to assure that District 21's boundaries encompassed a substantial Hispanic majority, the prize is not this election but future ones. Hispanics make up 55 percent of the 137,931 residents in District 21, which is often the first stop for many immigrants. Because many of the district's Hispanic residents are recent immigrants from South American and Caribbean countries, they make up only a quarter of the registered voters. 
 So while others were busy trying to get a candidate elected in the primary election this month, many Hispanic leaders conducted voter registration drives instead.
 
Huge Registration Drive
 The Hispanic leaders, many of whom have written off a Hispanic victory in this year's primary, hope to get people like Mr. Santos to become United States citizens and to persuade those who already are citizens to vote. If successful, Hispanic leaders say, the effort would give Queens its first Hispanic elected official ever in 1993, when the full and expanded 51-member Council comes up for re-election.
"The political leaders in our borough say that Latinos don't count because they don't vote," said Guillermo Vasquez, a member of the New York City Latino Districting Commission who also heads one of the groups trying to increase voter registration in the district. "We want to prove them wrong."
When District 21 was first drawn it included Lefrak City, a huge housing complex that is predominantly black. The Justice Department rejected that version of the district, saying it shortchanged Hispanic voters. New lines were drawn that moved the complex into District 25 and left District 21 with a population that is 55 percent Hispanic, 16 percent white, 15 percent black and 13 percent Asian. But like several other districts whose lines have set off fierce political disputes, District 21 will most likely not elect a member of the ethnic group it was designed for. In District 21, the winning Council candidate will probably be a black candidate.
The three Hispanic candidates on the ballot for the primary election are relative unknowns. And while Hispanics in the area account for more than half the population, only 24.45 percent are registered voters, compared with 38 percent of whites and 33.48 percent of blacks.
 
Incumbent and 3 Challengers
 The five candidates are: Helen M. Marshall, the 62-year-old assemblywoman who has represented the 35th Assembly District for nine years and is the Queens Democratic Party and Liberal Party candidate; Irvine A. Bryer Jr., the 44-year-old pastor of the Corona Congregational Church and a member of the New York City Board of Correction; Rafael Moreno, 60, an electrical engineer with Consolidated Edison and a member of Community Board 3; Eric Haroldo Ruano, 42, a civil engineer with the city's Department of Environmental Protection, and Victor Hernandez, 44, a real-estate broker in Corona who ran unsuccessfully against Ms. Marshall once for the assembly seat. Ms. Marshall is also supported by Mayor David N. Dinkins; Mr. Bryer has been endorsed by the Majority Coalition for a New New York.
Still, as Hispanics emerged from the redistricting process a stronger majority, most agree that a real opportunity was created for a Hispanic to eventually win a Council seat. Congressman Thomas J. Manton, the Queens County Democratic leader, said the two-year target may be too optimistic. But he added that there is no doubt that Hispanic voters will play a larger and larger role in New York City elections at every level.
"By the end of the decade Hispanics are going to have a meteoric rise because you have a young population in all the boroughs that's going to explode," he said. "They're going to come into their own."
As the first stop for many immigrants, not only Colombians, Dominicans and other Hispanics but also Indians, Koreans and Chinese, many issues in District 21 have more to do with economics than with politics. Merchants complain about the competition from illegal street vendors. Longtime residents complain of illegal apartments popping up in single-family homes and car repair shops in residential garages and backyards. Jobs are scarce for newcomers and long-time residents.
 
A Slew of Languages
 The district includes a disparate collage of signs in various languages in the business district in Jackson Heights, tree-lined streets and elegant homes in East Elmhurst and Dominican and Italian neighborhoods in Corona, all flanked on the northeast by LaGuardia Airport, Shea Stadium and Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.
Across the street from Ms. Marshall's office on Astoria Boulevard, for example, a billboard advertises jeans in Spanish.
Much of the impetus for the political activism, and for some of the Hispanic candidacies, is coming from the 1990 census, which showed that the number of Hispanics grew by 45 percent in the last 10 years. The redrawing of Council districts further galvanized Hispanics citywide and brought Hispanic leaders from neighborhoods and the borough together for the first time.
As they register voters at cultural festivals and mail letters to social clubs and civic organizations asking permission to address their members, Hispanic leaders in the district say they have reasons to expect that the community will fulfill its political potential. They point to the continued growth of the Hispanic population and the pressure sheer numbers will put on the Democratic Party to support Hispanic candidacies. There is also the nature of that population in District 21 -- Colombians, Ecuadorians, Peruvians and others, many of them small-business owners -- that could be a source of financing for future candidates.
 
Focus on Homeland
 A change in Colombia's constitution this year is also expected to have a major effect on District 21. William H. Salgado, a lawyer in Jackson Heights and president of the Federation of Colombian Organizations, said the new constitution allows those who become citizens of a foreign country to retain their Colombian nationality, therefore removing a main argument against United States citizenship and voter registration among Colombians in New York City. The metropolitan region's Colombian population is estimated at 450,000.
Many other Hispanics in the district remain focused on the homeland. Mr. Santos said he does not plan to return to the Dominican Republic and will probably become an American "one of these days." Mr. Santos recently complained that political candidates have never bothered to come to his neighborhood to explain what they can do for it.
"If they let themselves be known I would be more interested," he said. "And if they were Latinos, I'd be even more interested."
Ms. Marshall, who said she is running for the City Council because of her desire to use her legislative experience in the city, defended her candidacy in the overwhelmingly Hispanic district, saying she has represented the area as an assemblywoman and is best suited to continue representing it.
"How many times have white people represented me?" she asked. "What I try to go for is the best candidate.
"Eventually," she added, "we'll have Hispanic representation."

HEADLINE: Three Tests of Soviet Survival

 BODY:
Can the Soviet Union survive? Its political leaders are straining to construct a new political association of independent republics. Great constitutional and human rights issues are at stake as delegates to a national congress pass on how to reshape their country. But the ultimate answer to survival will be economic: whether what one leader calls the "corpse" of the Soviet economic system can be brought to life.
Yes, political issues are paramount and will ultimately be settled on political grounds. And yes, the republics may eventually control their own economic affairs. But if their economies are to survive, the new constitution will have to embrace economic cooperation. 
 At the moment, the United States is frightened by economic output that's slipping by less than 2 percent; by present estimates, the Soviet economy this year will plunge by a sickening 20 percent. The Soviet republics have been intertwined for more than seven decades. Given the critical economic circumstances, it would be suicidal for them suddenly to go it alone.
There are three tests of economic survival. They do not require one political format or another, which leaves negotiators plenty of room for maneuver. But whatever political plan the Soviet congress adopts, the three tests will be unrelenting.
Free Flow of Goods. Under Communist control, production has become highly concentrated, with thousands of products supplied by a single enterprise. This invites trade wars -- as republics withhold supplies of natural resources or manufactured goods in an attempt to take advantage of neighboring republics. Before long, internal trade would collapse, punishing everyone.
What is needed is an absolute ban on internal tariffs, quotas or any other impediment to free flow of goods and services among regions. No such impediments prevail within the U.S.; nor will they exist after 1992 within the European Community. Free trade will prove even more important to the Soviet republics, because they rely on each other more than California depends upon Virginia or France upon Greece.
Tight Currency Controls. Sentiments in the Baltics and other separatist republics probably rule out a single currency controlled from Moscow. Instead, the breakaway republics will issue their own currencies. That would make monetary control difficult but manageable, under a system of convertible currencies.
These would exchange freely with each other and with key international currencies at stable, predictable rates. Convertible currencies permit exporters and importers to write contracts without undue worry. They also assure foreign investors, who can count on taking back profits in a usable currency. But such stability requires each republic to hold to a tight regime of non-inflationary growth of its money supply.
Protection of Private Contracts. Foreign investors and domestic savers alike must be protected against arbitrary confiscation of assets. That requires enforceable laws governing authority at the union and republic levels. Independence alone won't eliminate present bureaucratic nightmares. Indeed, new lines of authority could make these uncertainties worse.
These are the three essential economic conditions; there are more that would be desirable. Soviet citizens would be best served if they were free to migrate internally in search of good jobs and better living conditions. And the new central authority needs ironclad taxing authority to pay for national functions like defense, foreign policy and the environment.
But above all, the three core tests have to be met. Unless Soviet society can do so, there's no convincing basis for the West to provide financial assistance. And in any case, unless they cooperate, the republics won't survive.

HEADLINE: How to Make Medicaid Popular

BYLINE: By Stuart E. Eizenstat; Stuart E. Eizenstat, a Washington lawyer, was President Jimmy Carter's chief domestic policy adviser.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The dire problems of the Medicaid program reflect the lack of middle-class support for domestic programs for the poor. The solution -- becoming part of a universal health-care system in which the middle class has a stake -- can become a model of how to regain the public confidence necessary for further social advances.
Medicaid and Medicare were passed in 1965, at the height of Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society, to serve similar goals: extending health coverage to an underserved population, in Medicaid's case to poor people and for Medicare to all the elderly. 
 Medicare has largely fulfilled its promise. By providing coverage for virtually every person 65 years and over it has developed a strong and vocal middle-class constituency. Because it is financed and administered centrally by the Federal Government, Medicare benefits, management and cost controls are uniform and stable. Younger workers have an interest in protecting Medicare for the day they and their parents will become beneficiaries.
Medicaid, on the other hand, is a disaster from virtually every perspective. Its costs are out of control, imposing a rapidly growing burden on the Federal deficit. For states, which partially finance it and must live under balanced-budget constraints, it is the fastest growing expense. Medicaid began as a $1.6 billion program in 1966, grew to $12.6 billion by 1975 and $52 billion in 1988. By the next fiscal year, it will have more than doubled in four years, to more than $105 billion.
Yet only about four million more people are served by Medicaid, now 26 million, than were served in 1975, and the percentage of poor covered by Medicaid has actually dropped from 63 to about 50 percent -- compared with 96 percent of the elderly covered by Medicare.
Physicians stay in Medicare but are dropping out of Medicaid because of lengthy delays in payment and ridiculously low payment schedules. Medicaid pays physicians on the average only 69 percent of what Medicare would pay for common services, and in some states less than 40 percent. Medicaid averages only 57 percent of the market rate of reimbursement for a pediatrician; not surprisingly, the proportion of pediatricians who refuse to serve Medicaid patients jumped from 26 percent in 1979 to 39 percent in 1989.
The poor who are the supposed beneficiaries find a crazy quilt of eligibility standards depending on the state. Because Medicaid eligibility is tied to each state's welfare standards, which have failed to keep pace with inflation for some 20 years, 47 states failed to maintain inflation-adjusted benefit levels between 1970 and 1986. In a country that prides itself on fairness, a family of three in Alabama must earn less than $1,416 annually to qualify for Medicaid.
There are many causes of Medicaid's miseries. Its mixed nature, in which the Government contributes 50 percent to 80 percent of state costs but states set eligibility standards and administer their own programs, produces a lack of uniformity in eligibility and services and precludes efficiency or cost control. Its beneficiaries are poor and unorganized.
But at the core of Medicaid's failures is the loss of middle-class support for expanded programs for the poor. In times of economic health, like the 1960's, a middle-class consensus could be created for programs to benefit those below it on the social ladder. But in times of stagnating income, such as the U.S. has experienced for almost 20 years, this consensus erodes.
Social policy has stagnated in the Reagan-Bush era because of middle-class resentment of spending on the poor when many Americans have trouble keeping their own heads above water. This is compounded by the means testing of programs like Medicaid that excludes many deserving workers. Only Medicare provides universal access, and it remains the most popular Great Society program.
The absence of middle-class support for Medicaid has made the health of the poor dependent on a small group of dedicated members of Congress. They have been able to mandate that states cover all poor children under Medicaid by the year 2000. But these efforts have gone as far as they can without structural reforms to build more public support.
The solution to Medicaid's problems is to tie it to middle-class health benefits. The time is ripe for combining Medicaid and Medicare into a universally accessible national health care system. There is dissatisfaction with the current system: 19 million working adults and 10 million children in families headed by workers have no health coverage; insured workers worry that their coverage will not follow them to a new job; and soaring health care costs are eating into employers' profits. 
By combining broadened access and more uniform eligibility for Medicaid beneficiaries to universal health coverage and strict cost controls, middle-class support can be obtained at the same time for improved benefits for the poor.
States should still play a role. They can pay for acute care, with the Federal Government taking over costs for long-term care for the poor elderly.
Medicaid will only fulfill its promise if it is consolidated into a broader health care program. Likewise, education, job training, and other forms of Federal aid must be more universally accessible if they are to win the middle-class support needed to have a better educated, efficient and healthy work force.

HEADLINE: Safety of Queens Residents Finishes a Poor Second to Tennis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Two Aug. 18 articles concerned Flushing, Queens: one reported that New York City is dropping plans to build a large apartment house and commercial complex called Flushing Center, the other that a preservationist group opposes plans to expand the site of the United States Open tennis tournament in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park (sports pages). 
 Both show the callous attitude of our city's politicians toward the people of Queens.
The Flushing Center article quotes the city officials overseeing the project stating that it was not virulent community opposition that killed the project but the recession.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and the United States Tennis Association have persuaded the Federal Aviation Administration to divert La Guardia Airport's air traffic during the tournament's two weeks. I am surprised that the safety of those who live near the airport was never considered.
Approaches to La Guardia change during the year to reflect wind conditions. The approach over the tennis center is used in August and September because wind conditions dictate that this approach is the safest. Although the F.A.A. will argue that the rerouting is safe, it is not the safest route possible and jeopardizes those who live near the airport.
A recent "60 Minutes" segment indicates that La Guardia is considered by many pilots who land there to be particularly dangerous because of its short runways. The Mayor, the tennis association and the F.A.A. have decided that it is more important for Pete Sampras to serve in peace than for a jet carrying hundreds of people to land safely.
It is not a surprise that the association's plans for expanding the tennis center in Flushing Meadows have the blessing of the Mayor and Queens Borough President Claire Shulman. The Mayor's love of tennis and the well-heeled corporate crowd that supports and attends the Open is obviously greater than his love of the thousands of nonelite people of all races and economic classes who enjoy the park. Ms. Shulman, the inheritor of the Donald Manes power base, is obviously more enamored of the clubhouse than of a ballfield or two.
I grew up in Flushing and have used Flushing Meadows Park since before the 1964-65 World's Fair. The park is an oasis for those people living in the Flushing-Corona area. Softball, cricket and soccer coexist very nicely. People enjoy this park -- it has light and it has air. Now New York City plans to take a piece of that away.
 
LEONARD L. FLEISIG
New York, Aug. 19, 1991

HEADLINE: World Bank Lives High on the Taxpayers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lance Taylor's letter (Aug. 5) criticizing World Bank policy toward third-world countries omitted some reasons the poverty tycoons at the World Bank deserve to be maligned. One is the World Bank's serious consideration of private-sector loans as a major field for future activity. The institution's most recent annual World Economic Development Report encourages a new focus on promoting private production and trade in addition to sale of state-owned enterprises -- a policy the United States, as the bank's largest stockholder, has long demanded.
As a part of President Bush's new world order, the Treasury recently attempted, but was stymied in its efforts, to cajole the World Bank into diverting 50 percent of its lending capacity to private-sector loans. Nevertheless, Barber Conable, the lame-duck president of the institution, agreed to increase the tempo of loans made with the intention of "supporting" the private sector, as well as to consider diversion of World Bank resources, even though this would clearly violate its founding charter. 
 The fear among social activists is that the World Bank, by aiming its lending thrust at the private sector, which already has multiple sources for new-investment capital, would likely charge higher interest rates across the board, jeopardizing the ability of essential public-development projects to secure the low-interest loans they require.
An additional criticism is that the World Bank pays only lip service to environmental concerns. Its recent catch-up efforts to facilitate ecological advances, including "debt for nature" swaps, are laudable, but hardly enough. Relentless outside criticism over the destruction of tens of thousands of square miles of forests and wetlands as a result of misguided development projects has forced the institution to be more sensitive to these concerns. Its directors should give urgent priority to a recommendation to set aside a certain amount of World Bank resources for environmentally sound policies.
A final concern, which the World Bank has made only feeble efforts to address, is its bloated and overpaid bureaucracy. Until recently, all World Bank travel included first-class overseas flights and accommodations, with most of its consultants and staff receiving excessively high, tax-free salaries and benefits, and also enjoying overgenerous pension plans. American taxpayers underwrote nearly one-third of these costs.
The minimal efforts the World Bank has made at reform, which include a switch to business class on some flights (saving $15 million a year) and a requirement that expenses be monitored more closely, have produced grumbles and self-serving talk of low morale among a staff that has been spoiled into self-indulgence in its personal, financial and comfort expectations.
The World Bank also recently voted a $60,000 pay increase for its president, raising his salary to an excessive $285,000 yearly, and an increase in staff salary ceilings by $36,000 to $190,000. Board members had no qualms about giving such raises because they are just spending the international taxpayers' money, and they feel they are worth it.
Those at the World Bank would do well to accept a hint of self-sacrifice in their professional lives, rather than marauding as if they were partners in some great Hanseatic banking house.
 
JOSHUA S. LEVENBERG
Research Associate
Council on Hemispheric Affairs
Washington, Aug. 14, 1991

HEADLINE: BRIEFS

 BODY:
Debt
 
* Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to announce today the interest rate for $650 million in seven-year debentures due Sept. 10, 1998. 

 
* Maine State Housing Authority is offering $17.8 million in tax-exempt single-family mortgage acquisition bonds tentatively priced to yield a maximum 7.15 percent for an issue due 2021 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co. HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mercedes Cutting Work Force in U.S.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc., the United States subsidiary of the German automobile maker, is cutting its work force by 7 percent. The company, based in Montvale, N.J., said the reduction of 113 employees would mostly take place at its headquarters, where jobs have become duplicated by regional staffs as part of a eorganization announced last year. The company also cited lower sales because of the recession and the luxury tax that took effect Jan. 1. 
 Mercedes sales through the first seven months of this year were down 22.1 percent, to 33,176 cars, compared with a 13.4 percent decrease for the entire industry. After the cuts, Mercedes-Benz of North America will have about 1,350 employees nationwide, including 570 in Montvale.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Little Movement in Dollar; Gold Prices Rise Modestly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed unchanged to lower in an uneventful foreign-exchange session yesterday, as traders awaited tomorrow's release of the August employment figures.
Gold prices rose modestly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $348.50 an ounce, up 20 cents from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $348.85 an ounce, up 95 cents. 
 Although several recent reports have pointed to growth in the American economy, currency traders said the market appeared to be concerned that the employment data would be weak. That could prompt the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates, which could erode the value of the dollar relative to other currencies.
"People choose what they want to pay attention to, and the employment number seems to be the one," said Christopher Bourdain, a currency trader with Credit Suisse in New York.
He said he had been astounded that the currency markets had shown remarkably little concern about the turmoil in the Soviet Union. The German mark, which many assumed would be hurt by Germany's close economic ties to the Soviet Union, has held its own in recent days.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 135.85 yen, down 0.55 yen from Tuesday's finish. Later, in London, the dollar bought 135.45 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 135.50 yen, down from 135.80.
In Europe, the dollar bought 1.7365 German marks, down from 1.7395. In New York, the dollar remained unchanged from late Tuesday at 1.7365 marks.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.694, from $1.692 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound cost $1.695, unchanged from late Tuesday.
Other late New York dollar quotes, compared with Tuesday's prices, included: 1.5240 Swiss francs, up from 1.5225; 5.8995 French francs, down from 5.9005; 1,295.00 Italian lire, down from 1,295.75, and 1.1419 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14145.
On the Comex, silver fell to $3.904 an ounce, from $3.905 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Bankruptcies Keep Rising

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
A record one million American consumers and businesses will likely file for bankruptcy this year, with the heaviest filings expected in New England, the American Bankruptcy Institute said today.
"The number of bankruptcies is increasing in an unbroken line and at a record pace," said Samuel J. Gerdano, executive director of the institute, a nonprofit group whose members include lawyers, accountants and other bankruptcy experts. 
 There were 880,399 bankruptcies in the 12 months that ended June 30, up 21 percent from a year earlier. Ninety-two percent of the filings were from individuals, the rest from businesses.
Mr. Gerdano said the pace of filings for the rest of this year should bring bankruptcies for 1991 to one million.
The biggest increases in the most recent 12-month period came in New England, the region hardest hit by the recession that began last summer. Filings rose 86 percent in New Hampshire, 77 percent in Massachusetts and 59 percent in Connecticut.
Mr. Gerdano said the recession had clearly contributed to the increase, but he added that filings had risen even in years when the economy was expanding. They rose 13 percent nationally in the 12 months ended June 30, 1990, and 8 percent in the 12 months before that.
"The ultimate cause is the level of personal debt," he said, adding that consumers total debt including home mortgages, represented 62 percent of their disposable personal income in 1983 compared with 83 percent in 1990.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Food Experts to Study Soviet Distribution System

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Two teams of agricultural experts ordered to the Soviet Union by President Bush this week will be led by Department of Agriculture officials concerned that the distribution of food there may be as much a problem as food supply.
The findings of the two teams will influence how the United States, Japan and Western Europe handle the possibility of food shortages and perhaps civil disorder in the Soviet Union this winter. One of the main issues is how the industrialized democracies should balance food shipments to the Soviet Union with technical assistance to improve the transportation and sale of food produced there. 
 President Bush said on Monday that he was sending Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan and Richard T. Crowder, the Under Secretary of Agriculture for international affairs and commodity programs, to provide advice on food distribution, to predict whether the Soviet Union will face shortages this winter and to propose solutions if shortages appeared likely. Coincidentally, both men worked in transportation before joining the Government.
Mr. Crowder will leave within several days to head the first team on a 10-day tour of Soviet regions with large food deficits and surpluses.
 
Similar Mission in May
 A similar mission that Mr. Crowder headed in May concluded in a report released last month that "Soviet agriculture produces on a per-capita basis sufficient food to feed the country's population." The production of meat and grain per person matched that of Western Europe, while potato production per person exceeded that in the United States and in all but one of the 12 member nations of the European Community. But the report added, "The loss of 30 to 50 percent of certain food commodities between field and table highlights the fact that distribution, more than production, is at the heart of the U.S.S.R.'s food problem."
Mr. Madigan will lead a group of Administration and private experts late this month or in early October. "We hope to be taking transportation experts, people familiar with the efficient operation of railroads, the efficient dispatching of trucks and other types of vehicles," Mr. Madigan told reporters at a news conference on Tuesday.
But Mr. Madigan also expressed concern about the likelihood of a small Soviet harvest this year and held out the possibility of direct food shipments. Transportation problems created local shortages last year, even with a record harvest, so there are fears that a smaller harvest this year might result in worse shortages regardless of whether Soviet republics with food surpluses ship their excess to republics facing shortages, Mr. Madigan said.
The interest in transportation and distribution problems may partly reflect the backgrounds of Mr. Madigan and Mr. Crowder. Mr. Madigan used to own the Yellow-Lincoln Taxi Company in Illinois. Mr. Crowder specialized in transportation issues during his two decades as an economist and then as an executive at several large American food processing companies before he was appointed under secretary in 1989.
 
Logistics and Economics
 Carol G. Brookins, the president of World Perspectives Inc., a Washington-based agriculture consulting firm, said the emphasis on logistics was fair in the case of the Soviet Union. In most years, "they would probably have few import needs if they could handle their logistical situation better," said Ms. Brookins, who spent last week in Moscow.
F. Paul Dickerson, the general sales manager of the Agriculture Department's Foreign Agricultural Service and a member of the mission in May, said that team visited a railroad yard, collective farms, a poultry processing factory, bakeries, various stores and even a dock for barges in Kiev. "We went to just about every segment of the food production chain," he said.
Distribution rather than supply was the problem last winter, Mr. Dickerson said, but too little information was available to conclude whether that would be the case this winter with a smaller harvest.
The report from the earlier mission also highlighted the effects of hoarding and the implications of Soviet officials' poor understanding of economics. Consumers who did not hoard last winter suffered, while large quantities of the hoarded food appeared to have gone bad in at least one city.

HEADLINE: Europe's Electronics Rescue Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 4

 BODY:
European governments are stepping up efforts to rescue the Continent's beleaguered electronics industry. They fear that further deterioration could leave Europe hopelessly behind Japan and the United States, not only in electronics but also in automobiles, aerospace and the many other industries that depend on electronic components.
In sharp contrast to Washington's hands-off approach to the United States' electronics industry, the European Community and several national governments are spending billions of dollars to buttress the Continent's computer and semiconductor manufacturers. 
 Acknowledging that Europe already lags well behind the United States and Japan in electronics, European officials are straining to help the Continent catch up. To that end they are financing research, pressing small semiconductor companies to merge, and rejiggering broadcast rules to help European producers compete in developing the next generation of television sets.
Such efforts are an attempt in part to alleviate the problems of Europe's computer industry, in which European producers have just one-third of the Continent's $60 billion computer market and are inconsequential in the supercomputer and microprocessor markets. Three of Europe's leading computer makers, Groupe Bull of France, Siemens-Nixdorf Information Systems of Germany and Philips Electronics of the Netherlands, have posted huge losses and laid off thousands of computer workers in the last two years.
France has taken the lead in Europe's interventionist efforts, with the Government providing $700 million in capital for the state-owned Groupe Bull and giving it an additional $400 million for research.
European officials feel a sense of urgency because several electronics companies have virtually collapsed -- like Nixdorf, before it was acquired last year by Siemens -- and others have been driven into foreign hands. Officials are also distressed over Europe's $40 billion annual trade deficit in electronics.
"It's one minute to midnight for Europe's electronics industry," said Robert R. Heikes, an electronics consultant and former head of the European operations of the National Semiconductor Corporation of the United States. "Europe is facing an utter disaster on information technology overall."
European electronics executives say they want to avoid what happened to America's consumer electronics companies, which are now almost all foreign owned. Indeed, some American executives, seeing how Japan's semiconductor giants almost dominate the world, say laissez-faire Washington could learn a few lessons from Europe.
 
Slim Share in Semiconductors
 The Continent's semiconductor companies have just 10 percent of the world market, compared with American companies, which have nearly 40 percent, and the Japanese, which control slightly more than half the market. Indeed, some European microchip executives say their companies are too small to survive against Japanese chip makers with five times their revenues.
In July Philips agreed to sell control of its troubled computer division to the Digital Equipment Corporation, based in Maynard, Mass. But what has truly alarmed European officials is that Britain's largest computer maker, International Computers Ltd., and Scandinavia's largest computer producer, Nokia Data, have each agreed to be taken over by Fujitsu, Japan's No. 1 computer company.
Many European officials are uneasy about such large, respected companies linking with the Japanese. They fear the Japanese will turn the companies into empty shells that may sell products that bear their nameplates but are really manufactured back in Japan.
In contrast to their attitude toward Japan, however, European officials often treat I.B.M. and other American companies with a long-established presence on the Continent as local companies. Seeing European-American alliances as a way to counter the Japanese, many European officials applauded when I.B.M. and Siemens announced they would collaborate to produce 16-megabit computer chips.
 
Europeans Urged to Cooperate
 At the same time, European officials urge European companies to cooperate with each other in such ways as pooling research funds. Filippo Maria Pandolfi, the European Community's technology comissioner, said he hoped that Bull, Siemens and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian computer maker, could solve their problems without throwing themselves into Japanese or other foreign arms.
But some experts fault European officials for fretting about Japanese ownership and alliances. They say one of the best ways to strengthen the Continent's electronics industry would be to encourage links with the Japanese to help bring their expertise and job-creating investments to Europe.
"It's counterproductive in the long run to protect European ownership," said Alan Cawson, a political scientist at the University of Sussex in England. "We ought to encourage firms that invest in Europe, and we should look at to what extent they bring manufacturing, research and design jobs."
But Europe's arms makers, echoing the Pentagon, say it would be unwise to depend on Japanese chip makers. The Continent's computer and consumer electronics companies agree. They fear that if they depend on Japanese chip makers, they might get squeezed by a shortage or the Japanese will jack up chip prices -- in either case making it harder for European companies to compete with their Japanese counterparts.
 
Debate Over Extent of Aid
 European governments are divided over how much they should intervene to bolster the industry. France is aggressive, while the more laissez-faire Britain, with its close ties to Japanese industry, favors having electronics companies fend for themselves.
After a long debate, the European Commission, the community's executive branch, has adopted a compromise policy that tells the industry not to depend solely on government subsidies for its survival.
"The main responsibility is with the companies," said Mr. Pandolfi, the technology commissioner. "I am not in favor of a dirigiste approach."
Although the community's industrial policy on electronics is far more aggressive than Washington's, many European industry officials say the community is still not doing nearly enough. "What they have done is just a first step," said Francis Lorentz, Bull's chairman.
Some industry officials say the community needs to spend $100 billion over the next decade to insure the survival of Europe's electronics industry, including semiconductors, computers and telecommunications. The money would pay for research and new factories, as well as unemployment and retraining benefits for workers laid off as the industry restructures.
Some electronics officials say it would take $10 billion to preserve Europe's semiconductor industry alone.
While some government officials ridicule these proposals, supporters of government aid say $100 billion is not outlandish, considering that the community's taxpayers and consumers subsidize Europe's farmers by more than $100 billion each year.
"Europe could be in a much stronger postion in 10 years," said Mr. Heikes, the electronics consultant. "The question is how do you get the political agreement to do that."
 
Following Japan's Example
 But some industry analysts say that all the government aid so far has done little good. For more than 20 years, for example, France has nurtured its computer industry. Yet Bull, its national computer champion, is in desperate condition, having lost $1.2 billion last year.
While acknowledging some mistakes, European officials say that if Japan's Government was able to help build the foundation for the stunning success of that nation's electronics industry, then European governments should be able to do likewise.
The community has contributed more than $500 million for research on new generations of computer chips by a consortium called Joint European Submicron Silicon, known as Jessi. France, Italy, Germany and the Netherlands have together kicked in a similar amount for Jessi. There are also government-backed research projects on data transmission and computer-aided manufacturing.
 
A Community 'Nervous System'
 The community plans to develop a "European Nervous System" that would connect government computers in the 12 community nations to transfer data about everything from taxes to pollution levels. This network aims to increase spending on computers and foster standardization for Europe's often clashing computer makers. Such a network could cost more than $10 billion to develop.
Mr. Pandolfi, the technology commissioner, is pushing Siemens, Philips and the Italian-French manufacturer SGS-Thomson Microelectronics to merge their semiconductor operations so Europe will have a chip company large enough to compete with NEC, Toshiba and Japan's other powerhouses. But Siemens and Philips are resisting because they fear a merger will mean culture clashes, large layoffs and hefty restructuring costs.
And in response to pleas from Europe's consumer electronics giants, Thomson and Philips, the community rejected Japan's broadcasting standard for high-definition television, or HDTV, which promises to display pictures with movie-like sharpness. Instead, Brussels adopted a European standard, and the community and the French and Dutch Governments have contributed hundreds of millions of dollars to develop a European HDTV system.
But whether Europe's various electronics investments will pay off remains open to debate. In HDTV, for instance, the community has bet on a system that many engineers say has already been overtaken technologically by a digitalized television system developed in the United States. And despite Jessi's grandiose research goals, community officials acknowledge that Europe's semiconductor race is being hampered because too little money has been sprinkled on too many projects.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Down in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in very thin trading yesterday, as credit market participants settled down to wait for August employment data, expected to be released tomorrow morning.
"The market is basically in equilibrium, waiting for the numbers," one government bond trader said. "I don't see people with any need to do anything between now and then." 
 In advance of the employment report, most market participants seem to be anticipating that the figures will reflect that economic conditions remained sluggish last month, and that the Federal Reserve Board will move to lower short-term interest rates shortly after the data are released.
 
Looking to Fed Action
 "Most people are looking for a Fed easing shortly after the number," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
Mr. Moran said he did not include himself in the majority.
"I am of the view that the employment report will be reasonably good for the economy, and not for the bond market," he said.
Business was so slow yesterday that traders said much of the session was spent watching televised testimony in the Congressional inquiry into the Salomon Brothers scandal.
Using price movements as a yardstick, yesterday's testimony had little effect on the market participants.
Since Salomon's admission on Aug. 9 that it had placed illegal bids at four separate auctions of Treasury securities, traders have worried that the regulatory response would lead to greater inefficiency in the auction system.
 
30-Year Bonds Down to 8.05%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the decline in prices yesterday left most securities at almost exactly the level they were early Tuesday, the first day of trading after the Labor Day holiday.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year Treasury bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 25/32, down by 6/32, to yield 8.05 percent, compared with 8.03 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 15/32, down by an eighth of a point, to yield 7.80 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 5/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 6.29 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.31 percent late yesterday, down a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late-offered rate of 5.36 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager on a $130 million, three-part offering of student loan revenue bonds for the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency.
The maximum yield was 8.405 percent on $65 million in residual interest bonds that mature on Sept. 1, 2026.
All three parts of the offering are subject to the Internal Revenue Service's alternative minimum tax provisions. The issue, insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, is rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In a development that could have significant implications for the handful of firms that provide bond insurance, Fitch Investors Service Inc., a ratings agency that is stepping up efforts to take market share from Moody's and Standard & Poor's, said yesterday that it had toughened its standards for rating the ability of bond insurers to pay claims arising from defaults.
In making the announcement, Fitch said it had given an AAA rating to the $117 billion in outstanding interest and principal insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, a subsidiary of the GE Credit Corporation.
Currently, Moody's and S.& P. have assigned an AAA rating to all bond insurance companies. Without an AAA rating, bond insurers would almost certainly see investor confidence in the securities they insure sag.
Mark H. S. Cohen, a Fitch managing director, said that when measured against his firm's new ratings standards, some insurers would not be able to qualify for an AAA rating.
"At this stage, it is very clear that some insurers would have to do something to materially alter their financial position in order to qualify for a AAA rating from us," he said.
Mr. Cohen said he was "not sure" Financial Guaranty would have qualified for an AAA rating without its relationship to General Electric.
"It is not possible to analyze a bond insurer without looking at the ownership pedigree," he said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by about an eighth of a point in light trading.
In corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues fell by an eighth of a point to a quarter of a point, also in slow trading.

HEADLINE: Union Pacific Sets Charge For Cutbacks

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had taken a special after-tax charge of $575 million to offset the cost of reductions of the size of crews on its freight trains.
The charge, which will bring big improvements in productivity, is mostly for severance pay for brakemen who will be eliminated on trains that will now have a crew of two instead of three. 
 Richard Davidson, the president of the company's Union Pacific Railroad unit, said 2,000 to 3,000 jobs were expected to be cut from its work force of 29,000, which has been vastly reduced in the last five years.
Union Pacific has diversified into trucking by buying the Overnite trucking company. Its Union Pacific Resources unit produces oil and natural gas and is now a leading producer among the nation's l5 independent oil and gas companies. Its core business, however, remains the railroad, which has had four years of record earnings as a result of savings from labor and new technology that has allowed it to respond more quickly to customers.
The company also said its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split and an increase from $1.36 a share to $2.72 a share in the annual dividend.
Freight railroads are benefiting from a finding issued last July by a Presidential Emergency Board. Since then most rail unions have agreed to binding arbitration as a way to help reach new contracts.
The board has recommended further reduction in the size of train crews and some changes in work rules that, for example, would allow railroads to use yard workers to do some of the jobs of road crews.
Most railroads have already put through significant reductions in manning of trains resulting in big savings in labor costs.
Union Pacific said that in the last five years, labor productivity as measured in gross-ton-miles per employee has increased by 80 percent.
"The productivity improvements have been astounding in the last several years," said Graeme Lidgerwood, a rail analyst for First Boston.
The company, which has most of its operations in the West, said 85 percent of the special charge, or $492 million, would apply to the railroad subsidiary.
The remaining $83 million will apply to reorganization of the parent company, which has its headquarters in Bethlehem, Pa., and the Union Pacifc Resources and Overnite Transporation subsidiaries.
The railroad also said it would sell, lease or abandon 7,100 miles of its light-density lines. Its total system has 21,000 miles of track.
Much of the trackage is expected to be sold or leased, which will enable the railroad to still serve its customers but have the tracks maintained by others.
"These actions reaffirm our continued confidence in the growth of Union Pacific," Drew Lewis, the chairman of the Union Pacific Corporation, said. "As the economy recovers, we are poised for strong earning gains."
Ms. Lidgerwood said that with new technology, special through trains could be manned by an engineer and conductor without a brakeman.
She said the displaced workers would be put on an a reserve list. As traffic grows, some will be called back and assigned to new trains.
The stock split for shareholders of record as of Sept. 16, will be in the form of a dividend payable on Oct. 1.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Browning-Ferris Unnerves Wall St.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

 BODY:
BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES, the nation's second-largest waste-disposal company, has frequently seemed more prone to burying its stock price than garbage in recent years. The company's latest unpleasant news for Wall Street was Tuesday's announcement that earnings in the current quarter -- the last of its fiscal year ending Sept. 30 -- will be down as much as 25 percent from its disappointing third-quarter result of $58.9 million, or 38 cents a share.
Investors responded by hammering the price of Browning-Ferris on the New York Stock Exchange, driving the shares down $4 on Tuesday and lopping off $1.25 more yesterday, to $20.50. It was the most active stock on the Big Board, with 3.8 million shares traded. No one was mollified by the announcement yesterday that the quarterly dividend would remain at 17 cents a share. 
 Adding to the sour taste surrounding the dismal profits projection was the disclosure in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that R. John Stanton Jr., the company's chief financial officer, had sold 60,000 common shares, or almost half of his shares, for $27.61 a share on Aug. 12.
For the first time, there are rumblings among analysts that investors would welcome the dismissal of the company's chairman and chief executive, William D. Ruckelshaus, the former head of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Mr. Ruckelshaus was hired in 1988 as part of an effort by the Houston-based company to overcome a legacy of troubled relations with state and Federal regulators. The company's accumulated violations had led to stiff fines, forced closings of disposal sites and a reluctance by some regulators to allow permits to open new sites or expand existing ones. Analysts say Browning-Ferris may indeed be making some progress on improving its reputation with regulators, but they say its performance in the last two years suggests a variety of other deep-seated management problems that Mr. Ruckelshaus and his team have yet to confront.
"Clearly, there is something besides the economy -- something internal -- that's causing problems," said Vishnu Swarup, who follows environmental stocks for Prudential Securities. On Tuesday, Mr. Swarup changed his recommendation on the stock from buy to sell. He had projected in July that the stock could rise as high as $31 by next summer. He now expects it to be trading at $18 to $22 next spring.
Analysts are quick to concede that Browning-Ferris has been operating in an unforgiving regulatory and economic environment recently. Nearly 60 percent of its business comes from commercial and industrial waste disposers. These big customers are generating less waste as a result of the recession, more efficient production techniques and recycling. The slowdown has also added to competition from other disposal companies.
But analysts say the general explanations that were once grudgingly accepted on Wall Street are now regarded more skeptically. "People sense now that management doesn't have a good feel for what the problems are," said Barry A. Mannis, who follows environmental stocks for Morgan Stanley & Company. "I'm not sure that's fair. But if they do have an idea, they haven't explained it well."
Several analysts chided the company for its reluctance to talk more about the performance of specific operations and specific regions, and to be clearer about its strategy for dealing with its problems. "The reasons given for every ratcheting down of expectations is always general," said Stephen L. Schweich of Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore. "It doesn't compute."
Fletcher Thorne-Thomsen Jr., Browning-Ferris's vice president in charge of investor relations, defended the speed and level of detail of the company's reporting. "The only way you get investor confidence back is with performance," he said.
Skepticism about Browning-Ferris has been heightened because a number of other waste-disposal companies seem to have been much less affected by the economic downturn. "Chambers Development, Mid-American and Wheelabrator are all doing great," said James D. MacDonald at the Chicago Corporation. And although Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest waste disposal company, has shown some modest negative impact from economic conditions, Mr. MacDonald rates that company a buy because it has "top-quality management, much more diversity and much more sophistication than Browning-Ferris."
Waste Management's shares were hurt by Browning-Ferris's woes. They fell $1.50 on Tuesday and another 50 cents yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, finishing at $37.50. But the fate of the two stocks is gradually becoming decoupled, Mr. Mannis said. Waste Management is now trading at a multiple of 24 times earnings, a substantial premium over the market average, and Browning-Ferris at a multiple of less than 16, below the market average.
Having peaked at more than $48 a share nearly 14 months ago, Browning-Ferris shares have now fallen so far that some analysts believe they are at or near their bottom. The shares had tumbled as far as $20 in January. "We have been getting a lot of inquiries from value-oriented investors," said Kenneth Leung, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, who is recommending that investors buy the stock. HEADLINE: Third World Ecology Investments Sought

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Armed with Federal loan guarantees, a private partnership is seeking investors for third world business ventures with environmental goals that are as green as a dollar bill.
But the program is getting a skeptical reception from some environmental groups, who view it with the same suspicion they have long directed toward international corporations and development agencies. 
 The partnership, the International Environmental Investment Fund, is to be jointly managed by the investment bank Kidder, Peabody & Company and the consulting group Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc. It was set up recently with the backing of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Federal agency that tries to stimulate American exports by providing financing and insurance for international development projects.
 
A New Approach
 Providing backing for an investment fund is a new approach for the agency, which is also supporting three regional funds to promote development in Africa, Eastern Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.
The environmental fund's aim is to give private investors competitive returns in a fund that sponsors projects like renewable energy production, sustainable agriculture and forestry, pollution control and ecologically oriented tourism.
The fund's initial capital of $100 million will consist of $60 million in equity put up by limited partners and $40 million borrowed with an OPIC guarantee of repayment. The minimum investment for a limited partner is $5 million. The fund is expected to attract large institutional investors like pension funds and university endowments that are seeking to put some of their money into "socially conscious" investments.
Private companies and government agencies have begun to embrace environmentalism as a goal of international business. One sign of the trend is a meeting sponsored by OPIC, the United Nations and the World Bank on Thursday and Friday at the Plaza Hotel in New York, where more than a hundred speakers will address environmental investments.
But leading environmental organizations are raising concerns about the OPIC fund's environmental credentials. They say the fund's sponsors have done nothing to guarantee that the projects it sponsors -- which have not yet been chosen -- will meet environmental standards.
"I have a feeling that what we have got here is OPIC trying to put a green cloak over a standard investment fund," said Lawrence F. Williams, director of international programs for the Sierra Club in Washington. "At this point, I would urge the investor to be very cautious."
 
Access to Experts
 Lawyers and managers at OPIC said in interviews that they would strictly supervise the fund's investments. They said they had access to experts who for years had helped the agency review the environmental effects of its activities.
"We met directly with the entire alphabet soup of environmental organizations in this town," said Harvey A. Himberg, OPIC's director of environmental affairs. "We had the benefit of a lot of input from the environmental community."
But OPIC's executive vice president, James D. Berg, in a letter sent last week to Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who had questioned the fund's environmental standards, offered no concrete guidelines on how the fund would select projects or solicit public comments.
"Determinations of sound environmental practice will be made on a case-by-case basis, using accepted definitions of sustainable development in each of the sectors in which the fund proposes to invest," the letter said. "As a private investment company with private-sector clients, the fund of necessity will be constrained with respect to public disclosure of potential investments before fund resources are committed."
Mr. Williams of the Sierra Club said that was not enough. "Basically, it boils down to, 'Trust us,' " he said.
 
Outside Input Suggested
 Paul Weatherly, an expert in environmental investing whose company, Resource Management Consultants, has been working for a number of environmental groups monitoring the fund, said that OPIC should establish an independent group to have input into selecting the investment projects.
But Robert O. Draggon, OPIC's vice president for finance, compared this demand to "a Good Housekeeping seal of approval," and said, "The private sector just doesn't work that way."
Howard L. Hills, OPIC's general counsel, said a large part of OPIC's mission was to bridge the gap between the financial community and the green movement. But he said it sometimes seemed easier to get the financial community interested in environmental projects than to get the environmental groups interested in the necessities of the marketplace.
"If we just make bankers environmentalists, then we have failed," he said. "We also have to get the environmentalists to be responsive to the market forces that are going to be benefiting the environment."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nordstrom Opens Bank for Its Credit Cards

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc., the Seattle-based specialty retailer, opened a nationally chartered bank Tuesday to issue and service its credit cards. The move will exempt the company from state limits on finance charges for consumer credit.
The creation of the Nordstrom National Credit Bank in Englewood, Colo., a limited-charter bank with no checking or savings operations, allows Nordstrom to standardize its credit operations nationally without having to negotiate the thicket of state regulations governing consumer credit. 
 "We don't see any rate-structure change in the foreseeable future, but it could be considered a defensive strategy to protect us from state legislative decisions to impose limitations on finance charges," said John C. Walgamott, the bank's president and chief executive. "Any national retailer has to do this to remain competitive."
 
Industrywide Trend
 As more states have put ceilings on finance charges, retailers have begun establishing card-issuing banks in states with few or no restrictions on finance charges.
With a card issued by a bank, a retailer can take advantage of Federal court rulings that permit a bank to charge customers in all states the maximum interest rate allowed in the state where the bank is based.
For example, interest rates are capped in Connecticut, but a consumer there who holds a credit card issued by a bank based in Delaware, which has no ceiling on finance charges, must pay whatever rate the Delaware bank sets.
Kurt T. Peters, editor of Faulkner & Gray Inc.'s Credit Card News, a trade newsletter, said that slightly more than half the states had placed limits on interest rates. But there are liberal usury laws in several states, including Colorado, where Nordstrom put its bank, and Arizona, the home of the bank set up by Dillard Department Stores Inc.
"There are not a lot of retailers doing it yet, but a number of significant ones like the Limited and Dillards have begun setting them up," Mr. Peters said of the banks. "They're doing it to avoid the rate caps that some states have established."
Dillard, based in Little Rock, Ark., set up its bank in Phoenix when Arkansas voters defeated a proposal that would have allowed interest rates in the state to climb to 17 percent.
"The advantage to retailers is in the standardization," said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates Inc., a retail consulting company in New York. "For a national company,it makes a lot of sense."
Spencer Nilson, publisher of The Nilson Report, a credit card industry newsletter, said department and specialty stores must charge an average of 22 percent interest on their credit cards to break even because they do not charge annual fees for their charge cards.
A sizable number of customers pay their bills in full each month and avoid interest charges. Because stores do not charge an annual card fee, they do not have a guaranteed source of revenue to offset the expense of administering their cards, and that, they say, is why they need high interest rates.
Mr. Walgamott said holders of Nordstrom cards would not notice any changes in the payment and collection of their bills, but would receive letters telling them their accounts had been transferred to the bank.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Fund Yields Are Mixed in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the second consecutive week in the period that ended yesterday.
Tax-exempt money fund yields moved up in the week because of a combination of more supply and less demand, as investors shifted to the higher yields offered in longer-term investments. 
 The seven-day compounded average yield of tax-exempt funds followed by Donoghue rose 7 basis points in the week, to 4.19 percent, with the simple yield up 8 basis points, to 4.11 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The average 30-day compounded yield of tax-exempt funds rose a basis point in the week, to 4.11 percent, and the simple yield was up similarly, to 4.02 percent.
 
Longer Maturities
 Donoghue said the average number of days to maturity of securities in money-market portfolios rose by two days, to 59. Donoghue's analysts said the increase indicated that managers did not expect a rise in interest rates and were extending their holdings to longer maturities for higher returns.
"This Friday's employment numbers, if weaker than expected, could probably cause the Fed to lower short-term rates further via the Federal funds rate and discount rate," said Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist.
Analysts said that if that happened, investors could expect further weakening in the yields of money market funds.
Donoghue said total assets of tax-exempt funds for the week fell by $1.1 billion, to $86.6 billion.
 
Taxable Equivalents
 For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable rate equivalent to the week's average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield was 5.89 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket was 6.07 percent.
Of the tax-exempt funds monitored by IBC/ Donoghue with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund was the best performer. The fund, which is distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee, had a return of 4.99 percent, down from 5.02 percent the previous week. Some of the securities that the fund buys could be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax for certain investors.
Assets of taxable funds fell by a hefty $4.8 billion, to $451.7 billion, in the week, as institutional and small investors scampered for higher yields in other investments like short-term bond funds, corporate bond funds, Ginnie Mae funds, stocks and short-term international funds, analysts said.
 
Average Yields Fall
 The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 5 basis points in the week, to 5.40 percent, as did the simple yield, to 5.26 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was down 9 basis points, to 5.48 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was down 4 basis points, to 5.34 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return was the Riverside Capital Money Market Fund of Columbus, Ohio, with a return of 6.45 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, main competitors of money funds, fell 2 basis points in the week, to 5.12 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index. The yield spread between bank money market accounts and money market funds narrowed to 28 basis points in the week, compared with 31 basis points a week earlier.
