HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL: Pentagon Besieged;
The Soviets' Eclipse Is Likely to Spur Calls for Curbs on Military Spending

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Fundamental changes in the once-monolithic Soviet military establishment are likely to force a re-examination of the United States armed forces soon, focusing on the still commanding size of the Pentagon's budget and the broad array of defense industries that support it, American military experts say.
The expected reassessment is at hand just months after defenders of present American military spending plans appeared to be in an unassailable position with the impressive United States victory in the Persian Gulf war. 
 Despite statements last week by President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney seeking to head off a Congressional groundswell for a peace dividend, unfolding events inside the Soviet Union appear certain to heighten national interest in further reducing American military spending in favor of domestic programs.
 
A Transformed World Scene
 "The coup and its impact on Soviet security forces means that the transformation of the world scene is being completed," said James R. Schlesinger, who served as Defense Secretary and Director of Central Intelligence in the 1970's. "The way we shaped our foreign policy and military forces for 45 years is going to have to be reviewed even more radically than at the time of the collapse of the Warsaw Pact."
Mr. Cheney, already sounding defensive, pointed out last week that the United States armed forces, at present two million strong, are at their lowest level since the months before the Korean War buildup; he said the $291 billion in defense spending for the next fiscal year, as a percentage of gross national product, was lower than it was in the days before Pearl Harbor.
Though some experts question the relevance of such comparisons to today's security climate, Mr. Cheney has been using them for two years to ward off those who would cut military spending. For the fight ahead, he may need some new arguments because several major defense issues appear ripe for re-examination.
They include whether to reduce the nuclear arsenals of the superpowers drastically, whether to abandon expensive strategic defense schemes, whether to cut back the Navy's fleet of aircraft carrier battle groups and whether to reduce the active duty ranks of the Army and the Marines significantly.
Some experts also question the need for a new generation of stealth fighters, bombers and helicopters, as well as battle cruisers and attack submarines, in quantities dictated by new war scenarios developed by Mr. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The scenarios state that the United States should maintain sufficient forces and weapons to fight a war like the one in the Persian Gulf simultaneously with a smaller regional war, while also being prepared to meet a resurgent Soviet military threat.
"All of the scenarios are falling apart as far as the Soviet Union is concerned, and I don't buy the Middle East scenarios," said William W. Kaufmann, professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and longtime adviser to secretaries of defense.
The question is whether a Democratic Congress will buy the Pentagon's view of the world as the Soviet Union moves closer to the West in democratic character and commitment to a free-market economy.
With the major changes continuing to take place in the Soviet Union after the failed coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last month, the 40-year-old concept of East-West military competition could soon be dead, leaving the United States looking like a superpower in an arms race with itself.
 
Soviet Officers Face Ouster
 "All my pillars of intellectual support are pretty well gone, because the Soviet Union and Soviet forces as I knew them no longer exist," said Lieut. Gen. Samuel V. Wilson, retired, who once was head of the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency. The announcement that Mr. Gorbachev's new Defense Minister, Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, would replace 80 percent of the Soviet officer corps was a signal that the Soviet upheaval had finally reached the country's most important institution. "To a degree, I share the attitude that the world has changed right under our feet," Mr. Wilson said.
Some experts, like Roald Sagdeyev, former head of the Space Research Institute in Moscow, believe that the aftermath of the failed coup not only has speeded the dissolution of the once vaunted Soviet military, but also has cracked the barriers protecting the military-industrial complex from conversion and change.
"The whole overproduction of tanks and submarines was a tragedy for the Soviet people, and this is why they are economically ruined," Mr. Sagdeyev said. He added that part of the "revolution" in East-West attitudes must come with help from the West in finding new roles for the shipbuilding and aviation industries.
Such change will encourage the kind of revolutionary thinking Mr. Bush alluded to when he forecast the "opportunity for a vastly restructured national security posture" last Thursday. It may be "way too early," as Mr. Bush also said, to consider such fundamental restructuring, but it may not be too early to begin a few months hence.
 
The Message Is Clear
 Representative Les Aspin's call last week to shift $1 billion within the 1992 defense budget to humanitarian aid for the Soviet Union was quickly assailed by Mr. Cheney, but the political message coming from the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee was clear: the Administration has some time to put together a new defense program, but not too much.
While Mr. Aspin himself may be loath to risk reopening the budget agreement that has locked in defense budget figures until after the 1992 elections, his suggestion served as an important trial balloon to determine whether the political spell cast over the defense budget by the successful Persian Gulf war has been broken.
Mr. Aspin acknowledged as recently as last month that the Administration was in an unassailable political position by pursuing a course of modest cuts and trumpeting military achievements in the Persian Gulf. But now the failure of the Moscow coup has ended the longstanding debate on whether Mr. Gorbachev's revolution is reversible.
Although the eventual shape of the Soviet military remains dependent on the new political architecture emerging in Moscow, United States military analysts speculate that the 4.5 million-member armed forces may become a smaller, highly professional all-volunteer force under a collective leadership that may emphasize purely defensive roles on behalf of diverse republics.
"A collective head is not going to allow the military to be an interventionist force," a Pentagon official suggested. "Can you imagine the Azerbaijanis voting for the incursion into Afghanistan?"
A Soviet Union that represents the collective sovereign interests of its constituent republics will be more likely to pursue arms control agreements to eliminate nuclear weapons, these experts say.
With the prospect of large-scale retirements and purges in the top ranks of the Soviet military, the slashing of military industries' budgets and the dismantling of the K.G.B. and the internal security forces, the fundamental transfer of resources out of the Soviet military sector appears to be at hand and will pave the way for the inevitable debate on a new definition for United States national security policy.
 
A Flood of Questions
 In the process, a flood of questions will emerge, a number of experts say.
*Should the Bush Administration seize the initiative to reopen strategic arms negotiations to lock in an even lower ceiling for warheads, missile launchers, strategic bombers and submarines held by the superpowers?
*Why should both sides continue to hold each other's populations and industries hostage to strategic nuclear targeting even as the Soviet economy begins to intermingle with Western economies? "Nuclear weapons have never been important to us except as a deterrent to the Soviet Union," Mr. Wilson said, "and once the need for that deterrent becomes less, I think that we and they will be in an excellent position to figure out some way to discard these things," leaving only a "modest" number of intercontinental strategic weapons on each side.
*Does the United States need 12 aircraft carrier battle groups, which were built as part of a global war-fighting strategy against the Soviets? Mr. Kaufmann argues that six carriers based most of the time in United States waters are sufficient to protect American interests around the world.
*Is it necessary to build a fleet of 80 or 90 Seawolf attack submarines at a cost of $2 billion each when their chief mission is to bottle up the Soviet fleet in Arctic seas in World War III? Some Congressional and Navy analysts are already quietly calling for the end of the Seawolf program in favor of a smaller attack submarine fleet of more modest design.
*Do both the Air Force and the Navy need new fleets of stealth fighters and bombers, or could stealth technologies be adapted to current production lines of F-15's, F-16's and F-14's?
*More important, does the Pentagon need to continue subsidizing through divided procurement strategies a broad spectrum of often redundant defense industries on the theory that "surge" production capacity is essential to be prepared for global war? For 45 years, the Pentagon has been propping up or bailing out major airframe manufacturers and shipyards that otherwise would succumb to market forces in the belief that these industries are critical to the military industrial base needed for war.
Whether much of this industrial capacity can now go safely into mothballs is a question that Congress will have to address -- against powerful parochial and pork barrel interests -- if it wants to undertake a significant transfer of resources to the domestic agenda.

HEADLINE: Dow Edges Down 9.17 to Close at 3,008.50

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower yesterday after the Dow Jones industrial average dipped to the psychological barrier of 3,000 and then rebounded slightly to close at 3,008.50, a loss of 9.17 points.
Anxiety over the employment statistics to be released by the Government tomorrow caused many traders to remain on the sidelines while a batch of program trades in the late afternoon caused the market to fall by nearly 18 points before beginning a slow recovery. 
 Volume totaled 157.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, slightly higher than in the previous session; declining issues on the Big Board outnumbered advancing stocks by a ratio of 9 to 5.
"It's a waiting game," said Gene Jay Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. "The market fell on a lack of buying rather than from terribly heavy selling."
The mood of the market is one of caution as investors wait to see whether a worsening employment picture will encourage the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. Cuts in interest rates have generally proved to be a powerful long-term stimulus to the stock market.
A small example of the effect of falling interest rates came yesterday when the Bank of England announced before the United States markets opened that it was lowering a key rate to 10.5 percent, from 11 percent. That caused a slight morning rally on the Big Board before stocks began to head down.
Trading patterns were similar in other markets. The American Stock Exchange's composite index closed down 1.53 points, at 369.99, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.99, to 517.92.
Ricky Harrington, director of investment policy at Marion Bass Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said that if volume remained steady, the market could experience a "technical rebound" in the next day or two.
"I think you can make a case that there's technical support at 3,000," Mr. Harrington said. "But if you begin to get diminishing volume, then look for a move back behind 3,000 next week."
Market analysts discounted the effect the appearance of Salomon Brothers officials before a House committee yesterday may have had on trading. They said that any market pressure had already been absorbed in stock prices and noted that shares of Salomon Brothers traded down only 3/8 yesterday to close at 25.
There was a split decision on two leading drug stocks. Centocor was the most active over-the-counter stock, rising 3, to 40 1/2. That came on news that the Food and Drug Administration had approved a Centocor drug to fight bacterial infections. But the agency did not approve a rival drug from Xoma, and that company's shares tumbled 5, to 15 1/2. The two stocks were the most actively traded yesterday.
The stocks of waste management companies also fell after the announcement on Tuesday that the earnings of Browning Ferris were still being hurt by the recession. Browning Ferris fell 1 1/4, to 20 1/2, and was the third-most-active stock.
Goodyear was one of the few bright spots among blue chips. The stock rose 2 3/8, to 40 7/8, after announcing tire price increases that were welcomed by analysts.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
U.S. Hoping Moscow Can Retain Control of Soviets' Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
The Bush Administration indicated today that it hopes to see the Soviet Union become a loose confederation of sovereign republics with a central authority that could at least control nuclear weapons, fulfill treaty obligations and work together with the United States on foreign policy initiatives like Middle East peace.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who outlined Administration policy toward a rapidly changing Soviet Union during a news conference at the State Department, carefully avoided spelling out the type of government the United States would like to see evolve, insisting that this was for the Soviet people to decide. 
 But the American policy guidelines he described would be virtually impossible to achieve without a Soviet Union that remains, at a minimum, a loose confederation of republics, with some sort of central authority.
Mr. Baker's comments, which followed a meeting with President Bush at the White House today, represented the Administration's first effort since the failed coup last month to distill its reactions to the political upheaval in the Soviet Union into a statement of policy. [Excerpts from the news conference, page A12.]
 
Applauds the Momentum
 The Secretary of State made it clear that Washington would like to see the momentum toward political and economic reform that followed the coup attempt continue apace, but hopes it will not lead to the total elimination of some central authority with which the United States and its allies can work on military and diplomatic issues.
Specifically, Mr. Baker said the United States would prefer that the Soviet Union's arsenal of 28,000 nuclear weapons remain under a central command authority rather than falling under the control of the republics.
"We do not want to see the transformation that's taking place in the Soviet Union either create or add to the problems of nuclear-weapons proliferation," he said. "I think that it would be probably on balance best if not necessarily they ended up all in one republic, but that they ended up under one central command authority."
Mr. Baker also indicated that the Administration was in no rush to recognize the independence of any republics other than Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania -- which he said he would visit next week on a trip that will also take him to Moscow.
The visit, intended to underscore American support for Baltic independence, serves the additional purpose of reassuring the large communities of Baltic-Americans in Chicago and other cities that the Administration is responsive to their interests.
American officials say they want to avoid doing anything that would hasten an uncontrolled breakup of the Soviet Union, such as opening diplomatic relations with non-Baltic republics that have declared independence. These republics will continued to be served by the United States Embassy in Moscow or the consulate in Kiev.
 
Complements Gorbachev Policy
 The Bush Administration's apparent preference for a loose confederation with some central authority dovetails with the sort of reform program that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been trying to persuade the Soviet republics to accept.
Mr. Baker's remarks suggested that both the substance and the semantics of American policy toward the Soviet Union are going to change. He never mentioned the names of Mr. Gorbachev or of Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, but instead constantly referred to "Soviet leaders" and "the Soviet peoples" as the interlocutors with whom Washington would deal.
The Secretary said that during his weeklong visit to the Soviet Union, he will explore the need for humanitarian assistance to get through the winter, as well as how the delivery of promised American technical help for reforming the Soviet economy, markets and distribution systems can be accelerated.
Mr. Baker also said that after consulting with Japanese officials, he hoped to talk with the Soviets about accelerating a settlement of the dispute over the Northern Territories, or Kurile Islands.
Japan has made return of the four islands occupied by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II a condition for any substantial economic aid to Moscow, something that the United States is eager to see since it would spread the aid burden.
 
Outlines Set of Principles
 In laying out five principles that would guide American foreign policy toward the Soviet Union, Mr. Baker said the first would be that "the future of the Soviet Union is for the Soviet peoples to determine themselves, peacefully and consistent with democratic values and practices." He added that in this process "there can be no legitimate place for threats, intimidation, coercion or violence."
Second, Mr. Baker said, the United States urged everyone inside and outside the Soviet Union to "respect existing borders, internal and external." He emphasized that "any change of borders should only occur legitimately by peaceful and consensual means" consistant with the principles of the Helsinki Final Act.
American officials say that a loose federation of Sovereign republics would help defuse ethnic and border tensions, which could easily arise if each of the Soviet republics decided to go its own way.
Third, the United States will support peaceful change in the Soviet Union "only through orderly, democratic processes, especially elections."
Fourth, the United States wants to see the "safeguarding of human rights, based on full respect for the individual and including equal treatment of minorities."
Finally, Mr. Baker emphasized that the United States will expect whatever political entity or entities emerge from changes in the Soviet Union to respect international obligations, especially human rights provisions.
 
How to Apply These Concepts
 Mr. Baker said that as the Soviet people and leaders "clarify the precise interrelationships both among the various republics and with the center," he will methods supportive of these five principles.
He added, though, that his agenda on next week's visit will be much broader. He will meet with members of the new Economic Commission to "urge rapid development of a new, comprehensive economic adjustment and reform plan in close consultation with the I.M.F., World Bank and other international economic institutions."
Mr. Baker conceded that he would not be bringing any specific economic reform plan to the Soviet Union, other than to urge rapid steps to create a free-market economy and private property.
Administration officials have privately said that the prospects for coherent and speedy economic reform will be much greater if the Soviet republics act together through some central coordinating body.
 
Debt and Default
 One of the questions hanging over Soviet economic reform, the Secretary said, is who will be responsible for the nation's foreign debts if the union breaks totally apart and what prospect there will be for individual republics to raise capital abroad if the Union is in default on a large scale.
Speaking of Soviet debts, Mr. Baker asked: "To what extent will republics that are leaving the Soviet Union disclaim any responsibility? To what extent would some accept some responsibility? And what does that do to the ability of those of us in the West whose laws call for certain credit requirements?
"All I suggest there," he said, "is that if there is going to be a devolution of rights and responsibilities, that it's both, not just rights but responsibilities as well."
Mr. Baker said he would be discussing with Soviet leaders various security issues "to insure proper follow-through on treaty commitments and understandings on nuclear safety."
He emphasized that arms control treaties negotiated with the old Soviet leadership are "still in our interest," and the United States would ask the new government to abide by its commitments in the conventional arms reduction treaty signed last November and the strategic arms reduction treaty signed in August.
Mr. Baker was pressed to explain how the Administration could ask the Senate to ratify these treaties when it did not know what sort of Soviet Union would exist to carry them out.
"If we're not satisfied come time to ratify, obviously, I think we would probably say, 'Let's wait till we're satisfied.' " he replied. "But don't interpret that as a statement today that says we're not going to do it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Salomon Scandal
A report from Salomon says rules were ignored and documentation was lax on its government bond trading desk. That casual approach also seemed to characterize the way senior management dealt with the scandal over improper bidding for bonds. [Page D1.]
Some in Congress say they will move to tighten regulation of the $2.2 trillion Treasury securities market. [D1.]

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Baker's Remarks: Policy on Soviets

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Following is a statement made today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during a briefing on United States policy toward the Soviet Union.
 In the last two weeks, we've seen another revolution blowing with full force across the Soviet Union. Of course, it's obvious that we want to see this revolution remain democratic and we want to see it remain peaceful. Building democracy and free markets across the Soviet Union is not going to be an easy task after decades of totalitarianism and central planning. The work of freedom will be hard, and the transition will be painful. 
 The Soviet peoples have to know that they have just embarked on what will be a very difficult road, but they must know, too, that there can be no turning away from democratic principles and tolerance if they truly hope to follow that road to its end and to join the democratic commonwealth of nations. We will help them move along that path of political and economic freedom.
As a first step, the President has asked me to go to Moscow next week to attend the C.S.C.E. human rights meeting and to have discussions with a number of leaders. I go to the Soviet Union with a four-part agenda.
First, I will convey to Soviet leaders and to the Soviet peoples the five principles that will guide this administration's approach to political change in the Soviet Union. However, on this overall question let me be very clear. The Baltic states have always been and they remain a special and indeed separate case for the United States.
We never recognized their incorporation into the Soviet Union. To us they have never been Soviet republics, but instead separate states for whom we helped keep alive the promise and diplomatic symbols of independence.
And of course on Monday the President took an important step to turn that promise and those symbols into working realities, beginning the process of establishing formal diplomatic relations with the governments of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. To emphasize America's continuing commitment to the Baltics' enduring freedom, I would like very much to visit these states on this trip.
As to the changes that are taking place in center-republic relations, our policy, that is, the policy of this Administration, toward the Soviet future will be guided by the following five principles.
First, the future of the Soviet Union is for the Soviet peoples to determine themselves, peacefully and consistent with democratic values and practices and the principles of the Helsinki Final Act. We call upon all Soviet leaders at all levels of government, including those of the republics, to show their support for these internationally accepted principles. In this process there can be no legitimate place for threats, intimidation, coercion or violence.
Second, we urge all to respect existing borders, both internal and external. Any change of borders should occur only legitimately by peaceful and consensual means, consistent with C.S.C.E. principles.
Third, we support democracy and the rule of law. And we support peaceful change only through orderly democratic processes, especially the processes of elections.
Four, we call for the safeguarding of human rights based on full respect for the individual and including equal treatment of minorities.
Five, we urge respect for international law and obligations, especially adherence to the provisions of the Helsinki Final Act and the Charter of Paris. Clearly one of the first and most important steps the Soviet leaders and peoples need to take is to clarify the precise interrelationships both among the various republics and between the republics and the center. We will recommend that these relationships be clarified in ways that are supportive of the five principles that I've just outlined.
The second item on my agenda on this trip will be our support for fundamental economic reform and immediate humanitarian needs. The Soviet political revolution must now be matched by an economic revolution. In Moscow I will seek to meet with Prime Minister Silayev and the members of the Economic Commission to urge rapid development of a new comprehensive economic adjustment and reform plan in close consultation with the I.M.F., the World Bank and the other international economic institutions. This we think is the critical next step.
I will also be discussing with Soviet leaders at all levels humanitarian needs for the winter. This work will complement the efforts being undertaken by the presidential mission.
And, finally, I plan to examine how our technical assistance can be accelerated to both help meet humanitarian needs and to prepare the foundations for long-term restructuring.
The third item on my agenda will be Soviet foreign policy. In particular, I will be continuing to work on efforts to convene a peace conference to launch direct negotiations and thereby to facilitate a viable peacemaking process in the Middle East. After consulting with our Japanese partners, I also would hope to be able to accelerate action on the Northern Territories, stressing the need to close out the last significant vestige of World War II.
And the fourth item on my agenda -- fourth, and finally -- I hope to have some talks about Soviet security policy generally so that we can assure proper follow-through on treaty commitments and understandings on nuclear safety and pave the way for a genuine and extensive defense conversion effort.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEW INCINERATORS TERMED ESSENTIAL IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
New York City will have to build as many as three new garbage incinerators, in part because it will not be able to recycle as much trash as state goals call for, the Dinkins administration has concluded.
The new incinerators could cost at least $1 billion and will most likely prompt fierce opposition from environmental and community groups. In his 1989 mayoral campaign, David N. Dinkins had held out hope that the city would be able to address its trash disposal needs without resorting to new incinerators.
But in a plan to be disclosed today, Dinkins administration officials acknowledge that in addition to expanding three existing plants, two to three additional new incinerators will be needed.
 
Burning Plus Recycling
 The administration also said that the city would have to burn 68 percent of its trash, slightly less than what was contemplated by the Koch administration. The city collects 14,500 tons of waste a day. "Even with very aggressive recycling, we still need to burn 10,000 tons," Steven M. Polan, the city's Sanitation Commissioner, said in an interview yesterday.
Many environmental and community groups have vehemently opposed building new incinerators because of concern over worsening air quality and neighborhood disruption by truck traffic. Incinerators emit several kinds of contaminants including soot particles containing lead, acid gases and dioxin, considered to be health risks.
The city will be able to recycle 25 percent of its trash by the year 2000, the same level required by city law but less than a state goal of as much as 42 percent by 1997, Mr. Polan said.
But any more than 25 percent cannot be economically justified because recycling markets will not be sufficiently developed to absorb all the material that New Yorkers could separate for recycling, he said.
Opponents of incinerators are very likely to take issue with the Sanitation Department analysis that only 25 percent recycling is economically feasible.
But city officials say that just to reach the 25 percent level will require adding to the six materials many New Yorkers currently separate for recycling pickup. About 6 percent of the trash collected by the Sanitation Department is now being separated under the city's struggling two-and-a-half-year-old recycling program.
Mr. Polan is to present highlights of the administration's plan at a state legislative hearing on solid waste today at 11 A.M. at 270 Broadway in New York City. A city solid waste management plan required by state law -- already five months late -- is expected to be completed and released for public comment by Nov. 1, Mr. Polan said. In the interview yesterday, Mr. Polan offered only an outline of the plan, and it was unclear when the new incinerators would be built.
After hearings in November and December, the plan will be modified and submitted to the state Department of Environmental Conservation. The city cannot build trash processing or disposal plants until the plan receives state approval.
Many officials, including Mr. Dinkins's First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, maintain that recycling has limits and that with landfill capacity running out, the city has no alternative except to burn a substantial amount of its trash. Incineration proponents say modern plants are safe if properly maintained.
 
Dinkins' 1989 Promise
 In 1989, Mr. Dinkins promised to delay a decision until 1993 about building more incinerators, pending a review of the city's trash disposal needs.
"We're not going to have giant, mass-burn incinerators in every borough belching poison into the air," he said, after receiving the endorsement of the New York League of Conservation Voters.
The next February, Mr. Dinkins said at a conference on the environment: "You all know that I have some very serious concerns about the consequences of proceeding with resource-recovery plants, especially with regard to the toxic ash produced by that technology. Unless my concerns are adequately answered, we will not proceed with incineration."
Resource-recovery plants are incinerators that convert garbage-generated steam into electric power.
Under one Koch administration plan, new incinerators would have been built in each borough. Mr. Polan said the Dinkins plan would require building two or three new incinerators and the expansion of three existing units, which is under way. Construction of an incinerator at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard remains a possibility, a department spokeswoman, Anne Canty, said.
The Sanitation Department's study found that incineration is the cheapest way to dispose of trash, Mr. Polan said, but an approach limited to burning would be at odds with the state's environmental priorities and increasing national emphasis on more recycling.
He reiterated that the city's current recycling program is struggling and needs an overhaul badly. Such an overhaul would require big revisions in the city's mandatory recycling law, which contemplated 25 percent recycling by spring 1994.
Sounding an old theme, Mr. Polan said achieving 25 percent recycling at an affordable cost will require changes in sanitation union work rules. The department needs more flexibility to move workers from collection to recycling routes, he said. Bargaining between management and the union has gone nowhere on the issue.

HEADLINE: Parents Weigh the Risks Of City vs. Suburbs

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
PEOPLE with children have always debated leaving New York City. But previous generations saw their trek to the suburbs as a move up to a better life.
Many New Yorkers who are leaving now have few illusions about suburban life. Some of them grew up in the suburbs and found the experience stultifying. The suburbs, however, represent safety. 
 To live in New York these days is to talk about the dangers here, which somehow seem greater now that the boom years of the 1980's have passed. Parents wonder whether they are risking their children's lives by choosing to live in New York.
Marcia Cohen, who recently moved from Manhattan to Scarsdale, N.Y., with her husband and two young children, said violence helped to push her out. Earlier this year, there was a shootout at 4:45 in the afternoon on her Upper East Side block, just as the children were coming home from school. "That just scared us to death," she said, and reinforced the family's decision to leave.
While violence is more common in the city, the statistical odds that her children will die young are no greater on the Upper East Side than in Scarsdale. Suburban teen-agers face a greater risk of dying in a car accident, a kind of carnage rarely considered when the bucolic suburbs beckon.
Death rates are admittedly a limited way to measure quality of life. City dwellers speak longingly of letting their children ride bikes in the street or walk alone to a neighbor's home. They believe that safety is assured only by keeping children under constant surveillance.
Nor do death rates take into account the high rate of crimes like muggings. Nevertheless, they are one of the few concrete ways to assess safety.
Elliott Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, unabashedly loves New York for its culture, its intellectual life and its high level of stimulation. He believes that the suburbs are riskier than people believe, and the city less dangerous.
"If you add up all the statistics," he said, "you trade a bullet for a car."
But living in the city with his wife and two young children requires him to be constantly on guard, which is enervating. His son, who is 8 years old, does not have the mobility that suburban children do. "I can't imagine allowing Jason to go anywhere by himself until he's 52 or 53," Professor Sclar said.
The fear of violence is only one reason parents leave the city. The quality of public schools and the cost of housing are big reasons. But fear of violence creates the feeling that the quality of life has declined in New York.
Vivienne Stultz, a native of Jamaica who has lived in New York since 1967, has with great regret decided to sell her house in Richmond Hill, Queens, because she believes the city has too many negative influences on her four children. "New York should be loved, and I love it," she said. But inadequate schools and unreliable subways are drawbacks, as is violence, or at least the possibility of it.
"Violence hasn't really touched me," she said. "But it is ever present."
National statistics on the relative safety of growing up in cities versus suburbs do not exist, according to demographers. But narrower studies indicate that financial status and education, not place of residence. predict the life span for young people.
"In general, the wealthier you are, the lower your mortality," said Paul Wise, a professor of pediatrics at Harvard University Medical School who has studied childhood death rates. Although his studies have focused on Boston, he believes his findings apply to the nation as a whole.
Harry Rosenberg, chief of mortality statistics at the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md., said social class correlates with death rates. "The race differential is wiped out when you can control for socioeconomic factors," he said.
Death rates among the poor in New York City are disproportionately high. For example, among people up to age 24 in Harlem, the death rate was 265 per 100,000 in 1988, compared to 75 per 100,000 in Staten Island. But in many parts of the city, particularly the wealthier areas, the death rate was equal to or even lower than that of young people in affluent suburbs.
Statistics, however, should be viewed with caution because in small populations, death rates can be radically altered by only one accident or fire in which many people die. Also, the most recent statistics, broken down by neighborhood by the New York City Health Department, are several years old. Suburban figures use 1990 population numbers and 1989 deaths, except for Bergen County, which uses 1988 data.
On the Upper East Side, the death rate in 1988 was 60 per 100,000 for people up to age 24, lower than the rate of 83 per 100,000 in Scarsdale in 1989 for that age group and the rate of 97 per 100,000 in Greenwich, Conn., in 1988.
TriBeCa had a death rate of 80 per 100,000, and Greenwich Village and SoHo each had a rate of 21 per 100,000 for that age group in 1988.
For Westchester County, the death rate for people up to age 24 was 88 per 100,000 in 1989. In Bergen County, N.J., an area with no urban centers and many small, wealthy towns, the death rate in 1989 for that age group was 65 per 100,000. In Nassau County on Long Island, the death rate was 82 per 100,000.
Some suburbs have the same death rates as parts of the city that have socioeconomically diverse populations. On the Upper West Side, for instance, the death rate for young people was 107 per 100,000; in New Rochelle in Westchester County, it was 108.
Parents who are trying to choose where to live speak of their culpability if something happened to their children. Those with the economic means to leave the city say that if their children died in an act of violence, they would feel that they could have averted it. But if their children died in a car accident in the suburbs, they would feel that it was just that, an accident; they would not feel that they should not have moved to the suburbs.
Robin Bossert, who lives in Brooklyn with his wife and child, is frustrated by the focus on violence in the city and the general belief that the suburbs are risk-free. He spent his teen years in Pleasantville in Westchester County, and he remembers fatal car accidents and suicides among his friends. The pervasive negative attitude about the city is so disheartening, he said, that he tries to avoid watching or reading local news reports that he considers biased.
"I go by my own personal experience," he said. "This city is stupendous."
Louise Hamilton, who grew up in New York, feels torn by the advantages and disadvantages of life in the city and suburbs. As friends leave, the city becomes less appealing and she has been talking with her husband about moving to the suburbs with their son, who is 8.
"Friends talk about it, yes," she said. "But if they do it, that makes a real difference."

HEADLINE: The Joyce Dances On Despite Soggy Stage

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
The American Indian Dance Theater will open the dance season at the Joyce Theater on Sept. 17 with a traditional blessing of the ground on which it will perform. That blessing will have an extra resonance this year, for the Joyce might very well have been closed for the season after a faulty sprinkler system in early August flooded the theater with 227,000 gallons of water, creating what one staff member described as "a reflecting pool" in the lower lobby. The stage floor was ruined, as were the theater's piano and its 464 seats and carpeting. Red dye dripping from the soaked front stage curtain stained the buckling ceilings and walls of downstairs offices, dressing rooms and rehearsal areas.
But in the days that followed, it became clearer than ever to the founders and staff of the Joyce, once a rundown movie house with sagging seats and a floor like flypaper, that the theater occupies an important place in New York's dance life. 
 "The support was incredible," Lisa Lawer, executive director of the Joyce, said yesterday. "Within three hours after the flood was discovered, employees and friends had come in to start mopping up. Almost every dance company that has performed at the theater sent messages of support. Lots of donors sent small contributions with notes saying things like 'a little something for a rainy day.' This theater is very loved."
A maintenance man discovered the flood early on the morning of Aug. 10, a Saturday in the middle of a summer engagement by the Feld Ballets/NY, the Joyce's resident company. The volunteer mop brigade worked three 16-hour shifts and by Monday night the Feld dancers were performing again, on a stage without a curtain to an audience that had wound its way into the theater past warning signs and still-damp areas.
"It was a miracle," Ms. Lawer said. "The insurance company told us that the first 24 hours of work saved the theater."
The flood, which caused over $500,000 in damage, was the result of a malfunctioning of a sprinkler system over the stage that had been mandated by the New York City Fire Department to replace asbestos curtains. Water poured into the theater for six hours. "It's a sensitive system, and I've heard other theaters have had problems," said Ms. Lawer. "There is material now that can replace asbestos. I think it would be great if the Fire Department considered options."
Despair over the damage soon turned to "wet jokes," as Ms. Lawer put it. "We were flooded with calls," she said, giving an example. And there were many calls and messages of support, along with three boxes of cookies sent by Merce Cunningham for the hard-working moppers.
"It was a terrible catastrophe," Mr. Cunningham said yesterday. "I think the Joyce has played a very good role in the theater world for dance. It's a kind of middle ground that's allowed so many companies to be seen in such a good venue, in a situation less complex than uptown. It's become a theater people go to to see dances. Everything can be seen there, and it's comfortable."
 
A New Stage
 The Indians -- and dancers with the 26 companies that will follow them into the Joyce during its 36-week dance season -- will have a new stage to perform on. And renovation work will continue through the spring. Yesterday, a week before the saxophonist Branford Marsalis opens at the Joyce for a three-performance engagement, the theater was full of workers hammering and sawing. Rusted stage lights lay about the floor, and sheets of wood were being laid down in the mirrored dancers' warmup room backstage.
The Joyce may have to cancel some or all of a dance season planned for next summer in honor of its 10th anniversary. But it will go ahead with the scheduled fall and spring seasons, despite a suggestion from the theater's insurance company that it close for repairs.
"There isn't another theater for these companies to go to if they're not at the Joyce," Ms. Lawer said. "A company can't go from a 100-seat loft space to City Center or Lincoln Center. Choreographers, like other artists, need time to grow and develop and do their work. And that is what the Joyce is here for, for companies of different styles, representing different cultures. We're not supporting one esthetic."
All dance performances are at least partly subsidized by the Joyce, which faces a 65 percent cut in government support this year. And education -- of dance companies, schoolchildren and adult audiences -- is an important part of the Joyce mission, Ms. Lawer said. An annual modern dance sampler season for smaller, newer troupes includes seminars on topics like advertising, budgeting and producing concerts. Audiences can attend regular post-performance talks with choreographers. And each engagement includes one free performance for children in New York City Public Schools. This year the Joyce will present eight Saturday family matinees, with reduced priced tickets for children. In another new program, the Pilobolus company will conduct workshops with ninth graders in two Chelsea schools.
These efforts may be paying off for the Joyce. Despite the recession, Ms. Lawer said, the Joyce's audience has grown over the past year. "This is an amazingly sturdy, strong little place," she said.

HEADLINE: Aides' Pay Pivotal to Nursing Homes' Future

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEXAS CITY, Tex.

 BODY:
In the sluggish American economy, health care is one of the few industries that has rapidly grown and prospered. But not everyone in the field has shared in the bounty: about 1.5 million workers -- mostly nursing home aides and mostly women -- are still paid close to the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour.
Now, industry officials say that dam is about to burst. Workers at the bottom of the health-care system should soon see big wage increases -- just as governments, insurers and health-care providers themselves are desperately seeking ways to keep costs down. 
 The officials say irresistible pressures are building behind the aides' wages. The population of the United States is aging, so hundreds of thousands more aides will be needed to care for the elderly in the 1990's.Unions are redoubling efforts to organize the workers. A Federal law now requires formal training and certification of aides, which enhances their value. And nursing homes want to stem the rampant turnover in personnel that plagues them.
 
Growing Financial Pressure
 "It's a real crunch issue," said Vincent Shepherd, the Texas regional human resources director for Beverly Enterprises of Fort Smith, Ark., which owns the College Park Care Center, a nursing home in this city 40 miles southeast of Houston. With 860 of the nation's 19,000 nursing homes, Beverly is the biggest operator in the business.
Van Ellet, a senior analyst for the American Association of Retired Persons, said low Medicaid payments to nursing homes, more than the tightfistedness of nursing home operators, account for the aides' low pay. In many cases, the wages are too low to lift aides above the poverty line and off welfare. "I think it's boiling over right now," Mr. Ellet said. "You're seeing some of the pressures coming on state Medicaid budgets."
The College Park nursing home has 111 residents, up to 104 years old. Of its 95 employees, 42 are aides; the rest are registered nurses, practical nurses, kitchen and maintenance workers and office workers.
One aide, Darlene Jefferson, said she enjoyed her work though it made most people squeamish, including many of the younger adults who have entrusted 1.5 million of their elders to nursing homes.
"I'm a bath tech," Mrs. Jefferson said. "I have 15 to bathe a day. I bring them to the shower room down the hall. They sit on a chair. I'll wash them and rinse them off and dry them. I'll wash their face, brush their teeth.
"It makes them feel good. It makes me feel good. I love what I do. Because of the residents themselves, the people who live here. They love you at times. Some of them are mean and hateful, but after you do things for them, they'll kiss you and hug you and love you for doing it."
Mrs. Jefferson is proud of her work. She said she could manage changing adult diapers, the strains of lifting residents and enduring the slurs of the demented. Her sole complaint is the pay.
After working 26 of her 47 years in nursing homes, Ms. Jefferson earns $4.46 an hour, or $8,700 a year, from her 37 1/2-hour work week. Separated from her husband, the mother of five with one child still at home qualifies for $66 a month in food stamps.
She cannot afford the company's health insurance plan, which would cost about $350 a year for herself and $1,300 if she included any children. So, like most Beverly nursing aides, she cannot count on receiving the kind of care that many of her patients received during their working lives -- or on getting the care in her old age that she gives them in theirs.
 
Effect on Health Budget
 Even at current wage levels, aides are an important factor in the cost of health care because there are so many of them. Aides are the people who work most closely with nursing home residents in dealing with their day-to-day needs, keeping them clean and fed and monitoring their vital signs. They make up about a fifth of the nation's 6.8 million health-care workers, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. About 60 percent of them, one million, work in nursing homes; most of the rest work in hospitals. Some men, usually called orderlies, do the same work and are paid about 10 percent more. But 91 percent of all aides are women, and 31 percent of all aides are black.
Without Medicaid, fewer of these people would have jobs, fewer old people would have care and fewer nursing homes would survive. More than half of nursing home residents lack the personal resources or private insurance to pay for their beds, so Medicaid pays. But the Federal Government and many states set limits on Medicaid payments. These limits have been rising, but not enough to permit significant wage increases.
Medicaid in Texas pays $54 a day for a patient at College Park, not much more than the rate for a room in nearby motels. The 10 percent of College Park's residents who are private patients pay $85, more than the home needs to keep them. So they, like private patients generally, help subsidize the care of the indigent.
 
Desire to Go Home
 College Park is a sprawling one-story structure in a residential neighborhood. Its patients wear white wrist bands embedded with a magnetic strip that sets off a deafening beeper when they try to slip out the door.
One recent afternoon, the beeper went off every 15 minutes. A woman in her 80's was trying to go home to Galveston and, she told aides, get married. "They've always got their minds on going home," said Glenora Keeling, 84, a good-humored, brightly dressed widow in a wheelchair.
Beverly Enterprises has weathered bouts with the courts over trying to keep out labor unions and charges of mistreating patients at a few homes. But not here.
"Some of the non-Beverly homes, they have no standards," said Orell Fitzsimmons, head of Local 100 of the Service Employees International Union, which represents College Park workers. "Beverly has certain standards. You have to give them credit for that. This is a clean home. It is well kept up. It doesn't smell."
The staff makes it that way. Donna Hadley, 31, wears a badge labeled "environmental services." She cleans 20 rooms a day along with the public restrooms and hallways. She is single and has no children. Still, she needs more money. She is thinking of looking for a second, part-time job, rather than leaving College Park for a job that pays more.
Many residents stay in their rooms because they are bedridden. Of those who can get around, the lucid among them seemed chiefly absorbed in the personal lives they have built for themselves and activities the home organizes, like bingo and sing-alongs.
Ludmilla Thurmond, 73, a widow with Parkinson's disease, seems more concerned with learning to cope for herself than with her confinement. Her knees are flat, with six-inch-long scars of deep incisions across them. "I haven't walked for eight or nine years," she said. "When I came here, I couldn't do nothing for myself. Now they still have to put on my shoes and my pants. But I take my own shower and I put myself to bed. I push my wheelchair. When I need help, they help me."
Janet Morris, the nursing home's administrator, called the turnover among aides "horrendous." She said four of every five aides she hired were gone within a year. Paul Willging, executive vice president of the American Health Care Association, the nursing homes' lobby, said the annual turnover for the industry generally was closer to 100 percent.
The problem will become even more acute as demand for nursing home care rises, with people living longer and with the surge of Baby Boomers who will start retiring in 15 or 20 years. At the same time, it is becoming harder to find qualified aides because Federal law now requires that they have two weeks' training and be certified.
Some recruits, usually unskilled women who are trained on the job to be aides, find the work demeaning and quit. Some, Mrs. Morris said, take a job just to earn a little money, and then leave. Still others move from nursing home to nursing home in pursuit of tiny wage increases of 5 cents or 10 cents an hour or bigger increases in hospitals.
High turnover can help keep a nursing home's costs down because workers who stay so briefly never move much above the minimum wage. But it also undermines one of the homes' selling points -- continuous warm relations between residents and aides.
Mr. Willging said turnover would probably rise because of a widening gap between nursing home wages, an average of $5.18 an hour nationwide last year and held down by Medicaid reimbursements, and hospital aides' wages of $7.20, which are less subject to Medicaid influence. To keep their employees from fleeing to hospitals, the nursing homes will need to pay more, he said.
The gap could widen even more because of new union pressure on hospital wages. In April, organized labor won an important battle with the hospitals in the United States Supreme Court. Having trouble organizing hospital workers, unions argued that hospitals stacked the deck against them by permitting bargaining units of only large groups of employees who perform very different jobs and have divergent interests.
Supporting a National Labor Relations Board ruling, the Court agreed that unions could split the employees into as many as eight units, each with common interests, like nurses, technical workers and maintenance personnel. Unions believe the decision will make it easier to enroll workers.
A 10 percent increase in the nursing home aides' wages, now ranging from $8,500 to $12,000 a year, would add about $1.5 billion to the nation's annual nursing home bill, or $1,000 per patient, unless the homes found ways to cut other costs or to train each aide to take care of more patients.
The effect on the nation's total health-care spending, currently about $700 billion, would be small. But in health care, as in all industries, higher wages for the lowest-paid workers tend to affect the wages of workers above them. So the effect could be much greater.
The kind of worker the nursing homes covet is one like Deborah Phifer, 19, a single mother of two young children. She transferred two months ago from a job in the kitchen to one caring for patients.
"I take their vital signs," Ms. Phifer said. "I get them up for breakfast, help them dress, feed some, make sure they're O.K. and dry and looking good." She earns $4.30 an hour, or $8,385 for her 37 1/2-hour week, which puts her $2,034 below the Census Bureau's 1990 poverty line for a family of three.
Ms. Phifer could train to be a registered nurse and earn $30,000 a year. But she said she wanted a career as an aide. "I don't want to be a registered nurse," she said. "They have so much paperwork. I want to work with the people,." she said.
Along with the wages, a drawback of the aides' job for many workers is having to face the deaths of their patients, four in July at College Park.
"You just do all you can when they're living," said Erma Tezeno, 59, an aide at the home for 17 years. "All you can do is make them as comfortable as you can."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I love what I do," said Darlene Jefferson, a nursing home aide, who helped Glenora Keeling at the College Park home in Texas City, Tex. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Factory Fire Leaves Pall Over 'All-American City'

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMLET, N.C., Sept. 4

 BODY:
Red, white and blue banners proclaiming Hamlet as an "All-American City" fly from poles all over town. But today the boast of those proud banners was eclipsed by American flags flying at half-staff and by a steady stream of funeral wreaths being hauled out of the local floral shop.
This town, which sprang up 94 years ago in the piney flats of southeastern North Carolina, is in a palpable state of shock over the fire at the Imperial Food Products plant that left 25 workers dead and 55 others injured. 
 Late this afternoon, almost 36 hours after the fire broke out at the poultry processing plant, small clusters of people were still gathered on street corners and in front of stores, talking about the fire, their voices often hushed.
 
Sorrow and Bitterness
 Many people who lost loved ones or friends in the fire expressed bitterness about the deaths and injuries. They acknowledged that the plant provided significant employment for residents in the area, but they were deeply concerned by reports that many of the victims of the blaze were trapped in the building by locked exits.
"This was unnecessarily caused," said Doris Fairley, who lost her sister-in-law, Peggy Anderson, and her son-in-law, Jeffrey Webb, in the fire. "Peggy cried every day about how much she hated working there. Jeffrey got killed by going back and helping others."
Whatever investigators ultimately blame as the cause of the fire and the resulting deaths and injuries, complaints about poultry plants and working conditions in them are commonplace throughout the South.
 
'We'll Be Together Again'
 In many ways poultry plants have replaced textile mills as the main target of workers' complaints in the South. And as with textile workers, poultry workers evince a bittersweet ambivalence about their employers and place of employment, mixing grousing about $5-an-hour pay and repetitive, mind-numbing work assignments with acknowledgments that, without the plant on the edge of town, there might be no bread on the table at home.
"When they told me about this I just felt like somebody just took me and flipped me over," said Flora Banks, who lost her 24-year-old daughter, Margaret Teresa, in the blaze.
"The first feeling was being bitter toward the plant," Mrs. Banks added as she left the police station here after seeking information about Miss Banks's death. "But God works together for the good of all. We all know that one day we'll be together again."
The Mayor of Hamlet, Abbie Covington, and the Richmond County Sheriff, R. W. Goodman, called the Imperial plant fire "the worst thing that ever happened" to this community of 6,100 railroad workers, poultry processers, textile mill hands, storekeepers and homemakers.
"The economy here had slowed like everywhere else, but we were doing all right until this hit," said Betsy McNair, the manager of the Hamlet branch of the Southern National Bank.
Hamlet and Richmond County seemed to be weathering the recession reasonably well because the local economy is more diversified than that of many other rural areas of the South.
 
Something Out of a Movie
 Over the years, poultry and plastics plants have moved in to pick up the slack left by the decline in the railroad industry and cyclical bounces in textiles. In fact, Hamlet was faring so well that it had managed to put up a new city hall and a new library and had succeeded in getting its hospital back on a sound financial footing. It had even persuaded a Hollywood studio to film a movie, "Billy Bathgate," on lower Main Street, where the century-old stores and shops look like something out of, well, a movie.
But that said, some people were having a hard time making it. Out on the edge of town, near the charred Imperial plant, the paved, leafy streets that run past prosperous-looking homes with rambling porches in the center of town give way to rutted clay, litter and battered public housing.
Still, Hamlet felt reasonably blessed until the first fire alarm sounded Tuesday morning.
"The people who run the 'All-American City' contest were impressed enough to name Hamlet as one of those cities last year," said Don McLain, the executive director of the Richmond County Chamber of Commerce.
 
Toll on Mind and Body
 But here in Hamlet, as in many towns where there are poultry plants, a few people have found that however badly they need the work, they cannot tolerate poultry processing.
For some there is too much gore, too many noxious odors. For others the unrelenting pace of the processing line wear the mind and body to the breaking point.
"I worked in there for eight days once," said Theresa White as she stood looking at the remains of the Imperial plant. "Then I quit. Slavery time's been over. I just couldn't do it anymore."
But for more than 10 years, some 200 residents of Hamlet and surrounding towns have showed up at the Imperial plant daily for their work shift. Elsewhere in Richmond County 950 other workers show up daily at a poultry plant run by Perdue Farms, one of the largest poultry processors in the United States.
 
A $1.5 Billion Industry
 Poultry is now the biggest farm enterprise in North Carolina, eclipsing even tobacco, and North Carolina is now the fourth-largest poultry-producing state in the country. In all, 24,000 North Carolinians are involved in growing, slaughtering and processing chickens, sending more than half a billion to market every year with an estimated value of more than $1.5 billion.
The state's agriculture experts like to brag that if all the drumsticks processed in the state each year were laid end to end the line would encircle the globe four times.
"Chickens are a very important industry to us," said Tom Smart, a former Mayor of Hamlet who runs Mabry Drug on Main Street, just down from the Prepare Your Hearts Church and across from the old movie house, where the last picture show played so long ago that no one can remember how long it's been.
"Chickens have helped keep us going here in Hamlet," Mr. Smart added. "The railroad is still important here, especially since it pays good salaries and good retirement. But you always want to keep a good economic mix to stay healthy. After all, when the movie people came here they didn't have to do a whole lot of fixing up to the buildings to make the place look antique."
What of Hamlet's future?
There was no word today from the Imperial plant about when, or whether, it would open again. But, despite the tragedy here, the chicken business in North Carolina, and for that matter much of the South, seems headed generally for still more expansion.
Agriculture specialists note that the consumption of chicken in the United States is steadily growing, standing now at more than 70 pounds a person annually, compared with less than 10 pounds in the early 1950's.
That growth has been propelled in large part by consumer concern over the fat content of many other types of meat and, more recently, by the increasingly availability of chicken in fast-food stores.
The Imperial plant here specialized in supplying the fast-food market.

HEADLINE: Texas Mother Gets 15 Years In Murder Plot

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Wanda Webb Holloway pleaded for mercy today, but a jury sentenced her to 15 years in prison for trying to arrange a killing to further her daughter's ambitions as a junior high school cheerleader.
At a sentencing hearing this morning, the 37-year-old Mrs. Holloway tearfully apologized for her mistakes and asked for probation so she could make amends to her intended victim, the mother of her daughter's chief rival in cheerleading competitions. 
 "I'm totally humiliated," she said.
Mrs. Holloway was convicted Tuesday night by the same jury on a charge of solicitation of murder. In addition to the 15-year prison term, the jury fined her $10,000 for plotting a murder that was never carried out.
 
Call for Life Sentence
 The prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Michael Anderson, had asked the jury to sentence her to life in prison, the maximum punishment possible. "Give Wanda Holloway what she paid for," he said at the hearing. "Wanda Holloway paid good money for a life."
The jury also heard from Verna Heath, the woman Mrs. Holloway was willing to pay $2,500 to have killed. "I've had nightmares at night and when I get in my car, I'm afraid to start the engine because I've often felt like my car was going to blow up," Mrs. Heath said today.
The chief evidence presented by prosecutors was tape recordings of six conversations between Mrs. Holloway and her former brother-in-law, Terry Harper. Although Mrs. Holloway never explicitly discussed a killing, the prosecutors contended that she had asked Mr. Harper to a hire a professional hitman to do away with Mrs. Heath and possibly also her daughter, Amber.
Mr. Harper, an unemployed pipefitter with a long criminal record, testified that he went to the police after Mrs. Holloway first told him of her desire to do away with the Heaths and that he was then equipped by detectives with a hidden microphone.
According to the prosecution, Mrs. Holloway ordered the killing on Jan. 28 when she gave Mr. Harper a pair of diamond earrings as a deposit on the fee to be charged by a professional hitman. In a conversation recorded that day, Mr. Harper asked her, "You want her dead?" She replied: "I don't care what you do with her. You can keep her in Cuba for 15 years. I want her gone."
While Mrs. Holloway never explained her reference to Cuba that day, her bizarre comment evidently made an impression on the jury.
After the sentence was announced this afternoon after two-and-a-half hours of deliberations, one juror, Tim Evans, was asked by reporters to explain how the jury arrived at the length of the sentence.
 
Sentence as 'Poetic Justice'
 "For one reason," he said, "she mentioned something about wanting her to go away for 15 years and it seemed to be poetic justice in a way."
Mrs. Holloway showed no emotion when the sentence was announced. Immediately afterward, she leaned over and hugged her 13-year-old daughter, Shanna, goodbye. Mrs. Holloway was then taken to the Harris County Jail.
In her trial testimony, Mrs. Holloway admitted that Shanna's failures to win a spot on the cheerleading squad had driven her to an irrational jealousy of Mrs. Heath and her daughter, who proved to be a star cheerleader. But Mrs. Holloway insisted that she was joking in the tape-recorded conversations and never seriously wanted to harm Mrs. Heath.
Mr. Evans and other jurors told reporters that the tape recordings convinced them of Mrs. Holloway's guilt. He said: "The tapes, you could not get away from the tapes. It's damning evidence." He dismissed her defense, saying: "She laughed a lot, but she wasn't joking. It was not a joke."
Mrs. Holloway's lawyer, Troy McKinney, said tonight that he planned to appeal the verdict.
Mr. McKinney cited as probable grounds for an appeal a decision by a state district judge, George Godwin, to exclude two defense witnesses. He said the two would have told the jury that Mr. Harper and his brother, Terry, Mrs. Holloway's former husband, had previously offered to help arrange killings. The defense contended that Mrs. Holloway had been entrapped into the murder-for-hire scheme by the Harper brothers.
Mrs. Holloway was also charged with solicitation of kidnapping, but the jurors entered no verdict on that count after the judge instructed them that she could only be found guilty of trying to arrange either a murder or a kidnapping, but not both.

HEADLINE: A Combustible Contest In a Smoldering Brooklyn

SERIES: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council -- An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council.

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
The City Council race in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn would seem to have all the ingredients for a Bonfire of the Vanities: Susan D. Alter, an incumbent Council member, is a white, Jewish woman married to an Orthodox rabbi, who is running in the 45th District, which is more than 75 percent black. Among her seven black rivals in the primary, she counts Colin A. Moore, the fiery lawyer and community advocate who is currently at the center of the racial conflict of neighboring Crown Heights, where he represents a family whose child was killed by a car driven by a Hasid.
But while the oratory between those two candidates occasionally resounds at a pitch worthy of Tom Wolfe, to residents of this working-class, mostly Caribbean immigrant community in the 45th District, Mr. Moore and Ms. Alter have much in common. Both are well known, powerful Brooklyn personalities with shallow roots in the immediate East Flatbush neighborhood.
 
A Note of Skepticism
 "I don't think it's right for people to come into a community just to get elected," said Terri Duncan, a longtime resident of East Flatbush. She paused and added a note of skepticism that is widely shared in her neighborhood, "But then I don't like the ones who live here, either." 
 Ms. Alter is not exactly a new face in East Flatbush; she represented a part of it for more than a decade until last year, when her district lines were redrawn in an attempt to create a Caribbean-American district and increase the chances of a black representative being elected. Ms. Alter was drawn into the neighboring predominantly white district represented by a fellow incumbent and Orthodox Jew, Noach Dear.
Rather than run against him, Ms. Alter sued, charging racial discrimination. When a three-judge panel ruled that this year candidates could run in any district, regardless of their place of residence. Ms. Alter chose East Flatbush, where she retained part of her former base, and where the seven black candidates were likely to fragment the vote and allow her to slip into the lead.
Mr. Moore, a Guyana-born lawyer whose clients have included the woman who sparked the Korean grocery store boycott in Flatbush and a defendant in the Central Park jogger case, has received attention throughout the city, but had not been a particularly active member of the East Flatbush community. "Why did he come here, and how long will he stay?" Mrs. Duncan said. "That sets people's antennas off."
Mr. Moore, who says he lives at his father-in-law's house in the area -- a residency some opponents have questioned -- said he was aware of some residents' misgivings. "I see the necessity of being active in my little space," he said, "but I believe in serving people wherever they are."
Outside interest in the 45th District has been heightened by East Flatbush's proximity and similarity to Crown Heights: both formerly white, middle-class neighborhoods that over recent decades have been flooded with new immigrants from the West Indies. Problems are similar, too: high unemployment among black youths, crime, poverty and drugs.
But behind the shabby thoroughfares lined with storefront shops hawking driving lessons, tax preparation and cheap travel are quiet side streets of brick row houses and handsome brownstones. There are fewer public housing projects in East Flatbush than in Crown Heights, and many more privately owned single family homes.
 
A Diminishing Minority
 Whites, though a rapidly diminishing minority, still live in parts of the area, but there is no separate, insulated Jewish area like the Hasidic community in Crown Heights. Friction between ethnic groups exists but is far less pronounced than in Crown Heights. Reynold N. Mason, a local lawyer who is acting as Mr. Moore's campaign manager, conceded, "I don't see much tension here."
Since the Crown Heights incident, Mr. Moore has only made a few campaign appearances in East Flatbush. He has repeatedly said the passions that flared up in Crown Heights would surely spill over into his district and galvanize voters. Mr. Moore explained in an interview last week that it was to his advantage that "Crown Heights happened just before the election, accentuating what I have been doing." The media attention, he said cheerfully, spared him from having to spend money on advertising.
"I have tremendous name recognition," he said. The disadvantage, he said, was that "it prevents me from doing a lot of campaigning."
Those candidates who have been knocking on doors, holding kaffeeklatsches and handing out leaflets to rushing, largely indifferent passers-by spoke indignantly of Mr. Moore as a political carpetbagger. "Colin Moore is making a lot of noise," said Ed Roberts, a lawyer, originally from Trinidad, who is one of the field of eight. "I'm not running for president of the A.N.C.," he said sardonically, referring to the African National Congress, "I'm running to represent this district."
 
A Widespread Refrain
 Skepticism about Mr. Moore's commitment to East Flatbush was a widespread refrain. "I don't see how representing paying clients in court over there can be taken as community service here," said N. Nick Perry, chairman of Community Board 17, who is also running. Mr. Perry, an affable, precise man who long toiled at the more prosaic community issues of garbage removal and neighborhood watch committees, said he viewed the race as between himself and Ms. Alter.
So did James T. Conolly, a Democratic district leader who describes himself in his campaign literature as the first black man elected to any position in the 42d Assembly District. Ms. Alter, who supported David N. Dinkins in the 1989 mayoral primary, has considerable black support in the area. Mr. Conolly, in contrast, was the only black elected official to endorse Edward I. Koch in the last mayoral primary and had garnered significant support from white voters in previous elections.
C-PAC, the political action committee established by Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone to support incumbents, is throwing its weight behind Ms. Alter, while the Majority Coalition, a political action committee established by progressive union leaders, endorsed Mr. Moore. Ms. Alter, calling in a political i.o.u., has sought an endorsement from Mayor Dinkins, but so far the Mayor has been reluctant to support the only white candidate in a district that was deliberately carved out to favor a black candidate.
 
Not Eligible to Vote
 The crowded area south of Church Avenue has the largest concentration of Caribbean-Americans in New York City. As candidates who have paced outside subway exits for hours trying to shake the hand of even just one registered voter can attest, many in the area are not American citizens and therefore not eligible to vote. There are fewer than 41,000 registered voters in a population of about 140,000 residents -- one of the lowest percentages in Brooklyn. The largest groups of registered voters are blacks, with 76.7 percent; whites, 16.8 percent, even though they make up 13.6 percent of the population; Hispanic, 5.6 percent, and Asian-Americans, 1 percent.
Ms. Alter, who because of her belated entry into the 45th District race got a late start in the campaign -- last week she was still struggling to fit an air-conditioner in her unfinished campaign office on Flatbush Avenue -- had by Aug. 8 raised almost twice as much as any of her rivals -- $37,301. She described Mr. Moore as her most pernicious rival. Of their contest, she added flatly, "Race is the name of the game." She accused Mr. Moore of attacking her for being white.
Mr. Moore responded that he has attacked Ms. Alter's performance, not her race. But then he quickly criticized the fact that her Council office was closed on Saturdays because of the Jewish Sabbath, citing it as an example that Ms. Alter "cannot identify with the community."
Janice L. Robertson, a novice who is running her election campaign out of her living room, is mainly known for having started a neighborhood block association to combat racism she encountered when she was the first black to move into an all-white neighborhood on East 49th Street. In debates, Mrs. Robertson, seeking to keep the peace, received generally good reviews from spectators. "I mean they attack each other," Mrs. Robertson said indignantly of the other candidates. "I'm acting like these grown men's mother."
While candidates try to measure the impact of race on the primary, voters seemed more interested in talking about the problems in their neighborhood. Adequate police protection -- and the lack of it -- was what preoccupied Daphne Hoppie, a seamstress and mother of three, originally from Guyana. "We'd just like to see it safe after school for our kids," Mrs. Hoppie said. "This is a really nice neighborhood; we just need more protection."
She, like others, angrily spoke of her perception that the Hasidic community in nearby Crown Heights received far more police protection than her neighborhood. Yet she also criticized Mr. Moore as exploiting the tension between blacks and Jews. "Guyanese people don't like it when you are too loud," she said. "We feel good that he has come this far, but why is he allying himself with someone like Al Sharpton?"
"I don't care," she added, "if a politician is black or white; we just want the person who can get the job done."
