HEADLINE: James H. Fogelson, 48, Lawyer And Supporter of Jewish Causes

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
James H. Fogelson, a corporate lawyer based in Manhattan who was active in Jewish affairs, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.
One of his partners, Martin Lipton, said he died of lung cancer. 
 Mr. Fogelson was a senior partner in the firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. His practice involved mergers and acquisitions, securities law and corporate counseling. His clients included investment banks as well as corporations.
Mr. Lipton, the senior partner in the Wachtell firm, said yesterday that Mr. Fogelson had been skilled at drafting legal documents "and very creative in the structuring of transactions."
For years Mr. Fogelson had been active in fund raising within the legal community and in other ways on behalf of the American Jewish Committee and the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. He won the Learned Hand Award of the American Jewish Committee in 1989 and is to be the posthumous recipient, in December, of the Proskauer Award of U.J.A.-Federation.
Mr. Fogelson was born in Manhattan, graduated from the Horace Mann School and received a bachelor's degree in economics from the University of Pennsylvania in 1964. He graduated in 1967 from the New York University School of Law, where he was an editor of the law review and a Pomeroy Scholar.
 
An Adjunct Professor
 He then went to work at the Wachtell firm and was promoted to partner there after three and a half years.
He was also an adjunct professor at the New York University law school.
Mr. Fogelson's numerous philanthropic activities included past service as chairman of the lawyers division of U.J.A.-Federation. Its communications manager, Jeff Prince, said yesterday that it is the largest local philanthropic organization in the world and provides financing for social services in New York, Israel and the Jewish communities in more than 30 countries.
Mr. Fogelson is survived by his parents, David and Gertrude Fogelson of Manhattan. The elder Mr. Fogelson was a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Schwartz & Frohlich, which no longer exists.
He is also survived by his wife of 24 years, the former Phylis Polakoff; a sister, Ellen Liman of Manhattan; and two sons, Robert and Matthew, both of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: BAKER ASKS DELAY ON ISRAEL AID BID;
Israel Plans Big Deficit

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 4

 BODY:
With Israel poised to ask the United States for $10 billion in loan guarantees to help absorb new Soviet immigrants, the Government approved a budget proposal today that some political commentators here warned could undercut Israel's case in Washington.
The proposed budget for 1992 includes a projected deficit that is higher than the Finance Ministry had wanted and that critics say may fuel American concerns about Israel's economy. 
In addition, the Government suddenly reduced, from 250,000 to 200,000, the figure it is using for the number of Soviet Jews that it expects to arrive here next year.
The shift appeared to be largely a budgetary maneuver. With events moving as rapidly as they are in the Soviet Union, Israeli officials acknowledge that they have no way of predicting precisely how many immigrants to expect in coming months.
Nevertheless, some commentators asserted that the lower forecast could leave Israel vulnerable to arguments that it needs less American aid.
The newspaper Haaretz said today that the proposed budget "will cast doubts over Israel's ability to pay back its debts, and raise fears that the repayment will fall upon the American taxpayer."
The loan guarantees have been developing into a contentious issue. A report on the Israeli state television Tuesday said President Bush had promised unidentified Arab leaders that there would be no loan guarantees unless Israeli halted its settlement activity in the occupied territories. But some Israeli officials challenged the report's reliability, saying that they knew of no such linkage and that if it were made they would reject it.
Israel calls the requested guarantees a form of humanitarian aid, to be spread over five years and intended to help provide housing, schools, roads, hospitals and jobs for up to a million Soviet Jews expected to come here by 1994. More than 300,000 have arrived in the last two years.
The aid does not involve actual American loans of $10 billion. Rather, it means that the United States would serve as ultimate guarantor should the Israelis fail to pay back money they expect to borrow from commercial banks. With Washington's backing, Israel would be able to get more favorable interest rates and terms than it could on its own credit rating.
But under American law, the Administration must set aside a reserve in case of possible default. This would involve an outlay of cash -- possibly hundreds of millions of dollars in addition to the $3 billion in yearly economic and military aid that Israel now gets -- and it could become a political issue in the United States.
Washington has sought to connect the guarantees to Israeli commitments to reshape an economy considered overly dependent on centralized planning, stumbling along with 20 percent inflation and high unemployment that some forecasters say could climb to 14 percent in two or three years.

HEADLINE: Toward a Soviet Re-Union

 BODY:
The collapse of the centrally controlled Soviet Union leaves a frightening void. It's no wonder that Soviet leaders are struggling to create a new confederation that decentralizes power but retains elements of unified control. Americans who welcome the impulse to escape the stifling grip of centralized power can also welcome these aspects of a limited re-union.
One compelling reason for cooperation is the short-term need to forestall economic collapse. Two other problems are just as worrisome. The world will not breathe easily until there is firm control of the 27,000 Soviet nuclear weapons. And without a compact among the republics, it will be harder to prevent or contain explosive ethnic clashes between and within republics. 
 All the 15 republics except Russia have declared some form of independence, most in the two weeks since the failed coup. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia fervently intend to secede. Others, like Kazakhstan, want to distance themselves from the old centralized structure while strengthening themselves for bargaining over new rules to govern relationships with the center. Still others, like the Ukraine, are desperately trying to ride, and contain, nationalism.
The nationalist fervor loosed by the collapse of Communism could inflame problems that some central structure might ease. Republics understandably want to insulate themselves from inflation and depression. But a burst of economic nationalism could be self-defeating, especially if it further impedes a free flow of goods and investment between republics.
The republics can do without union, but if they mean to reverse the nation's present economic plunge, they will need common internal markets, tight controls on money and firm protection for private contracts.
The arms control question begins to look more manageable given Russia's willingness to become the repository for the Soviet nuclear arsenal and the apparent desire of other republics like the Ukraine and Kazakhstan to divest themselves of their nuclear weapons. In any case, central authority is needed to avoid any relaxation of tight controls over weapons that could devastate the world.
The dangers posed by explosive nationalism are already evident in violent ethnic clashes like those between Azerbaijan and Armenia. A new structure at the center could facilitate negotiations among republics, help protect minorities and keep the peace. That's why Armenia, which previously asserted its independence, is now prepared to join nine other republics and President Gorbachev in proposing articles of confederation.
The new institutional arrangements to cope with disunion would bring the republics together as sovereign equals. A state council, consisting of Mr. Gorbachev and republic leaders, would coordinate all foreign and domestic issues. An interim inter-republican economic committee to "coordinate management of the economy" would have equal representation from each of the republics. And an upper house of parliament would have delegates representing the republics.
Economic cooperation . . . firm nuclear control . . . rational nationalism: the soundest way to achieve all three is for the republics to construct a new commonwealth. Communist misrule has sown popular distrust of all central authority. But chastened Soviet leaders are right to fight for some limited re-union.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Thinking '92: Voters Have Got to Care Again;
The Roosevelt Upset

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Allow this lifelong Republican and firm Bushophile to cite a bit of history for Democrats who believe their party's 1992 Presidential nomination isn't worth striving for. It is to be found in "The Brains Trust," an account of how Franklin D. Roosevelt came to be elected President in 1932, written by Rexford G. Tugwell, a leading figure in that effort. 
 After winning election as Governor of New York in 1928 in the face of Herbert Hoover's landslide Presidential victory, Roosevelt found himself bitten by the White House bug. His first move was to persuade the State Legislature to change the governor's term from two years to four.
Thus when he was re-elected in 1930, he was able to plan a 1932 Presidential run without having to risk his position in Albany.
From the beginning, Roosevelt and his inner circle -- the Brains Trust of Raymond Moley, Basil O'Connor, Samuel I. Rosenman and Tugwell -- concentrated on winning the Democratic nomination and gave much less thought to the election, which they expected Roosevelt to lose.
President Hoover, who had headed relief efforts to a starving Europe in the aftermath of World War I, still commanded enormous public respect. He would be an incumbent running for re-election.
And although the country fell into an economic depression in 1930-31, the steps taken by the Government -- less Federal spending, higher tariffs to protect domestic industry, increased taxes for the well-off -- were widely applauded. When President Hoover declared that "prosperity is just around the corner," people believed him.
The expectation of the Brains Trust was that Roosevelt, if nominated, would lose respectably to Hoover -- by less than a landslide. Meanwhile, he would have become known to the entire country and established an identity for himself separate from that of his cousin Theodore Roosevelt and the former President's son, with whom he was often confused. Finally, after being returned to Albany in 1934, he could run for President in 1936 as a twice re-elected Governor of the country's most populous state against a Republican who, because of the no-third-term tradition, would be a nonincumbent. All this plus the argument that after 16 years of Republican Presidents the time for a change had come.
The Roosevelt group held to this view through the convention and the summer of 1932. Only in September -- as the Depression worsened and Hoover holed up in the White House, apparently not knowing what to do next -- did it dawn on them that Roosevelt could actually be elected. Roosevelt stepped up his campaigning, the bandwagon began to roll, and in November he won in a landslide.
 
D. M. MARSHMAN JR.
Darien, Conn., Aug. 13, 1991

HEADLINE: Nebraska Senator Comes to Brink Of Democratic Bid for Presidency

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska edged closer to a race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, saying he would formally announce his plans in late September but leaving little doubt among Democrats that he intended to plunge in.
Mr. Kerrey's statement, issued this afternoon, came after two weeks of rising speculation about the Nebraska Democrat, a first-term Senator, a former Governor and a Medal of Honor winner who lost part of his leg in Vietnam. 
 Mr. Kerrey's move reflected a sudden quickening in the race for the Democratic nomination, coming one day after former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California announced he was forming a Presidential exploratory committee..
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, for four months the only declared major candidate in the race, said he welcomed the entry of new candidates. "I've been debating myself," said Mr. Tsongas, who in a speech at George Washington University today called for "a new Marshall Plan" to aid the Soviet Union.
Mr. Kerrey's brief statement declared: "My interest in running for President is based upon the belief that the possibility of a better future 20 years from now will be determined by our actions today. I will make a formal announcement of my plans toward the end of September."
Mr. Kerrey, 48 years old, earlier said he would make his decision before returning to Washington next week when Congress ends its summer recess. Today's statement, while still giving Mr. Kerrey the option of backing out, was taken by some party professionals as a signal that he would, in fact, enter the race but wanted more time to organize a candidacy.
"What he's trying to do is set up a way to make sure people know that he's inclined to run, but wants to put the pieces in place so that he can run well when he begins running," said a Democrat close to Mr. Kerrey, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
The statement today allows Mr. Kerrey more time to orchestrate a formal announcement, when a candidate usually tries to make the most of his moment in the limelight -- particularly important in a campaign starting so late.
Paul Tully, the political director of the Democratic National Committee, said of Mr. Kerrey and his supporters: "Everything we see is that they're on recess, I think he got a much better sense of the void that was out there in the public debate, that the case wasn't being made very well against Bush," said the Democrat close to Mr. Kerrey.
Moreover, the withdrawal of several leading Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, and Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, has left the field wide open for a new generation of Democrats like Mr. Kerrey to step into the fray.
"I think he brings a real star quality to the race, maybe more so than anybody else who's a candidate or potential candidate save Mario Cuomo," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker.
Mr. Kerrey, widely seen as the kind of outsider candidate who might fare well in 1992, ran for office for the first time at the age of 39, waging, and winning, a dark-horse race for the governorship in 1982.
 
Tsongas Urges Aid to U.S.S.R.
 Mr. Tsongas came to Washington today with a foreign policy address in which he sought to outline policy responses to the developments in the Soviet Union.
"I propose that America take the lead today in promoting a new Marshall Plan," he said. "The issue is not whether we can provide aid. We must provide aid. If George Bush can find $2 billion to add to 'Star Wars,' he can take some of the NATO money and provide it to the Soviet Union."
Mr. Tsongas added, "This winter in the Soviet Union, America can buy more defense with food aid than with additional missiles."
He also took the opportunity to attack his own party, arguing that "the reason we don't win the White House is because the country doesn't trust us with the economy -- and they're right."
Mr. Tsongas said the party should foresake "corporate bashing, class warfare, protectionism" and adopt policies encouraging economic growth and job creation.

HEADLINE: Ford Tinkers With Design of Taurus

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 4

 BODY:
So few models introduced by the American automobile industry in the 1980's qualify as success stories that it is little wonder the Ford Motor Company has been slow and cautious in revamping its formidable Taurus family sedan.
Sure enough, the new 1992 Ford Taurus and the twin Mercury Sable shown to journalists here today have only a few cosmetic exterior changes, like narrower headlights and a more sloping hood. The cars carry engines and transmissions nearly identical to those in the models they replaced. The biggest changes are redesigned interiors that are sleeker and more modern-looking. 
 The freshened-up cars run little risk of alienating buyers who have liked the Taurus since the 1986 model first went on sale in the fall of 1985. But with sales and market share slumping, Ford executives found themselves pressed today to explain why even such seemingly small changes took so long.
 
'Not Apologizing'
 "The customers are satisfied," declared Alex J. Trotman, Ford's executive vice president for North America. "Quality is high. Value is high. We are not apologizing."
In defending Ford's strategy for midsize cars, Mr. Trotman and others speaking at a news conference at Ford's Taurus and Sable assembly plant here said the company could bring out new models just as quickly as its Japanese competitors if necessary. Ford executives said they were convinced that their conservative path was prudent.
The original Taurus was acclaimed for its rounded, almost futuristic look and thoughtful creature comforts, like ergonomical driver controls and switches. Fritz Mayhew, a top Ford designer, recalled that Ford executives were extremely nervous in 1985 about introducing the first American car that lacked a grille.
More important, the Taurus soon became the best-selling car in the United States, helping to lift Ford profits to record levels. Wordwide sales of the Taurus and Sable peaked at 541,806 in 1988. Last year, sales were 447,883. Meanwhile the Taurus has been passed by the Honda Motor Company's Accord, which has undergone a series of face lifts.
Also troublesome for Ford, the Toyota Motor Corporation's new 1992 Camry is bigger and has a more powerful engine than last year's model and may give Taurus a run for the No. 2 spot. And the new Oldsmobile 88, made by the General Motors Corporation, and the Chrysler Corporation's new midsize models are due next year.
Ford does not plan to thoroughly redesign Taurus and Sable until 1995, 10 years after the initial $3 billion introduction. That means Ford will be able to delay spending the $5 billion to $6 billion needed for the overhaul of the engine, chassis and body.
Mr. Trotman said Ford's 1992 lineup, which also includes a restyled pickup truck, redesigned Econoline van and redesigned full-size models, represents a hefty $5.6 billion investment.
 
'Ford's No. 1 Problem'
 Some auto industry analysts have criticized the long replacement cycle.
"Ford's product renewal cycle is 10 years or more, while the Japanese are doing it in 4," said James Harbour, a manufacturing consultant to the automotive industry. "The market won't stand this any more. It's Ford's No. 1 problem."
"We have a broad range of vehicle types at Ford, unlike the Japanese, and it's not feasible to change them that often," Mr. Trotman said. "The life cycle of certain products like sporty coupes is short, but in others it is longer and more stable."
Ford dealers, who have depended heavily on the Taurus's popularity for their financial well-being, applauded the changes at their convention last month in Las Vegas, Nev., and the redesigned Taurus and Sable seem to be getting a generally warm reception from the dealers. Some said the new designs had freshened the cars' looks without straying too far from the design that helped make them so successful.
"We've got a good product, and you don't change your winner," said Ralph Paul, general manager of Bob Townsend Ford in Cincinnati. Mr. Paul added that Ford's decision to closely follow its original design will help maintain values of the used cars, which drop when a complete redesign of a car is introduced. "They're fantastic merchandise on the used car lot," he said.
From a financial perspective, waiting 10 years to spend the big money on Taurus may allow Ford to reap strong profits now, money the auto maker will need to pull out of its current doldrums. With current demand for cars still weak, overcapacity rampant and the number of competitive models growing, Ford in any case might not have been able to increase sales or command higher prices no matter how advanced the Taurus.
The new Taurus will carry a preliminary base sticker price of $15,503, though models with popular options, like air-conditioners and power windows, will cost more than $17,000.

HEADLINE: The Bastille And the Kremlin

BYLINE: By Simon Schama; Simon Schama, professor of history at Harvard University, is author of "Dead Certainties (Unwarranted Speculations)."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
A reactionary military coup is thwarted in a capital city when soldiers defect to the representatives of the people. A ruler whose allegiances are suspect is returned to the city in a brief triumph that leaves him politically disabled.
Rejoicing crowds surge through the streets bearing the new colors (red, blue and white) that symbolize the birth of a free nation. Public opinion, unchecked by censorship, demands food and identifies plotters for retribution. Euphoria and fearfulness march together while the world looks on, its congratulations edged with anxiety. 
 Moscow in the summer of 1991? No, Paris in the summer of 1789.
Facile analogies are, no doubt, the historian's professional vice. We take pains to reprimand politicians who mutter "Munich" when any international crisis impends and to insist that differences are as instructive as similarities. But sometimes it becomes impossible to resist the feeling of ghostly recurrence.
During the last weeks, Russian and Soviet historians have been reminded of the March Revolution of 1917 or the subsequent botched putsch of Kornilov, the czarist general, in the summer of the same year. And on this page, Anthony Lewis has drawn attention to the American Constitutional Convention as a rehearsal for the problems of Federal state-making.
But any historian of the French Revolution is going to be struck even more forcibly by parallels between the events in Russia and those in 1789 and may be inclined, as a result, to see dark clouds overshadowing the silver lining.
Like the Soviet Union, the monarchy of Louis XVI was an overextended empire, trying to be a global power while failing the elementary test of legitimacy: feeding its people. In a desperate attempt to break with a centralized command economy, liberal governments experimented with deregulation that in the short term made things worse. The regime ultimately collapsed from its ruler's fatal inconsistency in the application of reform and his reluctance to embrace representative institutions that could give these changes a democratic sanction.
Will the elegant, plausible Mikhail Gorbachev ultimately suffer the fate of the portly, inarticulate Louis XVI? Let us hope not. But to follow the parallel further is not especially cheering.
In 1991, as in 1789, the explosion of freedom, the sense that reactionary coercion had been frustrated by the people's will and the ritual desecration of symbols of tyranny (the Bastille and Dzerzhinsky Square) have acted as brief distractions from insuring that food is distributed.
Two hundred and two years ago, though, a chill autumn followed a blazing summer. The harvest was known in advance to be poor, bread had failed to materialize except at high prices, riots erupted and politics turned ugly.
The great beneficiary and hero of the summer events, the Marquis de Lafayette (like Boris Yeltsin) eventually became the object of suspicion. Lafayette was able to hold power only by sanctioning public acts of retribution against those held criminally responsible for the people's plight. Whole classes of people along with the institutions that had dominated the old regime were now stigmatized as enemies of the Fatherland.
Here, too, the parallels are already extraordinary. The Communist Party of the Soviet Union has been a combined version of the French Catholic Church and the nobility: both tepid theology and grossly privileged elite. Like the party, the church saw its buildings turned to civic functions, its assets confiscated and sold off in an attempt to create a viable currency.
This is not to say that there are not important differences. War, after all, as much as economic disaster and political chaos, was the condition for the nightmare of the Jacobin Terror. Yet France in 1793, like the Soviet Union today, was riven by regional tensions. Bordeaux and Marseilles were as alienated from Paris as Yerevan and Tbilisi are from Moscow.
However loudly revolutions in great nations invoke principles of universal liberty and solidarity, the engines of their anger are invariably stoked by a sense of wounded patriotism that comes dangerously close to xenophobia.
In France, that sentiment fired a war with the monarchies of Europe that lasted more than 20 years and consumed millions of lives before its heat was spent. The calamity began when the beleaguered revolutionary nation began to read the defensive indifference of the great powers first as selfish gloating and then as outright hostility.
Of course, the Gorbachevs do not have relatives ruling the powers of Europe who would be tempted to intervene in their fate. Nor is there a Communist Pope (despite Fidel Castro's eminent qualifications for the office) who might excommunicate anyone associated with the revolution. Should the nomenklatura be dispatched to a richly merited political oblivion, its fate would be genuinely less tragic than the tens of thousands beheaded on the guillotine.
In the end, the differences may count for more than the similarities. And the new Russian Revolution may turn out to be closer to the American than the French experience.
But historically, America has been unique in its capacity to move from the fires of liberation to the cooler work of federal state-building. Up to our own day, a temperate revolution has been an oxymoron. Perhaps in our time it can become a reality.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Encouraging Clue Points to Recovery

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
CHANGES in the spread between short-term and long-term interest rates may be the best means of forecasting business-cycle turning points. When short rates are lower than long -- as they are now -- the economy tends to grow. But when long rates drop below short, recession looms.
Over the last 25 years, movements in te "term structure" of interest rates, or yield curve, have correctly predicted all the major peaks and troughs in the United States business cycle, according to Prof. Campbell R. Harvey of Duke University's Fuqua School of Business. 
 Unlike other indicators, the yield curve has put out no false signals. In the third quarter of 1968, the curve began an inversion, changing its slope from positive to negative, and correctly signaled the recession of 1969-70, which started five months after long rates dropped below short rates.
The yield curve inverted two months before the 1973-75 recession began. In the fourth quarter of 1978 and in the fourth quarter of 1980, the yield curve inverted, recovered and inverted again, correctly predicting the double-dip recessions of 1980 and 1981-82, which some economists see as one recession.
How about the latest recession, which may or may not be over? The Administration attributed the onset of the recession to the outbreak of the Persian Gulf crisis in August 1990. But the inversion of the yield curve in the second quarter of 1989 had predicted the downturn that began five months later -- the average lag between inversions and recessions.
But so slight was the inversion in the last three quarters of 1989 that it was unclear whether the economy was facing recession or just a spell of sluggish growth. The inversion in the third quarter of 1989 was only 30 basis points (with long-term rates just three-tenths of 1 percent below shortterm rates). By comparison, the inversion in the fourth quarter of 1980 was 340 basis points (3.4 percent), correctly predicting the deep recession of 1981-82.
In July 1990, with the yield curve positive again, Professor Harvey correctly predicted that the economy would begin its recovery about the middle of 1991. That forecast now appears to be on target. The index of leading indicators posted a sharp increase of 1.2 percent in July.
But the downward revision by the Commerce Department of the preliminary estimate of the growth of gross national product, corrected for inflation, in the second quarter to minus three-tenths of 1 percent from positive four-tenths of 1 percent has made some economists dubious about the end of the recession.
For his part, Mr. Harvey holds that the present upward sloping yield curve signals a robust recovery, not a weak or moderate one, as most economists are forecasting. Using a model based on the yield curve, he forecasts real growth of 3.5 percent from the second quarter of this year through the second quarter of 1992. But he concedes that his model is better at forecasting turning points than rates of growth. He underestimated the degree of the current recession. But it was still milder than earlier recessions. From the third quarter of 1990 to the second quarter of 1991, real G.N.P. declined 1.1 percent, compared with the 3.3 percent in the recession of 1981-82, 2.3 percent in 1980 and 4.4 percent in 1974-75.
Expectations of a stronger recovery can now be based on the steepening slope of the yield curve. Measured by the spread between three-month Treasury bills and 10-year Treasury notes, the yield curve has grown more positive in the last 12 months: Long-term rates were 80 basis points higher than short rates in the third quarter of 1990, 90 in the fourth quarter of 1990, 160 in the first quarter of 1991 and 230 in the second quarter. This week the spread between three-month T-bills and 10-year notes was 244 basis points. This steepening curve gives no sign of a double-dip recession ahead, in contrast with the correct anticipation of the double-dip recessions of 1980 and 1981-82.
What explains the ability of the yield curve to call business cycle turning points? Most people are risk averse: if they expect hard times, they will try to even out their future income flows by shifting money into secure, longer-term assets, thereby bidding up their prices and reducing their yields. To finance such purchases, they will sell short-term assets, reducing their prices and raising their yields. Thus, the normally positive yield curve goes negative in advance of recessions.
But the typical yield curve was not always positive. The new addition of Sidney Homer's classic "History of Interest Rates," revised and updated by Richard Sylla, reveals that during the 19th century and the first three decades of the 20th century, short-term paper rates averaged far higher than did prime long-term bond yields. The yield curve went positive during the Depression of the 1930's, when short-term yields plunged, and has stayed positive most years since.
On the statistical record of the last quarter century, the yield curve has been a good forecaster of economic growth and recessions. But borrowers and lenders cannot really see the future or the shocks that will change it. So no economic forecasting model can be perfectly reliable, not even one based on interest rates.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drag; Dow Closes Unchanged

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The stock market ended the day exactly where it began -- at 3,008.50 points for the Dow Jones industrial average. The market traded in a narrow range and volume was about the same as the day before, reflecting an uncertainty that has kept many investors on the sidelines.
Much of the sluggishness shows a wait-and-see attitude by many investors in advance of August employment statistics due today from the Labor Department. The statistics could provide a clue as to the current state of the economy, which many analysts see as teetering between recovery and recession. 
 Volume of the New York Stock Exchange was 162.2 million shares, with declining stocks outnumbering advancing stocks by a 6-to-5 margin. The American Stock Exchange fell 0.63 point to close at 369.36 and the over-the-counter market fell by 0.99 to close at 516.93.
Market analysts said yesterday that investors were in search of some news to persuade them to buy or sell. In the absence of any such news, trading remained lackluster.
 
Little 'Selling Conviction'
 "The market lacked much selling conviction, but it doesn't yet have an injection of favorable news to push it sustainably into new high territory yet," said Eugene Peroni, director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia.
Still, Mr. Peroni felt the market displayed "good tenacity" in sustaining its current level in the face of few clear indicators. "The market has held up stubbornly in the face of what seems to be a lot of uncertaining about the economic and monetary outlook," he said.
Still, the much-awaited employment statistics may not provide as strong a clue as investors would like to give the market strong direction. Strong employment numbers are generally considered to be a bullish sign. At the same time, however, weakening numbers could also be interpreted as a good sign by investors since rising unemployment might force the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy with lower interest rates.
But some see the today's flat market as deceptive and say its underpinnings are far weaker than what the composite numbers might suggest. Robert Moseson, president of Performance Analytics in Chicago, said: "The Dow may indicate that the market is flat. But internals suggest anything but that."
 
Some Bearish Signs
 Mr. Moseson feels that the market is displaying bearish signs -- with more stocks falling than rising, volume remaining sluggish and a weakening appetite for over-the-counter stocks. "These are all symptoms that the bears are beginning to win," he said.
Among individual stocks, the most actively traded was Exxon, which rose 7/8 to close at 58 3/4. It was reported yesterday that an out-of-court settlement for damages from the 1989 Valdez oil spill appeared unlikely before Exxon's criminal trial begins on Oct. 7.
Shares of the Limited, a retailer, fell $2 to close at $25 3/8 after the company announced that it expected flat August sales. Wall Street had expected the retailer to report a slight sales gain.
Pepsico shares also fell by 1 1/4 to close at $29 7/8 because of an announcment a day earlier from Borden Inc. that expected lower profits because of a sluggish economy. The company's snack foods division was particularly affected, and Pepsico, which owns Frito-Lay, a snack food company, fell in sympathy.
IBP, a meat processing company, saw its shares fall $3 to close at $16. This is because Occidential Petroleum, which is putting its 51 percent share in IBP up for sale, has valued its holdings at $15 a share in a rights offering to Occidential shareholders. IBP shares had been trading at around $19.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trading Is Sluggish In Advance of Job Figures

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday in quiet foreign exchange dealings, as traders waited for the release of the United States employment data for August.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery was quoted at $347.00 an ounce, down $1.50. New York's Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $346.70, down $2.15. 
 Few currency traders were willing to take substantial speculative positions in advance of the employment report, which was scheduled for this morning.
 
Rise in Unemployment Expected
 "We have the whole market anticipating that Friday will be very, very active," said Bill Nevius, a trader for Chemical New York Capital Markets. Many analysts expected the unemployment rate to rise to 6.9 percent, from 6.8 percent in July.
Traders said a sudden rise in unemployment might force the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, a move that would make the dollar less valuable.
Dan Scherman, a currency trader for the Bank of Boston, said the market largely ignored a Labor Department report yesterday on weekly unemployment insurance claims, which held at 421,000 for the week ended Aug. 24.
Other analysts said the prospect of fall elections in Britain helped lower the pound against the dollar.
In London, a pound cost $1.6925, less than the $1.6940 late on Wednesday. In New York, sterling cost $1.6940, less than Wednesday's $1.6950.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar settled at 135.32 Japanese yen, less than Wednesday's close of 135.85. Later, in London, it rose to 135.85 yen. In New York, it closed at 135.70 yen, up from 135.50.
Other late New York dollar quotes, compared with Wednesday's prices, included: 1.7380 German marks, up from 1.7365; 1.52595 Swiss francs, up from 1.5240; 5.9030 French francs, up from 5.8995; 1,295.50 Italian lire, up from 1,295.00, and 1.14105 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1419.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $347.50 an ounce, down from $348.95 late on Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $347.25, from $348.70 late on Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.49, to $348.33.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
Soviet Resolutions: 'The Will of the Republics and the Interests of the Nation'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Following are the texts of two resolutions approved today by the Congress of People's Deputies, as translated by The Associated Press:
Resolution of the U.S.S.R. Congress of People's Deputies on measures resulting from the joint statement of the U.S.S.R. President and top officials of republics and the decisions of the extraordinary session of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet: 
 The coup d'etat committed on Aug. 19-21, 1991, endangered the process of the formation of new union relations between sovereign states. The resulting situation may lead to dire consequences inside the country and in relations with foreign states.
The elimination of the coup and the victory of democratic forces delivered a serious blow to reactionaries and all that held back the process of democratic transformations. Thus, a historic chance was created for the acceleration of radical transformations and the renewal of the country.
In order to prevent the further breakup of power structures, the U.S.S.R. Congress of People's Deputies proclaims a transition period for forming a new system of state relations based on the expression of the will of the republics and the interests of the nations.
 
UNION OF SOVEREIGN STATES

The Congress has resolved:
1. To approve in the main proposals resulting from the joint statement of the U.S.S.R. President and top officials of union republics and the resolution of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet on the situation created in the country in connection with the coup d'etat.
2. To accelerate the preparation and signing of the treaty on the Union of Sovereign States, in which each state shall able to define on its own its form of its participation in the union. The new union must be based on the principles of independence and territorial integrity of states, the observance of the rights of the nations and the individual and social justice and democracy.
3. To work out and conclude interrepublic agreements (treaties) on economic, monetary-financial, scientific and technological cooperation, ecological security and defense of the rights and freedoms of the citizens, on the principles of collective security and defense, while preserving a single armed forces and single control of nuclear and other arsenals of the means of mass destruction.
The Interrepublic Economic Committee shall begin immediately to work out and conclude a treaty on the economic union, which would have an open character: the participation in it would not be tied to the signing of the Union Treaty.
4. The U.S.S.R. President, the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and the State Council shall provide the legal succession of power and government and guarantee a peaceful and orderly transition to a democratic civil society.
5. During the transition period, all international agreements and obligations adopted by the U.S.S.R. shall be strictly observed, including those in the sphere of arms control and reduction, human rights and foreign economic relations.
To support the aspiration of republics for their recognition as subjects of international law and for consideration of the question of their membership in the United Nations.
6. All state organs, institutions, organizations and officials shall insure the observance of the rights and freedoms of the people which are proclaimed and guaranteed in the U.S.S.R. Constitution, the Declaration of Human Rights and Freedoms, the laws of the U.S.S.R. and republics, as well as freedom of the press, freedom of conscience and the right to establish political parties, trade unions and public unions.
7. While respecting the declarations of sovereignty and acts of independence adopted by republics, the congress stresses that the gaining of independence by republics which have chosen to refuse to join the new union necessitates negotiations with the U.S.S.R. to resolve the entire complex of problems relating to secession, as well as their immediate joining in the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and other important international treaties and agreements, including those which guarantee the rights and freedoms of the individual.
 
THE TRANSITION PERIOD

Law of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the organs of state power and government of the U.S.S.R. in the transition period:
Article 1. The supreme representative organ of power of the U.S.S.R. in the transition period is the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, which consists of two independent chambers: the Council of Republics and the Council of the Union.
The Council of Republics consists of 20 deputies from each union republic selected from the members of the U.S.S.R. Congress of People's Deputies and the deputies of the union republics, who are delegated by the supreme organs of state power of those republics.
To account for the federative structure of the R.S.F.S.R., it has 52 deputies in the Council of Republics. Other union republics that incorporate republics and autonomous formations will additionally delegate one deputy from each republic or autonomous formation into the Council of the Union. To insure the equality of republics during the voting in the Council of Republics, each republic shall have one vote.
The Council of the Union is formed by deputations of union republics out of the members of the U.S.S.R. Congress of People's Deputies in accordance with current quotas and with the agreement of the supreme organs of state power of union republics.
Article 2. The Council of Republics and the Council of the Union of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet jointly decide to introduce changes into the U.S.S.R. Constitution and to admit new states into the U.S.S.R., and hear reports of the U.S.S.R. president on the most important questions of domestic and foreign policies, approve the union budget and the report on its execution, announce war and conclude peace.
The Council of Republics adopts decisions on the organization and the order of work of union organs, ratifies and denounces international treaties of the U.S.S.R.
The Council of the Union considers the questions of insuring the rights and freedoms of citizens of the U.S.S.R. and adopts decisions on all issues in the jurisdiction of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet excluding those which are in the jurisdiction of republics. Laws adopted by the Council of the Union take effect after their approval by the Council of Republics.
The supreme organs of state power of the republics have the right to suspend on the territory of the republic the laws adopted by the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, only if they contradict the Constitution of the union republic.
Article 3. The U.S.S.R. State Council is established on an interrepublic basis for coordinated solution of the questions of domestic and foreign policies which affect the common interests of republics. The U.S.S.R. State Council consists of the U.S.S.R. President and the top officials of the union republics named in the U.S.S.R. Constitution. The U.S.S.R. President directs the work of the U.S.S.R. State Council. The U.S.S.R. State Council determines the order of its work. The decisions of the U.S.S.R. State Council have a mandatory character.
Article 4. The position of the U.S.S.R. Vice President is annulled.
If for any reason the U.S.S.R. President is unable to continue to carry out his duties (including reasons of health, confirmed by an opinion of a state medical commission formed by the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet), the U.S.S.R. State Council elects out of its members a chairman of the U.S.S.R. State Council who temporarily carries out the duties of the U.S.S.R. President. This decision must be confirmed by the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet within three days.
Article 5. Union republics form the Inter-Republic Economic Committee on the basis of parity to coordinate the government of the national economy and to coordinate the implementation of economic reforms and social policies. The Chairman of the Committee is appointed by the U.S.S.R. President with the agreement of the U.S.S.R. State Council. The U.S.S.R. President and the U.S.S.R. State Council direct the work of the union organs responsible for the questions of defense, security, law and order and international affairs.
The Interrepublic Economic Committee and the leaders of union organs are responsible for their activities to the U.S.S.R. President, the U.S.S.R. State Council and the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet.
Article 6. The status of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies is preserved for the duration of their term of authority, including the right to participate in the work of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and its organs.
Article 7. The first session of the new U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet with the new membership shall be called by the U.S.S.R. president not later than Oct. 2, 1991.
For the period before the beginning of the work of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet with new membership, the current U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet retains its powers and it may be called into session by the chairmen of the Chambers.
Article 8. The provisions of the U.S.S.R. Constitution are still valid inasmuch as they do not contradict this Law.
Alterations of the U.S.S.R. Constitution which are adopted by the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet take effect after their ratification by the supreme legislative organs of all union republics.
Article 9. This law takes effect from the moment of its publication, with the exception of Article 2, which takes effect from the moment of the opening of the first session of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet new membership.
 
M. GORBACHEV,
President, U.S.S.R.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Weaken

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Optimistic comments about the economy by two Federal Reserve officials outweighed actual data released yesterday showing that conditions remained weak in August, and credit market participants sold Treasury notes and bonds, pushing prices down and interest rates up.
As has been true all week, trading activity remained extremely light. Most dealers, and their retail accounts, were unwilling to establish new positions before August employment data are released this morning. 
 In separate comments, John P. LaWare, a Fed governor, and Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said essentially the same thing: The recession has ended and a recovery is under way.
Early in the day, Mr. LaWare had said that growth in the second half of the year should average between 3 and 4 percent. Later on, Mr. Parry said he expected 3 percent growth over the next 12 months.
 
Shift in Expectations
 On the eve of the employment report, the comments weakened somewhat the expectation among some market participants that the Fed would move fairly quickly to ease short-term interest rates.
"The consensus opinion is that the employment report will force the Fed to move," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "The question that remains is how quickly that will happen."
Dealers paid little notice to a series of reports that did little to buttress the views expressed by Mr. LaWare and Mr. Parry.
The Labor Department reported that initial unemployment claims totaled 421,000 in the week that ended on Aug. 24, unchanged from a week earlier. The figure left the latest four-week average of new jobless claims at 420,000, up from 406,000 a month earlier. Though a lagging indicator, initial claims tend to fall, not rise, during economic recoveries.
In addition to the claims numbers, auto makers reported that they continued to have trouble selling new vehicles during the last 10 days of August, as sales totaled a meager 6.1 million units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. Major retail chains also reported that sales were soft in August.
"It all boils down to the employment numbers," one government securities trader said.
In advance of the report, most analysts were projecting that non-farm payroll employment probably rose by between 20,000 and 40,000 jobs last month. An increase of that size might be sufficiently small to allow the Fed to ease policy, the analysts said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 11/32, down 14/32, to yield 8.09 percent, compared with 8.05 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, down 7/32, to yield 7.83 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/32, down 2/32, to yield 6.32 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.32 percent, up a basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a late offered rate of 5.36 percent.
 
Money Supply Up
 In addition to the comments by Mr. LaWare and Mr. Parry, prices of short-term securities softened a bit after the Fed reported late yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week that ended on Aug. 26.
The gains were larger than anticipated. The $6.4 billion increase in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, pushed its growth rate back above the 2.5 percent level that is the low end of the Fed's target range for M-2 growth this year.
Continued weakness in M-2 growth has been cited by analysts as another reason why the Fed might move to ease monetary policy.
Activity in other markets remained light yesterday, traders said.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues dipped by about one-eighth of a point, market participants said.
And municipal-bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt issues were unchanged to down one-eighth of a point.

HEADLINE: S.& L. Profits Down by 37% In Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Earnings at private savings institutions slipped in the April-June quarter despite the most favorable interest-rate conditions in four years, the Government said today.
T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, blamed commercial real estate losses at about 10 large institutions for the 37 percent decline. 
 Institutions earned $387 million in the second quarter, down from $610 million in the first three months of the year. The figures do not include savings institutions that had been seized by the Government by the end of June.
 
No Comfort for Congress
 The deterioration in earnings offers no comfort for members of Congress, who will be looking this fall at doubling the taxpayer appropriation for the bailout of savings-and-loan associations. Congressional hearings begin next week on the Administration's request for a second $80 billion appropriation.
"Clearly the grim reaper is going to be making the rounds again," said Paul Getman, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
Mr. Getman said that "literally hundreds more institutions" could be seized by the Government. "That means all of those estimates on the thrift bailout could be too low," he said.
Still, the most recent report was considerably better than the $302 million loss in the second quarter of last year and marked the first back-to-back quarterly profits since 1986.
"That is a significant and welcome sign of a rebounding industry," said Fred Webber, president of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions.
Mr. Ryan, however, noted that the slim profits were eked out at a time when the average interest that savings associations paid on deposits and other sources of funds was 6.94 percent, the lowest in nearly four years.
During the recession, rates on deposits have declined far more than rates on mortgages and other assets, widening the difference, or "spread," from which the savings institutions derive their earnings.
"Whether the interest-rate spread remains favorable is a question mark," Mr. Ryan said, refusing to predict the industry's performance in the second half of the year.
Mr. Ryan also attributed much of the industry's return to profitability to the Government's seizure of more than 600 failed savings institutions since passage of bailout legislation in 1989.
The figures reported today did not include 193 failed institutions under the control of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the bailout agency. Their losses will be reported separately later this month.
Also, industry earnings were bolstered by $462 million in continuing Government assistance paid to savings institutions under pre-1989 bailouts.
Mr. Ryan did not identify specific privately held institutions whose commercial real estate losses dragged down the industry average, but he said all were ones that had been audited during the quarter by agency examiners.
A number of publicly traded savings institutions have reported large second-quarter losses, including Glendale Federal Bank in Glendale, Calif.; California Federal Bank in Los Angeles; HomeFed Bank in San Diego; and Perpetual Savings Bank in Vienna, Va.

HEADLINE: Businesses Curtail Plans To Expand

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
American businesses, many with plants still idled by the recession, have cut back expansion plans to the slowest pace in five years, the Commerce Department said today.
Analysts said capital spending usually lagged behind an economic recovery, as businesses adopted a wait-and-see attitude before committing financial resources. 
 "Firms aren't anxious to put new equipment in place until their current capacity is used," said Joel Prakken, an economist with Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis economic forecasting company.
The Commerce Department said a survey conducted in July and August found businesses planning to spend $532.4 billion for expansion and modernization, 1.6 percent more than the record $523.8 billion spent in 1990.
But the increase would be a sharp cutback from the 3 percent advance projected in a Commerce Department survey last spring and the 3.2 percent increase that was forecast last winter. It would also be dramatically slower than the gains of 10.4 percent in 1989 and 9.5 percent in 1988.
Capital-spending growth slowed to 4.5 percent last year as the recession began.
 
'Pretty Good,' Considering
 Still, the 1.6 percent increase this year would be "pretty good when you consider the recessionary conditions since the fourth quarter of last year," said Thomas F. Carpenter, an economist with ASB Capital Management in Washington. "The fact that capital spending is up at all is significant," he said.
Both Mr. Carpenter and Mr. Prakken predicted capital spending would grow faster next year as business confidence rebounds and corporate coffers are refilled. Mr. Carpenter said he expected investment to expand by 8.5 percent in 1992.
Although capital spending inched up five-tenths of 1 percent during the first quarter of 1991, it sank 1.2 percent in the second. The Commerce Department survey projects that spending will increase 3.1 percent in the current quarter and five-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of the year.
In addition to stimulating economic growth, business investment is a key to increased productivity, considered vital to improving Americans' standard of living without increasing inflation. The Labor Department reported today that productivity grew at an annual rate of just five-tenths of 1 percent during the second quarter, compared with an average of 1.6 percent annually between 1982 and 1989.
The figures for equipment spending have been adjusted for inflation. Before adjustment for inflation, the survey projected a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in business investment, to $535.1 billion, after gains of 5 percent in 1990 and 11.4 percent a year earlier.
Spending plans include a 3.3 percent decline for manufacturing companies and a 2.6 percent increase for companies engaged in mining, transportation and other nonmanufacturing businesses.
Manufacturers are forecasting investment spending of $186.2 billion. That figure includes a 5.3 percent decrease in spending by companies producing durable goods -- big-ticket items, ranging from washers to warships, expected to last at least three years -- and a 1.9 percent decline by those producing nondurable goods such as food and fuel.

HEADLINE: Data on Jobless Claims Cast Doubt on Recovery

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims remained frozen at 421,000 in late August, the Government said today, in a sign that employers, skeptical about whether a recovery had taken hold, were still letting workers go.
In other weak economic news, the productivity of American workers rose at a mediocre five-tenths of 1 percent annual rate in the second quarter -- a much weaker performance than first believed -- while business investment plans were at a five-year low. 
 The numbers add up to an economy that has failed to make much headway toward recovering from the recession, analysts said.
 
'Crawling Out of a Hole'
 "In past recoveries, 'shot out of a cannon' is a typical phrase for describing the economy," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "What's happening here is crawling out of a hole."
The jobless claims report, which offered no encouraging news on the hiring front, may mean equally bleak numbers in Friday's unemployment report for August, analysts said.
In advance of the report, most analysts predicted that the jobless rate probably inched up to 6.9 percent from July's 6.8 percent. A separate survey of business establishments, analysts predicted, will probably show that the economy added relatively few jobs last month.
 
Jobless Claims Have Edged Up
 Today's jobless claims report from the Labor Department showed that for the week ending Aug. 24, the number of Americans filing new applications for unemployment benefits failed to improve, holding virtually level with the four-week average of 421,000 from the previous week.
Rather than falling, as would be consistent with a recovery, the jobless claims number has actually crept up, on average, over the last month, analysts noted.
The latest four-week average of new jobless claims is at 420,000; a month ago it was 406,000, according to analysts who calculate the four-week average from the Labor Department statistics.
"The recovery isn't strong enough, and convincing enough, to employers that they're willing to go out and add to their labor force," said Robert Dederick, an analyst at the Northern Trust Company. "What's more, they continue to lop off staff," he said.
Mr. Sinai added that businesses were "keeping costs down by keeping head count down."
"In a weak recovery," Mr. Sinai added, "business has no other choice if it wants profits to improve."
Companies' reluctance to hire, in turn, holds back the economic recovery by keeping huge numbers of Americans on the unemployment line, analysts said.
 
Fed May Be Forced to Ease
 If August's employment numbers are weak enough, the Federal Reserve may be prompted to provide a fresh round of interest-rate reductions in an effort to keep the economy from weakening, analysts said.
"I think the Federal Reserve stands poised to ease unless this report is going to be convincing evidence that the expansion is becoming embedded," Mr. Dederick said.
In a separate report, the Labor Department revised its earlier numbers on productivity -- defined as output per hour of work -- to say it grew at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent from April to June, rather than the 1.9 percent rebound first reported.
The poor second-quarter productivity growth followed dismal showings in the previous two quarters, when the nation's economy was mired in recession.
The downward productivity revision was not a big surprise, because the Government also recently revised calculations for April through June on overall economic growth. The gross national product, rather than increasing as first believed, actually fell slightly in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: 3 Latin Nations Agree to Ban Chemical Weapons

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 5

 BODY:
South America's three dominant military powers, Argentina, Brazil and Chile, signed a declaration today banning the development, manufacture and use of chemical weapons.
The signing by the Foreign Ministers of the three nations in the Argentine city of Mendoza was the latest in a series of steps taken in the region toward demilitarization and a scaling down of tensions that in the past have brought them to the brink of war. Another aim is to increase their international standing. 
 Military analysts here also noted that the agreement was a further step toward a broad integration of the economies in the region in an effort to become more competitive with Europe and the Far East.
"Fundamentally, this shows a change from a historical posture of conflict to one of neighborliness and cooperation," said Andres Fontana, a military specialist at the Center for the Study of State and Society here.
 
'A Good Sign,' U.S. Official Says
 Under the agreement, the three countries will also seek to control commerce in materials and technology that could be used to manufacture chemical and biological weapons.
"I think it's a good sign that Latin America is addressing the post-cold-war agenda," Bernard Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America, said in Washington in a telephone interview. "It shows that democratization yields important dividends in terms of security and peace and that these countries are not going to make the mistake of being trapped in a regional arms race and waste precious economic resources."
All three countries have said that they have no chemical or biological weapons programs and that no such programs existed even during the years of military rule. Western diplomats and analysts generally agree with those statements.
The only country over which there is any uncertainty is Chile, which was ruled by the military until March 1990. Last month, the Argentine President, Carlos Saul Menem, voiced concerns that Chile might have the ability to produce chemical weapons.
Rosendo Fraga, an Argentine military analyst, said that up to a year and a half ago the Chilean military manufactured some unspecificed components of the chemical weapons stockpile of Iraq. Western diplomats here said there was concern that large weapons manufacturers in Chile might also have such ability.
 
Militaries Are Curbed
 Over the last year, all three countries, which for long periods in the 1970's and 1980's were ruled by military governments, have sought to curb either the size or influence of the military, both to reduce the economic drag on their economies and to improve their standing in the world.
Last November, Argentina and Brazil signed an agreement that renounced the manufacture of nuclear weapons. Brazil uncovered a secret nuclear bomb project begun by its military and ordered its destruction. Argentina, at the insistence of the United States, agreed this year to end a secret air force project to build a medium-range ballistic missile.
Chile and Argentina last month signed a broad agreement that settled all but two points of dispute on its borders. And in Chile the 18-month-old civilian Government of President Patricio Aylwin has been trying to exert more civilian control over its military.
"In terms of foreign policy these countries are saying that they are going to act like good boys," said a Western diplomat who asked not to be identified.
 
Agreement Not Binding
 But some noted that the agreement signed today was not a treaty and did not bind the countries. Nor does it specify on-site inspections or export control procedures.
The declaration is perhaps most significant for Argentina, Though there has been a general reduction in tensions and a move on the part of all three countries toward demilitarization, Argentina's reduction of its military might has been by far the most radical.
This is primarily because the country's economic situation has been so bleak and the Menem Government has put a high priority on economic stability and a balanced budget.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Fell In August

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In a sign of continuing sluggishness, sales of American-made cars and trucks fell 11.6 percent in late August from a year earlier, auto makers reported today.
The degree of weakness was surprising, said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, but he said it was premature to say whether the market was in an overall down trend. "We may see some renewed pickup in September and October," he said. 
 But Tom Webb, the chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said: "These numbers make me skeptical that the overall economy can keep moving forward when the auto industry appears to be backing up."
In the 10-day period that on ended Aug. 31, cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.2 million units, compared with 7.2 million a year earlier.
 
Lower Annual Rate
 For the month, sales dropped 12.7 percent for domestic and imported cars, representing an annual selling rate of 6.1 million units. That figure compared with a rate of 6.8 million units in August 1990, and 6.8 million units in July.
The Big Three and the Japanese auto makers that operate factories in the United States sold 359,266 domestically built cars and trucks in late August, compared with 406,572 during the comparable period last year.
The number of domestically made vehicles sold by the Big Three was down 15.1 percent in late August, and the number sold by Japanese "transplants" was 1.2 percent higher. Thus, the Big Three's share of sales resulting from domestic production fell to 75.7 percent, from 78.8 percent in the 1990 period.
Sales of all American-built cars fell 15.4 percent in the late August period, to 217,569 units. The General Motors Corporation sold 87,589 American-built cars in the period, down 16.8 percent from a year earlier, and the Ford Motor Company sold 51,467 cars, down 18.1 percent. The Chrysler Corporation does not report 10-day sales, by it was estimated that the company sold 16,835 cars in the period, down 38.9 percent.
Of the transplant auto makers based in Japan, the Honda Motor Company sold 26,450 cars in late August, an increase of 4.9 percent; the Toyota Motor Company sold 22,483 cars, a drop of 1.3 percent, and the Nissan Motor Corporation sold 4,254 cars, a drop of 22.4 percent.
Sales of light trucks were off 5.1 percent, to 141,697 units, in the period. G.M. sold 48,849, a drop of 11 percent; Ford sold 44,301, a drop of 5.1 percent, and Chrysler sold 22,936, a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent.
For the entire month of August, sales of all cars and trucks, imported and domestic, fell 11.2 percent, to 1.03 million, from 1.16 million in August 1990. Car sales were off 12.7 percent, to 685,324, and truck sales declined 8.2 percent, to 350,042.
The Big Three's total vehicle sales in August, including imported models they sell, fell 13.7 percent; the Big Three captured 64.2 percent of the market, compared with 66.1 percent a year earlier.
 
Japanese Sales Off
 Sales by Japanese car makers, including vehicles built in the United States, fell 5.4 percent and captured 29 percent of the market in August, compared with 27.2 percent a year earlier. Vehicle sales by non-Japanese importers fell 10.5 percent, and their market share was steady at 6.8 percent.
G.M. sold 208,235 American-built cars in August, a drop of 13.6 percent from a year earlier; Ford sold 129,755, a drop of 15.5 percent, and Chrysler sold 44,135, a drop of 27.7 percent.
G.M.'s total market share for cars in August was 32.8 percent, compared with 33 percent in August 1990; Ford had 19.9 percent, compared with 20.7 percent a year earlier, and Chrysler's share was 7.5 percent, compared with 8.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Weak Sales for Last Month Are Reported by Retailers

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The nation's largest retailers yesterday reported weak August sales as consumers' confidence and spending failed to rebound.
The sluggishness was widespread. A Merrill Lynch index of the nation's 22 largest retailers showed a lackluster 1 percent increase in sales last month at stores open for at least a year, compared with their sales in August 1990. 
 "The August sales were quite disappointing and reflected the fact that consumers continued to be concerned about the direction of the economy," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retailing analyst with Merrill Lynch. Mr. Feiner said the August results reflected an economy operating in "slow motion."
 
Sears's Sales Off 2.7%
 Among the retailers reporting declines were the Sears Merchandise Group, where sales dropped 2.7 percent, to $2.56 billion from $2.63 billion, and J. C. Penney, whose sales dropped 3.4 percent, to $1.16 billion, compared with $1.2 billion a year earlier.
There were some notable exceptions to the weakness. In what is becoming a familiar refrain in retailing, the Gap Inc. and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. nimbly sidestepped the industry's malaise. Sales at the Gap were up 42 percent over all, compared with a year earlier, and up 21 percent at stores open for more than a year. Wal-Mart posted a 35 percent increase from August 1990, and a 10 percent gain at stores open for more than a year.
Aside from the economy, retailers said bad weather in some regions had hurt sales. Although the weather often serves as a catchall excuse for retailers, Hurricane Bob did cause a number of stores to close on the East Coast last month.
August retail sales, which include the back-to-school season, are considered an important indicator of the public's mood as the crucial Christmas shopping season approaches. There was little in the August numbers to give comfort to most merchandisers, many of whom had been forecasting improved sales in the fall.
"The bell for back-to-school rang, and the consumer didn't respond," Mr. Feiner of Merrill Lynch said.
Retail stocks have run up sharply since the beginning of the year, but based on the latest numbers some analysts said yesterday that the group would have a hard time maintaining its strong performance over the next few months. Nonetheless, Richard E. Pyle, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., in Minneapolis, said retail stocks were still likely to outperform the market for the year.
 
Retailers Expected to Be Cautious
 In reacting to the weak sales, retailers are likely to proceed as cautiously as consumers, keeping inventory levels low and a sharp eye on expenses, said Jeffrey Edelman, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence Inc.
Aside from the Gap, which specializes in stylish and affordable casual clothes, impressive gains were posted only by discount stores that offer a wide range of basic goods at bargain prices.
Wal-Mart, which uses the slogan "Always the low price on the brands you trust," sold $3.7 billion worth of goods in August, up 35 percent from the $2.74 billion a year earlier. Sales rose a healthy 10 percent at stores that had been open for more than a year. Changes in sales at stores open for more than a year is considered a good measure of a retailer's performance. Wal-Mart's share price rose 50 cents yesterday, to $50.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
K Mart's Sales Up 8%
 One of Wal-Mart's chief rivals, the K Mart Corporation, reported a sales increase of 8 percent for August. Same-store sales rose 2.9 percent. K Mart's share price tumbled $3 yesterday, to $43.50, after an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, David Poneman, downgraded his recommendation to "hold" from "buy."
The Target division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation posted a respectable gain, with overall sales up 13 percent and same-store sales up 6 percent. Target recently began to emphasize its lower-priced merchandise to increase sales.
"We are pleased with Target's resurgence," said Stephen E. Watson, president of Dayton Hudson. Sales were sluggish in the company's department-store and Mervyn's units. Over all, Dayton Hudson's August sales increased 8.4 percent, to $1.29 billion, compared with $1.19 billion a year ago. Sales at stores open at least a year were up 3.5 percent.
Dayton Hudson's share price was unchanged yesterday, at $76.125.
The May Department Stores Company reported an 8 percent sales gain for the month, to $820 million, from $759 million last year. Same-store sales were off slightly. May's share price fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $57.
 
Struggle for Mass Merchandisers
 Mass merchandisers continued to struggle. At Sears, same-store sales dropped 2.9 percent, even more than the 2.7 percent drop in overall sales. Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company, said the slow economic recovery had hampered sales but added that the company had double-digit increases in sales of women's sportswear, home computers and automotive accessories.
Sears's share price fell 75 cents yesterday, to $39.375.
At J. C. Penney, sales fell 5.3 percent in stores open more than a year. The company's chairman, William R. Howell, called the results disappointing, and thecompany's share price fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $49.25.
By contrast to the Gap's strong performance, the Limited Inc., another apparel retailer, continued to post weak results. While sales rose 12 percent for the month, sales for stores open for more than a year were flat.
The Limited's share price fell $2 yesterday, to $25.375, while the Gap's rose $1.50, to $43.50.
Following is a list of the sales reported by the other largest retailers:
 
Melville Corp.: Overall sales rose 15.7 percent for August and 20.2 percent for the year to date. Same-store sales fell five- tenths of 1 percent for August and rose four-tenths of 1 percent for the year to date.
 
Woolworth Corp.: Overall sales in the U.S. were up 1.4 percent for August and 2.8 percent for the year to date. Same-store domestic sales fell 3.3 percent for August and 1.9 percent for the year to date.
 
TJX Cos.: Overall sales rose 5.5 percent for August and 13.7 percent for the year to date. The company does not report same- store sales percentages.
 
United States Shoe Corp.: Overall sales rose 3.5 percent for August and 5.2 percent for the year to date. Same-store sales were unchanged for August and down four-tenths of 1 percent for the year to date.
 
Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc.: Overall sales rose 17 percent for August and 26 percent for the year to date. Same-store sales were unchanged for August and up 7 percent for the year to date.
