HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
More than two years ago, the Justice Department acquired tape recordings pouring out details of how the Bank of Credit and Commerce International used front men to acquire U.S. banks illegally. But the Justice officials kept the tapes secret and, as they now acknowledge, deceived bank examiners and other investigators about the tapes' existence. [Page A1.] The Justice Department unsealed the indictment of six officials of B.C.C.I. and a reputed leader of the Medellin drug cartel. [D1.]
 A British court indefinitely extended a freeze on assets granted to the Panama Government as part of its effort to recover $23 million reportedly stolen by Manuel Antonio Noriega. [D5.]
 Earnings of private savings institutions slipped in the April-June quarter despite favorable interest-rate conditions. [D1.]
 Sales of American-made cars and trucks fell 11.6 percent in late August from a year earlier. [D1.] The nation's largest retailers reported weak August sales. [D2.]
 The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims remained at 421,000 in late August. [D2.] American businesses have cut back expansion plans to the slowest pace in five years. [D2.]
 
Markets
 Salomon will pay no compensation, severance or future legal expenses stemming from the Treasury market scandal to executives who resigned, including John Gutfreund. [A1.] The Salomon scandal is putting a harsh spotlight on money managers and investment partnerships that control billions of dollars in capital. [D6.]
 Shearson said it had suspended two top executives in its equities trading group because of violations in connection with a Conagra stock offering. [D1.]
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day exactly where it began -- at 3,008.50 points. [D6.]
 Credit market participants sold Treasury notes and bonds, pushing prices down. [D13.]
 Corn and soybean prices moved lower, while cattle prices soared. [D14.] The dollar rose in quiet trading. [D14.]
 
Companies
Unisys has agreed to pay a record $190 million to settle charges stemming from an investigation into procurement fraud and bid-rigging, Government and industry officials said. [D1.]
 Procter & Gamble made an embarrassing error in judgment when it had police trace hundreds of thousands of telephone calls in an effort to identify a reporter's sources, its chairman said. [A18.]
 Lee A. Iacocca has agreed to retire from Chrysler at the end of 1992. The announcement halts for the moment the speculation over the company's executive succession that began when Mr. Iacocca decided to stay past the normal retirement age. [D1.]
 Disney will buy the operating assets of Discover, which ended publication when Family Media closed. [D15.] Warner Brothers said Mark Canton, an executive vice president, would leave the company by mutual agreement. [D15.]
 Bethlehem Steel said it intended to sell the coal operations of its Beth Energy Mines subsidiary. [D4.]
 
International
Japanese brokerages engaged in many more bogus transactions than previously acknowledged and also rigged trades involving U.S. Treasury bonds. [D5.]
 
Today's Columns
Changes in the spread between short-term and long-term interest rates may be the best means of forecasting business-cycle turning points. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 When Liz Claiborne said it expected slightly less growth in the second half of this year, investors took to the hills and have yet to come back, despite analysts' rosy projections. Market Place. [D6.]
 Domino's Pizza is celebrating the joys of pizza in its new ad campaign. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: CONGRESS BACKING ISRAEL AID DELAY

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Congress is likely to heed the Bush Administration's plea to postpone consideration of an Israeli request for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees until late this year or early next, Congressional leaders said today.
Lawmakers said the delay would accommodate a request made Wednesday by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd to postpone consideration until after a Middle East peace conference planned for October. The Administration's eagerness to put off consideration of the measure despite Israel's desire for immediate action was based on fears that processing the loan guarantee request could complicate planning for the conference. 
 Specifically, the Administration's concern is that the conference not be put at risk by the surfacing of differences with Jerusalem over President Bush's demand that the aid be linked to a commitment by Israel to halt settlements in the occupied territories.
Another consideration, lawmakers said, was the expectation that when Congress returns from its summer recess next week there will be a push, particularly by Democrats, to seek more funds to address domestic problems made worse by the recession.
Israel and its American supporters apparently misread Congressional sentiment by pressing ahead with the request for the loan guarantees, which would be earmarked to build housing and provide other help for the thousands of Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel. Before asking Congress to delay action, Mr. Baker had tried with no success to persuade Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to postpone a formal request for the funds.
 
Not Quickly or Easily
 Both Administration officials and Congressional leaders said today that Israel would probably receive the loan guarantees, but not as quickly or as easily as it hoped.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, said that after meeting Wednesday with both President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, he had decided to delay consideration of the foreign operations aid bill, which would include the loan guarantees.
The Vermont Democrat said in a telephone interview that at a lunch with Mr. Baker and at a subsequent White House meeting, "The President and the Secretary both stressed to me very strongly" that approval of the loan guarantees when Congress reconvenes next week could jeopardize peace in the Middle East.
"I think they make a very solid argument," Mr. Leahy said. "I think it would make sense to put off the foreign aid bill to either later this year or the first of next year," he added.
The Senator said that the delay would have broad bipartisan support in the Senate.
Representative David Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip and third-ranking Democratic leader, said, "My sense is that we're probably not going to do it this year."
"I think it's a delicate issue, given the settlement policy of the Israeli Government," Mr. Bonior said. "In addition, you've got these tremendous domestic demands here at home. That's not to suggest that we're going to turn our backs on Israel, but there are priorities that will take precedence."
The Israeli Government announced today that it planned to formally ask for the guarantees on Friday. It is not clear how Jerusalem will react to the delay.
Prime Minister Shamir today rejected the notion that there was a link between the loan guarantees and the peace negotiations. "We oppose any linkage of this kind," Mr. Shamir said.
It is not known whether the Congressional delay might prompt Israeli hard-liners to press their government to pull out of the proposed American-sponsored peace conference.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, said he believed that Congressional Republicans would support the delay.
Mr. Michel said in a telephone interview from Peoria, Ill., that "Jim Baker called me, too, and said that with the kind of progress they're making, they don't want to upset the apple cart."
Mr. Michel said that Mr. Baker asked for a 120-day delay, and that Mr. Baker had stressed that the loan guarantees were not in doubt.
To some supporters of Israel, however, the Administration's position was unpersuasive.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said: "To deny housing credits now because of the impending peace process would be a severe blow to the process, as well as to the new immigrants Israel must care for."
Supporters of Israel meanwhile prepared for an extensive lobbying campaign. The Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism urged rabbis to use the Jewish High Holy Days, which begin next week, to mobilize support for the loan guarantees.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
SOVIET CONGRESS YIELDS RULE TO REPUBLICS TO AVOID POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC COLLAPSE

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Bowing to the reality of a collapsing union and an ultimatum from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the all-Soviet Congress voted today to surrender power to a new government largely controlled by the republics.
The action served largely to confirm the collapse of central authority over the 15 constituent republics in the 16 days since the aborted right-wing coup and the increasingly urgent need to restore at least a modicum of order before the centrifugal forces turned uncontrollable. 
 The major effect of the new central structures approved by the Congress of People's Deputies was to grant sweeping emergency powers for an undefined transitional period to a State Council composed of Mr. Gorbachev and leaders of the participating republics, backed by a largely subordinate legislature and a central Interrepublican Economic Committee to manage the economy. [Text of resolutions and excerpts from Mr. Gorbachev's remarks, page A12.]
 
Gorbachev the Manager
 In so doing, the Congress effectively dissolved itself as the highest legislative authority in the Soviet Union and laid the foundation for a far looser union in which the republics would seem to predominate in deciding the policies and powers of a subordinate and reduced center. A major question remains the extent of Mr. Gorbachev's remaining power and influence. Although his powers seem sharply diminished, it is possible that he might emerge with important powers in the new State Council, particularly if the republican leaders pay more attention to their problems at home.
Under a rough timetable worked out today, the new two-house legislature will convene no later than Oct. 2, and will probably set up a commission to draft a new constitution. It is expected that the new constitution will provide for new elections to the presidency at some future date, at which time Mr. Gorbachev's political future would be decided.
 
'Rose to the Occasion'
 Mr. Gorbachev, who survived the coup only to stand on the brink of losing any viable levers of control, emerged in the interim order with considerably clipped powers and subordinate to the republics, less an executive president than a coordinating manager.
Yet the very fact of his survival, his experience in domestic and foreign affairs and the familiar determination he displayed at the Congress suggested that he could emerge with a significant role in the new council. Most republic leaders had problems enough at home, and Mr. Gorbachev was likely to be the major conduit for foreign aid.
Whatever the reason, his obvious good humor at the Congress testified to his satisfaction at what he described as a historic moment.
"By determining the principles and mechanisms for the transitional period, the Congress lays the groundwork for a future union of sovereign states," he said before closing the session. "The Congress rose to the occasion at this crucial and, without any exaggeration, historic moment in the development of our state."
For the moment, the arrangement was less a power-sharing agreement than a desperate attempt to create an emergency control center that could combat the incipient chaos and ethnic strife loosed by the coup, prevent the collapse of the economy and the fragmentation of the military.
 
Principles for the Future
 The law made no attempt to define the scope, functions or procedures of the new State Council, leaving that to the republican leaders and Mr. Gorbachev to sort out. It was unclear how the republican leaders would be represented in the council and how often the council would meet, whether Mr. Gorbachev, more attuned to Moscow, might rule between meetings with the Russian leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, or would have to check his every action with republican representatives.
The Congress did, however, pass a nonbinding resolution outlining broad principles for the future, pledging to honor existing Soviet agreements with other states and charging the State Council with "insuring the legal continuity of power and management, guaranteeing a peaceful and orderly transition to a democratic civil society."
The State Council was to hold its first meeting Friday, when it was likely to appoint the Economic Committee -- in effect an acting cabinet -- and consider emergency economic programs. There were reports that Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the prime advocate of radical economic reform, was readying a preliminary economic plan.
The council was also expected to recognize the independence of the three Baltic states, an issue the Congress avoided taking up for fear of prompting demands by other republics for similar recognition. The Baltics are the only states whose independence has received broad recognition abroad, and while most other republics have also proclaimed independence, all except Moldavia might yet form some new form of association.
The new Government was declared a transitional authority until those republics that wanted to could agree on a new relationship, still undefined. The law set no time limits, and deputies talked vaguely of a transitional period of two months to two years.
Besides Mr. Gorbachev, it was also a satisfying moment for those who had struggled for years against a monolithic and repressive system that had held their nation in thrall for seven decades, and who viewed the vote as its final burial.
The eulogy was proposed by Anatoly A. Sobchak, the liberal mayor of Leningrad: "I propose a fitting conclusion to our work by fulfilling the last will of Vladimir Ilyich Lenin and burying him according to the religious and national traditions of our people at Volkovo Cemetery with all appropriate honors."
 
Gorbachev Turns Tough
 Lenin had in fact asked to be buried next to his mother and sister in the Leningrad cemetery, but the proposal was quashed by Mr. Gorbachev.
The end did not come easily. For two days the debate at the Congress ranged from bitter resistance against the surrender of power to somber acknowledgment that the old order was out.
At today's session, however, Mr. Gorbachev turned tough. Flanked by Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of nine other republics, the man who six years earlier first loosed the democratic processes that created this Congress now sternly demanded that it fulfill its purpose by clearing the way for the new era.
Turning away all speakers, demanding silence and obedience in the vast Palace of Congresses, Mr. Gorbachev martialed vote after vote until the deputies balked on a critical paragraph. Twice they denied it a two-thirds majority needed for a constitutional change, when Mr. Gorbachev declared an ultimatum: "We've been talking for three days and we must move foward. Either take this decision and continue on the path, or we will seek new answers."
He did not elaborate, but the glare of the republic leaders made clear that they were the new law in the land with or without the endorsement of Congress. This time, by a margin of scores of votes, it passed -- 1,606 for, 116 against, 83 abstaining and 37 not voting.
Critical to the passage was the decision by Estonia and Latvia, despite their independence, to have their deputies take part in the vote. Lithuania withdrew its deputies from the outset.
The rest went easily, and by the time the Congress was called on to vote on a Declaration of Human Rights, no one even asked to speak. The declaration, which includes guarantees of free movement, is nonbinding.
The central action taken by the congress, the law on transferring power, was in part a compromise. The original proposal from the republican leaders had called for a largely nominal legislature appointed by the republics.
 
2-Chamber Parliament
 The final version created a two-chamber Parliament with a Council of the Republics and a Council of the Union.
The Council of the Republics would have 20 deputies from each republic except Russia, which would have additional deputies from ethnic subrepublics for a total of 52. The catch, however, was that each republicwould have only one vote in the Council of the Republics.
In the Council of the Union, seats would be apportioned by quota. Its action would be subject to approval by the Council of the Republics.
The law also lifted a requirement for the Congress to formally dissolve itself. Deputies were allowed to retain their credentials until the end of their term in two and a half years, along with their privileges and immunity, but regular assemblies were canceled.
Substantive powers were granted to the State Council, which was authorized to organize its own work and whose decisions were declared binding. The law said nothing about the relationship between the council and the Parliament, empowering the council in effect to rule by decree.
The law called for an Interrepublican Economic Committee to be named by the republics. All national military, security and foreign-affairs institutions were placed under the control of the council.
The resolution passed by the Congress gave a broad, though nonbinding outline of thenew Government's goals.
It charged the new leaders with "insuring the legal continuity of power and management, guaranteeing a peaceful and orderly transition to a democratic civil society," and it called for accelerated efforts to negotiate a new Union Treaty "in which each state can independently define the form of its participation in the Union."
The resolution called on republics to reach agreements among themselves on a variety of economic, fiscal, military and other issues. It pledged to honor all Soviet international agreements, and called for negotiated agreements with republics that wanted to leave the union.
While the Congress met, events across the land underscored the urgency of restoring order. Railroad lines in Moldavia remained blocked by women demanding the release of leaders of the "Dnestr Republic," an enclave largely populated by Russians and Ukrainians that opposes Moldavian independence.
A new wave of violence was reported in South Ossetia, a region that demands independence of Georgia, and in Georgia tensions were high after the police fired on demonstrators opposed to the authoritarian President, Zviad Gamsakhurdia. Armenia and Azerbaijan squared off for new confrontations over the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh and rumblings were reported in several ethnic regions of the Russian Federation.
Yet the documents adopted today marked a turning point in the tumult that swept over the Soviet Union with the collapse of the coup and the subsequent eruption of nationalist and republican claims. The same republican leaders who had rushed to declare independence now sat alongside Mr. Gorbachev and argued the need for maintaining a center, and the deputies who had defended or attacked the old order now mustered the dignity to surrender their own hard-won authority in the name of a new order.
At the center stood Mr. Gorbachev, still self-confident and assertive, a man who had come within a hair's-breadth of being swept away by the same processes he had set loose six years earlier, but who had clambered back to center stage by dint of his fundamental faith in the union's potential for renewal.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Delegates surrounding President Mikhail S. Gorbachev after Congress accepted his decentralization plan. (Associated Press) (pg. A1); A bus that had been used as a barricade during the failed coup has been put on display at the Central Museum of the Revolution of the U.S.S.R. (Bill Swersey for The New York Times) (pg. A10)
 
Chart: "Ruling the Soviet Union: A Transitional Plan"
The Congress of People's Deputies approved President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's transitional or "interim" structure for the Soviet Government yesterday. These are the main organs of power of the new Government, which is to rule the country until a new constitution and a new treaty defining relations among the republics on their role in the union can be worked out.
 
State Council
 Executive panel. Headed by Gorbachev and made up of leaders of the participating republics. Responsible for foreign affiars, military, law enforcement and security. Meets today for the first time.
 
Interrepublican Economic Committee
 Chairman chosen by Gorbachev, members chosen by the republics. Responsible for management of the economy, economic reform and social policy.
 
Supreme Soviet
 Parliament made up of two bodies. Bodies will be called into session no late than Oct. 2. is expected to write a new constitution.
 
Council of the Republics
 Members chosen by the republics.
 
Council of the Union
 Members chosen by the republics
 
DETAILS OF THE NEW STRUCTURE
State Council: Mr. Gorbachev, as President, will lead this council, which includes the leaders of all the republics. The highest Government body, it will coordinate decisions on domestic and foreign policy issues. It will run defense, security, law enforcement and foreign affairs. If the President is unable to fulfill his duties, the council will elect an acting leader. The council is to meet today to start work, and is expected to take up the issue of independence for certain Soviet republics.
Supreme Soviet: The highest legislative body, consisting of two chambers, the Council of the Republics and the Council of the Union. The total number of deputies in this body will depend on how many republics decide to take part.
Laws adopted by the Council of the Union take effect after they are approved by the Council of the Republics.
Council of the Union: The deputies will be chosen by legislatures in the republics, based on the number of lawmakers each now has in the Congress of People's Deputies.
Council of the Republics: Will decide on the organization and activities of union organs, and will ratify and annul international treaties of the union. Each republic will send 20 deputies to the council. They will be chosen from Soviet Congress of People's Deputies and republics' legisatures. In addition, autonomous areas - the smaller political subdivisions - in each republic can send one representative. The Russian republic will have the most members, 52, to reflect all its autonomous districts and regions. No matter how many deputies a republic sends, however, each delegation has only one vote.
Interrepublic Economic Committee: To coordinate the national economy and implementation of economic changes, this group is to work out a treaty on economic relations among the parts of the union. Participation in the economic pact would not be linked to signing of a union treaty defining the relations among the republics on their role in the union. This committee's chairman will be named by the President, with the approval of the State Council. (Source: The Associated Press) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
Personalized Bossa Nova From Veloso

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
"I go against the grain, sing against the melody, swim against the tide," Caetano Veloso sang in "Branquinha" ("Little White One") on his brilliant 1989 album, "Estrangeiro" ("Foreigner"). In fact, he makes every melody he sings sound luminous and newly discovered. But in following his own path, Mr. Veloso has become one of the world's most visionary songwriters.
Although he has been known in Brazil since the 1960's, Mr. Veloso released his first United States album, "Caetano Veloso," just five years ago. It was a selection of his songs from the two previous decades, yet it was a detour from the music that had made him a superstar in Brazil. 
 He didn't use the electric guitars and drums of his regular band; instead, he was backed only by his own acoustic guitar, an occasional second guitar and the quiet pattering of hand percussion. His voice, tender but sure, had the sound of a poet ruminating over his past, examining it with affection and curiosity. The music's delicacy reconnected the 49-year-old Mr. Veloso with the bossa nova that he had grown up on; at the same time, it showed how much he had personalized Brazilian music.
Tomorrow night at Town Hall, Mr. Veloso will be playing songs from that album and others, using the same backdrop of acoustic guitars and percussion. And next Tuesday through Sunday at the Ballroom, he will bring the small group into the intimacy of a cabaret.
 
Musical Revolutionary
 In Brazil, Mr. Veloso has been a musical revolutionary. At the end of the 1960's, he and other musicians from the state of Bahia (including Gilberto Gil and Gal Costa) decided to experiment with both words and music, adding electric guitars to their bands and using the fragmentation and imagery of modern poetry. "All the songwriters of my generation were influenced by modern Brazilian poetry," Mr. Veloso said by telephone recently from Rio de Janeiro. "Poets like Vinicius de Moraes, who started as a poet and became a pop lyricist, and Carlos Drummond de Andrade and Joao Cabral, who writes with a sharp knife. Fernando Pessoa, a Portuguese modernist, was also important, and the prose of Guimaraes Rosa. And there was Oswald de Andrade, a pioneer of modernism in Brazil. His poems are short, funny and very aggressive. He invented the idea of cultural anthropophagy, cannibalism. He said Brazil's history began when the Bishop of Sardinia was eaten by the Indians of the Amazon.
"When the Beatles started to interest us, I was already in love with the bossa nova, and with this Brazilian and Portuguese literature. I heard Bob Dylan after this, and he began to influence me when I couldn't understand one word of English."
A song Mr. Veloso wrote in 1967, "Tropicalia," gave its name to the songwriters' movement, but the excitement was short-lived; Brazil's military Government considered the new music a threat. Late in 1968, Mr. Veloso and Mr. Gil were detained by federal police, and after a period of house arrest they exiled themselves to London in 1969. There, they soaked up the era's psychedelic rock while sending songs back to Brazil to be recorded by singers like Miss Costa and Mr. Veloso's sister, Maria Bethania. When Mr. Gil and Mr. Veloso returned to Brazil in 1972, their reputations were intact and their audiences continued to grow.
 
No Lectures
 Mr. Veloso didn't turn into a finger-pointing protest singer. "Sometimes I love it when a very open political statment is in the middle of a song and it sounds like a political statement as a color added to other colors," he said. "But I don't like when a song is supposed to be a political speech or a politically useful thing, when it becomes a lecture and it's not beautiful. First, it must be beautiful."
During the 1970's and 80's, his music reasserted its sinuous, harmonically sophisticated tunefulness after its flirtation with blunt rock-and-roll, while his lyrics grew more associative and imagistic, blending an embracing Romanticism ("My vagabond heart wants to hold the world inside me") with glimpses of stark clarity ("the blah blah blah of economics on television"). Mr. Veloso's music has long since swallowed his influences.
His performances here follow a Brazilian and European tour that accompanied the belated Brazilian release of "Caetano Veloso." Once again, Mr. Veloso has re-examined his past. "Putting together a show, it seems to be casual, but it has to have a line inside from beginning to end, as if I was making a film," he said. "When you see a Jean-Luc Godard film, it doesn't have a story, but it has a wholeness."
 
A Little More Anger
 While he is performing with his lightest touch, Mr. Veloso is in the middle of recording a new album, working with Arto Lindsay, who co-produced "Estrangeiro." Part of it was completed in Rio de Janeiro, and Mr. Veloso will stay in New York to finish the final songs. "In this new material I am more somber, darker, more pessimistic, because things are very difficult in Brazil now," he said. "I am an optimist, basically, but things are very bad. In this moment we are not respecting ourselves as a country, as a nation, as a people.
"Bahia is incredibly dirty, there are lots of people unemployed in the streets, and nobody is trying to think of the possibility of becoming a real citizen. Lots of children in the streets are getting killed. This is the bottom of the well. So I think my songs are a little more angry."
Tonight and next week, Mr. Veloso will intersperse his older songs with material he has written for others. "When I write for Maria Bethania, she tells me exactly what she wants," he said. "She'll tell me she wants a song that has this word in it and that kind of feeling. One time she told me she wanted a song with the word 'baby,' in English, and the line, in Portuguese, 'Read it on my T-shirt.' So I do it. Writing for myself, I do the same thing. I kind of hire myself to write about some images or subjects, and sometimes I am able to respond. Other times, I don't know why I write a song. Some idea pops in my mind, even though I'm not preparing to write a song, so I do it. But most of the time, it is a question of will."
Mr. Veloso is to perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan. Tickets are $22.50. Information: (212) 840-2824. At the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, Manhattan, sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. Tuesday through next Sunday; there is a $35 or $40 cover and a two-drink minimum. Information: (212) 244-3005.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
2 Men Lead Democrats In Outlining '92 Tactics

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Senator Lloyd Bensten says, almost definitively, that he will not run for President, and no one has ever asked Representative Dan Rostenkowski to try for it. But the broad jurisdictions of their committees give the chairmen of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee the keys to the central issues of the Democrats' campaign for the White House.
Last month, in pushing through bills to provide additional weeks of unemployment compensation for people out of work for more than half a year, they sought to deal not just with the needs of the workers. In the end the workers got no help because President Bush killed the actual benefits, but the Democrats gained, perhaps substantially. They now have more ammunition to make the claim that they care about downtrodden Americans while Mr. Bush is more concerned with Kurds, Turks and Egyptians. 
 That bill will probably be back again this month. But both chairmen and their committees will also be dealing with two bigger issues that seem to be inevitable parts of next year's campaign: the relative tax burdens on the rich and the middle class and the cost and availability of health care.
Some of their colleagues wish the Texas Senator and the Illinois Representative were more inclined to straightforward partisan combat -- to defining a Democratic position and pushing it out of committee and onto the floor, whether or not they had the votes to pass it there and knowing that in any case they could not override a veto.
Each will do that, Mr. Bentsen a bit more readily than Mr. Rostenkowski, who will take directions from Speaker Thomas S. Foley, as he did in bringing the unemployment compensation bill forward. But neither is instinctively drawn to the partisan approach. They prefer to seek out compromises with Republicans that may result in real laws.
On taxes, compromise is not a real option. The Democrats want to raise rates on people with the highest incomes and cut them a bit for those in the middle ranges. The Republicans want to reduce capital gains taxes. So the outlook is for hearings and speeches this fall devoted, as Mr. Bentsen puts it, to helping "middle-income people who are really bearing the brunt of the problem." A bill could come to a vote next year.
On health care, the short-term prospects for major legislation are even more daunting, although more and more lawmakers seem persuaded that something major must be done about the sharply rising costs of a health care system with big holes in it. But those costs are huge, and Democrats are not as united among themselves on this issue as on taxes. The Republicans in Congress are uncertain, and the Bush Administration shows no signs of wanting to confront the issue before the election.
Mr. Bentsen says he thinks health insurance legislation, dealing with a manageable chunk of the problem, can actually be passed this fall. He will soon introduce a bill to cope with the problems small-business owners say keep them from insuring their workers. He would seek to prevent insurance companies from " 'cherry-picking' among small companies, taking just those cases where they have the younger employees with fewer health problems."
By legislating limits on how much premiums can be increased each year, prohibiting outright policy cancellations, outlawing the ouster of individual workers from a plan and narrowing permissible exclusions of compensation for pre-existing health conditions, he would try to break the current cycle workers face. "As things continue to escalate, they have to increase the deductible and the co-insurance, then drop the dependents and finally the whole policy," Mr. Bentsen said.
Mr. Rostenkowski may introduce an identical bill; the two of them work much more closely together than do most chairmen with corresponding jurisdiction. And they may find enough Republican support to pass a bill that would try to solve one element of the health care problem without even attempting to address the cosmic issue of how to assure everyone adequate, affordable health care.
Solving a discrete issue is "what I hired on to do," Mr. Bentsen is fond of saying. And passing a law on health and drawing a line on taxes, he says, ought to help whomever the Democrats run for President. But he says it won't be him.

HEADLINE: Senator Who Brings Home the Bacon

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Two years after Senator Robert C. Byrd was named chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, he declared that he intended to become a "billion-dollar industry."
What he planned to do, he explained in June 1990, was use his new power to funnel a billion dollars' worth of Federal projects and agencies into his impoverished state. 
 "I hope to become West Virginia's billion-dollar industry," the Senator told a crowd in Clarksburg. "I expect during my term to bring at least a billion dollars to West Virginia in projects that I put into the bill."
He has almost succeeded, much to the delight of his constituents, much to the sorrow of other legislators and much to the despair of some Government employees who find themselves headed for work in the hills and hollows of West Virginia rather than the bureaucratic warrens of Washington.
 
True to His Word
 In less than three years as appropriations chairman, Mr. Byrd has steered more than $750 million worth of Federal projects and agencies and more than 3,000 Federal jobs out of Washington and toward his constituents. The Federal Bureau of Investigation's new $185 million fingerprint center will soon be built in Clarksburg, bringing in 2,600 new jobs. His latest target is the Central Intelligence Agency. He wants it to shift 3,000 of its jobs to West Virginia.
In all, Mr. Byrd has shunted so many Federal dollars and jobs toward West Virginia that some of his Capitol Hill colleagues are gearing up to oppose further such efforts.
After almost four decades on Capitol Hill, including an 11-year tour as the Senate Democratic leader before taking over the appropriations panel in 1988, Mr. Byrd, who is 73 years old, is demonstrating anew that he can play the Congressional power game as well as anyone around, especially when it comes to "pork barrel" politics.
"This nation is made up of local interests," he is fond of saying.
 
The Sources of Power
 The Senate Appropriations Committee is one of the biggest repositories of project financing, or political "pork," on the Hill, and Mr. Byrd has dipped into it without hesitation to aid friends in the Senate and the people back home, thereby strengthening both himself and his state.
This willingness to use such power, along with seemingly tireless drive and a prodigious knowledge of Senate rules and procedure, has enabled Mr. Byrd to run the appropriations committee with a sureness not seen in years.
"Persausive," Senator Jim Exon, a Nebraska Democrat, said after the soft-voiced but intense West Virginian recently persuaded him to vote in favor of an increase in Congressional pay. The bill languished until Mr. Byrd took it up as one of his causes.
 
A One-Man Industry?
 But nothing Mr. Byrd has done since becoming appropriations chairman stands out so spectacularly as what he has done for West Virginia.
"He has become the most important economic factor in our state," said Bob Brunner, an aide to Gov. Gaston Caperton. "There's no way to overstate his achievements."
The expanded office of the Bureau of Debt is going up in Parkersburg, where it will create 700 new jobs. And the Fish and Wildlife Service's new $25 million training center is in Harper's Ferry.
Charleston is getting a new Federal courthouse, at a cost of $80 million. Beckley is getting a new Federal prison, at a cost of $50 million. Almost $200 million is being spent on water projects.
 
For State and Country?
 Other legislators can claim, legitimately, that they funnel major Federal projects and spending to their states. But no one else can claim to have attracted $140 million in new highway projects this year -- a third of the new highway money put up by Congress for the entire country.
"What helps West Virginia helps the nation," the Senator often says.
He explains that the F.B.I. fingerprint office ended up in West Virginia after the bureau's director, William S. Sessions, complained to him that the office and its system needed to be modernized. He says he offered to try to get Congress to put up the money for the modernization and then suggested to Mr. Sessions that the bureau consider West Virginia for the new office.
"Byrd has shown himself to be one of the great masters at making the appropriatons process work for himself and for others by trading favors and building loyalty," said Joseph White, a scholar at the Brookings Institution who is writing a book on Congressional appropriations. "You don't necessarily make great history doing this, but it's an inescapable part of the system."
 
'Slow This Train Down'
 Mr. Byrd's latest fight, over the proposal to move the C.I.A., could become politically ugly. He has persuaded fellow senators that the switch is a good idea, but he has been unable to win over House members. Now the issue must be hashed out in a House-Senate conference.
"We're going to slow this train down," Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said recently when his panel took a look at the Byrd proposal.
Mr. Byrd insists he did not use any of his considerable appropriations clout to pressure the C.I.A. and his Senate colleagues into agreeing to the move. Rather, he says, he learned that the agency had planned to consolidate some of its temporary offices that are scattered about the Washington area, outside its main headquarters in Langley, Va., and he suggested to agency officials that they "take a look" at West Virginia as a consolidation site, along with sites in Maryland and Virginia.
The agency, the Senator said, then found a suitable site in Charles Town, W.Va., 60 miles northwest of Washington, along with a second site in Prince William County, Va., about 30 miles southwest of the capital. At that point, the Senator says, he took steps to clear Congressional approval and money for the moves.
 
Commuting and Computing
 Modern-day communications and transportation systems, the Senator contends, make it feasible to put Federal complexes almost anywhere. Further, he says, many West Virginia towns and cities are within commuting distance of Washington.
Representative Frank R. Wolf, a Virginia Republican whose district is home for many Federal employees, particularly C.I.A. employees, does not accept any of this explanation.
"I don't want to get into what the Senator did or didn't do, if anything," he said, avoiding tangling with a man who has never been reticent about using political power to punish.
"What I do know," Mr. Wolf continued, "is that the C.I.A. went to the trouble to hire a real estate consultant to give it a reading on 700 potential sites, and that the agency initially narrowed its choices from that list to 65 sites, none in West Virginia. Then it cut that list to 10 sites, none in West Virginia. Then it came up with a list of four sites and -- lo! -- a West Virginia site was suddenly present. And, surprise of surprises, that West Virginia site made the final cut."
According to Mr. Wolf, the C.I.A. deleted the real estate consultant's criticism of the West Virginia site from its final report.
Why did a West Virginia site that had been ruled out earlier suddenly appear at the end of the process?
"We were not bound by the recommendations of any outside consultant," replied Ceferino Epps, an agency spokesman.
And what role did Senator Byrd play?
"None," said Mr. Epps. "None at all."

Byrd, shown in the committee chamber, has steered more than $750 million worth of Federal projects and agencies and more than 3,000 Federal jobs out of Washington and toward his constituents in West Virginia. (Andrea Mohin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Dinkins, It's a Retreat;
Fiscal Realities Lead Mayor to Backtrack

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Faced with New York City's harsh fiscal realities and daunting complexities, Mayor David N. Dinkins has moved to retreat from major policies that helped carry him into City Hall on the hopes of a liberal coalition.
On two disparate, intractable problems -- housing the homeless and disposing of garbage -- the Mayor has found himself this week pleading the limits of his ability to solve them in quite the ambitious ways he pledged, or seemed to be pledging, in his mayoral campaign two years ago. 
 First, Mr. Dinkins voiced concern that the city's shelter system might actually be luring people who are not truly homeless -- because they can increase their chances of winning permanent city apartments. Then he said the city would probably have to build more trash-burning incinerators -- because any other options would cost too much to be real options.
On both fronts, the Mayor edged perilously closer to embracing the policies, if not the philosophies, of his predecessor, Edward I. Koch, that he had sought to discredit in his 1989 race against him. Asked yesterday if the city's fiscal problems and his own experience in 20 months in office had required him to scale back his expectations, Mr. Dinkins said, "Not quite."
The Mayor said he was still committed to providing housing for all who really needed homes, and to maintaining and expanding the city's fledgling recycling program, whose budget had been set to run out in December, though he is not sure how he will pay for it.
But community groups and some other politicians who supported Mr. Dinkins in part because of his platform on putting homeless people more quickly into permanent homes, and his pledge to postpone a decision on building more incinerators until 1993 after a thorough study, put it differently.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, a longtime Dinkins backer, summed up the sense of reversal, calling the incinerator decision "deplorable" and the shift on the homeless "cynical and dangerous."
"It's hard to do what you want when dollars are scarce and the need continues to grow," she said. "But if you can't make giant leaps, you have got to take a set of baby steps that keep you moving in the right directions. And I do not think we have done that well enough with recycling or with developing a set of policies for addressing homelessness."
Such disappointment among strong allies is politically troublesome for Mr. Dinkins, already under fire from a raft of groups for recent cuts in the city budget. The ultimate effect on his old coalition is harder to gauge since no more liberal challenger has yet surfaced.
 
Qualified Language
 In the qualified language that is his hallmark, Mr. Dinkins sought yesterday to distinguish between his handling of the homeless and incinerator issues, saying, "We almost have apples and oranges here."
In fact, the questions are separate.
Mr. Dinkins never promised not to build more incinerators, only to delay building them until safety questions had been studied as part of a comprehensive plan. But he used words so strong that opponents of incinerator projects might well have thought he was abandoning the idea. He did so in the Democratic primary, in a tactical stroke that cost little, since the approval process for incinerators would take several years in any case, but gained him the support of environmental groups at a critical time.
"We're not going to have giant mass-burn incinerators in every borough belching poison into the air," Mr. Dinkins said then.
But now, facing pressure from the state to submit a comprehensive plan for handling waste -- without which the state will not permit it to build either recycling plants or incincerators -- the Dinkins administration was forced to show its cards. Those cards call for expanding recycling, though not nearly so fast as environmentalists wish, and building up to three new "resource recovery" plants that burn trash to create steam power, five fewer than the Koch administration originally envisioned.
"What I said was, there would be a moratorium as it were, pending finding out just what we could do, should do and so forth," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday. "That really hasn't changed, except that obviously I'd be more pleased if we were to come up with a situation that did not require resource recovery. But on balance, as you look at the various options, this makes sense, or certainly appears to."
But environmental groups sharply dispute that. They contend that the city could recycle 40 percent of its waste, instead of the 25 percent by the turn of the century that the administration foresees. They say that building incinerators takes away incentives for the city to pursue recycling and for private industry to develop a market for recyled goods.
"An incinerator built before recycling has been fully developed is likely to be an expensive white elephant," a coalition including the Sierra Club, the Environmental Defense Fund and the Natural Resources Defense Council said in a statement.
The Mayor's shift on homeless policy was more marked. He had made the issue a centerpiece of his tenure as Manhattan Borough President, issuing a report, "A Shelter is Not a Home," that called for moving families from large barracks-style shelters and welfare hotels into apartment-style units and permanent housing as swiftly as possible.
Under pressure from advocacy groups and politicians like Mr. Dinkins, the Koch administration eventually began moving in that direction, and when Mr. Dinkins took office, he accelerated the pace, giving newly homeless families priority for public housing, though Koch administration officials warned that doing so could increase the demand for shelter even more. Mr. Dinkins's report had dismissed that contention, saying, "There is little evidence that families forsake stable housing arrangements hoping to get an apartment through the city."
 
An Adviser's Frustration
 But the shelter population has continued to grow, and the Dinkins administration now forces families to wait longer in the shelters before getting apartments. Nancy Wackstein, Mr. Dinkins's chief adviser on the homeless and author of the report, resigned this week to head the Lenox Hill Neighorhood Assocication. She reflected on her frustration at the limits of the city to address such a complex social and economic problem, and acknowledged that her earlier conclusion might have been too optimistic.
The Coalition for the Homeless said yesterday that the lowered expectations of the administration and Ms. Wackstein amounted to "blaming the victim."
But Mr. Dinkins, while expressing compassion, was unapologetic.
"You have to take a real hard look at it," he said. "You have to determine that those persons who are in the shelter system really have no other option, that they're not there en route to try to get an apartment."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Rhone-Poulenc Names Chief of U.S. Division

 BODY:
The United States subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc, the giant French chemical company, said yesterday that it had named Peter J. Neff chairman and chief executive. Mr. Neff has been president and chief operating officer of the subsidiary, Rhone-Poulenc Inc., since 1987 and has had broad experience in administration and strategic planning.
Mr. Neff, who is 52 years old, sees his primary mission as developing the company's specialty chemical business in the United States and improving the profitability of its commodity and agricultural chemicals businesses. "We have some leadership positions in the specialty chemical area," Mr. Neff said in a telephone interview. "But we're looking to do a lot more developing in that area. We plan to do that by internal investment and through acquisitions." 
 He also stated that cost-cutting would be an important goal in the company's commodity chemical business, which is a leading producer of soda ash, sulfuric acid and chemicals used in recycling. "These are difficult times for the basic chemical business because the economy is not faring very well," he said "and we don't see any real recovery until the end of the year. So we are cutting costs and making some small acquisitions to round out our product line."
As president and chief operating officer, Mr. Neff has been a part of a series of acquisitions that has catapulted the American subsidiary from a company with $700 million in sales to one with more than $2 billion in revenue. That growth has been part of a long-term strategy in the last several years -- for Rhone-Poulenc and other European chemical companies -- to have a far greater presence in the United States market.
Rhone-Poulenc S.A. is the largest chemical and pharmaceutical company in France. "Already, we account for more than 15 percent of Rhone-Poulenc Group sales," Mr. Neff said. "And we expect that percentage to increase."
The company in particular seeks to enhance its role in the lucrative specialty-chemical industry in the United States. "We already have some leadership in the area of food ingredients and in other areas," Mr. Neff said. "But we plan to do more. We plan to bring in some technology from Europe."
Before coming to Rhone-Poulenc, Mr. Neff was president and chief executive of St. Joe Minerals, a subsidiary of the Fluor Corporation. He worked for that company 14 years, in positions like administration and strategic planning. Before that, he worked in marketing positions with Nabisco Brands. Mr. Neff is a 1969 graduate of Rutgers University, where he studied at night to earn a degree in chemistry, graduating magna cum laude, while working as a research chemist at the Exxon Corporation's chemical division. He later received an M.B.A. from Rider College.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
E Pluribus Unum?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
As we watch the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the attempt to cobble together a new system based on the separate republics, we wonder whether such a hybrid can work. How can a mosaic of states have an effective national economy? A foreign or defense policy?
One answer is that it has been tried before with some success: here in the United States. Our circumstances in 1787 were of course entirely different, the joining of independent states in a federation rather than an attempt to rescue some central power from the explosion of a centralized tyranny. But American history does provide some lessons in the workability of federalism -- of state governments functioning within a national system. 
 In the abstract, it must seem rather mad to have 50 different legislatures inside the United States, 50 state bureaucracies, 50 quite distinct legal and judicial systems. American federalism has indeed led to complexity, and helped to produce the most legalized society on earth. But it has also had great benefits.
Justice Louis Brandeis made the classic statement of one advantage of American federalism. In a dissenting opinion in 1932 he wrote: "It is one of the happy incidents of the federal system that a single courageous state may, if its citizens choose, serve as a laboratory, and try novel social and economic experiments without risk to the rest of the country."
There is good reason to believe that Brandeis had Wisconsin in mind when he praised state experimentation. This state, the home of the Progressive movement, led the way on such legislation as unemployment compensation -- a plan drafted by Brandeis's daughter and son-in-law, Elizabeth and Paul Raushenbush, who both taught economics at the University of Wisconsin.
Central to Brandeis's thinking was his belief that huge institutions -- corporations or governments -- were difficult to manage. He thought that aggregations of economic and political power were not only inherently dangerous but inefficient, stifling fresh ideas.
With the New Deal and after, liberals mostly fell away from the Brandeis view. They looked to the center, to Washington, to solve America's problems. But painful recent experience has made us see again that it is unwise to try to run everything from the center in a continental country.
If it is better to allow constituent parts of the United States to go their own way on some issues, how much more is that likely to be true of the vast Soviet Union, with its relatively primitive transportation and communications. Those realities coincide with popular revulsion against central direction after the Soviet record of material and moral disaster.
It hardly needs to be said that the effort to create some form of Soviet federalism will be daunting under the current conditions of political and economic disarray. Even without that factor, American history does not suggest that federalism is an easy political system to manage. We did have a bloody Civil War.
If there is one clear lesson from our history, I think it is the importance of a national market. States and regions may -- should -- go their own way in economic development, depending on their resources and talents. But they do need to be able to trade in a larger market, without tariff barriers.
The question is whether Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin will be able to preserve even that much of an economic union as they and leaders of the other republics try to write a new constitution.
Mr. Gorbachev's leading role in the enterprise is a testament to his astonishing political resilience. He came back from the coup seeming totally out of touch with the great popular movements against the Communist Party and toward empowerment of the republics. Now he has placed himself at the head of both movements.
Western conservatives who regularly denounce Mr. Gorbachev will no doubt cry "opportunism." So be it. We can agree that Mikhail Gorbachev is not a Madisonian believer in federalism.
But to leave it at that is grotesquely unfair. Mr. Gorbachev, by his opening of that closed society over the last six years, made real change possible -- made resistance to the coup possible. To fail to give him credit for that historic achievement is indecent, whether or not he can lead his people now into a federalist promised land.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
MARILYN QUAYLE has been appointed by JAVIER PEREZ DE CUELLAR, the United Nations Secretary General, to a new council that will try to reduce the loss of life, property damage and social and economic disruption caused by natural disasters around the world. 
 The new group's members include TAKEO FUKUDA, a former Prime Minister of Japan; SUZANNE MUBARAK, wife of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, and LISBETH PALME, the widow of Olof Palme, the slain prime minister of Sweden. It has an awesomely long title to go with its mission: the Special High-Level Council of the International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction.
Mrs. Quayle was busy yesterday preparing to accompany her husband on a state visit to Africa on Saturday and could not come to the phone. But Doug Eldred, her special assistant for disaster preparedness issues, said, "She is heavily interested in disasters because growing up in Indiana she found that natural disasters such as floods and tornadoes were commonplace."
In fact, Mrs. Quayle has been involved with a variety of relief organizations. She represented the Bush Administration in Bangladesh after the cyclone there in April, and two years ago she helped workers after Hurricane Hugo in the United States.

HEADLINE: Trash-Transfer Plan Stirs Up Queens

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
When Al Greenstein glances to the right of his office-supply store in Long Island City, he sees the 50-story Citicorp office tower rising a block away, like a bizarrely transplanted piece of midtown Manhattan. He and many others in Long Island City hope that the tower will be followed by similar additions.
But when he looks two blocks to the left, he sees something that not only typifies the Long Island City neighborhood, with its low-lying factories, warehouses and small houses, but something that he and some neighbors also insist threatens their vision of the Queens neighborhood's future. It is a freight yard where the Long Island Rail Road plans to permit the loading of garbage into boxcars for shipment to the Middle West. 
 "I hate it," the 63-year-old Mr. Greenstein said of the planned transfer station. "This would be the start of degrading the area."
His sentiments represent one side of an intense dispute roiling Long Island City, a section of western Queens where one of New York City's oldest and largest industrial strongholds mingles with residential stretches and newer centers of commerce and culture.
Another side is voiced by the railroad and a Kentucky-based waste-disposal company, which say that the proposed operation will benefit New York City. They say that the transfer station, where bales of commercial garbage will be transferred to railroad cars and shipped to the MiddleWest, will help to reduce traffic congestion and air pollution because fewer large trucks will be needed to haul the waste to landfills.
"It will operate unobtrusively and will not cause any problems to Long Island City," said Mark McIntyre, a spokesman for United Waste Removal Inc. of Louisville. He added that the garbage-transfer operation would not discourage developers from investing in the neighborhood. The company is seeking state and city approvals to begin the operation in the L.I.R.R. yard at Jackson Avenue and 46th Road.
But not discouraging developers is no consolation to many residents, particularly those who are against the garbage-transfer station and most major development in the neighborhood.
"I'm not pleased about either," Annie Tsantesaid.
Ms. Tsantes, a 39-year-old landlord and superintendent, argues that the waste operation would bring odors, rats and other vermin to the area. The railroad and United Waste Removal say such fears are unwarranted. As for redevelopment, Ms. Tsantes, who also works as a waitress, said that it would bring no benefits to local residents like herself.
Long Island City, immediately across the East River from the East Side of Manhattan, is poised for a major transformation, some city officials and local leaders say. Many predict that once the current recession ends, the area -- only a short subway hop from midtown Manhattan and at the end of the Queensboro Bridge -- will see additional development.
Most of the construction, they say, would occur along the Jackson Avenue corridor, which includes the L.I.R.R. freight yard and the Citicorp tower, and along the waterfront.
Projects already being considered include a development project at Hunters Point, where the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and New York State and City hope to turn a 70-acre waterfront site into a vast residential, office, retail and recreational complex. The complex would include housing for more than 6,000 families and several office buidings. There are also plans for another 1,000 apartments in a second development.
As in many neighborhoods where such plans are in the wind, property owners like Mr. Greenstein -- who long ago bought the four-building complex that houses his office-supply and printing businesses -- welcome redevelopment, with the higher property values it would bring. Similarly enthusiastic are Long Island City shopkeepers who see themselves gaining from the influx of office workers and middle-class residents.
But others who live or work in the area, like factory operators who lease their sites and artists who gravitated to the neighborhood because of its low rents, fear the dislocation that often accompanies community redevelopment projects.
 
'Looking to Compete'
 Such worries have been temporarily eclipsed, however, by the strife over the trash-transfer plan. United Waste Removal is seeking needed permits from the state's Department of Environmental Conservation and the city's Sanitation Department. Opponents are arguing against the permits and have vowed to go to court in an effort to stop the project.
Susan McGowan, a spokeswoman for the railroad, said the agency decided to add the transfer station as a way to increase revenues.
"We're looking to compete with trucking companies," she said. "We've been there for about 150 years moving freight, and I don't see this as all that different from what we're presently doing and have done in the past."
Mr. McIntyre, the United Waste Removal spokesman, said the planned transfer station would be different from virtually all the other 260-odd garbage-transfer stations where trash from offices, restaurants and other businesses are taken for disposal. The placement of a number of the other stations also led to local opposition.
 
Won't Be Picked Through
 At a typical transfer site, Mr. McIntyre said, private haulers who pick up trash from nonresidential customers first empty their loads for sorting and recycling. The trash is then compacted into one-ton bales that are trucked to landfills. By contrast, he said, the garbage at the L.I.R.R. yard would not be "routinely dumped onto the floor and picked through."
Rather, trash already sorted and baled at seven or eight other transfer stations in Queens would be trucked there and loaded directly into boxcars without being "stored or stacked or placed on the ground," he said.
"As soon as the boxcars are filled, they will be sealed," Mr. McIntyre said, adding that this and the fact that "we're not handling loose material" would preclude vermin and filth and greatly reduce odors, which he said would be totally eliminated by odor-neutralizing equipment. Mr. McIntyre, of Cameron Engineering, which represents the waste company in the permit-seeking process, said that up to 1,000 tons of trash would be handled that way between 9 P.M. and 7 A.M. daily.
Nonetheless, Jack Rainey, executive director of the Long Island City Business Development Corporation, suggested that the transfer station be put in a part of Long Island City that is "not slated for major commercial development."
Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, agreed, declaring her "unconditional opposition" to the transfer station. She cited the "millions of public and private dollars and years of commitment" invested in the area, including the conversion of Public School 1 across Jackson Avenue from the freight yard into artists' studios and galleries, as reasons to fight the plan.
Joseph Cerbone, whose father, Vincent, operates Manducatis, a popular Italian restaurant also across from the freight yard, said he also opposes the transfer station.
"On paper it sounds sweet -- no odors, no rats, no problems," he said. "It never works out that way. Forklifts will puncture the bales."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 7, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a proposed garbage transfer station in Long Island City, Queens, referred incorrectly to Annie Tsantes, who lives near the site. She is superintendent of the building where she lives, not landlord.

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
Adjustable Mortgages

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:

Adjustable-rate mortgages, down to levels not seen in many years, are currently attractive alternatives to the 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage, which is now about 8.98 percent. A decision depends not only on rates but on how long an owner plans to stay in a home and how high interest rates might go over the life of the mortgage. (Someone who plans to move in five years, for example, may benefit more from an adjustable rate than someone who expects to stay a longer period.) In most cases the adjustables, known as ARM's, have caps, usually a maximum of two percentage points a year and six points over the life of the loan. The table shows the monthly payments on two $100,000 ARM's with an initial average rate of 6.78 percent. One rises a percentage point annually; the other, two percentage points. By comparison, the monthly payment on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage on $100,000 at 8.98 percent would be $803.18; the four-year total would be $38,552.63.

HEADLINE: Ranomafana Journal;
Whose Forest Is It, the Peasants' or the Lemurs'?

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RANOMAFANA, Madagascar

 BODY:
Six years ago, Emile Rajeriarison and Loret Rasabo, who like generations of their families lived from the rain forest here, led some American researchers into the tree-canopied habitat they knew so well.
After some days of wading and walking, they spotted what they were looking for: a golden-colored lemur that the reseachers thought was probably extinct but that the men had known since childhood. 
 The newly discovered lemur -- long nose, bug-eyed primitive primate peculiar to this Indian Ocean island -- added to the 11 species already known in the Ranomafana Forest and convinced reseachers that the forest held one of the greatest unexplored diversities of fauna and flora left in the world.
In May the forest was declared a national park, the newest in Africa and the fourth in Madagascar.
 
An Enigmatic Ecology
 For scientists, the park presented a bonanza of unfettered research on one of the world's most enigmatic ecologies. For environmentalists, the park helped put on hold the destruction of Madagascar's forest, which was being cut so fast that scientists reckoned none would have been left by the year 2025. And for tourists interested in an exotic environment, the designation offered an untrammeled destination on the ever shortening list of remote places.
But for the 80,000 peasants who regard the forest as a source of wood for fuel and cleared it to make way for new rice fields, the transformation from usable forest to protected park spelled economic disaster.
The creation of Ranomafana National Park has thus become an example of one of the challenges for environmentalists in Africa in the 1990's: how to give a stake in conservation to peasants who suffer when their habitat is declared off limits.
At Ranomafana, about 240 miles south of the capital, Antananarivo, an unusually aggressive effort is being made to link scientific research and Western touristic pleasure with social benefit to the local people.
 
Training as Guides
 "This is not like Yellowstone -- created with no one living around it," said Mark Fenn, an American forester who has worked in West Africa and is now the director of the Ranomafana National Park Project. "We're asking the poorest people in the world to support wildlife. So an objective is to get the villagers to profit by training them as guides, getting them to set up camps for tourists."
Moreover, in an effort to show that the park will help rather than hurt the villagers, the project, which is partly financed by a $3.2 million grant from the United States Agency for International Development, plans to build schools in the villages, is already delivering health services and is searching for broad-scale alternative sources of income for the peasants, like vegetable gardening.
Mr. Rajeriarison, who is 30 years old, and Mr. Rasabo, 29, have dropped their former jobs -- herding cows in the forest and lopping fern trees to sell their trunks as decorative flowerpots -- and become permanent guides. They are being paid about $40 a month by Mr. Fenn's project, almost twice what they were earning before, to share their innate familiarity of the forest with the Malagasy and Western scientists who are beginning to flock here and to other parts of Madagascar.
 
Closed to West for a Time
 Situated 250 miles off the coast of Mozambique, Madagascar has long fascinated zoologists, geologists and botanists but was virtually closed to Westerners between 1975 and 1987, President Didier Ratsiraka allied himself with North Korea and the Soviet Union.
But in the last several years, as Mr. Ratsiraka has changed directions toward the West, a new wave of researchers have come to the island that is believed to be a torn-off chunk of Africa. Typical of the unanswered questions about Madagascar is the geological dispute over where it was when it was cast off more than a million years ago. Some geologists maintain that it broke off from what is now Mozambique, while others contend that it was out near Tanzania and floated down.
When Madagascar did split off, only a few types of plants and animals were on board. The flora and fauna were still at a primitive stage of evolution. Thus, the lemurs -- which had been widespread throughout the world -- were able to develop with no competition from higher forms of life, like monkeys.
There are no monkeys and no predators in Madagascar. More than 80 percent of the island's flowering plant species are not found anywhere else. For frog lovers, Madagascar is nirvana: 148 of its 150 frog species are endemic.
 
Rice Is Now Imported
 With its bulging population and diminishing supplies of the basic diet of rice -- the country used to be a rice exporter but now imports -- economists and scientists agree that the pressure on the forest that harbors much of this plant and animal life is almost uncontainable. At several spots along the road just north of the Ranomafana Forest, a visitor could hear the thud of falling trees and the swishing sound of an ax. In one place, a team of men and women hauled logs onto a makeshift trolley to sell for fuel.
Mr. Fenn said he believed that the forest here would have survived 10 to 15 years more if it had not been made into a park. And to convince the peasants that it is in their best interest, as well as the scientists, not to cut the trees, he plans to take some of the village leaders on a field trip to the coast.
"There are no trees because there are no seed sources," Mr. Fenn said. "I think I can convince them by taking them to the devastated areas along the coast that were once forest but are now desert."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Jobless Data Move Traders Off Sidelines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell in heavy trading yesterday and gold prices rose. Currency dealers attributed the activity to technical selling after release of the August unemployment report.
Many currency traders had refrained from active dealing since late last week, awaiting the Labor Department's report. 
 A sudden rise in unemployment could move the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates to aid a sagging economy, traders said, which would reduce the value of the dollar.
But the nation's jobless rate remained at 6.8 percent in August, in line with predictions. That did not prompt the dollar's decline, analysts said. But technical selling swept the market around noon, said Christopher Bourdain, manager of foreign exchange sales for Credit Suisse.
 
Heavy Selling Against Mark
 Alex Scarsini, a currency trader at Continental Bank in Chicago, said that trades that had been delayed before the employment report partly explained the heavy volume.
The heaviest selling was the dollar against the German mark, with the dollar quoted in New York at 1.7165 marks at closing, down from 1.7380 late on Thursday.
Traders also said some large investors sold dollars and Canadian and Australian dollars, which offer more attractive yields.
In London, the pound rose to $1.6965, from $1.6925 late on Thursday. In New York, sterling was quoted at $1.7180, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6940.
Earlier in Tokyo, before the unemployment figures were released, the dollar rose to close at 136.00 Japanese yen, from 135.32 yen on Thursday. Later, in London, it rose to 136.05 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 135.65 yen, down from 135.80 yen.
Other late dollar rates, compared with those of late on Thursday, included: 1.5075 Swiss francs, down from 1.52595; 5.8310 French francs, down from 5.9030; 1,280.25 Italian lire, down from 1,295.50, and 1.13925 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14105.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $348.75 an ounce, up from $347.50 bid late on Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $348.40, up from $347.25 bid late on Thursday.
In earlier trading in Hong Kong, gold fell 22 cents an ounce to close at a bid $348.11. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery was quoted at $349.10 an ounce, up $2.10. A late bid at the Republic National Bank of New York quoted it at $348.90, up $2.20.
In London, silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $3.97 an ounce, up from $3.88 bid late on Thursday. On the Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $3.969 an ounce, up 10.9 cents.
