HEADLINE: Money Gives an Unknown an Introduction

SERIES: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council/An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council.

BYLINE: JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Buses rumbling through the rundown streets of the Lower East Side have carried bright new advertisements in the last two weeks, urging people to elect Philip K. Howard, who until recently was well known only in a few corporate boardrooms and among the upper-crust civic-minded set who fought big developments uptown.
The bus advertisements are testament to the power of money to create a viable candidate out of a relative unknown in this year's City Council election, in which political strategists say they believe a few hundred votes could swing a race. 
 Mr. Howard, a corporate lawyer from Gramercy Park who said he decided in early July to run because he was disgusted with the city budget, has in short order become a candidate to be reckoned with, riding a flood of campaign contributions from lawyers and investment bankers who do not live in the neighborhood.
In the last four weeks, Mr. Howard has raised and spent more than $85,000, twice as much as any of his competitors, according to campaign finance documents filed last week. His list of contributors reads like a Who's Who of New York's corporate and legal world, including several close associates of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and even Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.
Mr. Howard's impressive fund raising has skewed the race in District 2, a polyglot community which stretches from the luxurious apartment buildings of Gramercy Park and Murray Hill to the projects along the East River where working-class Hispanic people and Orthodox Jews live. In between is the bubbling caldron of intellectuals, artists, students, anarchists, mainstream liberals and leftists known collectively as the East Village.
 
Things Change
 Only a month ago, Councilwoman Miriam Friedlander, the 77-year-old die-hard leftist who has represented the neighborhood for 18 years, was believed to be facing her most serious challenge from Antonio Pagan, a moderate liberal with strong support from Hispanic voters, building owners and developers.
The other Democrat in the primary race, Hyman Dechter, a conservative criminal lawyer from the Jewish enclave on Grand Street, was considered a long shot.
That was before Mr. Howard, a 43-year-old product of Yale and the University of Virginia Law School, weighed in with a barrage of advertisements on radio and television and three mass mailings. Between Aug. 9 and Aug. 30, he raised $85,430. No other first-time candidate this year has come close to that level, and only a handful of incumbents could claim such large treasuries.
Political strategists say Mr. Howard's spending could seriously test the campaign finance program's ability to limit the influence of money in campaigns. Mr. Howard is not in the program, but Ms. Friedlander and Mr. Pagan are, which means under state law they are eligible to recieve $2 in public money for every dollar they raise.
"The question is, can someone buy an election?" asked Howard Hemsley, Mr. Pagan's campaign manager. "We're at a severe disadvantage."
Among Mr. Howard's contributors are John C. Whitehead, the former deputy secretary of state and co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, and Vincent Tese, the State Commissioner of Economic Development, who donated $5,600, Mr. Howard's largest contribution.
 
'You Have to Get the Message Out'
 "I'm trying to win, and I'm trying to overcome an incumbent's advantage," Mr. Howard said, adding he favors the campaign finance program but entered the race too late to enroll in it. "When you don't have political clubs and the party machinery, you have to get the message out to the voters."
Ms. Friedlander has the recognition that comes only after nearly two decades in office, where she has earned a reputation for taking unwavering liberal stands on rent control, the homeless and women's rights.
"My record is one of activism," she said. "Proportionally I get a very large amount of money for my district."
Although an eloquent naysayer and conscience prodder, Ms. Friedlander is not viewed by City Hall insiders as an adept legislator who can cut deals. Her critics in the community also assert that she has stacked the local community planning board with liberals who resist gentrification by developers and in the process stifle construction.
 
'She's Done Very Little'
 Ms. Friendlander has raised about $55,000 and spent more than $38,000, her campaign manager, Frieda Bradlow, said. She also received $26,253 in public money and stands to get another $13,000 from the Campaign Finance Board.
For Mr. Pagan, Mr. Howard's brimming campaign treasury is a larger threat. With some public financing, he has raised $54,000 and spent $39,000. Even the public matching money Mr. Pagan could receive might not be enough to offset Mr. Howard's advertising blitz, Mr. Pagan said.
Mr. Pagan, a 33-year-old lifetime resident of the neighborhood who heads a nonprofit organization that builds low-income housing, contends the best answer to the Lower East Side's problems is more housing for working- and middle-class people. He accuses Mr. Howard of having no record of service in the district's poor neighborhoods. And he accuses Ms. Friendlander of being an ineffective ideologue who has done little to help the small merchants and property owners whom he calls "the cloth of the society."
"For 18 years, she's done very little for this district," Mr. Pagan said. "All you have to do is walk down our streets. Look at the filth. Look at our buildings. We have vacant buildings, vacant lots. We're talking about effective leadership. Do we need 18 more years of rhetoric?"
 
Closing Tompkins Square Park
 No issue has crystalized the conflict between Mr. Pagan's supporters and Ms. Friedlander's more than the closing of Tompkins Square Park and the eviction of the homeless who lived there. Mr. Pagan spearheaded the efforts to close the park, with an eye toward returning it to the taxpaying residents who live nearby.
Ms. Friedlander called the closing "absolutely outrageous," and accused Mayor David N. Dinkins of pandering to voters while sweeping the ugly problem of homelessness into vacant lots two blocks away. She favors establishing a drop-in center where the homeless could be coaxed into drug rehabilitation and housing programs.
Mr. Howard is running on a broad promise to cut waste, overregulation and inefficiency in the city bureaucracy. Before running for the Council, his main public service came when he headed efforts as a pro bono lawyer to stop the original Columbus Circle and Tudor City Park developments.
"You have to bring government back to the neighborhood level, and in the process of doing it, you also have to cut out 40 years of red tape," he said.
 
A Tough Race to Call
 Mr. Howard's entry into the race has made the contest difficult to handicap. Although Ms. Friedlander is believed to be unbeatable in the left-leaning sections of the East Village, Mr. Howard is expected to do well in Gramercy Park and Murray Hill, an area Ms. Friedlander has never represented.
Mr. Howard could also hurt Mr. Pagan because Mr. Howard has the endorsement of City Council President Andrew J. Stein, who is popular among the 15,000 Orthodox Jews in the Grand Street housing projects. Mr. Pagan was expected to poll well in those projects because Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, a longtime foe of Ms. Friedlander, endorsed him. Mr. Stein's support could swing some Jewish votes to Mr. Howard.
Another unknown is who will win the support of the 14,870 Hispanic voters. Historically, Ms. Friedlander has overwhelmingly carried the Hispanic vote.
But political strategists say Mr. Pagan has managed to make peace among the various Spanish-speaking leaders, uniting them behind his campaign.
"It's a tossup," said one Hispanic strategist. "It's quite possible Pagan and Friedlander will capture their respective communities and this guy Howard could turn around and squeak in. No one community has a majority down there. Half of the district is new even for an incumbent."

HEADLINE: Jobs Data Mixed Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
The first broad-gauge assessment of the economy's performance in August showed no clear trend, with the unemployment rate remaining at 6.8 percent and a second straight rise in factory payrolls countered by job shrinkage elsewhere, Labor Department figures showed today.
 But while economists groped for meaning, bond traders pushed interest rates down and Democratic politicians seized the occasion to express doubts that recovery is under way and to assail the Bush Administration for barring payment of extended benefits for the long-term jobless. 
The report did little to change the views of either optimists or pessimists, said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, adding, "It still leaves pretty unsettled the question of how long the recovery can go and how strong it can be."
 
Regional Variations
 While the national unemployment rate was unchanged, some areas recorded sizable moves. The rates in both New York and New Jersey posted increases of four-tenths of a percentage point, to 7.5 percent and 6.7 percent, respectively.
 Most private analysts say the recession ended in the spring but evidence of recovery has been spotty and the Federal Reserve felt impelled last month to make another round of interest-rate cuts to spur activity. Today's figures, though in some respects mildly encouraging about the recovery, were seen as likely to lead to further cuts in the next few weeks in the overnight lending rate among banks and in the Fed's discount rate.
 The most encouraging elements in today's report, said Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, were a rise of 42,000 in factory jobs, which brought the two-month gain to nearly 70,000, and a 12-minute increase in the length of the factory workweek.
 Still, she said, the labor market last month "continued to lack clear direction" since construction, mining, wholesale trade and other sectors kept shedding jobs and the financial problems of state and local governments were starting to be reflected in shrunken payrolls.
 News that the unemployment rate did not fall last month -- in July there was a decline of two-tenths of a point -- brought immediate pledges from Democrats to try again to extend benefits for those who have exhausted them after six months.
 Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said the August figures proved that "the Republican recession has created an economic emergency in America and it's time to do something about it."
 Senator James Sasser of Tennessee, head of the Budget Committee, said President Bush should not cite last year's budget agreement as a reason to oppose more than the usual 26 weeks of benefits since that act provided for emergency spending. He said the President had invoked the emergency provision to aid Kurds, Turks, Sudanese and Bangladeshis but not American workers.
 Last month Congress passed a $5.8 billion measure to provide 5 to 20 weeks of extra benefits. Mr. Bush signed the bill, saying he was doing so to show his sympathy for the jobless, but he refused to issue the necessary declaration of emergency for the money to be spent.
 Democrats also sought to score politically by asking four unemployed people to tell their stories today at a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee where the chairman, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, contended that the recession had "continued well into the summer."
 
A White House View
 At the White House, Michael J. Boskin, the President's top economic adviser, said that while the economy was not yet healthy it was improving and was unlikely to slip back into recession.
 Mr. Boskin also pointedly complained of widespread references to three million unemployed workers' having exhausted their benefits. He said he found "a little bit of chicanery" in the figure, contending it was exaggerated because more than half the three million had already returned to work and because many were unemployed because they had quit their jobs.
 The Labor Department report showed an overall increase of 34,000 in non-farm payrolls, about what was expected, with July's loss revised downward and June's loss revised upward by about the same amount. Goods-producing jobs rose 24,000, holding a big July gain in automobiles and adding sizable August increases in the auto-sensitive areas of fabricated metals and rubber and plastics.
 
Mixed Result in Services
 The modest gain of 10,000 in services benefited from another large rise, of 36,000, in health-service jobs and a renewed increase, 23,000, in business services. But this was more than offset by declines of 18,000 in wholesale trade, 15,000 in retail trade and 40,000 in state and local government.
 The department's survey of households, from which the unemployment rate is calculated, disclosed a further striking decline in the labor force, which fell 310,000, after a drop of 415,000 in July. The ranks of teen-age workers are shrinking, Commissioner Norwood said, while growth in the number of adult women in the work force has slowed sharply.
 The reduction in the overall work force nearly matched a 296,000 decline in jobs, as measured by the household survey, so the jobless rate did not budge from 6.8 percent, the same level as in March and two-tenths of a point below the 7 percent in June, which has been the recent peak.
 The jobless rate for adult women climbed to 5.7 percent, from 5.4 percent, last month, while the rate for adult men remained at 6.5 percent, the report showed. The rate for teen-agers dropped 1.6 points, more than wiping out a July surge.
 
Out of Work Longer
 The median duration of unemployment moved up to 7.2 weeks in August from 6.6 in July and 5.2 in August 1990.
 Among the 11 biggest states, 7 of which now have jobless rates above the national average, the biggest change was in Michigan, where unemployment climbed to 9.1 percent from 8.3 percent.
 By region, the jobless rate was 7.1 percent in the Northeast, 6.7 percent in the South, 6.3 percent in the West and 6 percent in the Midwest, with the Northeast shifting over the last year from the best of the four regions to the worst and the South moving from worst to second-best. Unlike the other data, the regional figures are not adjusted for seasonal variation.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 38; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
SEVENTH HEAVEN, by Alice Hoffman. (Fawcett Crest, $5.99.) When a divorcee named Nora Silk moves with her two children to Long Island in 1959, she has such a disruptive effect on the suburban calm that it is rumored she is a witch. Alice Hoffman "has complete control over this bustling story, shuffling its many vignettes as cleverly as she captures the nuances of its many voices," Alida Becker said here last year.
SATURDAY NIGHT, by Susan Orlean. (Fawcett Crest, $5.99.) Cruising in a muscle car in Elkhart, Ind., watching the debutantes in a Hispanic neighborhood in Phoenix, dancing at Blob's Polka Park in Jessup, Md., hanging out with the waitresses at the Hilltop Steakhouse in Saugus, Mass., and with the homeless men at the Bowery Mission on New York's Lower East Side -- Susan Orlean dedicated herself to finding out what is so special about those hours of mandatory recreation called Saturday night. Last year our reviewer, Scott Simon, said the book is written "with much zest and considerable insight" by "a fine and engaging guide." 
 ONCE UPON A TIME ON THE BANKS, by Cathie Pelletier. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $9.) Life in the sleepy town of Mattagash, Me., becomes less boring than usual when Amy Joy Lawler announces that she is marrying a French Catholic from the wrong side of the tracks. In 1989 our reviewer, Fannie Flagg, called this novel a "bawdy, poetic crazy quilt of a book."
FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS: A Town, a Team, and a Dream, by H. G. Bissinger. (Harper Perennial, $10.) Chronicling the 1988 season of the Permian High School Panthers in the football-obsessed town of Odessa, Tex., H. G. Bissinger found that the school spent $70,000 on chartered jets for the team's road games, $6,400 on rushed film prints of the games and $5,040 on teaching materials for the English department. Last year our reviewer, Michael Swindle, said the author "offers a biting indictment of the sports craziness that grips not only Odessa but most of American society, while at the same time providing a moving evocation of its powerful allure." In NO MEDALS FOR TRYING: A Week in the Life of a Pro Football Team (Ivy, $5.99), Jerry Izenberg goes behind the scenes as the New York Giants prepare for an important game with the Philadelphia Eagles. The book "gives us the feel of being on the Astroturf as 280-pound defensive ends bear down on us," Michael Lichtenstein said here last year. "Best of all, we don't have to worry about getting crunched."
MEDICINE RIVER, by Thomas King. (Penguin, $5.95.) Returning to a small town on the edge of the Blackfoot reservation for his mother's funeral, Will finds his niche as the town's first native photographer and joins an all-Indian basketball team. Last year our reviewer, Jack Butler, said this first novel is "economical, precise and elegant."
THE TRUE AND ONLY HEAVEN: Progress and Its Critics, by Christopher Lasch. (Norton, $14.95.) In a finite world, where perpetual improvement is impossible, the author argues, we should embrace the conservative values of progress's victims, the lower middle class. Earlier this year our reviewer, William Julius Wilson, said that "because of the sheer force of [Christopher Lasch's] critique . . . the book is required reading for any student of social criticism and cultural history."
UNDER SIEGE, by Stephen Coonts. (Pocket Books, $5.95.) When George Bush is wounded by a sniper, Dan Quayle takes over the fight to save the Government from Colombian drug lords. "Here is escape reading at its best," Newgate Callendar said here last year. Stephen Coonts "avoids the dreadful cliches of most of his colleagues. His dialogue is realistic, the story line mesmeric."
ROUGH JUSTICE, by David Heilbroner. (Dell, $4.99.) A former prosecutor says that his stint in the Manhattan District Attorney's office taught him that everybody lies, including police officers, witnesses and even victims. "Rough Justice" is "accurate, engaging and unsettling," Marcia Chambers said here last year.
THE FIREMAN'S WIFE: And Other Stories, by Richard Bausch. (Norton, $8.95.) In one of these short stories, a woman who is tired of being married to a firefighter learns that he has been injured in a disaster. Last year our reviewer, Bette Pesetsky, said that while this collection "serves us ample helpings of modern angst," it "also shows us how we manage to go on living. And in this it rewards us richly."
WIDOW'S JOURNEY: A Return to the Loving Self, by Xenia Rose. (Owl/Holt, $9.95.) After the cellist Leonard Rose died, his wife, a psychotherapist, struggled to get to the point where she could listen to music without crying. In describing her ordeal, "she is sharp as a novelist," Judith Moore said here last year.
THE GIFT HORSE'S MOUTH, by Robert Campbell. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) The precinct captain Jimmy Flannery is recruited by the Chicago political machine to find out who killed Goldie Hanrahan, a party secretary who may have been privy to damaging political secrets. The novel is "sentimental and funny, raucous and sad," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.

HEADLINE: Maestro of the Moment

BYLINE: By John Rockwell; John Rockwell is a music critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:
THERE WERE TIMES THESE PAST MONTHS when Kurt Masur, the new music director of the New York Philharmonic, seemed to be all over town -- poking into every byway of New York's musical life and working rooms like the politician he almost became.
One evening, he was in tiny Weill Recital Hall for a violin recital, the next at the Metropolitan Opera for "Salome" or at the Carnegie Hall centennial gala or seeing "Les Miserables" with his wife and son. During the day, he met with Philharmonic musicians, staff and board members or darted about the area in search of concert sites and a home. His jacket slung over his shoulder, his barrel chest incongruously topped by one of his collection of Western-style string ties, he looked the very picture of slightly touristy, heartily undaunted self-confidence. 
 He did seem confident, but he also rather sweetly confessed to past apprehensions. "All this activity is just keeping me busy -- it's not making me nervous," he says cheerfully. "I used to feel the danger of the city, but now I sense its energy, its excitement. Older friends felt at home here, and gradually I began to feel I could function in New York, too. If you have nothing to hide, there's no need to fear."
But if Masur feels optimistic about his formal debut as the Philharmonic's music director this Wednesday evening -- a concert that will be nationally televised as part of the "Live From Lincoln Center" series -- how will New Yorkers respond to him? When the Philharmonic chose him to succeed Zubin Mehta in April 1990, the news came as a surprise to almost everyone. The music director of the tradition-laden Gewandhaus Orchestra in Leipzig, Masur had built his entire career in East Germany, a literally walled-off enclave far from the tumult of the international music business. When one thought of him at all, it was as an exemplar of that lovely old German word Kapellmeister -- literally, master of the chapel; figuratively, a workaday conductorial craftsman.
With his appointment, however, and with the rapid collapse of East Germany, we began to hear more about Masur. Aside from bearing an amusing resemblance to Brahms (when he lets his hair and whiskers grow wild), he had slowly built an international career while remaining true to the city of Bach and Mendelssohn. He had also played a leading role in the liberalization movement of 1989 that defused potential confrontations as the old East Germany collapsed. He became so potent a symbol that he was seriously considered for the largely ceremonial post of East German President in that country's final months.
Philharmonic players championed Masur's appointment. They hope he will lend a new gravity to the orchestra's playing of the classics. But it is also possible that his musicianship, nurtured in the hothouse atmosphere of Leipzig, will pale in the glaring world of music as big business, tarnishing his wise and insightful image into the unimaginatively routine.
Leipzig's musical life offers tantalizing hints of what Philharmonic musicians and audiences may expect. Masur himself seems convinced that what worked in Germany will translate to the New World, and that his style and values, shaped by centuries of German tradition and his Leipzig roots, will survive under New York scrutiny. "I can't change," he says. "I am what I am, and you will get what I am as honestly as I can bring it."
THE COMMERCIAL center of the German state of Saxony, Leipzig was heavily bombed during World War II and then rapidly rebuilt into a grim, dingy epitome of Communist underachievement. Among the landmarks destroyed in 1944 was the city's beloved concert hall, named the Gewandhaus after a predecessor's original function as a fabric merchants' exchange hall.
The city's musical tradition is particularly rich. For centuries, the Thomaskirche, or St. Thomas Church, which still stands, was the center of municipal music life, and Bach was its music director. The Gewandhaus Orchestra, one of the oldest and finest in Germany, dates to 1743. Unlike in most German cities, the orchestra, not the opera, is the center of Leipzig's musical life, with Gewandhaus musicians (there are now some 200 of them) also playing for the opera company and Thomaskirche concerts. Mendelssohn was the orchestra's conductor from 1835 to 1847, and like most Gewandhaus Kapellmeisters, he took an active role in all aspects of the city's cultural life. His successors included Arthur Nikisch, Wilhelm Furtwangler and Bruno Walter, and Schumann and Brahms had close ties with the orchestra as well.
Today, proudly flanking the south side of a big open square called the Augustus Platz (until recently, Karl-Marx-Platz), stands the new Gewandhaus. Opened in 1981, it is a prime symbol of the arts in the midst of a city that has suffered through decades of East Bloc privation and two years of economic and psychological travail. Its irregularly shaped interior, with sharply rising tiers of seats cupping the orchestra protectively, crowned by an imposing, 6,638-pipe organ, has made it the modern center of the city. (Masur would like to install an organ almost as large in Avery Fisher Hall, for both musical and acoustical reasons.)
Looming over the Gewandhaus and this entire city of 600,000 inhabitants -- and, one might plausibly argue, over eastern Germany itself -- is the ruddy-complexioned, stockily built, 6-foot-3-inch Kurt Masur. Gewandhaus Kapellmeister since 1970, he rules his orchestra and the city's music and, indeed, his region's inner self-esteem in grandly sovereign fashion, for all his truly sincere espousal of democracy both within the Gewandhaus and in the country at large. As he walks through the streets of Leipzig, Masur is greeted with genuine affection, moderated by awed respect, by everyone from orchestra members to good burghers to tourists to working people to punks. "He was the one who built this oasis in the midst of this dirt and chaos," says Roderick MacDonald, a principal trumpet player and the only American currently in the orchestra.
The political and economic isolation of East Bloc countries preserved prewar conditions long since eroded in the West. Culture in East Germany, despite insistently progressive propaganda from on high, was an almost quaint haven of bourgeois idealist values. The Gewandhaus Orchestra's special character, with its dark string tone, plangent winds and old-fashioned instrument design (rotary trumpets, for instance), was reinforced by the inability of Gewandhaus players to gravitate freely to other orchestras and the unwillingness of most Westerners to play in Leipzig. Within the city itself, the Gewandhaus was a haven for musicians and audiences alike. Masur designed it that way, with spacious foyers and a big, comfortable cafeteria. "For us, it was a home here before 1989," recalls MacDonald with a twinge of nostalgia.
Watching a Gewandhaus rehearsal within the hall's gleaming confines -- a hall planned to the tiniest detail by Kurt Masur, although one suspects he graciously allowed the architects and acousticians a say -- gives only a hint of Masur's authority. The rehearsals proceed with the relaxed collegiality that can only come from long and friendly association. Masur is open-shirted and informal, sweeping the orchestra along without a baton in big, choppy, bearlike gestures, encouraging comment from the players yet maintaining genial, firm discipline.
Backstage, the true power structure of the place becomes manifest. One passes into Masur's inner chambers through a waiting room transformed into a sort of Japanese shrine; his wife, Tomoko Sakurai, is Japanese. The office itself, flanked by his deferential secretary's quarters, is spacious and grand, adorned with personal and Gewandhaus memorabilia. The Gewandhaus hierarchy seems strikingly simple. There is no chief administrative officer; Masur does that, too. With fax and telephone -- the conductor's radio phone is the only sure way to make contact with the outer world, given the continued vagaries of the telephone system in eastern Germany -- Masur is in constant contact with home base. "Masur has his hand in almost everything here," MacDonald says. "It's a good example of an old-style Kapellmeister. He has to pass on the hiring of everyone, from orchestra players to coat-check people. Everything has to go through him, but he does make time for it."
Certainly he seems admired, even beloved, by his musicians. "Masur is so strong a personality that he influences every musical institution in the city," says Hartmut Brauer, the head of the orchestra's elected governing committee. "The orchestra and he are more close now than ever. We need him as a musician and as a force in the city." Masur, for his part, is particularly proud that despite severe economic privations no member of his ensemble has yet fled to the West for higher wages.
The orchestra that he has rebuilt over the last two decades is a fascinating study in idiomatic provinciality opening up toward international-style excellence. In the United States, auditions are "blind" to minimize favoritism (or racism). In Leipzig, they are right out in the open, and favoritism is just another word for tradition. With 85 percent of its members graduates of the Leipzig Conservatory, with sons and students of present and former players rife within its ranks ("One could see it as nepotism, but it isn't," says Hans Jung, a member of the orchestra committee), the Gewandhaus lacks, quite completely, the aggressive brilliance that defines a top Western orchestra like the New York Philharmonic. "We don't like to take outsiders, especially strings," Masur explains. "We have our own style."
The Gewandhaus's spacious, soft acoustics reinforce the relaxed musical image. A performance of Ravel's flashy "La Valse" as part of a concert to open the annual Leipzig Fair hardly challenged the gleaming authority of, say, the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch. But Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony proved satisfying in ways that probed beneath merely note-perfect execution. In music close to the Leipzig tradition, which just happens to be the music at the center of the Western concert repertory -- Bach, Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven, Schumann, Mendelssohn, Brahms, Bruckner -- this ensemble sings with a naturalness that provides deep musical rewards.
THAT SONIC IMAGE IS A mirror of Masur's own musical preferences. When asked who had most influenced him, Masur instantly cited Bruno Walter. Walter was a Gewandhaus predecessor. But he was also (more in his American old age than in his European youth) a gentle lyricist seemingly removed from Masur's sterner directness. "I felt especially close to Walter after I read his autobiography, to his entire image as a man and artist," Masur says. "Toscanini fascinated me, but his was not my style. And of course Furtwangler, because of his ability to define structure and his emotional power, although he was bound to his time; we couldn't play that Romantically today."
Even if he isn't absolutely convincing with every composer he tries, that may be an unrealistic expectation. As Renee Siebert, a Philharmonic flutist for 17 years and chairwoman of its main elected committee, puts it: "Conductors are treated unfairly in terms of repertoire. Unlike everybody else, they're expected to master everything. If they're smart, they stick with what they're good at, and get others to do the rest."
Says Masur: "I've tried to concentrate on the composers who were meaningful to the Gewandhaus tradition. We've played that music a lot; I've maybe conducted Beethoven's Third, Fifth and Seventh Symphonies two or three hundred times each. I get involved every time, with new elements and nuances, finding new things to do with a particular orchestra. The basic conception remains the same."
For Masur, variety can rejuvenate routine: "People ask, 'Aren't you bored after 21 years with one orchestra?' But I bring fresh ideas from the other orchestras. If the players in Leipzig complain that a passage can't be played as fast as I want it, I can say, 'I just heard it played that fast in Chicago.' In Leipzig, we can't play as perfectly as in Chicago. But sometimes we can play more beautifully.
"When I was in Dresden, I did lots of Mozart. My personal position to Mozart has always been to play him spiritually, rather than esthetically. I think the early-music movement is important, but one thing is dangerous, that we only play older music on original instruments. That's the big problem with so-called purism. We have an original-instruments group in the Gewandhaus, but we also have a long Bach tradition. The Romanticization of Bach is less dangerous than his objectification."
Masur has shied away from opera in recent decades. He says his experience as chief conductor of the Komische Oper in East Berlin in the 1960's, under the director Walter Felsenstein, soured him on the vagaries of conventional opera, with its star singers and limited rehearsals. But he does conduct a wide range of music, including contemporary music. "I feel the obligation to master as many styles as possible, in the spirit of the composer in his time," he says.
"For example, Tchaikovsky has a different meaning in Leningrad than elsewhere; he's not just salon music. In my journeys, I try to observe how the music is played in different places, to achieve security of style," he adds, citing the late Russian conductor Yevgeny Mravinsky's way with Tchaikovsky. "I pride myself that I have no particular style of conducting, and I make sure my students don't imitate me."
In 20th-century music, Masur has championed Eastern European composers, from Janacek to Prokofiev, Shostakovich and Alfred Schnittke. His favorite East German composer has been Siegfried Matthus, whose dramatic gifts and orchestral ingenuity don't disguise a fealty to mainstream classical tradition. Yet the conductor's tastes may be friskier than that. For his first Philharmonic concerts this week, he has included two pieces by the American avant-gardist John Adams, along with Aaron Copland and Bruckner's Seventh Symphony.
"His reaction to the hundred or so American pieces we showed him was really interesting," says Jon Deak, the Philharmonic's associate principal double-bassist, head of its artistic advisory committee and himself an experimental composer. "First of all, he reads scores like comic books, which is very refreshing. He said a lot of the music showed a certain grayness and safeness. He really liked the guys who are taking chances."
MASUR IS NOW 64 years old. His entire career was fostered by the old East German regime, from postwar studies in Leipzig (he spent the last months of the war as a 17-year-old draftee in Holland) to engagements in Breslau, Leipzig, Dresden, Schwerin, East Berlin, Dresden again and then to the Gewandhaus. In Leipzig, he managed to cajole local officials and the Erich Honecker regime in East Berlin to underwrite his new concert hall, and he always traveled freely.
As a backlash against his post-1989 democratic prestige, there were hints that his liberalization was an opportunistic sham, and that like the former secret-police officials and Party functionaries who share his comfortable, leafy Leipzig residential neighborhood, he was somehow compromised. Those charges rose up in ugly fashion with recent tabloid insinuations that his culpability in a 1972 auto accident had been covered up by the Communists. He has always admitted responsibility for the crash, on the Autobahn between Berlin and Leipzig, which killed not only two young men in an oncoming car but also his second wife and left him temporarily paralyzed and traumatized. "For me, it was more a spiritual crisis than a physical one," he says. "I stopped conducting for months. Finally, the orchestra urged me to attempt Bach's Mass in B Minor. I started using only two fingers to conduct, but then it was all right."
Clearly he was a prized cultural export item for the Communists, and clearly his ability to combine idealism with practicality served him well. But no one has suggested damaging complicity on his part before 1989. He took real chances in the 1970's, championing a dissident Soviet composer like Schnittke. His role as a leader in the East German democratization movement is indisputable. At considerable risk, he spoke out early and forcefully against police suppression of demonstrators. He invited figures from all walks of Leipzig life to participate in open forums at the Gewandhaus -- the main demonstrations were taking place just outside, on Karl-Marx-Platz -- which defused potentially violent confrontations and eased the way toward reform.
Friedrich Magirius, a Lutheran pastor who was a leader of the democratization movement and who now serves as the second-highest municipal official, the city president, is a staunch Masur admirer. "Some people complain that he dealt with the old powers," Magirius concedes. "But of course he had to -- we all did."
The possibility that he might have become President of East Germany in its last months was real. "The orchestra asked him not to do it," says Brauer, the orchestra committee head. "I believe he accomplished more as Kapellmeister than he could have as President. He would have been a politician against his will." Masur refused to join a political party, calculating that his influence might be undermined by affiliation with any interest group. He makes light of those who still think of him as a potential political figure. "A politician who conducts Beethoven isn't believable," he says with a laugh.
Even today, though, Masur serves as an advocate of former East Germans against the injustices of unification, protesting widespread unemployment, too-rapid privatization and the abolition of cultural and scholarly institutions by competitors in western Germany. "You can't impose bureaucratic rules on a sick land," he argues. "There are legal rights and there are moral rights. Our fear is not that we will lose our musicians, but that the public won't have enough money to buy tickets." (At a Gewandhaus subscribers' forum, one concertgoer pointed out that a ticket still cost the equivalent of four beers, and figured that was a pretty good deal.)
His harrowing experiences in 1989 may not have altered his musical style significantly, but they did reinforce his self-confidence as an artist. "It made me stronger," he says. "It taught me to overcome fear. People saw more clearly what kind of artist I was. There are stars who are only interested in the gifts of their art, but not connected to the people. The events of 1989 brought us in the Gewandhaus closer to our public."
His political prominence may have tipped the balance in his favor during the Philharmonic's search for a music director. Dawn Riggs, then chairwoman of the main Philharmonic players' committee, spoke at the time of his "unimpeachable moral and musical integrity." "Music," Masur reiterates earnestly and often, "must be more than entertainment for two hours in an evening." It is an idealistic attitude that echoes the motto of the Gewandhaus, emblazoned above the stage in a Latin phrase from Seneca that translates: "To provide true joy is a serious business."
Masur has a stern side, an abrupt temper that can cow employees and awaken stereotypes of tyrannical Teutonism. Some Philharmonic players were nervous that he might "come in here like some commandant," as Deak puts it, although any temperament he has shown so far has been rationalized as a byproduct of his passion for excellence.
But there is a playfulness, too, as in a favorite stunt in which he stops up a gently spouting fountain in a Gewandhaus courtyard until it explodes with pent-up pressure. When he says things like "I don't want to be called a 'wonder' -- the wonder is the music," you believe him. "He takes the music and us very seriously," Deak says. "It's not a showcase for him, not just another stop for his bio, and we respond to that."
Masur's self-image is perhaps best summed up in a story he told late one afternoon at his Leipzig home: "I once heard a lousy performance of 'Eine Kleine Nachtmusik' in Tashkent. I asked the conductor, 'How could you tolerate that?' He said, 'You people from Western Europe think you're better. I was born here and I live here. In 1,000, years this orchestra will play it better, but I'm proud that I've been able to improve them a couple of millimeters.' I felt ashamed, and learned a great lesson from that."
THOUGH MASUR HAS A DRIVER and a security gate and a swimming pool with a removable cover for year-round usage, all of which sets him far above the average Leipziger, his home seems positively middle class by American standards. Orchestras closely guardsuch figures, but it is safe to assume that Masur will easily earn more than $1 million this season, from all sources. Certainly, the new home he is seeking -- mostly likely in or near Rye, N.Y., the site of a good German-language school for his 14-year-old son, Ken David -- will be far grander than this.
Still, it's comfortable and private; when the leaves fill out the trees, he says conspiratorially, one can swim in the nude. Aside from Ken David, the product of his marriage with Sakurai, a now 41-year-old violist and soprano, there is a daughter from his second marriage, Carolin, 24, a mezzo-soprano who lives and studies in Berlin, and three older offspring from his first marriage, which ended in divorce. There is also a big, bouncing dog named Caesar, who with all due respect to his human family seems to be Masur's favorite. Everyone seems genuinely to like one another; it's an affectionate house.
Ken David, who attended a Japanese school near London last year, is a sweet and modest boy who plays chamber music with his family. Masur can still negotiate his way around a keyboard with a dapper touch, despite a crippled right hand dating from his teens. The crippling was caused by an inoperable tendon condition and is what made him switch to conducting in the first place. With his imposing, hearty manner, Masur seems in vibrant good health, though he had an angina scare last year, diagnosed as brought on by stress from all his political and musical overachieving. He says now that his heart is firmly under control.
The Masur-Sakurai marriage appears to be a true love match. It must have been, in order to persuade a 24-year-old Japanese woman playing in a Rio de Janeiro orchestra to abandon that glittering metropolis in favor of grim, oppressive Leipzig and a man 23 years her senior. She calls him "Elephant" as an endearment, and his favored clasp for the string ties he has worn since their marriage is a carved wooden elephant, a gift from her.
IT WOULD BE SILLY TO portray Masur as some innocent provincial. He has conducted the great orchestras of the world; he knows how the music business works; he has been impressively successful in winning corporate support for his beleaguered Gewandhaus, raising orchestra wages from a mere one-quarter to nearly two-thirds those of a comparable West German orchestra like the Munich Philharmonic. An this despite uttering gloomy complaints that "marketing seems to rule the world."
He will be aided in his foray into New York by the fact that German conductors are enjoying a new cachet in the United States. There seems to be a fresh yearning for the orchestral discipline and mainstream authority, undistracted by flashy virtuosity or trendy accretions from early music or modernist composition.
"His first concert with us after his appointment was Mendelssohn's 'Elijah' last December," recalls Siebert, the Philharmonic flutist. "The rehearsals were very inspirational. He thoroughly knew the piece, the text, the spiritual meanings behind every word and how the music related to those meanings. It was wonderful."
In the "Elijah" performances, Masur was substituting for Leonard Bernstein. "Those 'Elijahs' were very sentimental," Deak says. "I myself have played 'Elijah' up to here. Masur stopped the first rehearsal after the first couple of pages and said -- I can't quote him exactly -- that there is the god of love and the god of fear and we weren't taking the difference seriously enough. Within 10 minutes, everyone was giving it their all. It was a big experience; it's why we become musicians. Lenny would have loved it."
In his plans for New York, Masur wants to import some of the ideas he has espoused in Leipzig. "He's used the word 'partnership' a lot with us," Siebert said. His programming agenda includes a series that offers comprehensive looks at a composer's work in chronological order or in historical context. In Leipzig, for instance, there were concerts combining Beethoven piano concertoswith Bruckner symphonies, and others with symphonies by Shostakovich and Beethoven.
Masur is also a great believer in the cultivation of youth. This means conducting conservatory orchestras wherever he goes, forging alliances that can infuse a city's professional orchestra. It also means active involvement in young people's concerts. For him, a cultural tradition is not something simply inherited. "The tradition was lost in Leipzig, too, after the war," he says. "It had to be rebuilt, step by step."
When his New York appointment was announced, he left vague his intentions about Leipzig, other than to say he would stay there through its 250th season in 1992-3. Now he's reinforced his commitment to both cities. After some juggling, he assumed the music directorship in New York a year earlier than the originally announced 1992-3 season. But he also agreed to stay on in Leipzig indefinitely. The reason is that he was concerned about the morale of the Gewandhaus Orchestra and of Leipzig itself, and felt that their casual abandonment would be unconscionable. "We're thankful that he's here and for all that he's accomplished," says Magirius, the city president. "It's very, very important that he stays."
Masur says now that he will cut down guest engagements and reside in both New York and Leipzig for more than five months each, sinking his roots as deeply into New York's musical life as he has already done in Leipzig. "There will be no problem," he contended at a New York news conference a few months ago. "It's like a marriage and a lover." He didn't say which was which.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Recession Spurs Connecticut Tax Sales

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AT 10 A.M. on Aug. 22, Virgilio's, a defunct restaurant on Highland Avenue, was auctioned by the Town of Cheshire to satisfy a delinquent tax bill of $45,900. About 15 people showed up on the steps of Town Hall, but no one bid.
So the town has, in essence, bought the property for back taxes, but it cannot take title for a year. In that time, the owner, a consortium of Bridgeport businessmen called Coastal Associates, or the mortgage lender, may redeem it by paying the taxes plus 1 1/2 percent interest a month, or 18 percent a year, mandated by state law. 
 "I thought the bank would be there bidding, but they didn't come," said Michael A. Milone, the town's Finance Director. Connecticut National Bank carries a first mortgage of $250,000 on the property and Frank and Margaret Calabro, original owners of the restaurant, hold a second mortgage of $350,000. Don Holley, Cheshire's tax collector, said the property is assessed at $875,000, "but the market value has probably dropped from $1.2 million in 1988 to around $700,000."
Connecticut National Bank stayed away, according to Drayton Heard, senior vice president in Hartford, because "I don't think the sale was a good market test of the value of the property."
The bank has scheduled a foreclosure sale for Nov. 2, he said. "People who are accustomed to buying in this manner will come, and there should be many more active bidders," he said.
In a tax-sale auction, the successful bidder undertakes to pay the taxes but does not acquire title for a year. If the owner chooses to end his delinquency, he will owe the successful bidder, the buyer in waiting, 18 percent interest on the taxes that the bidder has been paying.
The town's goal is to get the taxes paid up, but the process has the effect of putting pressure on owners or their mortgage lenders, who may be planning foreclosure procedures or already started them, to pay up sooner.
"So many towns are doing these auctions that we have been holding classes on tax sales, foreclosures and bankruptcies," said Patricia Moisio, tax collector in Redding and president of the Connecticut Tax Collectors Association. "This will be the first time that I have held a tax sale in the 12 years I've had my job. It's becoming routine after efforts to collect or make payment arrangements have been exhausted."
If the bank holds a successful auction on the Cheshire property, the town expects all back taxes to be paid when title transfers.
Among the buyers attracted to a recent tax-sale auction in the town of Guiford were Sharon Silvestrini and Diane Robinson, owners of the Evergreen Galleries. On April 26 they paid $8,495 for a new house at 181 East River Road auctioned by the Guilford tax collector. The builder, William Bailey, marketed it at $350,000 but never sold it. He has until April 1992 to reclaim it.
"It's a great investment," Ms. Robinson said. "Where else can we get 18 percent on our money, or if he doesn't pay up, a house for $8,495?"
BARBARA KOHLS, Guilford's tax collector, started out with 34 properties for the April sale. Most of them paid up before the deadline, seven were auctioned and seven were withdrawn because of bankruptcies. Six properties belonging to Thomas Doyle, a local developer who declared bankruptcy, included raw land, a commercial building and a house. Another bankruptcy, filed by Gorbach Properties of New Haven, a lien holder rather than an owner, was filed the day before the sale.
"I didn't realize that a lien holder can put a property out of reach by declaring bankruptcy to protect his interest in it," Ms. Kohls said.
As the recession deepened, preparations for tax sales became more complex and time consuming. Title searches are necessary so that each lien holder can be notified. The county sheriff and the property owners must be notified, and newspaper notices are required for three consecutive weeks, with the sale scheduled within 10 weeks of the first notice.
"It's a lot less trouble to wait for the banks,' Ms. Kohls admits, "but I feel the town needs the money now."
Three condominium units were sold for $15,000, $22,000 and $26,000. If the high bidder paid more than the amount of the tax bill, the excess was placed in escrow for a year, after which it will be turned over to the taxpayer or lien holder.
A three-quarter-acre parcel of marshland on Long Island Sound was bought by the Guilford Land Conservation Trust for $1,500, and 9,500 square feet of a commercial condominium building on the Post Road went for $6,500. The remaining unit of 3,100 square feet is owned by a 1989 buyer who paid $250,000 for it.
Larger cities seem to prefer turning over negotiations and foreclosure sales to lawyers, as opposed to having municipal tax sales. "Their lists of delinquent properties are much longer, the buildings are larger, more complex, they can involve abandonments and long hours of research that tax collectors are not equipped to handle," said Ms. Moisio, the Redding tax collector.
THE firm of Salvin and Salvin in Wilton limits its practice to tax delinquencies and handles the work for the City of Norwalk. "The number of cases has increased tremendously in the past three years," said Arthur Salvin. "People just plain don't have the money. Businesses are not doing business, and it's almost impossible to get a loan. The chief problem this year has been builders who own several pieces of property of high value that they are not able to sell or finance."
Lawyers' fees, set by the court, can vary from a high of 10 percent of the outstanding amount to as little as 0.5 percent, plus court costs consisting of a $125 filing fee and sheriff's fees for serving defendants, but averaging around $75.
"Sometimes the amount owed is in the hundreds of thousands of dollars," said Mr. Salvin, "in which case a 10 percent fee would be unconscionable."
Waterbury uses its City Attorney, George Tzepos. "We have 175 foreclosures pending in court," he said. "We prefer foreclosure sales to tax sales because they are definite. They do not tie up property for a year."
"However," he added, "we are exploring going back to tax sales with a strategy I don't wish to disclose at present."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

QUILTS AND SPREADS
More than 400 quilts, from antique to contemporary and from all over the country, will be exhibited for sale at prices ranging from $75 to $2,000 at the Stamford Historical Society's giant Quilt Show, on Friday from noon to 6 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. 
 The Stamford 350th anniversary commemorative quilt, made over a two-year period by the society's volunteers, will be on display. After presentation to the city's Mayor last May, it was shown at various corporate headquarters downtown before returning to the Historical Society, its permanent home. Measuring 8 by 12feet, it contains 30 squares depicting the city's history. Among them are a Post Road mail carrier of the 1680's, the 1705 Knapp House that still stands on Stillwater Road, the original railroad station, the First Presbyterian Church (dubbed Fish Church because of its shape), and the contemporary skyline with the G.T.E. Building, General Reinsurance and Landmark Buildings.
Quilt tops and spreads, food, trompe l'oeil painted furniture, collectibles and anniversary quilt notecards will also be for sale.
The Historical Society is at 1508 High Ridge Road and admission is free. The phone number is 322-1565.
 
POLISH CULTURE
 Central Connecticut State University in New Britain will be steeped in Polish culture through Oct. 20, while a Polish Arts Celebration continues, open to the public without charge.
An exhibit called "Voices from Krakow: Contemporary Prints from Poland" consists of aquatints, plaster prints, woodcuts, linocuts, etchings and lithographs by artists associated with the Academy of Fine Arts in Krakow. A companion exhibition, "Touched by Angels: Polish Folk Art," includes carvings, reverse-glass paintings, Christmas creches and paper cutouts.
Both exhibits may be seen in the Samuel S. T. Chen Art Center at Stanley and Wells Streets on the campus. Hours are Monday through Friday from 1 to 4 P.M. and Sunday from 2 to 5 P.M. Gallery talks by university faculty members will be given at 2:30 P.M. on Sept. 22 and at 7:30 P.M. on Sept. 26.
On Sept. 21 two Polish film classics will be screened in Welte Hall. "Ashes and Diamonds," an Andrzej Wajda film about a resistance fighter in World War II who assassinates the wrong man, will be shown at 7 P.M., followed at 9 by the Roman Polanski film "Knife in the Water," which deals with intense relationships among three people on a yacht. Free tickets may be reserved by calling 827- 7322.
"A New Vision for Peace and Justice in the 1990's" is the subject of a lecture to be delivered by the Rev. William Sloane Coffin at 8 P.M. on Sept. 28 in the Student Center Ballroom. More information is available by calling 827-7000.
 
MEN AND WOMEN
 Men and women are invited to a free session of the Men's Counseling Centers to be held in Westport on Friday from 7:30 to 9:30 P.M. at the Public Library, Bernhard Plaza. The topic will be "What Men Really Want and Need, and Their Difficulty Getting It From Women." Dr. Robert Helfand and Dr. Louis Kopolow, directors of the counseling centers, will lead the discussion. They said their purpose is to define "deep masculinity" and to foster the growth of a men's movement as a positive and compassionate response to the women's movement.
The organization will also sponsor a wilderness adventure for men on Sept. 21 and 22 at Camp Pomperaug in Union. The fee will be $135. For more information call 748-3241.
 
KITCHENS IN HISTORY
 Eating your way through eight kitchens dating from 1690 to 1990 in Moodus, East Haddam and Hadlyme will be the order of the day on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., when the East Haddam Historical Society has scheduled its Cook's Tour fund-raising event. Tickets, $12 each, may be picked up on Saturday, along with self-guiding maps, at the Amasa Day House on Moodus Green, or ordered in advance for $10 by calling 873-8144.
Homeowners will be on hand at each house, providing recipes and tastings of their specialties, ranging from 1800's Connecticut Western Reserve breakfast gingerbread to baked beans to salsa and tortilla chips.
The 1690's house actually has three kitchens: the original, a lean-to built when the house was a tavern and a new one installed in 1989. A 19th-century country kitchen typically has a fireplace for cooking, beehive oven and tin roasting oven. A wood-burning stove is still in use for cooking in a 200-year-old farmhouse, and the latest word in cooking may be inspected in a brand-new all-digital kitchen.
 
ABOUT WRITING
 Alfred Kazin, the critic, writer and teacher, will give a talk titled "An Old Man Mad About Writing" at 5 P.M. today in the Roxbury Congregational Church on Route 317.
The free informal lecture will focus on Mr. Kazin's more than 50 years as a writer, reader and reviewer for The New Republic, The New York Times, The New York Herald Tribune and Scribner's magazine. He has taught at Harvard, Berkeley, Cornell, Barnard and the City University of New York, and his most recent books are "A Writer's America: Landscape in Literature," published by Knopf in 1988, and "Our New York," Harper & Row, 1989.
 
SEEDLINGS AND FISH
 Each year the Fairfield County Soil and Water Conservation District in Bethel sells a limited number of seedling trees and a supply of fingerling trout for private ponds at below-market prices. Seedling evergreens are recommended as economical and decorative replacements for trees lost in the recent storms. They are sold at 6 to 10 inches in height and grow at a rate of 8 to 14 inches a year. Balsam fir, Eastern white pine, Scotch pine, white spruce, Colorado blue spruce and Canadian hemlock are the varieties available. Orders must be placed by Sept. 20, and 25 seedlings cost $15 to $20, depending on the species; 100 are sold for $40 to $45. Larger amounts are sold at greater discounts.
Rainbow and brown trout fingerlings are for sale at $26 for 50 fish. The rainbow trout are bred for ponds and grow quickly, bite well and put on spectacular aerial displays. Brown trout survive on lower oxygen levels, are sometimes hard to catch and are better at resisting acid rain. They also prey on fingerlings that are stocked later. Fish must be ordered by Sept. 27. They come in a plastic bag in which they can survive for about two hours. Call 744-6108 to order or obtain more information.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Extracting Siberian Oil

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Big oil companies remain wary about pledging billions to ventures in the vast oilfields of the Soviet republics. But a deal joining Phibro Energy Inc. of Greenwich, Conn.; a Houston-based independent, Anglo-Suisse Inc., and a Russian oil association nearly a year ago is already providing the Russians with foreign currency from crude exports.
Several other independent oil companies in the West had signed deals before the coup attempt last month, but few have moved as rapidly as the Phibro-Anglo-Suisse group, called White Nights. A Russian oil cooperative has 50 percent ownership. 
 "Our history of dealing with the Russians was that it might take months to hammer out a contract, but once it was done, the Soviets honored their commitments," said Ronald H. Benson, a Phibro executive who is president of White Nights. The group has nearly 1,000 workers, including more than 900 Soviet workers hardened to life in western Siberia.
Those harsh conditions and the collapsing Soviet economy have taken a toll on some Texans and Oklahomans. Gilles Labbe, president of Anglo-Suisse, said that this summer he fired two American administrators who were frustrated by the bureaucracy.
Yet production is rising. Output in three fields operated by White Nights has grown to 22,000 barrels a day and will reach 400,000 by 1996, Mr. Labbe said. Another deal signed in July among the same partners, called Golden Mammoth, will pump 600,000 barrels a day in five years, from 25,000 today, he said.
White Nights expects to invest $1 billion over 20 years and to drill more than 500 wells in three fields that hold 800 million barrels. Another $2 billion is expected to be spent in Golden Mammoth, which has two billion barrels of reserves, Mr. Labbe said.
Oil experts gauge the Soviet Union's total oil reserves at about 60 billion barrels. But some geologists say the region could surpass Saudi Arabia, with its proven reserves of 250 billion barrels.
Big Oil seems certain to join the hunt soon. Matthew Sagers, an analyst at PlanEcon, a consulting firm in Washington, said deals with Western companies could increase Soviet oil output by four million barrels a day in 1994, from about 10 million barrels today.

HEADLINE: Presidential Life's Embattled Founder Takes to the Stump

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

DATELINE: NYACK, N.Y.

 BODY:
Several months ago, as public jitters over the safety of high-yield junk bonds were sending the giant insurer Executive Life down its long road to ruin, Herbert Kurz went on the defensive. If policyholders of his Presidential Life Insurance Company got nervous, the junk bond-laden insurer could also face a destructive run.
So he drove to New York City, where he lectured at length to financial reporters about how Presidential differed from Executive Life. A few months later, Mr. Kurz was again on the stump, this time scolding a California news commentator for bad-mouthing Presidential on a radio talk show. Just a few weeks ago, he urged a group of insurance agents who sell his company's policies to ignore predictions that Presidential could be the industry's next fatality. 
 While other insurers have larger junk portfolios in absolute terms, Presidential is now the industry's junk-bond leader in relative measure. At the end of 1990, more than half of its $2.3 billion in assets, or $1.28 billion, was invested in junk. These high-yield holdings equaled 12 times its capital and surplus, the cushion it keeps against losses. Only Executive Life, which collapsed last April after scores of policyholders cashed in during a junk-bond scare, had a similar percentage.
The 71-year-old Mr. Kurz, who founded Presidential 25 years ago and almost singlehandedly built it into one of the country's larger life insurers, argues that several factors distinguish his company from Executive Life. Indeed, its junk bonds are of much higher quality than were Executive Life's.
For now, no one is predicting -- at least not publicly -- that Presidential will fail. According to New York insurance regulators, the company remains firmly solvent and has been able to meet all requests for policy redemptions. Presidential is also one of the more profitable companies in the life insurance industry, with returns on shareholders' equity consistently in the high teens.
But then, Executive Life was among the industry's biggest money makers before its demise. And that similarity, along with Presidential's heavy exposure to junk bonds, is why Mr. Kurz's company, more than any other life insurer, has faced such intense scrutiny since Executive Life's fall and spooked so many analysts.
"We're watching the company's earnings and bond portfolio extremely closely," said Philip Tsang, who follows Presidential for Standard & Poor's.
Many others have been, too. Presidential's stock, traded over the counter, has plummetted from a peak of $14 in November 1989, closing at $3.125 on Friday. Its policyholders, while by no means showing signs of panic, have been cashing in their Presidential policies at a quicker pace: In the first six months of 1991, they redeemed Presidential annuity contracts worth $176.9 million, up from $146 million for all of 1990.
And Moody's and Standard & Poor's have both rated Presidential's claims-paying ability to be weak relative to that of competitors. While the bulk of the bonds in Presidential's portfolio are paying the interest and principal due on them, Robert Riegel, the Presidential analyst at Moody's, says "with their sort of exposure, a hit here or there could significantly weaken the company."
And because the two rating agencies wield substantial clout in shaping insurance agents' opinions about which life insurers can be counted on to make payments over the long haul, the decision by Moody's and Standard & Poor's to assign Presidential a mediocre rating could hamper Presidential's ability to sell policies in the future.
Clearly, Mr. Kurz is on the firing line. While maintaining that Presidential's strategy is sound, Mr. Kurz, responding to critics and taking advantage of the high prices junk bonds are fetching now, began selling some of his bonds several weeks ago. Even so, Presidential still has what by industry standards is a high exposure to junk bonds: 45 percent of total assets.
Mr. Kurz, who stands a lean 6 feet, 5 inches tall, started out in the business as a rather conservative investor. A World War II Air Force navigator and Brooklyn College economics graduate, Mr. Kurz quit his uncle's X-ray equipment company to sell life insurance. Later, in 1966, he formed Presidential to sell "term" life insurance, a type of coverage that provides only insurance protection; it has no savings component. When Presidential's term insurance business was firmly established, Mr. Kurz moved Presidential into the annuity business in the early 1970's. At first he invested the company's annuity dollars in short-term, corporate I.O.U.'s known as commercial paper. But as the market for annuities grew, Presidential moved heavily into junk bonds.
As was the case with Executive Life, many of the junk bonds Presidential purchased in those early days -- and many of the bonds that remain in its portfolio today -- were sold by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street firm that went under after Federal law enforcement officials accused it of securities-law violations. Mr. Kurz, who counts Michael Milken, the former head of Drexel's junk-bond operation, as a friend, says Presidential accumulated such a large junk-bond portfolio in part because of Mr. Milken's urging.
But Mr. Kurz insists that the two insurers are a world apart. Executive Life, he maintains, purchased the great bulk of junk bonds Drexel presented, while Presidential was more selective, typically buying only one in seven bond issues and ultimately one in 40 issues once Drexel's legal problems started to surface.
Executive Life was also more vulnerable to a customer run because it sold its policies through stockbrokers rather than insurance agents. The agents tend to be more loyal to the insurer and thus more likely than a stockbroker to encourage nervous customers to sit tight rather than cash in their policies when rumors start, Mr. Kurz said.
Executive Life was also vulnerable by virtue of the size of its clients. It sold so-called guaranteed investment contracts, or G.I.C.'s, which promise locked-in interest rates, to pension clients, one or two of which had the power to bring the company to its knees by withdrawing their money. Presidential's clients, in contrast, are much smaller. And unlike Executive Life, which was known for bolstering its capital with accounting gimmickry, Presidential has a reputation for keeping clean books.
Moreover, to this day, Presidential has virtually no commercial mortgages or real estate on its books, two areas that have produced chaos at other large insurers. "We missed most of the problem areas," Mr. Kurz said in an interview at Presidential's headquarters here last week.
And Presidential's junk portfolio, while highly risky, appears to be healthier than Executive Life's. As of June 30, many of Presidential's bonds were higher-quality junk -- companies rated "BB" by Standard & Poor's, like Chiquita Brands. But the largest portion were rated "B," including the FMC Corporation and Bell & Howell. While these debtors are making all of their principal and interest payments, they are viewed by rating agencies as posing a markedly greater risk of default than "BB" bonds. An additional 8.7 percent of Presidential's bonds were rated "CCC" or lower, meaning that specific business developments have made them candidates for default. Executive Life had a higher percentage of "C"-rated bonds.
For their part, New York State regulators say there is nothing they can or would do to rein in Presidential. Terence Lennon, the chief of the New York Insurance Department's Life Insurance Bureau, noted that Presidential is paying all claims promptly, does not appear to be suffering a run and has repeatedly passed examiner's solvency tests.
"If the economy stays good and those junk-bond credits do well, Herb will make a lot of money," Mr. Lennon said.
But investors, rating agencies and some customers are uneasy about those if's. The junk bonds would be less of an issue if Presidential had substantial capital to cushion against losses. But Presidential's capital position has also become controversial. Mr. Tsang, the Standard & Poor's analyst who follows Presidential, argues that Presidential's capital, reported at $126 million as of June 30, is "conservative" for a company of its size.
But an analysis by Weiss Research, a West Palm Beach, Fla., firm that rates insurance companies, found that, based on historical bond default rates, Presidential's capital could be easily wiped out in a recession. "Basically, Kurz has been telling people that he is low-risk and high-yield and that is just not true," said Martin Weiss, the president of Weiss Research.
Presidential fared relatively well in the current downturn, said Weiss Research, because many of its junk bonds were issued by manufacturing companies, which were not hit as hard as the service sector. Unless the company unloads some of its junk, the company, it said, might not be as fortunate the next time the economy slumps.
Until now, Mr. Kurz has been able to confound even his sharpest critics. Presidential would have to suffer at least $126 million in losses on its junk bonds to wipe out its capital cushion and become insolvent. So far, the losses have been nowhere near that.
Last year, for instance, Presidential reported "realized capital losses" of $5.9 million, or well under 1 percent of the company's total assets. The figure refers to performing bonds that have been sold at a loss or to bonds in default that have been sold. In addition, Presidential reported "unrealized losses," meaning losses from bonds that have gone into default but have not yet been disposed, of $73.9 million.
Presidential has also had more than enough investment income -- some $260.8 million last year -- to offset its losses.
What is more, the losses seem to be narrowing. In the first six months of this year, realized and unrealized losses were only $12.8 million.
"The key difference is that we know how to make money," said Mr. Kurz. "With profits, we can make a few errors."
But critics say that the decline in its losses on junk bonds has little to do with the health of Presidential's bonds. Rather, they say, it reflects the drop in interest rates, which has driven up prices of junk bonds and allowed Presidential to sell its junk at less of a loss or even a gain.
If Mr. Kurz has emerged as Presidential's leading cheerleader, it should come as no surprise. In addition to being the architect of the company's junk-bond policy, Mr. Kurz still owns roughly a third of the company's 28 million shares. As the stock as fallen, Mr. Kurz has seen the value of his personal holdings decline by more than $100 million.
Mr. Kurz has been spending his days writing letters to agent groups encouraging them not to write the company off. In coming weeks, Mr. Kurz will meet with more agent and customer groups and is set to talk about Presidential on a local radio talk show.
Defending Presidential is a challenge he seems to relish. "I built this company in my image," he said. "When someone makes it bleed, I bleed."
 
 
WHY CONFIDENCE IS KEY
Ultimately, of course, the outcome at Presidential could turn on policyholder confidence. Presidential's chief, Herbert Kurz, insists that the company is extremely liquid.
That means his company could sell its entire junk-bond portfolio and pay off the vast majority of Presidential's annuity and life insurance policy holders without suffering a loss on the transaction.
This is largely a consequence of the fact that many of Presidential's junk bonds are paying sky-high interest and thus have risen in value as interest rates have fallen.
But interest rates could turn. Critics note that if rates were to rise sharply, Presidential's junk bonds would fall in value and the company would not have as easy a time meeting policy redemptions. While Presidential might then still have the means to pay everyone who came knocking, all this assumes that policyholders don't panic and cash in their policies at once.
Given the events earlier this summer at Mutual Benefit Life, that assumption might have to be reconsidered. The giant Newark-based insurer failed because concerns over Mutual Benefit's mortgage investments sent hordes of policyholders streaming through Mutual Benefit's doors for refunds.
"Even if Presidential doesn't face major defaults on its junk bonds, there still is a big risk," said Ted Brownstein, the head of insurance ratings at Weiss Research, a West Palm Beach, Fla., firm.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Waiting to See How Far Gold Falls

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Already well in decline, gold has been dipping even further in the last two weeks. Some hopeful analysts are raising the possibility that gold is finally near its bottom, which would be a signal to buy. But for others, gold's dismal performance in recent years is such a bad memory that they are waiting -- even hoping -- that it will fall considerably more. Then, and only then, do they be expect a rally, even if it is just a small one.
On Friday, gold closed in London at 348.05 an ounce, its lowest level since June, 1990 and below the psychologically important $350 level. It dipped to $347 an ounce a week ago. 
 Warren Myers, a vice president at Merrill Lynch, expects that at the $350 level gold will find a secure bottom as demand picks up from jewelry manufacturers and investors in Japan and many developing nations, like those in the Middle East, where shaky economies sometimes make gold more attractive.
"I do believe that gold is locked in a trading range between where it is now and $390," Mr. Myers said. He said that getting beyond this range will take some "Armageddon" event.
While he is not predicting one, he cites four possibilities: A halt in gold production in South Africa, the world's largest producer, if a civil war were to break out; a disruption of the flow of gold from the new, more loosely defined Soviet Union; a significant jump in the United States budget deficit, already at record highs, or the failure of one or two major money center banks in the United States.
Alan Posnick, senior vice president of the MTB Banking Corporation, a New York gold coin dealer, said, "the message that gold is sending us is that it is the forgotten financial commodity."
He said that at $347, gold could be forming what analysts call a double, or solid, bottom on charts of gold prices. Normally, this would be a signal to buy. But, he added, "I would prefer that gold trade down to $325 and establish a new low."
His reason is this: Given the weak performance of gold in the last five years, "too many potential investors have seen gold stuck in this range for some time." But if gold moved $25 an ounce lower and then held there, investors might think it was really ready to rise again. The resultant buying, naturally, would be fine for a coin dealer like MTB Banking.
But even if gold holds at the $347-to-$350 level, Mr. Posnick still does not expect it to get higher than $365 to $375 by the end of the year.
Joseph Rosta, a research analyst for the CPM Group in New York, said the explanation for the drop is simple. "Traders and speculators decided that the price of gold did not have much room for appreciation in the near term, so they bailed out and took their assets elsewhere," he said.
Mr. Rosta, pointing to the $350 range in the prices for the December gold contracts on the New York Commodity Exchange, expects gold to hold at the $350 level. But he said there is still a chance gold could break loose and fall to around $320.
This would happen if the price moves decisively below the $350 level. On the charts many analysts use to follow gold, the next stop below $350 is around $320. Orders to sell based on these charts could push the price down that low rather quickly.
"The trend of gold has been downward from $370 an ounce on March 8," added David A. Poole, chief economist at International Investors Inc., a gold fund in New York. "You really cannot call a change in the trend so far."
 
Bonds Are Up
 Americans investing in foreign bonds had their third-best month of the year in August. The gains averaged 1.89 percent after exchange rate fluctuations were factored in, according to the J. P. Morgan government-bond index.
The best markets were in Spain, Canada and Australia. In those countries, local bond prices rose during August; the countries' currencies also rose against the dollar, giving investors a double gain.
But for the year so far, the sharp rise in the dollar has made Europe in general a bad place for American bond investors. While local bond prices have jumped sharply in Spain (13.95 percent) and Britain (12.31 percent), the peseta and the pound have dropped sharply against the dollar. The result is a 2.50 percent decline in Britain and a measly 0.34 percent rise in Spain, including the 3.18 percent jump in August.
The bond market rallies in local currencies have been boosted by cuts in official interest rates and investors' hopes for more to come. Strong improvement in inflation rates have also helped.
For example, much of the rally in Australian bonds, which were up 1.87 percent in August and 13.17 percent for the year in local terms, has come on the back of the Government's new emphasis on fighting inflation. The expectation is that Australian inflation could fall as low as two percent in the next year or so. In addition, the Government also cut its key short term interest rate one percentage point last week.
In Britain, the bond rally was sparked by official interest rate cut, including another half of a percentage point last week. And inflation, which had been double digit, is heading to below 5 percent.
