The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: September 8, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1607 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 1-6

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Why It Took So Long to Expose B.C.C.I. 

When the Justice Department unsealed six indictments against officials of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and a reputed leader of the Medellin drug cartel for money laundering, some wondered why it took so long. "Today's indictment should have occurred two or three years ago," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, who released a report last week critical of the slow pace. The problem, he said, is that leads were never followed up. Some suspect B.C.C.I.'s network of consultants and highly placed friends slowed discovery. The Internal Revenue Service said that in 1988 it gave information about B.C.C.I.'s secret ownership of American banks to the Federal Reserve; nothing happened. The Central Intelligence Agency, in 1986, knew about the money-laundering. "There is possibly a cover-up or conspiracy," Mr. Schumer said. "But it is also a 50 percent chance that it was just ineptitude."
 
An Apology of Sorts From P.& G.
 
When the Procter & Gamble Company admitted it had set in motion a probe of the records of 803,000 phones in Cincinnati, it was bad enough. The company was trying to find out which of its 94,000 employees had leaked information to The Wall Street Journal about P.& G.'s plans. But when Edwin L. Artz, P.& G.'s chairman, apologized in writing to the staff for snooping he may have angered even more people. He admitted the company did something wrong, he wrote he was embarrassed, but he asserted that the wrongdoing was for all the right reasons. P.& G., Mr. Artz wrote, "had a clear legal right to seek the assistance of the authorities to investigate potential damaging leaks of confidential company information." But to investigate an entire city? Legal suits against P.& G. are expected to follow.

Ford Goes Back to the Past
 
A little "freshening up" is how the stylists at the Ford Motor Company described their revisions on the 1992 Taurus and Sable models. They made the hood slope a little more, narrowed the headlights a tad and steamlined the dash. But without the warning, the changes could have gone unnoticed. The cars look surprisingly like the original 1985 models. What was sleek then (they resembled bars of Sweetheart soap, analysts said) may be dowdy now. "Ford's product renewal cycle is 10 years or more, while the Japanese are doing it in four," said James Harbour, a manufacturing consultant to the automotive industry. That is costing Ford market share. While the Taurus remains a 1985 fly caught in amber (engines and all), the Honda Accord has seen three new sets of skin, pushing the Taurus aside as the nation's No. 1 selling car.

Coke's Image Doctor
 
Coca-Cola may be one of the world's best-known trademarks, but after the "Coke II" fiasco -- a series of forgettable commercials and a promotion that featured a pop-up dollar bill that didn't pop up -- Coke's image needed some sprucing up. The company announced last week that it had hired Hollywood's premier power broker, Michael S. Ovitz, to help with its global marketing, advertising and image. (What exactly Mr. Ovitz will do, Coca-Cola did not say.) Mr. Ovitz is the talent agent who fashioned the deal to sell MCA Inc. to Japan's Matsushita Electric Company and Columbia Pictures to Japan's Sony Corporation. Mr. Ovitz, the chairman of Creative Artists Agency Inc., represents Hollywood celebrities like Madonna, Michael Jackson and Kevin Costner. Mr. Ovitz will need all the client clout he can get to match the sizzle of Diet Pepsi's Ray Charles spot, "You've got the right one baby, uh-huh."
 
Unisys Confesses
 
The Unisys Corporation pleaded guilty last week in a Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., to bribery, conspiracy and filing false claims with the Pentagon. Unisys will pay $190 million to settle the charges.

Punishment at Salomon
 
It was a week full of apologies. Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor who is interim chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., told a House subcommittee that he was sorry for "the actions that have brought us here." Then he presented a report to Congress about some of Salomon's wrongdoings. The report detailed what was a lax management style. It said Paul Mozer, Salomon's former head of the government trading desk, changed records of submitted bids and called in at least one unauthorized bid for a customer he was not even in touch with. It said the trading desk had "rules" about who could and could not approve illegal activities. The severity of the report must have persuaded Salomon to judge more harshly the top executives who resigned because of the scandal. The executives, including John H. Gutfreund, the former chairman, will not share in bonuses, will not get office space and will not be defended at Salomon's expense.
 
The British Treasury last week ousted Salomon from managing its sale of British Telecommunications stock in the United States.
 
Fast or Tasty?
 
With some home-delivered pizzas, it is hard to taste the difference between the cardboard and the crust. There have also been accidents -- some fatal -- as companies rush to deliver their pizzas faster than the competition. So Domino's Pizza Inc., which had $2.65 billion in sales last year and is first in home delivery, is fashioning a new $50 million ad campaign that emphasizes taste and downplays speed. The campaign is being created by Grey Advertising Inc. in New York. In these ads, said Edward H. Meyer, Grey's chairman, "the product plays the hero role."

 
 
ECONOMY

 
A Business Buying Spree
 
Every month, the National Association of Purchasing Management surveys 300 of the nation's largest companies on their ordering plans. Last week the association said its index surged to 54.8 percent in August, up from 51.8 percent in July. Anything above 50 percent denotes an economy that is expanding.

Autos Are Barely Moving
 
For the nation's car and truck makers 1991 is a year they would rather forget. Last week there was more bad news. Sales by domestic manufacturers during the last half of August slid 11.6 percent from the same period last year.

When Companies Defy Logic
 
Most economists abide by one rather dubious proposition: People behave rationally. Lower the price, economists say, and people will be only too happy to buy. So with interest rates falling and the price of money coming down, businesses should be borrowing and investing for the future. But according to the Commerce Department, companies will be increasing their investments in new plants and equipment this year by a scant 1.6 percent, far less than the 4.5 percent increase in 1990, when interest rates were high and the recession began. When the economy finally picks up, a number of supposedly rational companies may find they have too little capacity.

Interpreting the Jobless Rate
 
The unemployment picture could have been painted by a Cubist: it fuses together more than one perspective. The figures themselves, according to the Labor Department, were virtually unchanged for August with 6.8 percent of the work force still without jobs. On the positive side: Lots of new jobs were added in manufacturing. On the negative side: Construction and mining showed sharp declines. The markets saw the numbers and figured interest rates will fall further.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Space Station of One's Own
 
The Soviet space program -- the world's largest -- is running out of money. To keep it going (they still launch more than 100 payloads each year) the Soviets are turning to the West. One money-making project -- no one has said how much it made -- was an experiment paid for by the Coca-Cola Company. It was designed to measure what happens to the gases in soda when cosmonauts aboard the Mir orbiting space station drink Coke. Another project has been to sell trips on Mir. A Japanese company paid $12 million for a journalist to spend a week on Mir -- he was nauseous the whole time -- and some German, British and French guests have signed up. But last week the Soviets announced the unthinkable. They are considering selling the station altogether. For an estimated $600 million to $700 million, some lucky buyer could have a slightly used 100-foot-long space station 240 miles out in space. Considering NASA's plan to spend $30 billion to build a similar model, the Mir looks like a bargain.
 
Israel Wouldn't Wait
 
President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had asked Israel to delay its request for $10 billion in loan guarantees for at least 120 days. The Administration wants peace negotiations between Israel and its Arab neighbors to begin before it considers the request. But last week, Israel, confident it had strong support from Congress, made its request anyway. The aid -- which would probably cost the United States $50 million to more than $1 billion -- would allow Israel to borrow $10 billion in the capital markets at more favorable rates. Israel wants the money so it can construct housing for as many as a million Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union. The battle in Congress is expected to take months.

The Japan Scandal Grows
 
Tales about abuses in Japan's securities industry continue to surface. Last week, reports in Japanese newspapers -- confirmed by the Ministry of Finance -- told of rigged bidding for securities sold not only in Japan but in markets around the world. The bogus trades allowed individuals and companies to make illegal payments to each other outside the jurisdiction of Tokyo authorities.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2439 words

HEADLINE: Learning to Dance with a Bouncy Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

DATELINE: SUNNYVALE, Calif.

 BODY:
Robert J. Prantis is neither a software wizard nor a hardware guru. But when he loaded up his car and left Chicago two years ago to begin a new career in Silicon Valley, he was exactly what Sun Microsystems Inc., the hot young manufacturer of computer work stations, needed. His expertise was in the arcane world of currency markets and hedging against the sudden fluctuations in the value of the dollar. His move to Sun shows how sophisticated many American corporations have had to become at dealing with dollar volatility as they compete in the global marketplace.
Sun wooed Mr. Prantis away from the Beatrice Corporation because, like more and more American companies, it found itself heavily dependent on sales outside the United States -- more than 50 percent of its sales are abroad and involve as many as 20 different currencies. Sun did not want swings in the currency markets to throw its financial plans into chaos. And in the years since Mr. Prantis arrived, Sun has managed to minimize the impact of this volatility. 
 Sun isn't the only company that needs foreign exchange expertise. Last year, according to the Commerce Department, 19 percent of American corporate profits came from abroad, up from 11.7 percent in 1986. In the first quarter of this year that percentage rose to 23.8 percent. But a quick run-up in the dollar can dent a company's foreign sales and quarterly profits and even cause a sudden drop in the stock price. That's what happened to companies as varied as the Ford Motor Company and the Amdahl Corporation after the dollar soared in February and March and held most of its gains through the summer. The Polaroid Corporation, lost 11 cents per share in the first quarter because of the rise of the dollar.
"In a place like the United States, that is tied to the quarterly earnings report, foreign exchange is more and more a driving force," said Thomas J. Meredith, Sun's treasurer.
Many companies are being driven to expand their foreign exchange expertise by memories of the wreckage caused by the dollar's rise during the early 1980's, when it soared more than 50 percent, reaching all-time highs against many currencies. American goods suddenly became prohibitively expensive abroad, giving foreign competitors an edge and causing American exports to decline. Imports rose at home, as foreign products became cheaper for Americans to buy. The balance of trade worsened and American manufacturers were pummeled; entire industries went into decline.
Between 1980 and 1985, more than a million manufacturing jobs were lost, according to William H. Branson, an economics professor at Princeton University, and James P. Love, a lecturer at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton.
Corporate currency management and demand for experts like Mr. Prantis have thus grown with a vengeance. Although the immediate mission of the currency hedgers is to protect the next quarter's bottom line, at more and more companies -- Merck, Tandem Computers and Eastman Kodak, for example -- they also have instructions to look to the mid- and long-term, to anticipate broad trends in global interest rates and currency flows and to take steps to reduce the impact of such shifts or even ride them to additional profits.
 
Insurance Against Adversity
 To do this, the hedgers are growing ever more sophisticated. They are turning to familiar hedges, like contracting for delivery of a currency at a set price in the future to lock in the present dollar value of a big sale. But they are also using strategies like currency options, currency proxies and elaborate combinations of currency trading instruments. Many of these instruments are new and some are exotic, but they all basically buy insurance against an adverse move in the dollar. Corporate hedgers are also pushing accountants for additional rule changes to increase the opportunities for hedging.
And the most experienced companies are venturing into a broader type of hedging that can cross the line into strategic planning: economic hedging. This is an approach that looks years ahead, considers who the competitors will most likely be and how currency strategy relates to products, plant locations, labor and suppliers.
"People are starting to view foreign exchange with a much more strategic view," said Scott S. Silver, vice president of International Risk Control in Palo Alto, Calif., a consultant on currency hedging. "They are looking at how currency rates effect the competitive nature of their business, not just how it impacts their quarterly earnings. It is hedging on a grander scale."
To be sure, one reason chief financial officers and their staffs can hedge currency fluctuations with some success is that the dollar is less volatile overall than it was a decade ago. There will always be some sharp swings. But most experts say that the United States and its economic allies are doing a much better job coordinating economic and monetary policies in a way that helps reduce extreme moves in the $700 billion-a-day foreign exchange market.
 
Riding the Volatility
 And Sun Microsystems, as well as companies like Ingersoll-Rand, Colgate-Palmolive, International Paper, Dow Chemical and Hewlett-Packard are better prepared to ride out even the sharp swings of recent years, including the 27 percent rally since mid-February and the sudden fall of 6 percent in mid-July.
"No one likes the volatility, but you look to see what you can do within the movement," said Fred Lopatynski, manager of foreign exchange at Ingersoll-Rand. "People have learned to adapt and to adjust to it."
Added Hans Pohlschroeder, the manager of foreign exchange at Colgate-Palmolive: "In today's environment, where governments are talking more and trying to harmonize economic policies, we are getting more well-managed fluctuations of the dollar. And that will lead you to believe that you should be able to manage your currency positions well."
One measure of hedging growth is the rapid rise in corporate activity in the foreign exchange market. According to Greenwich Associates, a consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., total corporate trading volume has jumped to an average per company in 1990 of $7.178 billion a year from $3.784 billion in 1988. Another measure is the increase in corporate trading staffs. Tandem Computer's staff, although still lean, has tripled since 1987, to three. Ingersoll-Rand has not increased its staff, but has grown in other ways, Mr. Lopatynski said. It has installed new computers and communications systems that track changes in the company's currency exposure much faster than before.
 
From the Ground Up
 The impetus for Sun's buildup came during a financial crisis in 1989 when earnings suddenly sagged and it appeared that the company, famed for its Silicon Valley Cinderella growth, was stumbling. Every dollar began to count. "We didn't know where we were making our money," said Mr. Meredith.
When he arrived, Mr. Prantis had to begin with the basics. "There was no organizational chart and it was difficult just to find the people in the company who were responsible for flows of money," he said.
He began by identifying Sun's exposure to foreign exchange risk. It was not as easy as it sounded, because information can travel slowly in a growing company. "Sun has to be vigilant month to month and has to identify all the exposures," Mr. Meredith said. "A supplier agreement could lapse and the internal reporting mechanisms could not catch it fast enough." Also, in a company with decentralized operations, there can be jealousies about giving up authority. "There was a battle to get it centralized," Mr. Prantis said.
One thing Mr. Meredith, Mr. Prantis and Dianne M. Edmonds, another member of the Sun treasury operation, found was that Sun's subsidiary in Japan was buying work stations from Sun in the United States in dollars and selling them in yen while headquarters was selling dollars to buy yen to pay for work station components it bought from Japan. This meant there was a flood of currency exchanging, which left the company doubly exposed to the risk of dollar-yen fluctuations.
Unraveling this problem was not easy, and some Japanese banks lost much of Sun's currency business. But eventually, the home office prevailed, and the yen-dollar exchanging ceased. This left Sun with what is called a natural hedge: it was being paid in yen by customers and paying suppliers with the same yen so there was no exposure to currency fluctuations. The change, Mr. Meredith estimated, has saved the company about $1 million in the last year.
 
Balancing Gain and Risk
 Sun is developing similar natural hedges in Europe, but they are less extensive than in Japan. So the company deals with that currency exposure by purchasing currency "forwards," which work this way: If the company sells a number of work stations to be delivered over several months at a certain price in French francs, Sun buys a forward for the amount of the buyer's purchase orders. That locks in the current price of the franc and protects Sun in case the franc's value dives in the coming months as the work stations are delivered. Sun knows, of course, that the foreign currency could rise sharply in those months, causing the company to miss a chance to make some extra money. But Mr. Meredith and his colleagues prefer to avoid the currency risk completely simply by locking in the value of the mark.
Some companies have been hedging currencies for much longer than Sun, even back to the 70's when the dollar was freed to float against other currencies. And some, like Merck & Company and the Eastman Kodak Company, are larger players in the market. At the end of last year, for example, Merck had hedges of $1.327 billion in place. David Fiedler, director of foreign exchange planning at Kodak, said his company also had major positions, though he declined to reveal how much.
Like Sun, these companies use natural hedges and buy currency forwards. But they also employ things like currency options. With an option, Kodak might pay a fee for the right to buy dollars against the company's marks or yen at a set price in the future. When that future time arrives, the company does not have to buy the dollars if the market price is not advantageous, but it loses the fee it paid for the right of purchase. Thus, options provide insurance against an adverse move in the dollar while maintaining the opportunity to profit.
Hedging is rarely perfect but it can pay off handsomely if there are sharp, unexpected moves of the dollar. When asked how they capitalized on the dollar last spring, several companies said they were prepared for the rise, but not for such a dramatic rise.
More and more companies are also pushing for accounting rule changes to broaden the opportunities for hedging strategies. Hedge accounting requires that a company be able to show that its transactions actually will take place. If it has sales invoices in hand for future delivery of a product, a company can then carry currency hedging instruments on its books without having to change their value every quarter to reflect the current market. If a company had to follow this "mark to market" approach, it would experience the volatility hedging is designed to avoid.
Mr. Fiedler at Kodak, for one, is aggressively seeking the rule changes. "It is safe to say that on the margin there are companies that are recognizing economic risk but do not hedge because they can not get hedge accounting," he said. Hedge accounting rules tend to limit hedges over longer periods of time and hedges that would be made against anticipated income from the development of new products, as compared with expected sales from existing merchandise in the future.
 
Out in Front of the Rules
 Accountants with experience in corporate hedging say that their profession is often slow to recognize the legitimacy of various hedging strategies and permit their clients to avoid mark-to-market accounting requirements. "The accountants are, as usual, a little behind in getting the rules up to what is going on in practice," said Bob Mills, national industry director for investment banking at KPMG Peat Marwick in New York.
Merck is regarded as one of the leaders in long-term economic hedging. The philosophy, according to Judy C. Lewent, vice president and chief financial officer, is to protect Merck's cash flow so that the company can be certain of having the money for the research and development that is so vital to its competitive position in the global drug industry.
For example, the new drug Proscar, for treating an enlarged prostate, has been in development for years and is still going through the approval process at the Food and Drug Administration. In planning its hedging strategies, Ms. Lewent said the company set a goal for the cash flow needed to pay for the development of that and other drugs. It used forwards, options and other hedging techniques to try to guarantee the necessary cash-flow level.
Compared with companies like Merck, Sun is just a beginner. Only recently did it move beyond natural hedges and the simple world of forwards. Now it is pushing into currency options and proxy currencies, which is the use of one general currency, like the German mark, to represent several European currencies, instead of hedging all the currencies individually.
Until July 1, Sun routinely hedged all its sales abroad by buying currency forwards. But now, in a move that reflects its growing sophistication, the company tries to take advantage of the dollar's movement. This means that when the dollar is weak or falling the company may elect not to put a hedge in place. The risk of course, is that the dollar won't move as predicted, costing Sun money.
Like many companies, Sun has been conservative because it has taken so much time to move the entire company along the hedging learning curve. But it also holds back because it fears getting burned in the foreign exchange market.
There are glaring examples of companies whose operations have gone bad. This year, Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British food and liquor company, reported a foreign exchange loss of 150 million pounds, or about $265 million. Three of the company's top executives have since resigned, though the company did not explain what happened in detail. Some analysts believe Allied-Lyons had begun speculating on currency movements rather than just hedging and fared badly.
"When you start playing the foreign exchange game you are adding risk to the equation," Mr. Meredith said.

Graph tracks the value of the dollar in Germaqn marks, Jan.-Sept. 6, 1991 (Source: Datastream) (pg. 1); "Over the Ocean," tracks U.S. corporate profits from abroad as a percentage of profits, 1986-1991* (*1991, first half.) (Source: Commerce Dept.); "A Growing Specialty," tracks U.S. corporate currency trading volume in the large customer market, 1988-1990 (Source: Greenwich Associates) (pg. 6)
 
Chart/Graph: "Hedging: The Art of Reducing Risk"
 
A U.S. company agrees in late January to sell 10 computers to a German company for 15,000 German marks, or $10,000 at the 1,50 exchange rate of the day, for delivery in July. But by July, the dollar has rallied to 1.83 marks, making 15,000 marks worth only 8,200.
 
Here are some hedges the company can use to protect itself from a potential loss:
 
NATURAL HEDGE
 
The German subsidary of the U.S. company buys and sells in the same currency, the mark. In this case, it does not convert the 15,000 marks from the sale to dollars but uses them to buy supplies in Germany.
 
CURRENCY FORWARDS
 
When the company signs the deal in January, it buys a forward contract in the foreign exchange market, paying 15,000 marks exchangable for $10,000 in July. Even though the dollar has rallied by July to 1.83 marks to the dollar, the company is protected against the $1,800 loss because it locked in to the lower rate in January.
 
OPTIONS
 
Options offer a company insurance against a loss as well as an upside opportunity which means they are more expensive than forwards. In this case, an option would be placed to buy the dollar in July at January's rate of 1.50 marks, or $10,000 for 15,000 marks. By July, the dollar has rallied to 1.83 marks, so the company exercises the option to prevent a loss. But if the dollar had fallen to 1.40 marks, say, the company wouod drop its oiption and instead buy the dollars at 1.40 marks, getting $10,071.
 
CURRENCY FUTURES
 
Currency futures work like forwards except that forwards are worked out in private deals, while futures contracts are standardized with set amounts, fixed delivery dates and are traded on formal exchanges.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Time to Open The Treasury's Auction Club?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The Federal Government has always depended upon rich and powerful men to help it make ends meet. For the past two centuries, the plutocratic assistance has been provided by the likes of John Jacob Astor and J. P. Morgan and, of course, Jay Cooke, the legendary banker and devout abolitionist who almost singlehandedly sold the Treasury bonds that financed the Civil War.
Today, the rich and powerful men on which the Government relies are the usually obscure executives of the 39 firms known as "primary dealers," the firms through which the Federal Reserve Bank of New York buys and sells Treasury securities to adjust the nation's money supply. The Fed also requires primary dealers to bid regularly at Treasury auctions and to make a market in Treasury debt. In return, the primary dealers are the only institutions, besides banks, that are allowed to submit auction bids on behalf of other investors -- and thus, they can spy out market trends and attract new customers seeking their guidance. 
 This vague but apparently valuable "franchise" is coming under intense scrutiny in the wake of disclosures that executives at Salomon Brothers, a primary dealer, submitted phony customer bids to circumvent Treasury limits on how much each bidder can purchase.
Some critics ask why auction bids should be channeled through this club at all. Richard Sylla, an economic historian at New York University, said the system offers some protection in that the Treasury will not lack for bidders -- a comfort, given the projected growth in Federal deficits in the next few years. No one can be forced to remain a primary dealer, however, so the assurance is hardly ironclad. "And the disadvantage," said Professor Sylla, "is that the Government is, in effect, sponsoring a cartel."
Jacob Dreyer, chief economist for the Investment Company Institute, also questioned "whether the market would not be better served if there were more bidders" -- the nation's mutual funds, for example.
E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Fed, explained at Congressional hearings last week that the Fed simply cannot do business with everyone when it needs to adjust the money supply. That, he added, "necessarily implies that some will be chosen and some will not." But it is not clear why those chosen to handle the Fed's money-modulating business should, ex officio, get the right to play a privileged role at Treasury auctions.
In the distant past, as Professor Sylla noted, the Government turned to tycoons to sell its debt because it could not find buyers otherwise. But the perverse lesson of the Salomon case is that demand for Treasury securities debt is so strong today that people are breaking the rules to buy more of them. "It does strike me as a little funny," said Professor Sylla. "In a global financial system, perhaps it just doesn't make sense to limit the bidding anymore."

But Borrowing Needs Are Still High," tracks administration estimates of budget deficit, 1991-1996.

HEADLINE: All About/Luxury Cars;
A Race for the Young and Affluent

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
At its recent preview of new models, Cadillac touted some virtues of its 1992 Brougham: the greatest length of any car produced in this country, rear-wheel drive and maximum insulation from the road. They are qualities -- none of them new -- that have helped make Cadillac the nation's best-selling luxury marque. But they are features that are also aimed at a core market that is heading over the hill; the median age of a Brougham buyer is 66.
So to attract younger buyers, Cadillac, a division of the General Motors Corporation, has drastically redesigned two of its models: the 1992 Seville and Eldorado, which were introduced last week. These cars have less chrome, a leaner more "European" look and firmer suspension systems for maximum contact with the road. The new Cadillacs, which sell for $32,500 to $38,000, are more expensive than the average Cadillac, which now costs about $29,000. 
 Cadillac brought out its new Eldorados and Sevilles to compete in the loosely defined luxury market of cars selling for $20,000 or more -- a market that is not for car makers with shallow pockets. Advertising and marketing costs are high.
The new Japanese entrants into the luxury field have been spending $50 million to $60 million a year to market their products. General Motors, which spent $1.5 billion on all domestic advertising last year, does not release its expenditures by division.
The luxury-car market has also been hurt by the recession; sales have fallen by 9 percent so far this year. But they are expected to grow from their current level of about 1.3 million cars to 1.6 million by mid-decade, according to analysts.
The high costs of marketing, combined with the recession, have taken their toll. Last month, Peugeot, the French auto maker, and Sterling, of Britain, announced they would leave the American luxury market.
Peugeot and Sterling may be in retreat, but last month the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan said it would jump into the luxury car race in 1994 with a separate division called Amati.
 
The Power of Upstarts
Complacent Europe Stumbles and Falls
 To jump into the growing luxury car market in the 80's, Japanese car makers used the same strategy they used to push into the American market for less expensive cars.
"They come into the market as good value for the dollar," said Susan Jacobs, a luxury-car market analyst with her own consulting firm in Little Falls, N.J. "Then they work off this base to develop more sophisticated products." While some of the original Acuras sold in 1988 were priced at about $16,000, the new NSX model goes for $62,600. But unlike many of the Europeans, the Japanese companies have not abandoned the bottom of the market.
The proliferation of models from the biggest Japanese car makers is quickly crowding the field. And as these car makers gain acceptance among buyers, new entrants from Japan are plunging into the market. Mitsubishi, for example, introduced this year its new Diamante, which sells for $19,939 in its basic configuration.
 
It Worked Before
Japan Spends Big, And Proliferates
 The mid-1980's were good years for European car makers. Porsche, Jaguar and Saab all watched their American sales more than double between 1982 and 1986. Jaguar sales hit a record 24,464 in 1986, while sales of Saabs peaked at 48,250 in the same year. Other European companies, including Mercedes-Benz, Volvo and BMW, also reported heady sales gains during the 80's.
Some car makers figured good times would continue and built more plants to meet anticipated demand.
But what these auto makers did not expect was the chilling effect on sales of the 1987 stock market crash. They also underestimated the Japanese, which in the late 80's took direct aim at the Europeans. Honda's Acura division, Toyota's Lexus and Nissan's Infiniti all earned critical acclaim.
The Europeans figured the status associated with their own products would keep the upstarts at bay, but they were mistaken. "Buying smart has really been coming in in the last four or five years," said John Hammond, a senior partner with J. D. Power & Associates in Agoura Hills, Calif.
In 1987, according to analysts, European car makers had 32.1 percent of the American luxury market. By 1990, their share had fallen to 23.7 percent. So far this year, Europe's luxury cars had just 19.8 percent of the market. During the same period, the American share of the luxury market -- dominated by Cadillac and the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln division -- held steady at about 50 percent.
In response, some European car makers are fleeing the increasingly competitive lower end of the luxury market where the Japanese are congregated and moving further up to enhance their prestige, which could hurt their volume but increase profits.
Mercedes-Benz has not released prices for its big, new 1992 S-Class models due out in October, but one analyst predicted they could cost 20 percent more than the 1991 models they replace. The new Mercedes 500 SEL sedan is expected to bump up against the $100,000 mark, compared with roughly $80,000 for the current 560 SEL.
Porsche, from Germany, which has seen its sales tumble to 9,140 in 1990 from 30,471 in 1986 is also moving to appeal to more-affluent buyers by introducing several costlier models. Almost alone, BMW is holding the line. It is marketing a new, entry-level 325 series with models that cost about as much as the cars they replace.
But in a crowded market with lots of appealing cars to choose from, the European car markers' strategy may backfire. Stephen Reitman, an analyst with UBS/Phillips & Drew in London, said some of the sharper price hikes for new European models may be too steep for the choice-rich consumer. "The American consumer has become more cost-conscious," he said. "The rich watch their dollars as much as anyone else."
 
Their Parents' Dream
Do Real Boomers Drive Cadillacs?
 Like Cadillac, Lincoln is retooling for the future, despite steady sales gains throughout the 80's that it won mostly at the expense of Cadillac. "As baby boomers move up, are they going to want a smaller car? That's our $64 million question," said Chuck Snearly, a Ford spokesman.
Part of Lincoln's answer is to turn out a new Lincoln Mark VIII next year with a more aerodynamic design than the Mark VII.
"We're not dismissing the Japanese entries," Mr. Snearly said. "They're headed right at us."
Lincoln's gamble on a smaller, more European-style car just might pay off. Lincoln's "evolving image is in step with the luxury market," Ms. Jacobs, the analyst, said. "The new products coming will be good competitors."
But while Lincoln has been able to build a track record of delivering quality cars, some analysts fault its marketing. "They've become somewhat invisible," said Mr. O'Grady. "In order to keep their buyers, they need to freshen up their marketing."
Lincoln disagrees. Mr. Snearly said its sales speak for themselves: they hit 231,660 in 1990, up from 101,574 in 1983. But Lincoln will run new television ads this fall.
Even so, Lincoln and Cadillac face challenges, analysts say, in trying to reach younger buyers. "They're trying to go to people who don't consider them. It can be done, but it does take time," Mr. O'Grady said.
For its part, the Chrysler Corporation is moving to promote its New Yorker models, which have not been redesigned in recent years, as affordable luxury cars. Chrysler is no longer trying to provide all cars to all customers. In the future it will focus on a narrower range of products.
 
 
ZEN AND THE ART OF BUYING A CAR
 When Americans shop for a car, they generally start by considering six models. Then they narrow the field and usually visit three showrooms before they settle on a model. In all, this takes an average of two weeks, according to J. D. Power & Associates, a consulting firm in Agoura Hills, Calif.
But buyers of luxury cars typically take twice as long to decide how they will spend their dollars. One reason is that there are now dozens of luxury models to choose from. As a result, manufacturers are placing more emphasis on the quality of the customer's shopping experience.
This has led to sizable investments in showrooms and their furnishings, typified by fountains and dramatic architecture at the Infiniti showrooms. Some Nissan Infiniti showrooms even have indoor bridges and "contemplation zones" -- designated areas where a customer can sit without harassment to think about a car in Zen-like silence.
Efforts by Infiniti and Toyota's Lexus "have sort of dragged everybody up there with them," said Ted Orme, of the National Automobile Dealers Association.
But all this elegance may backfire, said Pete Swetish, a senior partner at MOR-PACE, a consumer research firm in Farmington Hills, Mich. "They are meaningful statements to some buyers, but you might look at those kinds of things and say, 'Geez, I'm paying for that?' " he said.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Making the Scene At the U.S. Open

 BODY:
It's a sweltering afternoon at the U.S. Open, and Boris Becker is drenched with sweat going into the third set. The stadium's upper levels are packed with spectators, but down below, the crowd is sparse. At center court, the two boxes belonging to the Chase Manhattan Corporation are conspicuously empty, their blue plastic seats shimmering in the sun.
Don't think Chase doesn't harbor serious tennis fans. Just outside the stadium, in an enormous air-conditioned hospitality tent, a handful of Chase executives -- and their guests -- are lolling on wicker settees, swilling Bloody Marys and shouting at Becker's image on a big-screen television. From time to time, they amble by the bar for another cocktail, or select a few hors d'oeuvres from the silver chafing dishes on the buffet table. When Becker smashes a volley, they break into cheers and whistles. 
 Welcome to the U.S. Open, executive-style. For two weeks at summer's end, many New York business leaders have abandoned the canyons of Manhattan for the courts of Flushing Meadows. Discussion turns to finding the best tickets, the best parking spots and the best meals at the biggest corporate sporting event of the season. Executives have apparently found that entertaining clients at the U.S. Open pays -- whether or not anybody actually watches the matches.
"Most of these people have little or no interest in tennis per se," said John Feinstein, author of "Hard Courts," a recent book about the Grand Slam, tennis's four major contests. "They want to go back to the office and tell everyone, 'I was there; I saw Becker.' But they don't really follow the game."
What many do "follow" is the other spectators. "This is the people-watching event of the year," said Tom Ogdon, chief executive of the Ogdon Partnership, a New York executive search firm, which has a prime box. "You see a lot of people you know out there or people you'd like to know."
His neighbors for the two-week tournament -- which ends today -- have included the real estate developer Lew Rudin, Primerica's chief executive, Sandy Weill, and Saul Steinberg, Donald Trump and Teddy Forstmann -- plus assorted bigwigs from Chase Manhattan, Merrill Lynch and Bear, Stearns.
Renting a courtside box at Flushing Meadows -- several hundred are available, at $7,800 per season -- is not hassle-free, however. For one thing, there's a 15-year wait. And once you get a box, deciding on the guest list is no easy matter. "There are a lot of people waiting for the phone to ring to be invited," said Mr. Ogdon. His rules for issuing invitations are simple: 75 percent of his guests are clients, 25 percent friends -- a formula that makes it tax deductible -- and all must demonstrate an appreciation of the game.
Securing prized seats is just the first step. The cognoscenti also vie for "Marquee" parking passes -- the closest to the stadium entrance -- so they can leave their BMW's and Mercedes nearby, guarded by uniformed attendants. Once inside, they don't wait in line for popcorn and beer; they flash stadium-issued V.I.P. cards at Slew's Place, a dining room in the U.S. Tennis Association's hospitality tent, or Racquets, a private eating club attached to the stadium. "It's nice to have a cool, comfortable retreat," said Mr. Ogdon. "There comes a time when you need air-conditioning."
The U.S. Open's corporate hospitality tents may be considered lavish by most standards, but some critics find them lacking. "If you were to go to parties every night at this tournament, you'd be bored stiff after three nights," said Mr. Feinstein. "You'd have tried the chicken, the roast beef and the salmon." He contrasts that to Wimbledon and the French Open: "In Europe, every party is a culinary adventure."
Some executives, however, don't care for elaborate entertaining. "A lot of the people I bring are happy to eat hot dogs in the box," said Gene Beard, chief financial officer of the Interpublic Group, a New York advertising agency, who invites only "people who are selling or recommending or following our company's stock." But with their hot dogs, Mr. Beard's guests also get a view: nearby seats have been held by such business celebrities as Henry Kravis and Meshulam Riklis, and the heads of Shearson Lehman, Manufacturers Hanover and J. P. Morgan.
This year, 22 companies paid to be the tournament's corporate sponsors, up from 20 in 1990. For their money -- ranging from $200,000 to more than $1 million -- they get to plaster their logos around the National Tennis Center. "Following the recession and the gulf war, the rise in sponsors defies all logic," said Barbara Perry, a vice president of the International Management Group, the Cleveland-based sports agency. "But corporate America has this infatuation with tennis."
Clairol, for one, pays a premium so its spokeswoman, the actress Linda Evans, can present the women's singles victor with her winning check. "We've always been dedicated to helping women achieve their full potential, and we view the U.S. Open as a good opportunity to show our support," said Nancy Coleman, a Clairol spokeswoman. "You can do a lot with a sponsorship that you can't do with straight advertising."
While companies with boxes invite about 100 guests, corporate sponsors host many more. This year, the Chase Manhattan Bank offered 3,800 tickets to local employees. But access to its hospitality tent is reserved for present and potential big customers.
How much business actually results from all this company spending? Nobody keeps track. But Mr. Ogdon, for one, said the U.S. Open is great for business. "I've never walked away from a session without a new engagement, and one commitment more than pays for the seats," he said.

HEADLINE: SOVIET TURMOIL;
EXPERTS WORRIED OVER FOOD SUPPLY FOR SOVIET WINTER

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Predicting a poor Soviet harvest, and concerned that financing problems may delay Western food aid, Administration and private experts on agriculture are increasingly worried about how the Soviet Union will feed itself this winter.
The consensus among the experts is that the Soviet harvest will be as much as 25 percent smaller than last year's. Crops have been gathered and sold to central authorities late, if at all, partly because of the political turmoil in the wake of the failed coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
 In response to an urgent request from the Soviet authorities shortly after the coup plot was foiled, President Bush announced two weeks ago that he would immediately make available $315 million of $500 million in agricultural loan guarantees for the Soviets that had been planned for Oct. 1. The Soviets wanted to start moving grain in September to insure that their antiquated distribution system did not become overloaded in October.
 
No Guarantees Claimed
 But a senior Agriculture Department official said today that no American or foreign bank had yet claimed any of the guarantees, so no grain was being prepared for shipment.
"The President's purpose will not be served if that $315 million is not touched," the official said, adding that Soviet officials had asked the United States for help in financing the deal.
Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister, warned today of possible food riots this winter. "If there's a shortage of food, then of course the people are going to protest," he told the British Broadcasting Corporation. "Last time round it was a palace coup. I don't think that will happen again. But that doesn't mean people won't take to the streets to rebel against chaos in the economy."
 
U.S. Banks Shun Loans
 Last month, before the coup, banking and grain industry executives said that no American banks took part in a $600 million loan to the Soviet Union for grain purchases, although Washington guaranteed almost all of the loan's principal and half of the interest. The only lenders were four European banks that were said to have acted under pressure from their governments.
Banks have been nervous about lending to the Soviet Union since the coup because of worries about a possible Soviet debt rescheduling and squabbling among its republics over whether to divide up the nation's foreign debt.
The Agriculture Department is now considering ways to help the Soviet Union finance the $315 million deal if no banks are willing to take part, the official said, declining to elaborate.
The options could include guaranteeing more of the principal and interest of bank loans or providing direct government loans to the republics or central Government. The guarantees currently cover 98 percent of the principal and the first 4.5 percent points of interest. All of the American loan guarantees are for borrowing by the central Government in Moscow and cannot be used by the republics.
The Agriculture Department is under pressure from Midwestern farmers and grain exporters who want to sell food to the Soviets, while commercial banks have been lobbying for more generous guarantees. But the Agriculture Department has been reluctant to set a precedent for other countries to demand expanded guarantees, which could increase the cost of an already expensive program plagued by loan defaults.
The European Community promised the Soviet Union about $1 billion in food aid and loans at the beginning of this year, but did not begin delivering it until June. Much of the food still remains to be sent because of distribution problems in the Soviet Union, a European Community official said. No additional food aid has been authorized since the coup, she said.
President Bush announced on Monday that he would send two teams of experts to the Soviet Union in the next several weeks to assess its food supply and food distribution problems. The first team left for Moscow on Friday.
Even with last year's record harvest, the transportation and distribution problems endemic to the Soviet system created local shortages. And officials of two large grain-producing republics, Russia and the Ukraine, have said they will insure their own populations are fed before allowing food to go to other republics.
Soviet state farms have become less willing to sell their crops privately for fear of being accused of speculation in the current turmoil, although their alternatives are to sell to an inefficient state system or allow grain to rot in the fields.
 
Poor Crop Predicted
 "It is our expectation that the Soviet harvest will be considerably less than it was last year, and you will recall that even with the dimensions of last year's harvest there were still some problems within the Soviet Union," Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said at a news conference this week. "So we would anticipate that with a diminished harvest, those problems would be exacerbated even if the relationships between the republics were clearly understood today."
Private experts disagree about whether time may be running out for large-scale shipments.
"If they don't get it moved in the September, October, November time period, it's going to be even harder to move in December, January, February," when the harsh Soviet winter makes the country's transportation problems worse, said Carol G. Brookins, the president of World Perspectives Inc., a Washington agriculture consulting firm.
Bernard Steinweg, a senior vice president at the Continental Grain Company, a New York-based company that is one of the nation's largest grain exporters, was more optimistic. "We've shipped to the Black Sea throughout the winter months," he said today, but added, "Obviously, the more you get in there before the winter months, the better off you are."
 
Installment Due in February
 President Bush authorized $1.5 billion in loan guarantees for the Soviet Union on June 11. The first installment of $600 million was given then to the Soviet authorities, who needed a month to find banks willing to lend.
Four European banks ended up lending the money, led by the Banque Nationale de Paris, which is entirely owned by the French Government.
The final installment of $400 million is scheduled for February.
A broad consensus in favor of large-scale food aid from seven industrialized democracies to the Soviet Union emerged in London on Aug. 29 at a meeting of the personal representatives of the heads of state of the Group of Seven countries.
The United States and Japan have been concerned that food aid may be wasted if it rots on arrival in the Soviet Union for lack of transportation, as reportedly happened to some grain last year. But they nonetheless support aid this year as a way to stave off possible civil disorder.

HEADLINE: Field of Maybes Is a Spirit Lifter For Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The race for the Democratic Presidential nomination finally lurched to life in Iowa this weekend with a fledgling class of potential candidates, a lot of full-throated Bush-bashing and an almost palpable relief among Democratic loyalists that their party was fighting back.
"We have, finally, candidates who are willing to take on George Bush and point out what his vulnerabilities are," said John Roehrick, the chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, as he joined with more than 500 Democrats to cheer on the potential standard-bearers in Sioux City on Friday night. "For far too long we've been silent." 
 After a long, ominously quiet summer in Democratic Presidential politics, this weekend's forum in Iowa, the scene of the first Presidential nominating contest in February, signaled the start of a busy fall.
Over the next month, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska are all expected to announce their Presidential intentions. And all are seen as likely, if not certain, to enter the race, joining former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who announced his candidacy last spring.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa told The Associated Press today that he planned to announce his candidacy on Sept. 15.
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California announced the formation of an exploratory committee this week, injecting another variable into the field, while the Rev. Jesse Jackson has yet to announce his decision, although many Democrats expect him to forgo a race in 1992.
Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has suddenly found himself with several horses to tout after a summer of nonstarters. "The dynamic is shifting rapidly and it appears we will have a strong field by the end of September," he said this week.
This new class of potential candidates, most of them novices to Presidential campaigns, is filling a vacuum created when many of the party's heavyweights decided not to challenge Mr. Bush, who maintains his high ratings in the public opinion polls.
"I always thought that people would see the merit of getting into a race that people didn't expect them to win," said James Ruvolo, a member of the Democratic National Committee from Ohio. "They're somewhat liberated."
At the very least, Mr. Ruvolo argued, "they can raise issues and build a five-year plan," thus positioning themselves for 1996.
 
'Year of the Leapfrog'
 Carter Eskew, a Democratic consultant who has worked for Mr. Harkin, suggested that it was "the year of the leapfrog" in Democratic politics, with rare opportunities for "people who are very appealing" but would not be heard in ordinary years.
The Democratic fund-raising dinner in Sioux City offered candidates and potential candidates a chance to be heard by Democrats from Iowa, Nebraska and South Dakota. Each of the Presidential speakers sought to stake out his market position.
Mr. Tsongas offered himself as the prophet of economic decline, a Democrat who can remake his party's economic philosophy to encourage investment and job creation.
 
'Get Off Our Knees'
 Senator Harkin, addressing a hometown crowd, delivered a rousing version of his Democratic credo, a plea to return to traditional party values, "get off our knees" and take the fight to Mr. Bush.
One of his liveliest lines concerned the Republicans who deride him as another George McGovern, the party's 1972 Presidential nominee, who lost 49 states and who was the keynote speaker last night.
"Charlie Black and Roger Ailes and old George Herbert Walker Bush and J. Danforth Quayle, if they want me to repudiate George McGovern, if they want me to repudiate what he stood for all his life in politics, from Food for Peace to ending the Vietnam War and bringing our troops home, to getting that crook Nixon and his den of thieves out of the White House," Mr. Harkin roared, "if they want me to do that, why they can just go straight to hell." The crowd went wild.
Mr. Clinton argued that the nation had a host of dangerous problems, from lagging educational progress to the failings of the health care system that had to be confronted by national leadership. "The President counts a thousand points of light, but I promise you that leaves a lot of darkness," Mr. Clinton said, referring to Mr. Bush's emphasis on voluntarism to solve domestic problems.
 
Tone of a Centrist
 Still, Mr. Clinton, trying to position himself as the centrist in the race, said the Democrats must couple their belief in an active, problem-solving government with a new emphasis on personal responsiblity. That would apply, he said, both to people at the bottom of the economic ladder and to the people at the top.
"I'm still waiting for George Bush to say the first word about what Salomon Brothers did the other day, about the S.& L. ripoff, about all these things that have happened in America, where people on the top have taken advantage of people on the bottom," Mr. Clinton said.
There were some common strains among the potential candidates, particularly a strict focus on domestic issues and a demand for new Federal spending priorities to reflect the realities of the post-cold-war era.
Mr. Harkin put it starkly: "If you want to continue to spend $160 billion of your money to defend Europe from the Soviet Union, or whatever it's called now," he said, "take your ballot and put it in the Bush box."
He added, "But if you believe, as I believe, that Europe is strong enough and rich enough and powerful enough to defend itself if it wants to, and we can take some of your wealth and we can invest it in new roads and highways and bridges and health care, then you take your ballot and put it in the Democrats' box."
In addition to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Harkin and Mr. Tsongas, the group also heard from Larry Agran, the former mayor of Irvine, Calif., and a dark horse candidate, who wants to cut military spending in half.
Mr. McGovern's keynote address was an unabashed attack on Mr. Bush's foreign policy, including his handling of the war in the Persian Gulf.
Arguing that sanctions should have been given more time to work against Iraq, Mr. McGovern asserted, "After American bombers devastated the vastly overmatched forces of Iraq and its civilian infrastructure, Mr. Bush led the nation in an outpouring of self-congratulatory jingoism that would have been more appropriate in the days of Caesar."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Potential Democratic Presidential candidates at a forum in Sioux City, Iowa on Friday were, from left, Paul E. Tsongas, a former Massachusetts Senator, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Mr. Tsongas has already announced his candidacy; the others are expected to run. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Thorpe Still Hasn't Received All He Deserved

BYLINE: BY ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
THE Maltese Falcon of sport is a mysterious silver chalice, 2 feet long and 30 pounds, in the form of a Viking ship. Lined with gold and encrusted with jewels, it had once been owned by the czar of Russia. Now it belongs to Jim Thorpe's estate. Or does it?
And where is it? 
 This weekend, as Robert Helmick, president of the United States Olympic Committee, explains the circumstances of his possible conflicts of interest, the silver ship seems to be sailing even further out of sight. "Ironical, isn't it?" said Jim Thorpe's 69-year-old daughter, Grace. "My first reaction was, Dad got $15 a week and they took away all his medals, and now this one got how much, a hundred thousand?"
Grace Thorpe's second reaction was more practical. If Helmick loses his position, she will have to find another well-connected champion to help her hunt for the silver ship and a four-foot-high bronze bust of the King of Sweden. Those two trophies of the 1912 Games were taken from Thorpe along with the gold medals for winning the decathlon and the pentathlon after Olympic officials judged him a professional for having played minor league baseball in 1909.
Grace Thorpe and her brothers and sisters are trying to build a Jim Thorpe Museum in Yale, Okla., where their father owned a home, and where some of them were born. The ship and the bust would not only be prime exhibits, they would stimulate the lagging fund-raising.
There doesn't seem to be a lot of interest in Jim Thorpe, even in this post-"Dances With Wolves" era. But for native Americans particularly, his story still has great resonance.
"He was beaten by the system," said Oren Lyons, a faith keeper of the Iroquois Confederacy, "but he was never tamed. He was his own man."
Lyons, an Onondaga, remembers the middle-aged Jim Thorpe visiting his reservation to watch lacrosse games. Lacrosse, a traditional Indian game, had been banned when Thorpe was at the Carlisle Indian School, as was any language or custom that would divert the natives from total integration into white society.
Yet when the integration occurred, it was never properly credited. Thorpe's accomplishments in baseball, football and track and field were reported to be "natural" rather than the result of any training or hard work. And when King Gustav at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics said, "Sir, you are the greatest athlete in the world," and Thorpe replied "Thanks, King," the exchange marked Thorpe forever as a noble savage.
In a glitch of guilt before the 1984 Los Angeles Games, Olympic officials gave each of Thorpe's surviving children a gold medal. Several weeks ago, Helmick explained to me the reason: "We acknowledged that the rules of the times were unfairly restrictive against minorities and those who were economically disadvantaged. Thorpe got bad counseling. In the spirit of fairness he deserved the medals back."
It was in 1983, while getting those medals, that Grace Thorpe first heard rumors that plans to exhibit the ship and the bust at a Los Angeles museum were canceled because authorities were concerned that "those Indians would come steal the trophies." Further inquiries on her part were stonewalled.
Since then, in calls and correspondence with Helmick, who has been responsive to Grace and to me, we have been told that the International Olympic Committee is preparing a full report on the case. But the trophies, the I.O.C. maintains, were never Jim Thorpe's to keep; they were so-called "traveling trophies," to be held for only four years by each decathlon and pentathlon winner.
"If that's so," asks Grace, "who else had them after Dad? And where are they now? I'd like some facts."
Have they been sold, stolen, lost? Have the precious gems been pried out, the gold melted down, fakes created as replacement? Are they in the basement of the I.O.C. headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland? Where's Sam Spade?
The Jim Thorpe Memorial Foundation in Yale, Okla., has raised about $160,000 so far. It needs to raise $725,000 by next July to qualify for a $150,000 challenge grant from the Mabee Foundation of Tulsa. While the Oklahoma State Historical Society runs a Thorpe exhibit in the original Yale home, the new structure could house the diaries, photographs, uniforms, research materials and other Thorpe memorabilia scattered around the state and the world.
With Helmick's own amateur standing in jeopardy (he must explain his role as a paid consultant to companies and organizations with at least indirect Olympics ties), Grace, a retired congressional aide on Indian affairs, has been searching for other allies. She has even written to that other complex American sports hero, Arnold Schwarzenegger. But she hasn't quite written off Helmick.
"Don't forget, I'm also a part-time judge for the Sac and Fox Nation," Grace said. "The man hasn't been tried yet. I'd just like a few more facts, please."

HEADLINE: Insolvent Boston Suburb Faces Threat of Takeover

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
The small, impoverished suburban city of Chelsea, made up largely of immigrants and the elderly, is so short of money that it can no longer pay for its own basic services, leaving political leaders and financial experts unsure how to save it or whether it can survive at all.
Gov. William F. Weld on Friday proposed legislation that would put the city of 28,000 people north of here into receivership. 
 Today the state Senate's Local Affairs Committee held an emergency hearing on the bill, and the Governor is expected to meet with legislators next week to lobby for the measure.
The proposal would remove Chelsea's Mayor and replace its government for up to five years with a receiver appointed by the Governor. The receiver would have the authority to break city contracts with unions representing the police, firefighters and teachers, thus potentially saving Chelsea money. But the receiver could not raise taxes, severely limiting his ability to resolve Chelsea's large and chronic budget deficit.
State legislative leaders immediately expressed opposition to the plan. William M. Bulger, president of the state Senate, said that unless provisions were included requiring Chelsea to raise its taxes to help bail itself out, the Legislature might not approve the Governor's plan. Mr. Bulger, a Democrat, pointed out that several Massachusetts cities were on the verge of bankruptcy as a result of the recession and that the Legislature could not afford to save them all.
Referring to raising Chelsea's taxes, Mr. Bulger said: "If they don't do it, why should we take it over? Where will it end if we take it over?"
At today's hearing, Senator Martin Dunne, the Democrat who heads the committee, was one of several speakers who criticized the Governor's proposal. "I just don't see the receiver having the ability to resolve this," said Mr. Dunne, a former Mayor of Holyoke, another city facing severe financial problems.
 
Saying No to Higher Taxes
 Mr. Weld is opposed to tax increases and insists Chelsea be rescued by cutting its budget. A state voter referendum limits the amount of tax increases a community can institute in any given year unless voters override it, and Chelsea voters have repeatedly rejected attempts to override it.
Chelsea has an estimated $9 million deficit in its $48 million budget. The state is already contributing almost 50 percent of the city's budget, and on Wednesday a state-appointed financial control board that has been trying to straighten out Chelsea's finances rejected an interim budget, leaving the city without money to pay its bills.
 
'Not the End'
 Governor Weld, a Republican, described his proposed solution as "radical." It would be the first time a town in Massachusetts has been placed in receivership since the Great Depression.
Within the 1.8 square miles of Chelsea itself, reaction to the proposal ranged from elation to anger.
"This is not the end of our city," said Mayor John Brennan. "It's the beginning of a new Chelsea."
Mayor Brennan has been urging the state to take over the city since last spring, when residents overwhelmingly voted down a tax increase that would have helped close the budget gap.
But Michael Thompson, a 29-year-old firefighter and Chelsea native, said of the receivership plan: "It stinks. After us being here for years, and working hard, the receiver is going to come in here and tell us what do do."
Mr. Thompson expressed fear that a receiver would lay off many of firefighters and reduce the salaries of those who remain.
Despite his anxiety, Mr. Thompson was still at his job on Friday at the Central Fire Station, as were many other municipal employees, even though Chelsea has no money to pay them. But the city's schools, which had been scheduled to reopen Thursday, remain closed. The schools, which have the worst test scores in the state, have been administered by Boston University since 1989.
 
Factors of Decline
 Chelsea's deficit reflects both the state's recession and the city's singular situation. The city is dominated by the Tobin Bridge, an elevated expressway that bisects it and is the main route between Boston and its northern suburbs. The bridge has long lowered property values and contributed to a sense of Chelsea as a dumping ground. The Chelsea River, lined with malodorous oil refineries and chemical plants, is an additional eyesore.
Demographically, Chelsea is largely a city of recent immigrants and the elderly. According to municipal statistics, 43 percent of the city's schoolchildren speak Spanish as a first language, 10 percent speak Khmer and 5 percent Vietnamese.
More than a third of the city's families earn less than $10,000 a year, and, state officials say, Chelsea has the state's highest percentage of residents living below the Federal poverty line. The school budget has been so tight that students often share textbooks.
Chelsea's poverty has resulted in a decline in its tax revenue, which has dropped to $13 million this year from $14.5 million a decade ago. That represents a decrease of more than 40 percent after inflation.
 
A Question of Survival
 Susanne Tompkins, a member of a state-appointed advisory committee that studied Chelsea, said the city's problems, taken together, are just too great for Chelsea to survive.
"We concluded it's not viable as a city," said Ms. Tompkins, who is the research director of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, a business-financed watchdog group.
The revenue gap is too great and the city is too poor for any action by a receiver to make it work, she said, adding that even if the receiver laid off many police officers, firefighters and teachers the budget could still not be balanced and maintain a liveable city.
"Our belief on the committee was that the only way out is for the state to provide extraordinary revenue now in loans," Ms. Tompkins said. Then, in the long run, she added, Chelsea would have to try to be annexed to Boston or possibly share its municipal services.
Boston officials have indicated no enthusiasm for annexation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The problem facing Chelsea, a city of 28,000 on the edge of Boston, is partly a reflection of Massachusetts's economic decline and partly a result of its own conditions. The city is dominated by the Tobin Bridge, which has long lowered property values and added to a sense of Chelsea as a dumping ground. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)
